Also every time I come, I tell the chef to surprise us with a few different fish or sushi. He always does a great job at that. I've tried a lot more and everything is absolutely great and fresh!
I would suggest making a reservation as it gets pretty busy in the evening especially thurs-sunday.
author: G O.

description: All the food is very fresh and delicious here! The hamachi is buttery.  The avocado roll has the most avocado I have ever seen inside a roll before.  I especially love the spider roll, which is chock full of super tasty tempura crab.  Prices are reasonable for the quality. The restaurant itself has clean and comfortable atmosphere, and the staff members are all friendly and attentive. Can't go wrong here!
author: Melissa H.

description:
Friday night date night. After waiting a couple minutes beyond our reservation time, they sandwiched the two of us in between parties of four, flanked by wasted twenty-something trustafarians. In such a quaint neighborhood, I would've never anticipated having to yell over the cast of Mean Girls while getting beer shrapnel on my pant leg from the adjacent table's irish car bombs.

"Yo Dave said he's got a bunch of alcohol at his place, let's cruise there before Union St."

Random notes-
The service was impeccable and the food came quickly. 
The prawn pod roll was the best thing we ordered. 
Lighting was wayyy too bright for a polished sushi restaurant on a Friday night.
Go here to catch up with friends or take your family. Not a date spot.
author: Jon S.

description:
Considering I've been here 3 times in the past week ... This place is pretty heavenly. They have a pretty good spin on the "unique" rolls as well as other rolls. They have some pretty amazing sushi lettuce wraps. The fish here is always very fresh! What could be better at a  sushi joint? Right? The only spot they lack in is customer service. All the  servers as wek as the owner him self seem pretty cold. But none the less that shouldn't stop anyone from checking this place out.
* just a little tip ... Make reservations, they are always packed! Especially on the weekend
author: Jolly L.

description:
This is my fiancé and I's most favorite restaurant ever!!!

When we first started dining here back in 2010, I wasn't even eating seafood yet (not part of my picky-eater palate), just cucumber rolls. But we were very impressed by the quality of the food and the attentive service. They are there at every turn! And they all help each other out. You can ask any server/host/bus person and they will help you. We like that, and coupled with the good food, we keep coming back.

Because we were so comfortable in this environment, Sushi Bistro is where I first ventured out and tried eating seafood. And now I eat raw fish and sushi rolls all the time! 

It does get busy so make a reservation if you don't want to wait. My fiancé and I don't usually make reservations because we like to get there right when they open at 5PM. 

We always sit at the bar so that we can have Skip, the bartender, be our main server. We love Skip; he is a great, attentive server. We used to come just because the food is so fresh and delicious but now we come because of the service.

The other servers are good too but they come and go. Skip has been there since we've started dining there and so has the host, David.

To the food! What we order everytime:

Appetizer:
Gyoza
Magic Mushroom

Main:
Red Devil
C-2
New Legend
Yellowtail Basil

Sashimi (Our Dessert!):
Seared Albacore
New Zealand Ocean Trout (melts in your mouth!!!! oh so-good!)

With one appetizer, four rolls, and two orders of sashimi, along with our drinks, it usually ends up being about $70-$80. 

We travel to Sushi Bistro from San Jose. We'll drive up to San Francisco just to eat dinner here and then drive back home... we've even done it during weekday rush hour traffic. That's how much we love it.

What we don't love. Parking. It is a residential area and all the residents are back home and not going anywhere at dinnertime... it can take up to 30 minutes to find a parking space! But that's just something we have to put up with! 

Love Sushi Bistro!
author: Linh F.

description:
This joint was cool.
The atmosphere is really neighborhood-y: it's small, lots of people waiting, varied crowd from hipsters to families.
I'm not much of a roll eater, so no comment there, but the nigiri and sashimi were pretty good. We also had the jalapeno yellowtail, which wasn't exactly up to Nobu standards, but was still delicious. They have a decent sake menu, with probably 5-7 nigori choices (my fave), which is kinda rare.
I expected to be paying big bucks at a hipster sushi place in the middle of San Francisco, but prices were totally affordable. I think for 3 of us to eat the nigiri special, sashimi special, yellowtail entree, salads, edamame, pitcher of sapporo, and bottle of sake, it was like $120.
Only bad part: parking. We drove around for probably 15 minutes before finally finding a spot about 3 blocks away.
author: Mindy A.

description:
EH, for the price we paid.. I expected better. 

The only reason we ate at Sushi Bistro was because of all the great reviews and the various awards they received (they received so many, their window/door was covered with stickers saying they're the winner of "blah blah blah award on blah blah blah year" ). Given that, I expected this place to be off the wall AMAZING. 

But instead, it was JUST OKAY. Granted, the restaurant was clean and chic looking.. the food was only okay. The rolls were unique (as Cindy C says) but the portions were itty bitty. I think the only reason why this place received such a high rating is because of the presentation of the food. But taste wise, it's was only alright. 

Overall, I expected a lot more out of a restaurant that allegedly won so many awards.Which makes me question, how did they receive so many? 

Like Jenny K., I feel a bit fooled by this place.
author: Jess s.

description: Delicious food, fresh sashimi, good atmosphere and great service. For the prices it's worth it, the quality of food is that you get what you pay for. Would recommend to friends and family and will be coming back more than a few times.
author: Roman L.

description:
I have been there once.
I really liked the service: friendly and fast.

The restaurant was empty but they sit us at the bar :(. Great date...
Anyway, I was disappointed by the food. Portion are really small and that suck when you know that in a 3 block radius, you have better for cheaper.

The place looks nice and the service is good, but the food is really average. Did not gave me a "wow, I love it" feeling.
author: Tarek A.

description:
Wow! I am surprised about all these 4 star reviews.  When my GF and I walked in, we were seated instantly.  The service was excellent, but the food was not so great.  We ordered the gyoza, the scallops, and a roll.  I would have ordered a combination box, but the thing is they don't offer it here. That's a first...  The plating was pretty nice, except my scallops had some things on it that were questionable to me.  It appeared to look as if the whiskers from shrimp had been plucked and put on the scallops as decoration.  Cool right?  Well not if I'm allergic to shrimp.  Oh well, no big deal.  I just picked them off and ate it.  The scallops should be called "Soy Sauce Scallops" because they were overpowered with some type of salty sauce.  The menu said they were "seared" but i felt and tasted no sear at all.  As for the gyozas, they were not crispy, but felt soggy. 

 As for the check..they added a sushi roll that 1) we did not order and 2) they don't even sell that roll anymore.  Epic fail. I'm not one to care much about the bill but this place was pretty pricy and did not fill me up. Won't be coming here again!
author: Victor L.

description:
The combination of good sushi, a great atmosphere, and incredibly fast service makes this spot one of my favorites.

I have had a lot of different rolls here and every single one has impressed.  The sushi never tastes heavy, and the flavors never just mash together.  Each roll has a unique and light feel and taste that surprises me with every visit.  The menu goes far beyond your normal rolls but does not just go wild for the sake of it.  A tried and true taste is present in each option that always seems to just work perfectly.  I always get the butterfish as an appetizer and I have yet to be unimpressed.  

Usually just good sushi would not warrant a 5 star rating, but combine this with a fun and upbeat atmosphere, and then pile on lighting fast service.  I have been there just as a group of two and also as a group of 5.  Every time the restaurant has been packed and every time the appetizers, drinks, and rolls come out quickly and with almost perfect timing.  Appetizers finished? Plate cleared, a minute or two of talking, and all of the sudden the next roll is there.  The service is great and it is not just fast, it is well timed regardless of the volume they are experiencing. 

Seriously though, get the Butterfish
author: Greg M.

description:
First time I've heard of Sushi Bistro. After finding out that a nearby sushi restaurant that we wanted to go to was closed, we decided to try this out since there were a good amount of positive reviews. However, I came away with negative thoughts about this place.

The customer service is pretty bi-polar. You walk in and are greeted by someone who is very enthusiastic and happy to see you then you get seated and the waitress just has a sour attitude and rushes you while you're trying to decide what to have. You could see that she was annoyed and took it out on us (even though we didn't do anything).

Everything was sticky. The chair was stuck to the floor, the chair was sticky, the table was extremely sticky. It felt like someone spilled soda all over the place and no one cleaned it. Something you don't want to see at a restaurant..a dead fly in our water. Disgusting...

The menu was a bit unclear. We thought the "something unique" was sushi because it wasn't clearly marked, but those are appetizers. We got the Double Jeopardy, which was--unique, and it tasted really good. It was like asian guacamole. It was guacamole with fresh fish and shrimp chips. We also ordered the Albacore Dream, Sexy Scallop, and the Watermelon-man. My favorite was the Albacore Dream. The mangos in the Watermelon-man were hard and the Sexy Scallop was a bit too spicy. The fish is probably fresh and delicious, but it is hard to tell because the fish in every dish is masked by all the other sauces and flavors that they put on the rolls.

The food is definitely on the expensive end ($10-15) for a standard roll. I probably won't be coming here again..
author: Kevin H.

description: The veggie rolls weren't rolled it felt as if I was eating seaweed salad. The waitress was uninterested and probably just wanted to go home
author: Ravi R.

description:
Ate here for dinner this past saturday night with my boyfriend in honor of our anniversary.  I've been waiting to try this place for months now, and well, let's just say we'll be back for more.

Had dinner reservations at 7:30PM and we got seated pretty fast.  We looked at the menu but I already knew I wanted to get the butterfish blasters (recommendation from a good friend) and the ahi poke.  So, that left us with one more thing to order since we thought that would be a good amount of food for us to share.  The last roll we got was the african spider.  Saw a lot of reviews about it so we had to try it out.

Everything was AHH-MAZ-ING!!  The butterfish blasters melted in our mouths, the ahi poke was just right and the african spider sealed the deal.

I'm so happy I got to try this place whilst I was in the bay.
Five stars for the awesome service and food :)
author: Criselle O.

description: The food is delicious，and there is a relaxed environment. But the waitress has a bad service，and when I want her recommend some Sushi for me，she just left unexpectedly. And she didn't ask us whether anything is ok. If I go to there next time，I hope another waiter service for us.
author: Maggie T.

description:
Yay another place off my list!

Found parking a block away, came around....630ish and got a table....

very cool atmosphere, dark, and hip.

we ordered alot...

butterfish blasters- these were only okay to us...doesn't do butterfish justice....nice flavors but eh. 6 pieces $14
grilled whole squid- this tasted slightly better than izakaya sozai...the texture was good, they need a different dipping sauce though. but good
12 piece sashimi- YUMMMM, they were so fresh and melted in your mouth! 
M&L forever roll- we asked the waitress for recommendations....i didn't really like this one...if its the humungous roll with fried outside stuff....too sweet...and overwhelming.
monster in laws- spicy....it was good....but maybe we were too full to enjoy it!
oh yea hamachi kama- we got a pretty large piece....but maybe under seasoned since we didn't really like it as much as other places...

also had the kamotsuru sake....didn't really like it...tasted too much of rubbing alcohol...eh

overall was superrrr full....and left fairly happy and ate everything....EVERYTHING.

bill came out to $120 or so. reasonably priced.
author: Christine M.

description:
We celebrated my bf's birthday here this past weekend and they were very accommodating with the reservation change for the number of people.  It was quite difficult to find a Japanese restaurant that was able to hold a large party.  We were seated in a backroom by ourselves which was great, the only thing was the size of the table was very small, so it made it hard to find places to put all of our food and drinks.

Our server was helpful and told us about some awesome specials that many of our table took advantage of.  there was a diver scallop with monkfish liver and fresh uni on top of the shell (see picture), toro,  and oysters on a half shell.  

Their menu offers an array of food for the sushi connoisseur or for the beginner sushi eaters who like to eat fancy rolls.  I would definitely try their "unique dishes" as everyone at our table tried different kinds and was pleasantly surprised. 

Food:
Agedashi Tofu: 4 pieces of really large tofu slightly battered in a ponzu sauce.
Monte Blanc roll: brown rice with avocado, cucumber, shrimp tempura, and butterfish on top.  (Really delicious and it came with a lot of pieces)
Sashimi Spirit: Salmon with tobiko and avocado wrapped with soy paper (this roll wasn't bad but not the best one)
12 piece sashimi: the fish was really fresh and melted in my mouth.

Prior to this experience, I have only been to the one in the Mission, and I would definitely come back here if I'm in the area.
author: Carli F.

description: Yumm! We were lucky to park half a block away. First things first.. The bf and I tried their variety of hot sake and decided to go with the sweet one (I forgot the name). We ordered the tuna poki special. Our favorite was the Yellowtail Basil.. Definitely recommend. Good service and good food!
author: Vanessa Y.

description: It's the best sushi I've ever had. The service was fantastic and the food was just amazing. They have classic sashimi and nigiri but also some really flavorful unique rolls that don't divert focus from the quality of the fish. The setting of the restaurant is great, the ambience was nice. It was a packed house on a Friday night so make reservations. Literally everything was delicious. Trust in their recommendations- they know what they are doing. It was a great dining experience that I will remember for a long time.
author: Mitch W.

description: Service was horrible. The waitress had no costumer service skills and after they noticed we didn't leave a tip we got harassed. The bus boy was the only nice person in there.
author: Kadie A.

description:
When I said I wanted sushi during a visit to SF, DK suggested Sushi Bistro in the Inner Richmond. Since by definition, there really is no such thing as a sushi bistro, I had my doubts, but those fears subsided once I took a quick look on Yelp and found a four-star rating.

The place took reservations, which is sometimes a rarity in the city. There's a bar and then like a row of tables alongside one wall. There are also more tables in the back, although I didn't see how many, but I took a quick glance when going to the restroom. 

I guess no one eats at 5:30 except for me in the city, so we were immediately seated. They brought us some green tea, with teabags in the cups, which made me wary because you only see that in non-Japanese-owned establishments. Speaking of which, I looked behind the sushi-counter and didn't really see anyone who looked Japanese. Oh well, with almost 1,000 reviews and a four-star average, I had to trust in the system. 

For three of us, we just kept the rolls coming. What was great was that we would order one or two at a time and when they were brought out, we would order another, but there were not huge lulls in between. They came out at just the right pace and our waiter/host was really nice, and then I learned he spoke Mandarin when he was talking to the table next to us, which kind of threw me for a loop. So we got the following:

1) african spider   12.95 (NOT A FAN, THERE WAS SOMETHING WEIRD ABOUT THE SAUCE AND THE WAY IT WAS FRIED, PASS!)
soft shell crab, sprouts, tobiko, deep-fried cajun albacore and salmon topped with avocado, eel sauce, and spicy sauce.

2) monster in-laws   12.95 (WAS SUGGESTED THIS OVER THE YT JALAPENO, AND IT WAS GOOD)
chopped spicy albacore, cucumber topped with yellowtail, jalapenos, spicy and ponzu sauce.

3) rock'n roll   8.25 (ALTHOUGH NOT A ROLL, IT STILL CAME IN 8 PIECES AND WAS MY FAVORITE OF THE MEAL)
baked spicy scallops served on top of a California roll. 

4) 49er     8.95 (ALWAYS LOVE THE REFRESHING COMBINATION OF SALMON AND LEMON)
avocado and tobiko topped with salmon and lemon.

5) aloha 101   9.95 (REALLY PRETTY PRESENTATION WITH THE SUSHI, MARRED BY WHAT DK CALLED LEFTOVER RAMEN SOUP BASE FOR THE DIPPING SAUCE. I DID NOT LIKE THE SAUCE AND FELT THAT IT RUINED THE DISH WITH HOW IT LOOKED AND TASTED. PLAIN OL' WASABI AND SOY SAUCE WAS BETTER)
ahi tuna, mango & cucumber wrapped in seaweed, flash-fried, served with spicy garlic sauce.

6) butterfish blasters   13.95 (ORDERED THESE BECAUSE OF ALL THE RAVE REVIEWS, BUT NOTHING REALLY SPECIAL. GOOD, BUT WOULD PROBABLY TRY SOMETHING NEW NEXT TIME, AS OPPOSED TO GETTING THIS AGAIN)
snow crab meat and avocado wrapped in butterfish torched with a garlic-soy

I think we had one more order, but I can't remember what it is at this time. In short, great sushi, really great, friendly service and takes reservations. And they split our credit cards three-ways, no complaints. What else can you ask for in the city? It's on my come-back list for SF visits.
author: Ming-Jou C.

description: Wow. Came here on the recommendation of my sister and it was amazing! They have a broad selection of vegetarian/vegan items, as well as an amazing selection of traditional fish based sushi. We ordered a little bit of everything and it seemed like each dish was better than the last. They also had a great Pinot Noir as their house wine. Service was excellent and the prices were reasonable. Seriously one of favorite sushi spots ever!
author: Casey C.

description: Miso soup was excellent. Dragon sushi to die for. Udon soup was made with love. The tempura came in very generous serving. Nice ambience. Will definitely come here again.
author: S. R.

description:
When you're craving those delicious, gigantic, sauce-covered trendy LA rolls, head over to Sushi Bistro where you have a long list of awesome options to choose from! They have beers on tap, sake, and some interesting cocktails (I think?).

I was impressed by the quality of the yellowtail appetizer I got, although it's difficult to judge the fish quality in the sushi. It was delicious though!

$35 for 3 rolls, and an appetizer. I will be back and can't wait to try out their Mission location!
author: Jess C.

description:
Sushi Bistro. OH MY GOD. 
im so glad a couple of friends and i stumbled across this place, because i don't regret  the 90 bones i spent here. 
I'm thinking the experience we had was because of the time we got there-- right when it opened.
the food was super good, no doubt, definitely worth all of my money. 
everything came out fast, which it should have, because we were 3 of the 7 people in there. 
the waiter, or whoever helped us didn't really make any conversation. but then again, as long as i got my food i was fine. 
either way... 5 stars for all around a very good time!
author: Chelsea B.

description: The food is great but unfortunately I found a roach in my to go utensils. I really love this place but it's definitely not a good look to find a pest in my utensils to go. So I would have to rate this a 2. Only because the food is great and the place looks good... But unfortunately they have ROACHES..
author: Sherlynn T.

description: Japanese food in general can be pricey, but the sushi rolls are delicious and well worth the price. My boyfriend and I have only been here once and will definitely come back again. They have very unique, fresh rolls. I can't wait to come back and try other rolls.
author: Kristen F.

description: Delicious.  Quick to serve. Everything was Awesome.  Definitely order Double Jeopardy. Ikura was super fresh, sashimi was great. It was ALL great. Can't go wrong with anything
author: Blake S.

description: Long-time customer but very disappointed in recent service. Seems like they don't have anything in order there. Waited way too long for my food, it was double the time and I had called ahead. Management didn't offer any apology or help to me. Won't be coming back anymore.
author: Jacob W.

description:
Yum, yum! 

I got the veggie salad roll and the asparacado roll. Both of the sauces were served in a side dish. I think it would have been better if they topped the rolls with sauce. However, they were both amazing. I love the great selection of veggie sushi. 

My uncle got the daily special sashmi and he said it was the best sushi he has ever had, very fresh.
author: Nicole S.

description: Best sushi place ever by the area so far ! All the seasonal nigiri sashimi special are so fresh and when u put it into your mouth it just melts away ! Nice service and staff are great, recommend this place.
author: Edu B.

description: Delicious sushi! They have lots of interesting rolls- we tried three different ones and loved them all. It's a bit pricey for specialty rolls but definitely worth it.
author: Laura M.

description:
My boyfriend took me to Sushi Bistro for my birthday a few months back and we were not disappointed. 

He had made reservations for around 6pm, but we didn't really need them. We've been back since then and still have never had to wait for a table. Keep in mind we eat a little earlier than the dinner rush hour.

Things we've ordered:
- Sexy Scallop Roll ($10.75) - Salmon wrapped in rice and soy paper topped with scallops.
- Albacore Dream ($10.95) - Spicy tuna and avocado topped with albacore.
- Omega 3 ($8.95) - Fried Salmon, cucumber, and avocado topped with salmon and albacore.
- Monsters In-Laws ($11.75) - Spicy albacore topped with albacore and jalepeno.
- Spicy Crunchy ($9.25) - Yellowtail, salmon, snapper, shirmp, and macadamia nuts deep fried.
 - African Spider ($12.50) - Cajun flavored albacore, salmon, and soft shell crab.
- Salmon Sashimi ($7.90) 4pc.
- Hokkaido Sea Scallop Sashimi ($11.90) 4pc.
- Tempura Appetizer ($7.95)

The Sexy Scallop is by far my favorite roll. Salmon and scallops are my two favorites and this roll has both, so what's not to love. The sashimi here is ridiculous. The slices are HUGE and the quality of the fish is actually pretty good. The Omega 3 Roll is also very good as is the Monster In-Law and Albacore Dream, which my boyfriend really likes. People seem to really like the Spicy Crunchy roll, but we weren't that impressed with it. I'm not a big fan of deep fried rolls though, so I guess I'm kind of biased. 

Overall Sushi Bistro is the kind of place you go if you want creative rolls. If you're looking for traditional sushi, this is not the place to go. Biggest complaint is that the tables are only inches from each other. Each time we've been we've felt like we were part of the other tables conversation. But if you are looking for something creative and tasty for around $70 you can get 4 rolls, an appetizer and some sashimi.
author: Eifeh S.

description:
Sushi Bistro is a decent sushi stop. Miso soup was very good. I had a spicy tuna roll. The tuna did not seem very fresh. It was almost minced. The ratio of tuna, avocado/other vegetables was very off. Way too much minced tuna. 
There are better placed anywhere in Japantown SF.
author: Maey P.

description: Very disappointed. You will wait forever for your order. Bad customer service and business etiquette from management. It seems that they just want to take your money.
author: Kay A.

description:
Sushi Bistro is a great place for sit down sushi. I always experience great service here. 

They have unique sushi combinations (they have great vegetarian options, even) and their food is always fresh!
author: Sarah D.

description:
Sushi Bistro is upscale American sushi featuring rolls that eschew tradition and combine a mish-mash of cuisine and flavors. Here you will find rolls containing a variety of nontraditional ingredients such as deep fried asparagus, red serrano ginger sauce, mango, chicken, mushrooms... the list goes on. If you are a sushi purist looking for only the freshest sashimi and fish-on-rice nigiri walk out the door and head 8 blocks east to Okina. If you are open to creative and fun fusion rolls, and willing to splurge a little in the $$ range then step right up and prepare to enjoy!

Rolls I have enjoyed:
49ers: salmon, thin lemon slice, avocado 
Sexy scallop: spicy white tuna, salmon, avocado and topped with spicy chopped day-boat scallop, tobiko and scallions.
Aloha 101: ahi tuna, mango & cucumber wrapped in seaweed, flash-fried, served with spicy garlic sauce. 
Red Devil: butterfish tempura, aioli, avocado & cucumber, topped with spicy tuna, scallions, and red serano ginger sauce.

Avoid:
The agedashi tofu. It is very inexpensive and the portion is HUGE but the tofu is completely flavorless and has the consistency of mush, which is strange considering it is served lightly fried. Perhaps it needs to be fried longer to crisp it up a bit and dry out the tofu.
author: Tomas K.

description:
Mediocre. They do use good quality fish for the nigiri. I've had the scallops, salmon and some other pieces that were quite good. This was where I had lemon and soy sauce on raw scallops for the first time and it was excellent.

The rolls aren't that great. The Billie Jean, supposedly baby Lobster with fresh avocado, cucumber and wrapped with soy paper and aioli and topped with salmon tasted like a California roll with a slice of salmon atop of it. To be fair, I substituted seaweed for the soy paper since I'm not a huge fan of soy paper. The African Spider was good, but I get a similar spider roll in most other places. This place will throw some Sriracha in it, which I don't like.
 
Magic Mushroom - umm ... this tasted like sweet and sour pork at a cheap Chinese restaurant. They just substituted the pork for mushrooms. Not a fan of this dish.
author: Alton Y.

description:
Perfect taste, spice and crunch. 

Friends from SF took us here. Great atmosphere and Great Sushi and special Rolls. Really loved the Rock N' Roll, Monster in Law and African Spider.
author: Alan R.

description: Food is great!  Expensive as hell, but good food.  Some reason even though it's expensive, I get it at least once a week!
author: Blane A.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed this place, and thought the fish was fresh and tasty.  That being said, I tended to be more impressed by the "something unique" dishes than by the rolls themselves.  Standouts included the Butterfish Blasters, Spicy Girl, and Kona Carpaccio.  For the rolls, our favorite was the Hawaiian Breeze.

As for service, I thought the waitstaff was friendly, knowledgeable, and attentive.  Definitely had no complaints there.
author: Scott E.

description: All the sushi is fresh and delicious, my only caveat is that some rolls come with something they're calling cajun seasoned tuna... which tastes more like canned tuna salad with some cajun seasoning mixed in. Not a fan. Avoid those and you're all good.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I loooove Sushi Bistro!  The rolls are all just okay, but points for creativity.  For their category of crazy American style rolls, they definitely have more creative rolls than your standard California Roll, Rock n Roll, Lion King, Dragon Roll or what have you.  Nothing wrong with those types, but it's refreshing to see a new take on sauced up maki rolls.  Unlike other maki rolls, these are not on steroids but you still get stuffed.

You get generous slices of sashimi here.  I especially love their shiro maguro and butterfish.  Their butterfish is amazing.  

If you think their prices are a little more than what you normally pay, I assure you that it's worth your money, not just in quality but quantity.
author: Erika C.

description:
What do you mean AHI TUNA POKE is an appetizer????? I can eat 3 of those as my entree.   Fresh fish with mixed greens, slices of avocado and crispy fingerling potato strips tossed in a delicious but not too heavy dressing. So good, so crunchy and a little addicting...please try this it will not disappoint. (see picture)

Butterfish Blasters are my second favorite dish here. They have really creative names for their dishes by the way. The garlic-soy dressing combined with the freshness of the butter fish melts right in your mouth. (see picture)

We also tried the Magic Mushrooms which were good as well. If you enjoy mushrooms this is a fried mushroom medley with a hint of sweet and spicy flavor. 

The reason why this place is not 5 stars is because the maki/rolls were not on par with their sashimi/appetizer/small plates. It might be the ones I ordered but I tried 3 different rolls and they were all meh. Perhaps they will come up with more creative rolls like their appetizers. 

We finished off with the green tea fried ice cream. It was sliced into 6 pieces...a lot easier to share because most other places serve this in one scoop. (see picture) 

The atmosphere is casual and the crowd is fairly young here. I came here on a weekday night with 6 and we were seated immediately. The dishes came out pretty fast and the service was great. Almost forgot to mention that this place is totally affordable and decently priced.
author: Wendy L.

description:
So this place has been on my radar for a while and we finally got to try it tonight. And I have to say that I was NOT disappointed! All the rolls that we tried were fresh. big, tasty, and with little rice. My favorite roll was the sexy scallop and the new legend. All the elements just came together to make the greatest party in my mouth. The sauces never overpowered the fresh fish. There was never too much rice...which left us to enjoy the actual fishes. Also the double jeopardy was just awesome. Tuna poki mixed with avocado and rice crackers to scoop it all up right into your mouth. 

The prices are pretty middle of the road $10-14 per roll. The service was great as well. Our glasses were never empty and our empty plates were never left on the table for too long. 

The atmosphere was darkened to give it a trendy, yet romantic vibe.

We were surprised to see it sooo packed on Wednesday night. So I would definitely recommend making a reservation if you want to be seated right away. 

This place is A+ all the way!
author: Michelle I.

description: The hip atmosphere and creative specialty rolls made dining at this an enjoyable experience.  I think the sushi was slightly sub par but the rest of the menu was visually pleasing and delicious. The waitstaff was friendly and helpful, but the parking was a pain in the butt, plan ahead...
author: Mike S.

description:
I am a purist when it comes to sushi and the food here was disappointing.  Their shari (sushi rice) was lame.  I mean the presentation was fine--of adequate size, and styled--yet the fish (hamachi, toro, maguro) was not of high quality and therefore tasteless.  My uni was beyond fresh so had lost most of its cat-tongue texture (I KNOW it grosses some you out, but that is part of the discrete and essential charm of experiencing urchin gonads!) and was just this side of edible.  I ate it anyway, because it was expensive, I was hungry, and our servers were so nice.

My friend's nigiri fell apart when he lifted it from the plate.  Sticky rice is supposed to be sticky; it's really the unsung star of any sushi experience in my book, holding it all together and imparting those slightly sweet and sour, seaweed-ish under notes against which all manner of delicate fish meats seem bright.  It should be made with dashi, of which there are different kinds.  Dashi can be made from kombu (dried kelp), katsuo-bushi (dried bonito flakes), niboshi (dried small sardines), hoshi-shiitake (dried shiitake mushrooms), and more.  Sorry, but we just started laughing!  We did not like the rice.

Sushi Bistro signature rolls are the reason to go there, though.  Colorful, creative and made for an American palate they come rolling out at just the right temperature in the arms of a good-looking and attentive staff.  I had a hard time finding ones that did not have deep-fried fish bits or "spicy" (what you do with fish that is no longer sushi grade) hashed with mayonnaise mixes included, though.  The ratio of fish was notably weighted towards the roll on all three selections we ordered but, again, we were trying to avoid the gobs of fish-flecked mayonnaise and batter-fried mascots of the deep adorning all the tables surrounding us.

We've been here a few times before, mostly with friends from the East Bay who buzz to SF specifically to fill-up with the hip and friendly Sushi Bistro crowd.  We usually order a bottle of cold saki, the names of which I can never remember.  This time, the two of us split a large hot (house) sake--yuk ... swill.  Oh well, I'm not a sake connoisseur and some things just taste better when you're enjoying them with friends.
author: Vicki O.

description:
This is everything I dislike about restaurants: overly pretty and way too snazzy of a menu (and people) means the food isn't great and the prices are too much. This is basically all those things. The food is good but for the price, it's not really worth the trip. 

The service is really nice though and you won't be disappointed with your meal but I prefer other sushi joints.
author: Diana Y.

description: This is definitely one of my go-to sushi restaurants in the city. Fresh sushi, good selection of rolls and entrees and never a long wait since they moved into a bigger space a couple spots down from their old restaurant. It's a good place to eat and chat it up with friends since it's spacious enough where they don't rush you out the minute you finish your meal. They also give you this little saucer of pickled cucumber which is really refreshing before your meal.
author: Queena T.

description:
The rolls are what I recommend - high quality fish, interesting combos and tasty sauces (put the soy sauce away).  The New Legend is my favorite, but you can't go wrong with Aloha 101, Red Devil, M&L Forever, Five Wishes and C2.  Butterfish Blasters, Hot Love and the Butterfish Salad are also delicious, as is the tempura.  

They have non-Asian draught beers (IPA, pilsner and wheat) which is a big plus.  Service is friendly but it does get packed so plan accordingly.  It is a bit pricey but well worth it.
author: OhTheRogue S.

description:
Five stars seems a bit much, but I really like Sushi Bistro. They have great vegetarian sushi options (cheaper, and made with brown rice), as well as tons of regular options for fish-lovers like myself. The rolls are packed with delicious bits of everything (crab on top, avocado rolled in, whatever) and the presentation is nice too.

Not too pricey. Not great, but not terrible. I've been here a few times and it's a good deal if you're sharing rolls with a few people. And the names are so cute! One of my favorite rolls? Billie Jean. It's got to be somewhere around 12 bucks.

The servers are friendly - not at all overbearing or absent. The vibe is trendy... spacious, but intimate as far as table set-up. It's a really good place to bring friends or visiting family members any night.
author: Jiordan C.

description: Food standard sushi fare, easy to get a table. The servers were not very attentive and left us hanging a few times. We would have ordered more rounds of rolls and drinks if they came by our table often enough... Their loss.
author: Amie G.

description:
The service is good here. The food...well not so much.

The sushi rolls are definitely very americanized. While the fish is fresh, the way it was put together in a roll is not very authentic.

So if you're a sushi snob who loves the simplicity and elegance of sashimis and nigiris, this place is not for you. But if you like americanized sushi (which is fine too), then give it a go
author: Ngan B.

description:
amazingly fresh and unpretentious in SF.  rare i know. but that's only because we have the best taste and access to the best ingredients. (see what i did there)

what else can I say that hasn't been said? 
yes, go here.

snapshot:
get waitresses recommendation for some fresh nigiri sushi
especially loved the ocean trout nigiri
NEW LEGEND specialty roll (MUST)
monster in law- great but familiar
author: Jenna D.

description:
Excellent sushi.
The ambience was lovely- the decor was very classy and modern and although it was rather loud and crowded, it didn't detract from the meal or how much we enjoyed the restaurant.
I went with my boyfriend, and we shared the C-2 roll and the Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon roll.
Both rolls were of excellent quality, plated very nicely and tasted amazing. Very fresh fish, the avocado and eel were crazy yummy, and my only complaint is that the shrimp tempura, although tasty, overpowered the other and slightly more delicious flavors such as the eel. Honestly, i could've eaten that eel by itself and been happy, it was that good.
Anyways, I definitely recommend this place! Sushi Bistro has some of the best sushi I've ever had!
author: Laura G.

description:
The ambiance is nice, especially in their new location. The rolls are creative and the white tuna is quite tender. (What white tuna isn't?)
Their fried oysters make Swanson's TV dinners shine. Yuk. Please improve, anything would be better.
I would definitely return with friends, but I would stick to what makes this place popular and not tread too far off the menu path.
author: Brian J.

description:
What's the hype about this place? I don't get it... I got fooled. The pictures look great and the description of the rolls were very much attractive but their fish were bland and did not have the quality of taste. For the price I paid, I deserved a decent grade of sashimi. 

Never again. Now I know.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I really like this place. The ambiance had a very intimate, dark setting. However, the tables are uncomfortable close to one another. The service was great. 
We got the Aloha 101 Roll that had cucumber, mangoes and a large chunk of tuna and the 12 piece sashimi. I must say, the sashimi was very fresh and neatly placed on the plate. The roll was alright. The mangoes probably weren't in season so the roll just tasted kind of plain. It came with a sauce that made the rolls a little bit more flavorful, but overall, this roll in itself wasn't too filling. 

As a starving college student, this restaurant was a little bit out of my normal price range. It's definitely worth checking out, especially on a date :)
author: Sheila X.

description:
It used to bother me when I go to a sushi bar and find out the chefs are not Japanese. And although I love sashimi and Uni, this is not the place.  I would definitely go to a more authentic Japanese restaurant for super fresh fish. But when I'm in the mood for Americanized sushi rolls, like Rainbow roll, Billy Jean or 49ers roll then I come here... And if I don't feel like getting all dolled up, because this place is super casual... Overall this is a great place to grab sushi grub w/ friends or casual date. Customer service has always been super friendly, even when they are slammed. 
Unfortunately now that I have moved from the Panhandle area, I no longer come here. It's always so much more convenient to go to a restaurant in one's neighborhood. Funny how 3 or 4 miles seems so far away now. I do miss it:)
author: Myra M.

description: Came here with the fiancé who was craving sushi so we yelped sushi places close to us. We found this place and it seemed to be rated pretty good. Overall the sushi was a bit overpriced for small portions. Also parking is difficult to find in this area.
author: Cindy N.

description:
Privileged.

We met here: www.youtube.com/watch?v=OuQhz-_eAbc

Years later he's telling me what to eat here:

- Excellent ahi tuna poke special

- Amazing New Wave roll (steamed mahi-mahi, crab, avocado, mango salsa)

- Divine First Crush roll (albacore, tuna apple, salmon, ponzu sauce)

- No room but made room for the delicious apple crème brûlée

Having a good friend on Sushi Bistro's staff might bias my review. But these four things transcend the loyalties of friendships. Each were a privilege to consume.

Not everything is perfect. Edamame was too buttery and the Watermelon-Man roll (tuna, mango, sesame seeds) tried to hard and lacked focus.

But like Tiësto's recent sound we all make mistakes.

Space has a sleek and clean vibe with plenty of dark wood and seating. Entire staff was attentive, friendly and made us feel welcome.

About $70 for the two of us was just about right. Dining with a good friend visiting from China made the experience even better than just right.

Music. Friendships. Food. Extremely grateful life is full of these privileges.
author: Jason B.

description:
Crazy white boy rolls galore. Ok flavors. Not bad for SF, but sushi isn't sustainable. Lacking in ambiance, though this is some soulless persons idea of chic. 

Really what can I say when a roll arrived rice/seaweed only covering 270 degrees. So you pick it up and the whole roll falls apart so you couldn't even eat it functionally. Sorta missing the WHOLE point of sushi and frankly not even sure how someone could look at that an think it should go out. 

Fair prices and OK service, though again my roll didn't even have a 4th side. I simply cannot take this place seriously.
author: Zack S.

description:
I came here with high expectations, but it was a disappointment. With the high reviews, I thought the sashimi and rolls would be fresh and cut well. My party ordered salmon sashimi, monsters in law, island, and a udon. Unfortunately, the sashimi was mediocre and the rolls fall apart. 

Although the sushi and sashimi wasn't amazing, you could come here for the udon and poke salad. The udon broth was made very well. The poke salad with thin crispy noodles was a great combination. If you are looking for a lite meal, this would be a good choice.
author: Sylvia C.

description:
I've been here twice in a week!

The sashimi here is really good... 

You know when you get a sashimi platter, you always want to sub out the ones you don't like?  For me, I like buttery texture fish like salmon (high fat content).  I ordered the 12 piece sashimi and ALL the pieces had that buttery texture.  I also really liked that butterfish (aka super white tuna) was also on that sashimi list.

Oysters were their special of the night.  They were also very tasty, but a little on the small side.  Although, the smaller the oyster, the more delicious.  

I haven't tried any of the sushi rolls because I came here with my family (one of who is on a no carb diet)  So, we just had oysters, sashimi, and I also had some sake to go along with it.  Great times!
author: Christina C.

description:
MMM kind if disappointing after reading the high reviews here.

Came here for Mother's Day, and we got a BUNCH of rolls.
I liked that they had a VARIETY and they were all pretty unique. But in my opinion, they were all generally just covered with mayo/sauce where I couldn't even taste the fish sometimes. I wish they toned down on the sauce, then it'd prob be a solid 4.

A surprising fav of the night for my family was actually the sashimi combo. The pieces of sashimi were fresh and the serving size was pretty good compared to the price tag.. usually sashimi is expensive!

Service was great, and I like how they tell you what roll they just gave you (since some restaurants don't do that).. the servings are pretty good too, about 6 pieces per roll.

OH! We also ended with the "fried" ice cream for dessert which was a big disappointment.. skip it.. it's just ice cream with like.. pancake-like batter covering the outside? I was utterfly confused..

I denno.. still not sure if I'll come back. Maybe I'll check out their lunch or just get sashimi + something else next time!
author: Emily C.

description:
Le meh. 

I should not have to ask to hear the specials, for one. 

Número dos, a staple in sushi joints like akami maguro should not make me recoil because it has a fishy taste.

The rolls omega 3 and butterfish blaster was just okay. The fish is just fresh enough. 

I would probably give this place 2 stars if it were not for their very good albacore belly.
author: Margaret S.

description: A delicious sushi place with really unique and fantastic rolls. My boyfriend and I have been here twice and we've gotten the African Spider, Albacore Dream, Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon, Sashimi Spirit, Spicy Crunchy, and Waikiki. We've also gotten the Salmon Filet teriyaki here. The rolls are all delicious. The only downfall for me personally is that a lot of their rolls in rice paper or cucumber instead of nori. I'm sure if you ask, they would substitute it for nori so I will probably ask for them to do so the next time. I also wish they would state how many rolls come in the dish. Some of our rolls had 12 and others had 6. The salmon filet teriyaki was absolutely amazing and the portion was humungous. My boyfriend is 6'5 and 210 pounds and he had a hard time finishing it. Overall, one of my favorite sushi restaurants in San Francisco!
author: Hana K.

description: My favorite sushi in SF. Large, delicious slices of fresh fish, luscious saki and dub beats.  It can be a little loud so I wouldn't recommend it for a quiet date but it's definitely a good time.
author: Leigh F.

description:
Sushi Bistro, you have lost a customer for life! 
Utterly annoyed and to the point of pissed-off with the dining experience here. 

Sunday dinner began with a warm welcome when we entered the door. From the moment we sat down, an unhappy waitress comes to us and ask for our drink order, proceeded by food order. We must have ordered 8 items (rolls, sashimi, gyozas). The sushi rolls were pretty good and the sashimi was tasty but the "idle" time in between when the dishes came out was a bit disappointing. We were done with one plate and then sat there twiddling our thumbs until the next dish arrived. Given our tables weren't big, the dish size was huge which took a lot of room. Mind you the sushi or sashimi didn't require so much platting space. The waitress would shove one dish to the other and request that we hand over the plates that were done. Why didn't she just lean in a grab it herself? Ain't like the table is big anyways. 

Now the part that got me worked up was when we received the bill. The restaurant charged us for a roll we simply did not order OR receive! This was the Billie Jean roll. Now if you read the description of the roll, one who did see or eat it will know they had it because it's much different than your everyday roll. We did not have no roll that was wrapped in soy paper, that included baby lobster and topped with salmon & lemon! We told the waitress we did not order or get it. She hands the bill to someone and a RUDE ASS sushi chef or whatever that A-hole wants to call himself comes to our table adamantly claims he brought out the roll along with another roll. He then puts down the bill hard on the table and walks away. WOW! Are you f-cking joking with me? Who does that? We sat there with a blank face because we couldn't believe that just happened. We didn't want to make a scene since we were celebrating an event so we went ahead and paid for the freaking bill including the stupid mandatory 18% charge for a party of 5. Mind you, we would be fine with paying any "mandatory" fee if the service was up to par. 

Needless to say, I will NOT be coming back here or recommend this place to ANYONE. So sad because I love to support small businesses in quiet/small neighbors but this one will NEVER be on my list. Good riddance!
author: Dee T.

description:
Hands down, my favorite sushi spot in SF. 

For starters, it's location is definitely out of no where, but I find that refreshing since it can be a total pain to find parking in the city. 

Now lets talk about the food. Personally, I've always been attracted to extravagant rolls, the ones that literally send your mouth into a flavor tornado. This place definitely provides that. 

But as of late, I've also redeveloped my simple taste palate, and so I ordered the albacore nigiri. Now I've had this dish in many places, some places that I never thought could be beat. But when I tried it here at SB, it was a wrap. Hands down, most buttery, smooth, tasty nigiri a dude could ask for. Kudos on that one!

And to top it off, service was excellent. Very accommodating and helpful. Salute to you SB!
author: Richard L.

description:
I'm really surprised at all the great reviews. I eat at a lot of sushi restaurants and I'd say this place is mediocre at best. Everything I had was soooooo bland and tasted the same. I ended up dousing it all in sriracha and soy sauce. 

I only came here to meet with friends. I would definitely not make a special trip. I'm willing to give it another try (because my friends go here often as it's kinda in their hood), but it's frustrating when you have to figure out what DOESN'T suck. 

Three stars for a nice vibe and fast, attentive service.
author: Ashleigh R.

description: Great spot, small sushi
author: Matthew R.

description: They serve large pieces of fish. But the fish was not buttery and super fresh tasting, to me. Instead, it felt like the fish had been kept for slightly too long at too cold of a temperature.
author: Morris R.

description:
Quality sushi that WILL break the bank. Spending $90 for 2 people for a sushi dinner (and not even being full) isn't my ideal dinner. Don't get me wrong, the quality of the fish is 'good,' it's just not absolutely amazing. This is my second time here and I feel the same way each time.

Must get:
Butterfish blasters - if you like soft cod / sea bass / moist fish, this is perfect. The butterfish fits its name and tastes amazing, with crab stuffing. 6 pieces for $15. I really liked it.

Pretty good:
Spider roll - similar to other sushi spot's deep fried soft shell crab, but with a bit more. I enjoyed it. 6 pieces for $15

Skip:
Wine - the merlot was pretty boring and not worth the $8.
Sexy Scallops - i've had much better sushi scallops before. These were lacking in flavor that even the roe couldn't balance it out. Also, it had too much cucumber and the soy wrap was nothing special.
The sashimi tuna roll (i forget the exact name, started with an S), just not worth it. It had quality fish, but again 6 small pieces didn't give me enough.

I left a bit hungry and short $90. Come here for butterfish blasters and nothing else. Walk a block for much better sushi for half the price.
author: Chuck N.

description:
A random sushi restaurant a friend and I chose to go to one night because we were craving sashimi. This place was definitely a prime pick! The place is a small place, but we didn't have to worry much about waiting since it was a Wednesday night.

Our waiter was nice and was helpful with the details on the special and our orders. The atmosphere was chill, a great place to go to with friends or significant other if your craving sashimi.

I've been to a couple of sushi restaurants where I would order a plate of sashimi and I would receive meager cuts. However, these guys weren't stingy with their cuts and each slice was fresh and succulent.

The highlight of our meal was the order of Toro (Fatty Tuna) and believe me when I say, IF YOU LOVE SASHIMI ORDER THE TORO. The price was well worth it as well. I'd definitely come back here again.
author: Richard C.

description: Went here with a few friends, and ordered few rolls and an app. Nothing was terribly memorable, aside from how pretentious and unique the sushi seemed. The rolls, while lovingly presented really didn't live up to the hype. It either had so many ingredients that I really wasn't able to make heads or tails of it, or just was unpleasant to consume. Service was quick and lovely and they were kind enough to accommodate my dining partners allergy needs. But I was sadly disappointed with the food here.
author: Andrew L.

description: I love this place. The sushi is creative and delicious, and the service is impeccable.   They have a room in the back that is great for a 10-20 person birthday dinner!
author: Liz A.

description:
I came here about a year ago and made a mental note to come back because I thought the quality of the fish was fantastic.

Fast-forward to Saturday night. I showed up in an attempt to fulfill a sushi craving after watching a documentary on a famous sushi chef. Unfortunately, the sushi at SB did not match up. Instead, what I found found was lackluster quality and forgetful dishes.

We got a mix of rolls and nigiri so I can say it wasn't limited to a single dish or item. Some of the standouts bad dishes:

The uni lacked texture and was watery, possibly suggesting it was thawed from a frozen state? The other fish we had was mushy too, for a lack of a better adjective.

I took Yelp's suggestion and ordered the Hot Love dish (baby lobster with avocado and crab meat). The dish sounded good but in actuality, it was stringy and there was way too much lemon. In fact, I got a big bite of rind in my first bite.  

Overall I was quite disappointed by my return visit. I'd look for another sushi spot in the neighborhood.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
Sorry Yelpers, I think this one is rated a little too high.  The quality of the sashimi, in my book, always the thing that's the hardest to get right, was very good to excellent.  The ahi poke appetizer in particular, was fantastic.

But maybe I'm just too old school and prefer traditional sushi.  I do like the new wave of flavors and styles of sushi, but it always seems just a little "tricked up" to me.  As "new age" sushi goes, Sushi Bistro is very good.  But I thought many of their sauces were only OK, and while I enjoyed my meal, I didn't think it was close to "to die for."
author: Thommee H.

description:
This place serves excellent fish that is really fresh and tender! The serving sizes are awesome too! We didn't have to wait to be seated (at 6pm) and everything came out really quickly. Our server was very attentive and gave great recommendations!

Got the Butterfish blasters and they were just as amazing as everyone said they were! Tender juicy butterfish with a cold avocado center... yummmmm!! The sauce with it is really good too - $14. 

Seaweed Salad - this was decent. I've had better, but I was craving it so it definitely hit the spot. $4.50 - not worth this price!

Salmon Sashimi - 2 pieces $4.25 and they were LARGE pieces! Tasted HEAVENLY, gosh I regret not ordering another one of these. 

Kampachi Sashimi - (special off the menu) 2 pieces $6.50 - this fish was tougher and the aftertaste was a little weird. I was fine with it, but my friend didn't like it at all. I wouldn't order it again.

Monster-in-law Roll - I like it spicy so this was perfect for me! Has sriracha and a jalepeno on top to add a little kick to it and the roll itself was packed nice and tight and packed with such intense delicious flavors! One of the best rolls I have ever had! Wish I could have had more of this... $13

Total was $54 for dinner for 2. I'll DEFINITELY be back!
author: Kriti R.

description:
Why did you have to ruin my hole in the wall with your Urban Spoon application commercial, Apple???

I mean, I'm glad the restaurant is doing good business, but I wanted this place all to myself.  Now I can only reminisce about the good old days when the place wasn't filled on a Friday night with the Marina crowd at table 2 and 5 doing sake bombs.  

I liked the vibe at the original location; it was smaller and more charming, but the new location (2 doors down) is bigger and more modern.  

Sushi Bistro has some of the freshest, best tasting fish I have ever had.  The sushi is innovative and delicious.  They have, hands down, the best tuna poke salad, and the YT jalapeno is perfection.  So despite the new found popularity, Sushi Bistro remains the same at heart.  The menu, and the music, has not changed.  And although having dinner at Sushi Bistro is more of a hassle now than it used to be, it is always something I look forward to, and something that I wish I could do more.
author: Sandy K.

description:
I am a regular sushi consumer eating it at least once a week. Sushi bistro's fish quality was sub-par. A few of the rolls were not bad, others were fishy and over-dressed with powerful sauces that did not pair well together. Was hoping for Mochi, but no dessert menu. 

Service (once seated) was very fast. Prices are not bad. 

Probably will not return - Ebisu is much better.
author: Alana S.

description:
Everyone enjoyed their meal, the service, and atmosphere. 

Yo Yo
author: Ben C.

description:
Their service was amazing, thank you to the wonderful waiters! 

Never did I have to ask for a refill on my tea or my water. Nor did it ever come close to even being half empty, or close to three fourths empty. 

My favorite roll was the Red Devil

I think everything seemed to taste really fresh, but don't hold me to that as I didn't go for the sashimi. We ordered four rolls, and I've listed them in order how good it tasted

Red Devil. 
Spicy Crunch
M&L forever
Spider Roll


I loved the ambiance! You get the more Americanized feel to it (this didn't matter to me at all). 

The rolls are definitely not your traditional rolls. I will definitely be back for the red devil and probably be interested in trying other rolls. 

I did not like the spider roll at all it just tasted I was eating a cucumber roll. The spicy crunch was good and I might possibly order that again. The M&L was okay. The reason I may think that the spicy crunch and M&L were okay because I usually like rolls that have the raw fish on top and have more of a moist taste (if you get what I mean). M&L and spicy crunch were more on the fried side.

I wish I could rate closer to 4.5, this is just due to the spider roll. Sushi bistro I think you can do so much better! And the size of the rolls were okay, maybe slightly on the smaller side, but I was pretty full sharing with one person after 3 rolls.
author: Sophie C.

description:
I'm a big fan of Sushi Bistro. I'll admit I'm not a sushi connoisseur like most other reviewers on yelp, so I can't attest to the authenticity of the place. That said, I wouldn't recommend eating here in order to try the silly Caucasian Afro, etc. (see "doing it wrong"). However if you want some of the freshest fish in town, stop by for a cold Asahi paired with a clean hamachi belly, or a nice king salmon when it's in season. Also I will be checking out the low-star reviewers' favorite sushi places to see how they compare.

Side note - it IS a little dark in the place, but I've taken many beautiful dates here, and my ability to appreciate them has never been hindered. I also think the music could use a bit of a change, but then again I don't run the place.
author: Mike K.

description: Solid sushi, solid atmosphere. I always judge a sushi place by their specials.  Anybody can build a spicy tuna roll.  It's the special rolls that tell you about the sushi place's talents.  There were really good.  I've had better, but these were good.
author: Dan V.

description: my favorite sushi joint in SF. Found this place back in 2007, keep coming back for unique appetizers and fresh sashimi :)
author: Julie R.

description:
Good experience 

Setting: Lights are very dim, kind of hard to see the menu. Decent size place for an SF restaurant. The waiter was good at checking up on us. 

Price: is a little more than average. i paid about 30 for 2 rolls. 

C-2 and Devil Sushi:
presentation is very good. Very nice looking and of course taste the way it looks! Very flavorful! the size of each piece is not bad, not too small, but not too big. Also, they gave about 10 pieces per roll so they don't rip you off.
author: Kristina L.

description: Family and I were in town and were looking for a good sushi spot.  Yelp lead us here.  My first impression was great, clean, and man, they have really good customer service.  Very friendly folks work here.  They assisted us quickly and food came out quick as well.  Sushi was on point. Their teriyaki chicken dinner was delicious also. I am not a local here, but at least I know where to go when I am in town and craving sushi!
author: Cesar C.

description:
Great sushi! All the specialty rolls sounded tempting but I went with the "M&L Forever".  It had tuna crab, spicy albacore, plus some veggies.  And boy was it good! I devoured the whole thing in minutes on top of a regular spicy tuna roll.

The service was prompt and friendly.  If you're looking for a good sushi restaurant without breaking the bank, I recommend Sushi Bistro.
author: Riley S.

description: Seeing some negative review but I've always had such a great experience here. The quality of sushi definitely reflects in their prices, but make a reservation for Fridays & weekends cause it can get super crowded sometimes! I mostly order from their signature rolls. One of my favorites is the albacore dream. It has always been super fresh and doesn't taste like plastic or hard unlike some other places & their hot sake is yummy too! I know they have a back room area for larger parties but usually I only come here with 2 to 3 of my friends so I've always been seated in the front area, it can get a little loud sometimes but not too bad. Definitely worth the visit!
author: Allison C.

description:
A purveyor of quality raw fish pioneer in the Inner Richmond--a neighborhood that is long on sushi, but short on freshness-- Sushi Bistro is bringing upscale sushi to the 'hood.

The nigiri features super-sized cuts of the freshest fish you can hope for:  shiro maguro (albacore), hamachi (yellowtail), and hotate (scallop) were all huge and amazingly fresh.  The selection of rolls is outstanding.  From the ubiquitous California roll and spicy tuna roll to the more adventurous sexy scallop roll (spicy white tuna, salmon, and avocado topped with spicy chopped scallop, tobiko and scallions:  piquant and yummy) and the big island roll (salmon, tuna, yellowtail  tobiko, snow crab, avocado, and sprouts wrapped inside a thinly sliced cucumber:  absolutely delicate and delicious) diners will not be disappointed.  An unique selection of non-traditional appetizers does not disappoint:  jalapeno hamachi sashimi, ahi poke, and seared branzino (sea bass) with daikon were all super.

There is a good selection of premium sakes, including the fresh, clean Suigei and the sweet, melon-like Otokoyama, as well as hard to find Japanese beers like Echigo in addition to the normal Sapporo and Kirin.

Service was super-fast and friendly.  Dishes arrived quickly and used plates were removed almost immediately.  In addition, the servers were knowledgeable about the menu and the preparation processes of many menu items.

If you are in the neighborhood, swim on over to Sushi Bistro for some of the best sushi in the Inner Richmond.
author: CJ G.

description:
I can't believe it has taken me 4.5 years to write a review for this Sushi B!!

I can't say enough good things about this restaurant. It's the most amazing fish/rolls I have ever had. Fresh, unique and delicious.

The service is great--always super friendly staff and ready to give suggestions etc.

Perfect design. A back room that is great for parties (ie-every birthday I have had in the bay). Good music, sports on most times. 

Just great. I really don't think I have had a friend that has come to town without me taking them here.

GO!
author: Ilana I.

description:
Finally had time to come here. Service was EXCELLENT. However, the food was alright, nothing really stood out. We were disappoint with the sashimi because it was was cut to big. 

Overall stars? 3.5
author: Trinity L.

description:
I've been searching for a good sushi place in the city and I haven't quite found a spot that I can rave about, let alone "crown" as my top sushi place.  SUSHI BISTRO, where have you been all of my life?  The service is prompt.  The place is clean.  The fish is fresh!  The rolls are AMAZING (yes, that's me raising my voice in excitement).

I've tried numerous dishes here but I have my three absolute favorites:

-Appetizer-
Double Jeopardy   
salmon, albacore & avocado chopped tartar style, mixed with wasabi aioli, spicy garlic soy & served with shrimp chips

-Rolls-
M&L forever   
spicy tuna, crab meat, cajun flavored albacore, avocado, and grilled big eye tuna inside a crispy exterior drizzled with bonito sauce

Red Devil   
butterfish tempura, aioli, avocado & cucumber, topped with spicy tuna, scallions, and red serano ginger sauce.

Add a large order of hot sake and a large bottle of Sapporo and you're good to go!  I will be back for sure.  Probably sometime this week.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
This is I think the third time I've been here & I got to admit, for a hip, Americanized, younger-generation target, the rolls & fish are really fresh & uniquely made. Prices are reasonable too.

I still love love the Dave's Legacy Roll which is not on the menu. It is a sweet potato tempura roll with hamachi on top. The roll portions are relatively huge too so don't order too many if you have a small party. Many different varietals of sake available & customer service is fast & good.

Now I live right down the street so I may just have to fancy this place often :)
author: Alysha K.

description:
"Meh."  

First of all, what are you hiding in there?  Why so dark?  Guys, take your dates here if they are a little rough in the face.  She'll look real good in this lighting.  

Secondly, I've only ever heard that this place had amazing sushi.  What we ordered wasn't amazing sushi (I am currently making a sad face).  We ordered the Butterfish Blasters, the African Spider Roll, the Double Jeopardy, and the Caterpillar Roll.  To start, the Butterfish Blasters needed a blast of heat because those bitches were lukewarm to cold.  And almost flavorless.  More sad face.  The African Spider Roll was kind of weird.  Also why does it have to be African?  The Double Jeopardy was probably my favorite thing, but, brace yourself, I myself can make a better ahi tartare.  For real.  And the Caterpillar Roll was your average "good."  

Bummer!  It was my sister's birthday and I wished I had taken her elsewhere.  Sob.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
Fresh delicious sushi- try the Sexy Scallop roll- I dont usually eat scallops but my compadre ordered it and it was DELICIOUS. Green onion added a delicious flavor. Also tried the Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon a shrimp tempura roll with eel on top. It was good but not my favorite. The tempura tasted like it had been sitting for a while. The Albacore dream was delicious- it had spicy tuna with Albacore on top and a spicy mayo based sauce drizzled on it. The Hawaiian inspired roll (can't remember the name) had macadamia nuts sprinkled over a mango, tuna and a sweet pesto based sauce was tasty as well. The snow crab roll was chock full of fresh crab and ripe avocado and on the salty side but good!
I like this sushi. The green tea iced tea is made to order with green tea powder and is so delicious!!! Yum!
author: Piper W.

description: My favorite place to get sushi in San Francisco -- miss living right by it. I came here at least once or twice a week, and the service was always stellar. Great price point too!
author: K T.

description: This place would have gotten 5 stars if not for the terrible service I received from a waitress tonight. It was a group of 5 of my friends and I, we are all very considerate college students. She was immediately rude, even when simply taking our order. It was clear from the getgo that she was not pleased to be serving 5 young college students, and she showed it the to entire night. (Wouldn't you want to work harder to make us want to tip you graciously??) At the end of the night when we asked to split the bill, she reacted very harshly when we were trying to reason a good way to split it. They only allow two cards per bill, and one of us had cash while the rest had cards. We simply asked her to take the cash that one of us had and subtract the amount of that meal, so we could accurately figure out how to split the rest (tax and all) fairly among 4 of us while only using two cards. She REFUSED to do so. The whole ordeal lasted 5 times longer than it should have because of her incompetence to best serve us, the customer. It would have been one thing to politely say that she couldn't do that or didn't know how, but NO she sternly replied and was very very disrespectful. The sushi came out fairly quick and was very good, don't get me wrong. But not good enough to mask the blatant discrimination we felt.
author: Leah H.

description:
Two words: butterfish blasters!

They are the best sushi that I have ever had. I still remember them half a year later. Their amazingness is a constant reminder that I need to write a review. 

The seating here is a little crowded and the lighting a little dark for my taste, but the food makes up for any draw backs.
author: Kimberly F.

description: My favorite sushi in the city. Always fresh tasting, interesting flavors, and the owner & staff are all very nice and accomidating.
author: Candace D.

description: The sushi here is excellent and they have many unique rolls. It was crowded and loud when I went.
author: Brian M.

description:
Sushi here does not require soy sauce. 
The service is great too.
author: Hannah A.

description:
After almost an hour wait (I called in and they said 40 minutes and we ended up waiting for another 20), we were finally seated around 9:15 p.m. on a Friday night.  There were no Asians eating here, which got me a little worried.  Why is this place so crowded?  It's because of the Butterfish Blasters.  It was the best roll that I've ever had.  It comes in a family of 6 and has plenty of fish and sauce so you don't have to ruin it with soy sauce.  The Hot Lava had two pieces so it was hard to share with more than two people.  The lemon at the bottom was a nice touch and balanced out the crab and squid on top.  The sushi rolls are about the ingredients other than the rice.  I didn't feel too full from the rice but from the actual fish.  They go light on the cream sauces here too, which I appreciated.  The Monte Carlo also had butterfish but it was not as good and you can't really taste the brown rice.  The Sexy Scallop roll was ok but I would not recommend it.  The agedashi tofu was lightly battered and perfect. I'd come here just to eat the Butterfish Blasters and the tofu.  

Our waiter looked like someone from Moby Dick (probably b/c of his mustache) but he was nice and efficient.  Less is more type of guy.  They did charge me twice on one of the rolls and he promptly took it off.  Be sure to watch the bill here!  Four rolls plus the agedashi tofu with tip and tax was about $75.
author: Chris L.

description: Hidden gem in the neighborhood! Wow, I was pleasantly surprised by how good the sushi was at Sushi Bistro. They have a great selection of appetizers that are delicious and beautiful. We really enjoyed the drunken halibut and the hamachi jalapeño. We liked it so much that we ordered them twice. Their rolls are also very creative and tasty. My personal favorite was nemo found. We will definitely go back and make this a regular sushi spot for us.
author: Kyoko T.

description:
I love sushi and I was really excited about trying Sushi Bistro because I saw how popular it was. In addition to being really popular it looked like a good place for people my age. 

Anyways, came here with my two girlfriends and we ordered Finding Nemo, Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon, Five Wishes, and Volcano roll. I also got a house salad. Let me say this.... I was very dissatisfied with my salad. It was just a plain ol' salad. Not even the awesome miso dressing that most Japanese places use. Ok, enough about lame old salad, the rolls! The rolls were pricey, lemme say that first. My favorite of them all was the Volcano. It had scallops and crab. I didn't like the Five Wishes, the crab in it was all creamy and tasted really weird. Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon - unagi, avocado, and fried tempura was really fresh and yummy, but nothing amazing. I didn't try Finding Nemo, but it seemed like my friend liked it? Haha

I would prob. come again just for a bite, but it has not won me over just yet!
author: Jackie M.

description:
It's pretty hard to earn 5 stars from me, but this one is close. This is my favorite sushi place in SF for sure.

I've had a wide array of rolls from here and never been disappointed. My favorite is definitely the Hawaiian Breeze: Mango, avocado and fuji apple topped with tuna, macadamia nuts and drizzled with cilantro pesto.

My friends have been coming here for years, and it's one of their faves too. I'm a little shocked that some people haven't always had as good of an experience. When I've eaten there, the staff has always been fairly on top of things, though the atmosphere can be a little dark.

I challenge anyone to find a better sushi place in San Francisco!
author: Jeff D.

description:
Although the food was good (and some only care about the food), the service was poor.  They sat my daughter and I at a table for four.  A little while later a party of three came in and so the manager asked me if I would mind if they moved half the table.  I said yes, but quickly came to regret it as I was sitting on the same side as my daughter so I could better help her eat. Now we were sharing a single side which was tight.

I don't want to sound like it's all about quid pro quo but it was clearly inconveniencing us yet the manager never offered anything in return.  Worse, when the threesome on the other side of us left, I asked the manager if we could move to that table and he said no.  

In SF you have to treat your customers well because they have so many options.  It's disappointing because I've been looking for a good neighborhood sushi place. I will not be going back.
author: Dylan M.

description:
Yes, I am a fan indeed of this delightfully small feast. Minus one star because it simply wasn't enough!!! Burned a hole through my wallet, but the quality overrides the price, so I'm satisfied! Here' s the breakdown if you're wondering what will be worth it

Hot Love: There's a reason why this is in every review so don't think, just let it be the first thing you order. I'll leave you to come up with your own adjectives after you taste the awesome goodness.

Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon: I chose this personally, but I'd say be adventurous with the other rolls, this didn't wow me in uniqueness.

Nemo Found: My boyfriend didn't like it, but I on the other hand loved the lightness of this roll. The salmon was so fresh and flavorfull. Yet, this doesn't call for slightly bigger appetites, just to warn you if you're hungry.

African Spider: This would literally be the mother, widow, turantula, whatever super spider of all spider rolls. Again, the portion isn't humongous, but it packs a HUGE taste that your taste buds will go crazy over. 

12 piece sashimi: yes, all fresh, all slithering through your mouth that even a person without teeth can easily gnaw through it. yum.

There were two other dishes we had which I don't remember, but I'll add when I ask my friends lol. We shared, and with sushi I wish I didn't have to, but sometimes ya gotta give some to get some.... :)
author: Quinallison D.

description: I was really excited for the restaurant because of all the good reviews. When I got there, I got a table fairly quickly even though it was all packed which gave me even more of an expectations. I was also impressed with the menu because of the variety of sashimi and sushi. The sashimi was really fresh and tasty, I got toro, salmon and butterfish. It was the rolls that threw me off completely. I was excited to see that they had brown rice sushi and i ordered the First Crush, Hawaiian Breeze, Rock n Roll, and Omega 3 roll. Rock n Roll was the best out of the 4, which tasted alot like a Lion King roll. The worst roll was Hawaiian Breeze which was absolutely tasteless.
author: Jenny N.

description:
Michelin Guide Recommended? WTF?!?

Those are the words found on their website. If this is true, then I find Michelin Guide as reliable as Yelp reviews.

We found this place thanks to a rec from a friend that lives in the city. We were here with friends from the East Coast and we wanted to impress them with some great sushi. Getting here wasn't easy as parking was a nightmare in this sketchy neighborhood. Once in, we were treated to nice service in this small low lit restaurant.

The menu was interesting as it had a variety of fusion items. Disclaimer:  I'm usually not a fan of restaurants that use the term "fusion". We ordered a variety of rolls and I can honestly say none of them were impressive.  They were just ok. If anything the ones that were fried were over fried. It was just ok. I guess I was expecting more from a sushi place in the city.  Maybe this wasn't the best rec.

But there were two standouts:

Double Jeopardy $12.95 - salmon, albacore & avocado chopped tartar style, mixed with wasabi aioli, spicy garlic soy & served with shrimp chips. This was absolutely delicious.  I've never had this and I am definitely a fan. This was a big surprise and the highlight of our dinner. Think Guacamole :)

Sparkling Sake - I don't remember the name of the bottle (I should've) but it was refreshing. This was my first time having sparkling sake and it was a nice rec from our waitress.


It's a small but nice place and the service was great but the food was just ok. Unfortunately, we did not impress our friends and ended up taking them to Mizu in SJ for awesome sushi.  They raved about it! 
I guess we just should've done that from the beginning but we were expecting SF was going to blow them away.  Live and Learn.
author: Rav V.

description:
I really did not want to like Sushi Bistro. Japanese rolls with a Latino and Caribbean twist? (crickets)...
