But the food lives up to the hype. My favorite fusion roll was the New Legend. The shrimp tempura is cooked to order and crunchy. It's nicely contrasted by the seared albacore and very tasty spicy garlic sauce. I've ordered this roll on 2 visits and it tastes better every time!

Rolls I would not order again: rock & roll (baked spicy scallops atop a california roll) and spider roll (lightly battered and fried soft shell crab, avocado, cucumber, sprouts, and tobiko). The baked scallop topping on the rock & roll was really heavy with mayo and made the rest of the roll soggy. The soft shell crab in the spider roll had a mushy, unpleasant texture in the inner portions of the roll. 

For the purists, Sushi Bistro satisfies with its EXTREMELY FRESH sashimi. Wow, talk about good. REALLY GOOD. Melt in your mouth, decadent, sinful, creamy good. We've ordered the 12-piece sashimi platter and we eye each other nervously over how many pieces each person eats. The best fish is the Butter Fish, the white fish nestled in the middle of the sashimi platter. True to its name, it's like butter in your mouth.
author: Monelle A.

description:
If I order sushi in Japanese (like it is listed on the menu) and the waitress looks at me with a confused look on her face, I get worried.  

This sushi was mediocre and the service was atrocious.  It took me 5 times to get a refill on my tea and water (Pet peeve).  

I will admit that they have some cool things on their menu, but I am not one for that sort of thing.  Authentic Japanese food for me please!  If that's what you are looking for, please go to Oyaji on 32nd and Clement (it's actually run by Japanese).
author: Jessyca M.

description:
I can't believe I'm going to give a four star rating to a place that lists "Billie Jean" and "Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon" as the names of two sushi rolls. I want to hate places like this from the outset. But after two visits here, I'm clearly impressed with the service and the quality of the food. I would classify this place as the default sushi place one would go if they didn't want to think about somewhere new to try and just want something good and satisfying to eat. 

The clear standouts for me are the 12 piece sashimi platter and the "New legend Roll." I've been told that the best sushi should stand on its own, without any type of soy sauce, and that when you bite into it, it should simply "melt" with each subsequent bite. This is that type of sashimi. Added plus for being generous with the portion size. 

The spicy garlic sauce and scallions adds great flavor to the seared albacore in the New Legend roll. I also love the crunch that the shrimp tempura provides. 

Even the standard miso soup and side salad with Japanese dressing are good. They also provide very good (and complimentary) sweet pickled cucumbers to start the meal.
author: Lael A.

description:
This is my favorite sushi in San Francisco. The creativity of rolls and quality of fish is quite outstanding. Sometimes hard to get service, but only because it gets busy. 

Highly recommended for anyone willing to try new and interesting sushi combinations.
author: Mason B.

description: We were brought to Sushi Bistro while visiting in SF, and all I can say is WOW!  The creativity in this place is amazing, but more important, the flavors are great.
author: Steve G.

description:
Actually visited this place a few years ago and wasn't overly impressed but totally forgot I'd been here and came again a few months ago.  I'm mainly writing this review so that I don't forget a few years down the road and give it another shot! 

This place isn't bad, it just isn't that great.  The quality of the fish is just okay, there is a large selection though and prices are reasonable.
author: wingless g.

description: I don't go here often due to the location, but when I am in the Inner Richmond for dinner, Sushi Bistro doesn't let me down. It's a great date place as the menu has a ton of variety and fun combinations you don't find at every sushi restaurant. The staff is attentive and friendly. The best part, they don't rush you through your meal so you can enjoy the atmosphere and company you are with. It's worth the trek.
author: Desiree P.

description:
I wanted to go to Kabuto for my last supper before I get my wisdom teeth removed.  Unfortunately, Kabuto is closed on Mondays!

Their rolls are way too complicated and drenched with sauce and stuffed with too many things.  All I tasted was a mess of flavors.  TOO MUCH.

The yellowtail jalepeno is DEFINITELY not as good as Kabuto's.  

:( Next time I have a last supper it MUST be at Kabuto.
author: Vivian H.

description:
This was my first time in this little hood. And I likey.
Dark, sort of trendy atmosphere.
Lots of tea pouring.
The menu is very appealing. We tried lots of different kinds of sushi. 
The best were the unique rolls - the waterloo - I think - soooo good. Stinky salmon with crispy onion on top - also soooo good.
Afterwards, we had fried ice cream of the mango and green tea variety.
I have no regrets. It was tasty.
author: Andrew K.

description: If you're willing to spend a few extra dollars beyond what you would spend at other ol' sushi joints--the quality, the taste, the snazzy, modern atmosphere will leave you with a full stomach and no regrets. Parkings a biatch, jsut a heads up...but I guess that's San Francisco for ya. Hot Love, Caucasian Afro, Aloha 101 were pretty damn good. You'll need a few minutes longer than usual too to look at the menu, cause everything looks good and the names are pretty funny.
author: Anna K.

description:
I have now been to Sushi Bistro 3 times, and I can confidently say it is a gem! All the rolls and lettuce wraps are delicious. I highly recommend the summer and winter lettuce wraps. The fish is fresh, and the servings are large - well worth the price! I also had the pleasure of doing sake bombs during my visit last night, which made the Sushi taste even more delicious and the ambiance feel warmer.

The interior design is well thought out. And the main waters are very attractive men. A well-deserved 5 stars!
author: Mike S.

description:
nice decor and intimate atmosphere with unique and somewhat delicious rolls but small portions. Most dishes are around ~$14 each and are of appetizer size. Good and attentive service.

Hot Love
more like an appetizer for 2 that included some lobster/crab and was wrapped with avocado, lemon, and some spices. Good presentation and decently tasting.

butterfish blaster
6 pieces of crab and avocado wrapped in butterfish. Again it was a good appetizer but not really a main course. It was a little fishy but I liked it more than the hot love.

teriyaki beef with vegetables
The best bang for your buck dish that we got. Had pan fried beef with sauce drizzled on top of a bed of more than generous amounts of vegetables that would make a vegetarian happy. Plain and simple main course dish.

udon with tempura
sweet and msg broth with udon and pieces of tempura that became soggy in the soup. This dish was plain and simple; nothing too special or exciting.

As future yelper Cassie K stated, we could have probably gone to komes (http://www.yelp.com/biz/kome-sushi-buffet-daly-city#hrid:CcLNYARTX_iwc2YFVJntXA) with the amount of money we paid. I would have to agree with her.
author: Robert Y.

description: Went here a few nights ago. Cant stop thinking how horrible it was for me and all my family. - 1 one star for the oversized plates with ridiculously small portions. -1 star for being bland. -1 star for being overpriced. And last but not least -1  star for calling yourself BISTRO.  I'd rather go to "BISTRO" Jack and the box for better quality.
author: Ray R.

description: Super attentive and friendly service. Sushi was delicious! Came here on a Saturday night without a reservation, the place was packed. We got seated at the bar and it wasn't an issue. The atmosphere was laid back and trendy. Will definitely be back again!
author: Louise Z.

description: Absolutely amazing sushi. We are from out of town and were hoping to find a great sushi spot that wasn't inundated with tourists. We found an absolute gem. Great, modern atmosphere with San Francisco locals only. Fast service and awesome sushi!
author: Audrey T.

description: The African Spider and Red Devil rolls are delicious! For appetizer, the sesame chicken is very nice. Service is first rate too.
author: Johnny A.

description: I'm giving them 2 stars because they had the game showing at the bar, but the food ranges from mediocre to terrible. We ordered edamame as an appetizer, which took 15 minutes to get served. My bf and I stared at the microwave where our server placed a bowl of edamame to heat up in 45 seconds, he wondered off into the kitchen, passed us 3 times before the beep in the microwave reminded him of our order. Over salted and soggy edamame, fine all take it I'm starving. The rolls were ok, nothing outstanding, too many ingredients in some of them. The volcano roll was the worst, it was like eating spoonfuls of mayo with a hint of spice. I think 2 attempts at this place is enough, it hasn't left a good impression.
author: Katie L.

description:
I've been waiting to come back to this place so I could actually take pictures!  I love Sushi Bistro.  It's small and there's always a wait, but they make some great sushi creations.  I've been to both the Inner Richmond and Mission locations and they're roughly the same size/wait.  Their fish is really fresh though and I love their apps.   

Hot Love - baby lobster, avocado and crab meat rolled in snapper.  I don't usually like baked things, but this one was SO yummy.  One of my fave apps.

Tempura Appetizer - tempura fried veggies and shrimp.  Pretty standard.

7-flavor Albacore Salad - seared albacore with seven spices served with fried onions and green salad.  I LOOOOOOVE albacore so therefore I loved this app.  This could also serve as an entree

Monster In-Laws - chopped spicy albacore topped with yellowtail, jalapenos, and spicy ponzu sauce.  If you can't handle spicy, then make sure to take the jalapenos off.  Other than that, it was a mediocre roll.

African Spider - soft shell crab, tobiko, deep-fried cajun albacore and salmon topped with avocado, eel sauce, and spicy sauce.  Another mediocre roll.  I'm not a fan of tempura though.

M&L Forever - spicy tuna, crab meat, cajun flavored albacore, and grilled big eye tuna inside a crispy exterior drizzled with bonito sauce.  Hands down my favorite roll of the night.  We all agreed that this was the best roll that we ordered.

Red Devil -  butterfish tempura, aioli, avocado and cucumber topped with spicy tuna, scallions, and red serano ginger sauce.  Filled with brown rice, I'd have to say this was my 2nd favorite.
author: Jane N.

description:
I came here on a Saturday night at 9pm without reservations.  The wait wasn't terribly long... maybe 20 minutes tops.  The place was dimly lit and a little loud.

I had the toro, butterfish, and hamachi sashimi.  The slices of fish were larger than most sushi places and it was fresh.  The uni was good.  I also ordered the watermelon man, African spider, Hawaiian breeze, and the monster in law rolls.  Eachi individual piece was bite size and the rolls were a larger portion than other sushi restaurants.  I don't recommend the watermelon man.  It was bland and there was nothing special about it.  I really liked the African spider.  It was very flavorful.  The sauce really helped.  The Hawaiian breeze was good.  I found it very refreshing with the slices of fuji apple.  The monster in law was good too if you like spicy foods.  I think the rolls could have been better had they used more sauces to liven up the flavors.  I liked how they didn't load the rolls with tons of rice.

One thing I founds pretty interesting on the menu was that they offered brown rice rolls.  It's a healthier alternative.  Maybe I'll try it next time.

My only complaint was that parking was pretty difficult to find.  I was told that the area had a lot of apartments.  It took almost 30 minutes to find parking and that was 4 blocks away.  

Come here for some good sushi.  Bring good company to make it an even better experience.
author: Laina T.

description:
If you're looking for authentic Japanese fare, simple melt-in-your-mouth cuts of fish, and traditional rather than flashy rolls of sushi as I was, I would suggest looking elsewhere. If you are, however, in the mood for "Gringo Sushi" (creative Americanized rolls for made especially for white people) you've hit the jackpot with Sushi Bistro!
TRIED:
Monster-in-Law Roll- fail
First Crush- Fish and fruit? Meh.
Watermelon Man- not bad if you like the idea of mango and macadamia nuts w/your sushi  
Caucasian Afro- nice name, taste not bad. spicy tuna w/avocado in an "afro" of crispy potato vermicelli. 
Butterfish Blaster- this one was actually as good as it sounded, snow crab meat and avocado wrapped in butterfish torched with a garlic-soy. yum
Hot Love- baby lobster, avocado and crab meat rolled in  snapper, baked with spicy sweet sauce. good, although I preferred the butterfish blaster
author: Mahsa K.

description:
Sushi Bistro is by far my favorite sushi place in San Francisco.  Their rolls are amazing, and the most amazing of all: Hot Love roll. (lobster/crab cooked with eel sauce) .
Even my parents loved this place.  

I come back as much as I can.

The only caveat:  Make sure to make a reservation first, as this place is always packed.
author: Ardit B.

description:
What a huge disappointment.

After hearing and reading about so many great reviews, I was excited to dine here but walked away feeling ripped off. Maybe it was the hype?

The menu is chock full of creative rolls and never before seen sushi combinations. I ordered the crouching tiger hidden dragon, volcano roll and the miso glazed sea bass. The sea bass was flavorful and soft, probably the best dish but doesn't constitute a complete dinner. The rolls were unimpressive. The aioli on the volcano roll was confusing to my tastebuds (I generally expect baked salmon to come with a sweet mayonnaise-type of white sauce) so this little food adventure threw me off in a negative way. ~ See photos.
author: Jenny T.

description: My wife and I have been coming here for 5 years now and always look forward to coming back.  Always consistent and well priced for what you get.  Very fun and relaxed vibe.  Parking in the Richmond is always rough, so plan ahead for that.
author: Jaime R.

description:
One step into Sushi Bistro transformed my persona from nerdy to cool instantly. The ambiance definitely earns a star-- very clean and classy.

Our waiter (Vince?) was very attentive, constantly checking up on us and filling our waters. 

Reading the menu will tickle you pink with titles like "hot love", "caucasian afro", and "spicy girl" ( that's me!). I had heard so much about the butterfish and was tempted to get the butterfish blasters, but decided to get the 10 piece sushi/sashimi combination. This included yellowtail, salmon, albacore, shrimp, butterfish, tobiko, tamago, albacore tataki, halibut & tuna for $20.  I liked being able to try a little bit of everything AND it came with a salad and miso soup. Similar to other reviews, I found the food very fresh and worth the money. I also tried some of their tempura which was battered to golden perfection. 

I'll be back for those butterfish blasters!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
This place is good, not great. I've only visited this place once, which is weird because I live in the neighborhood & am in love with sushi, but I guess it just didn't scream out "amazing" to me. Perhaps it's because there are many sushi places like it - with their signature rolls & their tad bit overpriced nigiri/sashimi - I guess it's what you can expect in SF. 

With that said, I got the Albacore Dream roll, which was pleasant. & my friend got one of the rolls with baked salmon on top - it was really good. They have a nice selection of original rolls. They also serve complimentary miso soup & salad which is always a plus. I like the place - it has a warm, cozy feel to it. I would like to go back, when I have the money, to try their nigiri & perhaps more of their rolls.
author: Junel S.

description: My daughter let me in on this secret. I had the roll with scallops and crab and veggie potstickers and WOW! So good! The wait staff is very friendly but not too friendly. I wish they were open for lunch
author: Kendra J.

description: Excellent sushi, way better and more innovative compared to New York. Everything is fresh and delicious and they have an excellent selection of sake. Highly recommend.
author: Max Z.

description:
It's been 4 years.  Yes.  4 years since I last came here.  It's changed locations, waitstaff, decor, etc.  But it's still kind of suck.  Yeah.  It pains me to use such poor English but there's no better way to describe it than suck.  

I got some nigiri: Amaebi, uni, hamachi-toro and hotate-gai.

It was just after the restaurant opened for evening service.  The interior of the restaurant was painted all black and had that sexy-in-a-bad-way vibe.  The bright sun outside overpowered the subtle mood lighting inside and made me feel like I was a salary man in Tokyo, sneaking in a snack at a panty shack before heading home.  If there was a dancer on the bar top, it would have completed the mental image.  I was a bit ashamed to be eating there.  Alone.  

My nigiri arrived in 3 parts.  The first was the hotate-gai.  Not bad.  But not much flavor either.  It's a plus when the nigiri does not smell like over-ripe seafood.  But it's a minus when there is no flavor at all.  I could have been eating vegetarian agar atop rice.

Second came uni and hamachi-toro.  The hamachi-toro had some knife work on top and a little squiggle of extra fish.  But the fish was not tender.  It was not melting.  I had to use both hands to tug apart the slice of fish as I bit into it.  The power of chopstick kung fu alone was not enough.  Something akin to gristle prevented my teeth from cleaning separating the two bites.  I was left with have a slice of fish hanging out of my mouth.  The uni was also not flavorful.  The dim lighting prevented me from admiring the color and texture of the uni.  I attempted to ascertain the freshness by squinting at it while holding it so the light from outside fluttered in.  When I ate it, there was no burst of intrigue.  I cannot say what it was.  Except it was suck.

Last, the amaebi.  I appreciate that they gave me three instead of the usual two due to the small size of the shrimp/prawns.  But the heads were not battered, and the whole thing was dowsed in this sharp brown sauce that overpowered everything.  It was too strong, too salty, too sour, and it got everywhere.  

I gave up on that sushi meal.  It was disappointing.  The whole experience was unusual and surreal.  Similar to karaoke where you think you're going to sing Frank Sinatra but instead you get something from Tu-Pac.
author: Christina C.

description:
The sushi roll selection was pretty cool; lots of interesting combinations. I especially like the fact that they offered brown rice sushi rolls.

Ordered the First Crush (brown rice), Five Wishes, butter fish thing, Hawaiin Breeze, and one other shrimp tempura one. I also ordered a miso soup that never came, so I cancelled it midway through the meal.

My favorite of the bunch was the butter fish. Both Five wishes and butter fish contained no rice in the roll, making for protein-rich bites. 

Complaints: 
- The snow crab described in the menu was HEAVILY mixed with an egregious amount of mayo, giving it that ultra creamy texture. I personally did not like this Americanized kami. 
- Brown rice didn't look or taste like brown rice.
- Tuna was not fresh
- The overall taste of the rolls didn't come together very well; just one thing overpowered another.
- Fuji apples are always awesome, but I was a bit...ambivalent on how it played out in a sushi roll. The sweetness offered an overbearing flavor so that the final impression is how sweet the sushi roll was, and you could hardly taste much else. It adds a nice crunch though.

Positives:
- Simple and elegant presentation.
- Rolls not overpadded with rice.
- Decent number of rolls and size for the price. Not unreasonable.

Meh experience overall. I probably would not return simply because there are innumerably better sushi experiences elsewhere.
author: Stephanie L.

description: The sushi isn't half bad, I usually come here for your run of the mill bento box and sake (which is reasonably priced). The restaurant had a nice ambiance and the staff is courteous.  I would recommend it for a group.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Over rated. 
Charges for tea. 
Sushi wasnt good.
Automatic gratuity for party of 5

Will not come back even though I live a block away from this place.  I'm feeling sick as I write this review
author: Benjamin L.

description:
Grade A sushi and the best version of a Spider Roll (African Spider) I've ever had.  A great personal find since they have good vegetarian rolls for my fish-hating girlfriend.  They are also able to replace seaweed with soy paper for any roll for those who find that part of sushi offensive.  Finally a sushi place where I can have my fish and feed my gf too.

Service is great.  Food is fast but not rushed.  Very good selection of beers on tap.
author: Chris H.

description: This place is delish!!! My husband and I randomly stumbled upon this place a few months ago as we were searching for a new sushi spot in the neighborhood that had tvs to watch the Warriors game.  We sat at the bar and it was great!  Then, last week, we went back.  The rolls are amazing and fresh and there are so many other options in the event that you aren't craving sushi.  The udon soups are awesome (i've tried the chicken and the shrimp tempura).  The butterfish blasters are good but a bit pricey... you get 6 pieces.  My husband literally CRAVES the grilled squid... the first time we were there, he actually ordered two... for himself!! haha.  Anyways, I would definitely recommend Sushi Bistro to those looking for a cute, fun sushi hotspot in the inner richmond district.  It's a good date night spot too! We will definitely be back soon!
author: Kelly M.

description:
Sushi here is really not that great. I was quite disappointed actually after reading such good reviews.

Tried 3 of the most popular items on the menu: omega-3, Monster in Law and butter blasters. I was disappointed with all 3 items.....none of them tasted particularly good/I would not order these rolls again or recommend them to anyone. What's so special about them..? They weren't even on the 'good' side. 

However, the sashimi here is VERY fresh! Props for that.
author: Sophia L.

description: Ate here last night for my belated bday dinner with a couple of my friends. Walked in and luckily there was no wait, so we were able to grab a table right away. We ordered a pitcher of beer and a bottle of sake to start. The sake was really hot so I would either let it cool down first or just pour it into your beer before you drink it. For food, we ordered the Poke salad, the Hot Love, a scallop roll, the African Spider roll, and one more roll that I forgot the name of. The poke salad was super good!! The poke tasted really fresh and there were chunks of it in the salad. I can probably eat one whole salad to myself...yum! The Hot Love was pretty good as well but was kind of hard to split these 2 round pieces between the 4 of us, since the inside was mushy. All the rolls were also really good but I definetely enjoyed the scallop roll and the African Spider roll more. Service was great here as well! Can't wait to try their other items on the menu next time I come here! =)
author: Mary C.

description: Very delicious sushi restaurant! Highly recommend paying this restaurant a visit! Love the tempura and crunchy sushi as well as the sexy scallops. Yummy!!! Must try this place!
author: Shaun E.

description:
It was a friday night and the stomach rumblings were heard loud and clear. The choice was between Sushi Bistro and Tekka. We made the wrong decision. Sushi Bistro -gimmicky at best, nausea inducing at worst.

Me and a friend shared three rolls, the butterfish blasters, the billie jean, and the m&l. My first thought when looking on the menu was oh look a sushi roll with baby lobster AND salmon sashimi? DONE. The little bits of lobster turned out drier and chewier than imagined, and the salmon - less flavor than the pieces from a sushi buffet. I can't even remember the M&L roll, the only thing I can recall is something relatively dry being inside of it.

The best roll was the butterfish blasters. With a name like that what can go wrong? Except after the meal me and my friend were both feeling the rumblings in the stomach... but not in the "feed me i'm hungry" situation, it was more of a, "watch out food may be excavating through the entrance" sort of deal. Pretty unpleasant .. should've went to tekka's.
author: Colin H.

description:
I came here on my birthday.

It was my first time here, and i thought it was little out of the way in some nice neighborhood. After arriving, it quickly came to me that this is the local neighborhood Japanese food fix hotspot.

The fish quality is super duper fresh. I had my doubt walking to our seats, and looking at the menu mainly because they advertise a lot of ROLLS. Most know Japanese restaurants who does rolls are usually fake or lower end restaurants.


With every order arriving at our table, Sushi Bistro quickly deleted my questions about this place. The fish collar is excellent. yellowtail is awesome. 

TORO just melts. 

A little bit pricey but it is in SF, and it is a swank Japanese sushi bistro. 




I would definitely go back to this place.
author: kent c.

description:
Guess who has a new favorite SF sushi restaurant?! MEEE, MEEE!

We came for my bf's best friend's birthday. What a pleasant little surprise hidden in the inner richmond. Unfortunately, it's not a sushi restaurant I could come back to once a week. (Because once a week is how often I would prefer to eat sushi :] but anyway...) Rolls range from about $8 - $14. We were a group of 6 (5 adults, 1 child) and we couldn't decide on what to order for the life of us. Soo, this is how our ordering went:

Waiter: what would you like?
Us: What are your favorite 3 rolls?
Waiter: Well, the [blahblah-insert names]
Us: Can you just order us 10 of your best rolls?
Waiter: Sure, anything you guys don't eat?
Us: No california rolls!
Waiter: Ok, any allergies?
Us: Nope.
Waiter: Do you like spicy food?
Us: Sure!
Waiter: Okay, I got it.

Well let me tell you that was the start of a good good night! As soon as I had my first bite I started writing down what we ordered just so I could yelp about each dish. Now I'm matching the names I wrote down with the description on their website. Yes, I want you to know exactly how wonderful my meal was. Our order came out:

1 - Butterfish Blasters ($13.95): These were uuuh-mazing! One of my favorites of the night. It is crab meat and avocado wrapped with butterfish. Made a unique and tasty combination that had great flavor and texture!

2 - Original ML ($11.50): Very good and not even on the menu!! (That's how dope our waiter was) This one had baked baby lobster inside- yum!

3 - Dave's Legacy (11.75): Again, not on the menu. This one was another one of my favorites. It had Japanese squash inside.

4 - Spicy Crunchy (9.25): Be careful with this one because it comes out piping hot! I was overly excited by how good everything was that I stuck the whole piece in my mouth. BIg mistake - it was so hot I couldn't thoroughly enjoy it. I think if it would have let it cool I would have liked it better.

5 -Hamache Kama (9.50): had yellowtail inside of it.

6 - Monster in Laws (11.75) This one had some albacore, yellowtail, and even jalapeno in it. 

7 - C-2 (11.95): Another favorite of mine! This one had stripped tempura on top of the roll and eel sauce dripped on top, too!

8 - Watermelon man (8.95): It looked like a watermelon piece, how cute! Also, had some mango and macadamia nuts inside it!

9 - Aloha 101 (9.95) - A really original roll. Very fresh tasting and it came with a garlic dipping sauce.

10 - Rock n Roll (7.95) - Not your usual Unagi and avocado rock n roll. This one had baked scallops on top of california roll. I've had this roll better at other restaurants, probably wouldn't order it again. If you like dynamite, this is the roll for you.

11 - African spider (12.50) - The best that a spider roll will ever get! You can get a spider roll anywhere, but this one's on crack and I'm addicted!!!

By the way, did I mention the complimentary cucumber salad prior to dinner? So our grand total was $130 (gratuity wasn't included). Is there any reason not to love Sushi Bistro?!
author: Danielle G.

description:
This place was not bad, I know I've had better sushi though. I tried a few of their speciality rolls but wasn't too impressed, felt as though it needed more to it. The environment was nice though and located in an OK area, not too hard to find.  The waiters/ waitress were very friendly though and service was pretty speedy. Overall I rates it due to the food, if it had more specialty rolls that wowed me I would have rated it higher. Maybe I'll try it another time to give it more of a chance.

Sushi as good as some tushi!
author: Fabian S.

description: It was very good, but I think I need to do a do over because I didn't really order real sushi. Just rolls and tempura. I ordered two rolls, a tempura side platter, and a beer. The cool part is that they have a vegetarian options that are really refreshing. The servers were great and they helped us decide on what to order, unfortunately finding parking in the neighborhood is difficult.
author: Theresa D.

description: I like it and Sushi Dojo on Hayes. It's not Japanese, Chinese owned I believed, offering Americanized kind of sushi rolls. I like Butterfish appetizer and Hamachi Jalapeno Sea Salt carpaccio plus other kinds (they have so many). I love how generous they are with the fish slices. Regular customer, but parking here can be a B####.
author: Clemencia S.

description:
The sushi is outstanding.  The menu offers you with a big variety of options... and I must say the baked sushi is a winner.
Service is excellent.

The place is nicely decorated, slightly dark and nice for groups. The music is always great.
author: Monique T.

description:
An old buddy of mine and I decided to give this place a go.  We ordered a few rolls -- Waikiki, Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon, Aloha 101 -- and also ordered the ahi tower and two pieces of yellow tail sashimi.  I was definitely impressed with the signature rolls, they were delicious.  The Aloha 101 was probably my least favorite of the three rolls but the fresh ahi tuna that was in it was not to be ignored.  The cuts of sashimi were quite large, much to my pleasant surprise.  Not only were the portions generous, but the quality and freshness of the fish was very good.

If you don't mind sitting in a semi-dark room with music playing just a few decibels below that of a night club and having the adjacent parties within elbow's length of you, then you must try the sushi and sashimi here.
author: Erich D.

description:
This place has a modern look along with their modern twist of sushi on the menu with fun names like "nemo found, spicy girl, and drunken halibut." It gets busy on weekend nights so be prepared to wait or reservations are highly suggested. Overall great food and ambiance with friendly service.

- Hamachi w/ Jalapeños: exactly what the name says, fresh but no spice to the jalapenos, but that can be substituted with wasabi
- Red Snapper Sashimi: not sure how i feel about it coming with so much skin, but it was good
- Magic Mushrooms: a bit too fried, sauce was overpowering, not bad though
- Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon Roll: very good and tasty, unagi was really good along with the tempura and sauce
author: Linda C.

description:
Rock and Roll-DELICIOUS

I am always the happiest camper when I leave this place.

Ocean trout, strawberry Creme Brulee (omg fresh strawberries) 
Delightful-amazing place
author: farah b.

description: If you're craving sushi at reasonable prices, this place always hits that spot. MUST MUST go! And it has a really nice ambience too!
author: Reema M.

description:
This is a cute sorta trendy sushi place in the inner richmond. The price is a bit more than I'd like to pay for sushi but it seems pretty typical for an SF sushi place. I really like that they offer brown rice sushi along with a rice paper instead of seaweed option.

I highly recommend the brown rice for at least one of your rolls. I'm indifferent about the rice paper though.

Sashimi is fresh and they had some really unique and tasty specialty rolls as well as very well-done usual rolls (rainbow, gragon roll etc)

Right across the street is a jankier and much cheaper sushi. I would go there for a quick sushi bite and save Sushi Bistro for an occasion.
author: An-Nhien L.

description:
Sushi Bistro is definitely worth a try, but I'm hardly impressed. The food, while tasty, is overpriced (the average price for a roll being at least 12-13 dollars). The swanky, trendy-bistro-in-the-Marina feel gets a little tired, especially when you're in the Inner Richmond and just want a chill dinner with a friend to catch up and are trying to converse over the loud club music blaring in your ears. Also, there is always, always a wait so it's recommended that you drop a friend off to put your name on the list while you circle (for days) looking for parking.

If you do find yourself in this part of the city and have a hankering for a modern, fusion take on sushi, though, I do recommend these rolls: 

- Five Wishes: (tuna, salmon, hamachi, albacore) and avocado wrapped around a creamy snow crab mixture. It's rice-less and because it is, every piece is soft and creamy and sort of just melts into your mouth.)
- Rock and Roll: Essentially a California roll baked/topped with a creamy scallop mixture. The scallops are tender, the sauce has a delicious, tasty kick to it, and at only $7.50 (possibly their cheapest roll), this warm delicious roll is a winner.
- The New Legend: Your standard shrimp tempura roll that's dressed up a little prettier and topped with seared albacore. Solid, reliable, delicious.
- The C2: Pretty much the same as the New Legend, another reliable roll with familiar components that people always generally like in fancy rolls (lobster, tempura, eel sauce). 

There's also brown rice rolls, a vegetarian section, and a unique list of appetizers that is interesting to try (with names like "Magic Mushroom" and "Butterfish Blasters" - how can you resist?). 

So,it's good, but there's just that certain je ne sais quoi that's lacking. I've yet to try anything really outstanding enough to garner the sometimes ridiculous wait and worth the nightmarish attempt to find parking (I know, not necessarily the restaurant's fault, but it is what it is and it does matter sometimes). They do get points for innovation/an attempt at fusion cuisine. While fusion is usually a hit or miss, I find that SB falls somewhere in between that. 

Decent, but not amazing. Almost, just almost, Sushi Bistro.

Oh, side note: one of the waiters/servers here is super cute - he's tall and Asian (Chinese, I believe). Ladies (and gentlemen), you'll know who I'm talking about. ;)
author: Betty W.

description:
I really liked this place, all i wanted was a sushi place at 9:30 at night, and unlike many other places that close at 10, this one closes at 10:30; i got my sushi craving in for the night. This place is pretty fancy, and has a tv that played actual important information. I watched the counting of the votes, pretty exciting stuff as i was enjoying my food. 
I had the African Spider, I don't think I've ever tried that mix before, but it was delish! 
I'm definitely coming back to try the rest of the menu!
author: Mimi H.

description:
Been wanting to try this place even before I passed by here everyday on the way to class. Over 1000 reviews and 4 stars means they're doing something right. Right?

I want to start off by saying that sushi bistro is definitely more fusion and catered to american tastes. Most sushi places (that I go to anyway) are typically fusion and not authentic japanese...but this place was really Americanized. Small restaurant with dim lighting for dinner. We came at about 6:30pm and there wasn't a wait for 2 at the bar, but it was basically a full house. 

The waitstaff is super friendly and attentive. They clean and swipe up all your dishes the minute you're done! I'm not sure I really like that, but hey! Anyway, on to the food...Maybe we ordered the wrong things, but our food was just ok. I don't think I'd come here if I was craving sushi. 

We had the sexy scallop roll which consisted of spicy scallops atop some sort of fish and avocado roll wrapped in soy paper. If I remember correctly it was salmon and white tuna or something? I love spicy scallops and it's sad to say that they were very fishy :-(. We also got the crouching tiger roll which had shrimp tempura and unagi which was the better of the two, but also not very memorable. The poke tuna salad was mediocre with strange chunks of tuna. (think chain restaurant poke salads) I appreciated the generous amounts of avocado though. I think the best part of our meal was the agedashi tofu and sake. Large pieces of nice soft tofu in a light sauce and fish flakes. Not sure what the sake was but we requested something "light, girly and perhaps fruity" and whatever the waiter got us was pretty good. Our total came out to be about $60 for 2, I guess that's sushi though.
author: Stine H.

description:
When I looked at the menu, I was instantly in heaven.  I wanted to try EVERYTHING.  EVERYTHING sounded melt-in-your-mouth good.  Everything was different from the typical menu.  Granted, the prices were a little high, I wanted this new experience.

Anyway, 3 stars.  My boyfriend loved many of the dishes, but honestly, nothing made my mouth really sing.  Granted, nothing was bad, but for the price I wish we had gone to Ibisu.  Anyway, there was this one dish called Hot Love or something like that which was really really heavy.  The first bite was warm and buttery, but by the second bite, I felt sick.  Perhaps that's my fault for eating it, but I felt a little sick for the rest of the night and I couldn't enjoy the rest of the food.  I feel like there needed to be a balance.  Even a heavy roll like a Lion King is buttery but more balanced.
author: Aly A.

description:
I came here a few times before, but I didn't get enough variety until recently. I can finally justify a review!

I ordered the Billy Jean roll (with no cucumber). It's a roll with baby lobster and avocado inside, with salmon on the outside. All of the ingredients were so fresh! I love raw fish, but rolls with ONLY raw fish can be hit-or-miss based on quality. This roll definitely MORE than satisfied and I would get it again.

My friends got the African Spider roll, which was delicious but a bit too fried for my taste. The spicy crunchy roll was actually not your typical crunchy roll. It's not just a roll with tempura flakes on top, but the entire roll is fried!

Appetizers...
-Tempura: pretty good, but it was overall your standard tempura plate
-Mushroom special: AMAZING! The mushrooms come wrapped in something fried, with some sauce on top. The fried part and the sauce were flavorful, but not enough to take away from the mushroom flavor. My friend hates mushrooms and she still loved this dish!
-Gyoza: Pretty good -- not too crispy, which I rather enjoyed. I don't like things that are too fried.

Service was great! They were really nice about allowing us to bring our own cake for our friend's birthday.

Overall, it's not your "classic" sushi restaurant. Don't go here if you're looking for 100% traditional/authentic. It's more of a trendy-style, experimental, great place to gather with friends type sushi restaurant, which makes it rather fun!

Parking was TERRIBLE (Friday night, after all)...be warned.
author: Angela K.

description:
Sushi Bistro you are a beast! 

Get the butterfish roll, probably the most unique and delicious sushi I've ever had. Overall, pretty much ALL of their sushi they create is truly unique and consist of flavors you can't help but get more! Go to sushi bistro! :)
author: Megan D.

description:
Doesn't live up to the hype. Sushi is not quite authentic either.

The place is very clean and has a vibe like you're at a hip LA restaurant.
The rolls are unique (we had one with mango salsa), but they were SMALL and very expensive. I would've thought the sushi would be fantastic, but everything we ordered was just ok.

I don't get it. Will not be going back.
author: Cindy C.

description:
I wanted to take my friend here for dinner for her birthday since we're huge fans of sushi. I had heard about it before but never got a chance to try it out. I miraculous found parking right away and then we got seated by the bar right as well as soon as we walked in.

The waiters were attentive and helpful, which is always a plus.

We ordered:
  - 49er Roll: not of fan of having lemon on of my salmon, but the salmon was good   
  - Crouching Tiger Roll: shrimp tempura, avocado, AND unagi?! WINNER!
  - M&L Forever: It consists of spicy tuna, crab meat, cajun flavored albacore,   
    avocado, and grilled big eye tuna. Different from other rolls and very delicious.

The rolls are definitely different than other places I've been to since it's more fusion than traditional Japanese. If you're into that, it's something to check out.
author: Kathy L.

description: Sadly, this place is not worth the price. Food was just OK. 50% good, 50% not...I give it to them for unique options. I was surprised with their specials and rolls, many options that you don't normally see on sushi menus. For sure the quantity (portion size) is there! I have never had sashimi so large...but sadly the quality was mediocre.
author: Jason P.

description:
Ate here on a recent road trip from Seattle, WA. One thing about this place is that it is VERY popular and you have to get a reservation or your wait will be very long. People were waiting outside because the place was small to accommodate a lot of customers.

We ordered a bottle of Utatane cold sake for $33 which came out to be about 3 shots per person for our party of 4 people. It tasted ok but I'm not a fan of sake so this is just my opinion. For food we had the Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon $10.95 (5*), Hawaiian Breeze $11.95(3.5*), Magic Mushrooms $8.95 (4*), The New Legend $12.75 (5*), Omega-3 $9.75 (3.5*), Seaweed Salad $4.50 (4*). All were really good and wish we would have ordered more but the bill was already gettin' high. Plus we were pretty full. 

I can see how this place got good reviews and is very popular. Definitely a top 10 in the best sushi I've ever eaten!
author: Annie F.

description: Really good sushi place. I don't remember the exact rolls I ordered because it was a few weeks ago, but they were all pretty intricate from what I remember. The sushi is a bit pricier than most places, but its a pretty nice place. Give this place a try.
author: Nikita K.

description: So far, my favorite sushi in the city. Every single thing I've tried is so fresh and yummy. Side note: impossible to park
author: Tatum T.

description:
Yes, it is geared towards the Americanized sushi palate, but that doesn't mean this place isn't good. The butterfish blasters were tasty, albeit pricey.  They have a pretty big selection of rolls and even a special brown rice section. Perfect for date-night or a night out with friends. It does get a bit packed and crowded. I found that the one in the Mission is smaller. Regardless, I would say seating time is pretty quick. Not a place for those that like more traditional, simple sushi.

JJ
author: Josselin A.

description:
Husband and I were looking for a yummy sushi place that was still open at 8:30pm during the week and we came across Sushi Bistro - and it was great!

Everything we ordered was delicious, from the most basic avocado veggie roll to the spider roll and their specialty C-2 which I could eat every day of my life. All the fish was firm and fresh, the rolls were decent sized portions and the service was attentive... not much more I could have asked for. 

The tables on either side of us both ordered the agedashi tofu and it looked amazing so next time I'm back at Sushi Bistro, that will definitely be on the top of my list of items to order (along with the C-2 roll, seriously, it's delicious).
author: Littany W.

description:
Not your mom n pop sushi house. More your Americanized, dark and trendy date spot, which means you won't get sake on the house or off-the-menu specials, but you can request brown rice with any roll (major clutch!) while watching football on the bigscreen TV. It was bustlin on a Tuesday at 8:30pm, so call ahead.

FOOD: [Fresh, creative, reasonably priced big rolls with lots of fish]
I dig they have a veggie roll menu section that's actually creative... sun-dried tomatoes, shitake mushrooms, etc. My friend had the asparacado roll that came with this bomb garlic onion aioli we ended up dipping everything into. 

The menu itself is pretty creative--combinations you generally wouldn't see: albacore/yellowtail (monster-in-laws), lobster/salmon (billie jean), spicy scallop/white tuna (sexy scallop--which I had. Delicious, but get it without Sriracha). I like that they still have classic rolls too and that the sushi comes rolled in different ways: no rice, brown rice, nori, soy paper, etc.

SERVICE/AMBIANCE: [Too rushed, pretty noisy]
The tables could be further apart, it's pretty noisy, and I felt really rushed by the service. They cleaned our plates right as we were finishing, gave us the bill when we didn't ask/hardly waited for it, and cleaned our edamame dish when there were at least 3 edamame left (hey, I wanted them!) It wasn't like there were people waiting for the tables either. Though rushed overall, my roll came out a good 5 minutes after my friend's (no bueno).
author: Magnolia E.

description:
Thank you Sushi Bistro for making this vegetarian girl really excited about sushi! They have some really creative veggie rolls, and I was so excited to see that they make rolls with brown rice too. However, my Tuscan roll was riceless- sundried tomato, avocado, fried, a little kick of spice and super awesome dipping sauce. Hey, at least I know brown rice will be there for me if I need it. I also had the shitake roll, which was probably healthier but once again I was foiled by the dip that came with it. Yum yum yum! I loved the cucumber salad and the edamame. It was so fresh and the edamame was warm!! I was over the moon about the edamame alone. I know it doesn't seem like a big deal, but too many places seem to serve that cold, not fresh looking stuff. 

I can't wait to go back here and try every other vegetarian thing on the  menu- udon soup, agedashi tofu, more rolls, tempura, gyozas, etc. 

Love that this place is in the Richmond :)
author: Libbi K.

description: Sushi nigiri was okay but customer service was bad. And inside 5wishes roll, crab was frozen and udon didn't taste like udon.  Tempura was shit too. I don't know why people say this place is good.
author: Kimberly K.

description:
Billie Jean Roll - Bland. Even eating everything separately did not bring flavor to each ingredient. It was almost completely tasteless.

Omega-3 Roll - Flavorful! Lots of flavors in it and you could taste each of the ingredients forming wonderful, spicy dances in your mouth!

Ahi Tuna Poke Special - Probably one of the best salads I've ever had. The poke was chilled, but didn't taste frozen. Those potato shoestring things were great and the greens were not smothered in the dressing. Very good overall, price was a little steep.

3.5 rounded to 4. I would like to try other things from here as well.
author: Timothy L.

description:
I will preface by saying I'm not a fan of raw fish. I'm not a fan of anything raw. However, my review is based off the California hand roll and chicken teriyaki / tempura dish I ordered. I have to say, their food is excellent. The California hand roll was delicious and quite affordable. It was a little hard to eat because I refused to use my hands because I'm a germaphobe, but that's my fault. Additionally, the chicken teriyaki was seasoned well and came with a great teriyaki dressing. The tempura was fresh out of the fryer and made eating vegetables enjoyable. I finished off the night with a mango mochi ball. Was similar to the ones you'd find in the stores, so maybe next time we'll try the crème brulee.

Tables are a little close together and I didn't receive a water refill, but those are minor things. The staff was otherwise attentive and honored our reservations, which I recommend making. We'll be coming back again.

My tummy gives Sushi Bistro...5 Stars!
author: Allan L.

description:
I came here on a late Saturday night with a group of 6. Each one of us ordered 2 dishes each and shared.
Seemed like a crazy night, but service was still on point.
I had the M&L and the C-2 rolls, really fresh fish and soft rice texture.
Ahi Tuna special was good, sashimi/guacamole style served with crab chips.
Another favorite was the Y.T Jalapeno, thin slices of yellowtail with a kick of sliced jalapeno on top.
Some other dishes that were just not my style, and very mayo-ee; five wishes & african spider. It was just too overwhelming.
All in all, definitely a good experience with fresh fish. 
Average roll is about $12/per speciality roll.
author: DayDay D.

description:
I finally dined here on a whim which was lucky because they were able to seat us right before hella people started lining up!

Sushi Bistro lacks a star because it was so completely loud inside I could hardly hear what my date was saying although I thoroughly enjoyed the rolls we ate.  We had the albacore-spicy tuna (the roll had a clever name but I can't seem to remember) and the 49er roll which was buttery salmon over an avocado sushi with a lemon slice.  Dear Lord, I dreamt about that roll all night.  BUT they were out of the red snapper nigiri.  They had sold out of their specials.

The waiters were very attentive, quick and nice.  We almost got served twice the water and twice the condiments by 4 different servers.  It was quite hilarious.  Either they wanted to turn the table over fast, or they are simply great at their jobs!
author: Susan C.

description:
I went on Yelp to find a Japanese restaurant that had specialty rolls, since most Japanese restaurants don't... so after hours (okay more like minutes) of searching, I came across Sushi Bistro and added this restaurant onto my favorites folder labeled "places to eat." I took a look at their website and was pleased to see what a wide selection of sushi they had. Everything sounded so delicious!

So obviously I made a trip down to Sushi Bistro. I was impressed with the place. I liked the dimly lit lighting, big screen TVs, chill reggae music, ambient atmosphere and most of all the fact that they seated us by the window (that's always a plus for me). The place just looked so chic, so I expected the food to also be as cool. Well I suppose I was pleased with my roll to an extent. I ordered the Sashimi Spirit, which was about $11 for ONLY 6 pieces? Okay, the roll was delicious, but for $11? Come on! I know another place where I can get 8 fat pieces for $10...! But it's okay. I'm very forgiving about things like this. I wanted to get another roll, but I didn't want to throw down another double digit figure for just a lousy six pieces so my friend let me have some of the chicken udon they were having. Ehh, the udon was alright, pretty plain, nothing special. 

I wouldn't mind coming here again just to try the other goodies on their menu, but I'll just have to remember about their sushi portions and prices.
author: Ally C.

description:
Okay...so yes, now I know I can easily spend over $100 on sushi and just not give a hoot...
Budget-shmudget...

If you sit me at the Sushi Bar I'm blinded by the deliciousness of every roll that comes to me... everyone fades away since my back is to them and I'm in "the sushi zone".

Sushi Bistro - you are MY "First (Sushi Restaurant) Crush"
author: Katy A.

description: Okay tried this place as there are so many reviews. The rolls are okay and fish is okay.
author: P C.

description:
I need to agree with Jenny K. What exactly is the hype about this place?? It's overpriced and the rolls all taste the same. Actually, everything with a bit of sashimi in it tasted the same to me. 

The place is hip and really clean inside. It had a nice ambiance and the service was great. As for the food and the quality of the food... I don't konw why everyone loves it so much. The rolls and appetizers are not authentic. Authentic Japanese sushi doesn't need a bunch of garnish to spice up their rolls. White rice with a piece of raw fish on the top? DONE. 

I don't have much to say about our rolls...

We each paid $25 for some things that surely filled out bellies up, but my hypothalamus was telling me I was not satiated by this meal.
author: Rosanne L.

description:
Why do we go out to eat? 1) Food 2) Ambiance 3) Service. Lets see how Sushi Bistro gets its score. 
The Food: Consistently excellent fish and everything else for that matter. Unique seasonal specials, excellent presentations, a fantastic selection of creative rolls and appetizers to satisfy the most demanding of connoisseurs. Good selection of beers and sake.
The Ambiance: Well thought out decor with great music that complements the modern feel of this restaurant. It feels comfortable for anything from a night out with friends, a date night or a solo mission for great food at the bar. Theres a reason this restaurant is popular.
The Service: This place has a huge following so that means that there are a lot of people that come here. Yet the staff gets everyone in and seated quickly without rushing the diners out. Food and drinks come out perfectly paced. The staff is knowledgeable about the food and is always on point.
End result? If you want great food in a comfortable restaurant then this has to be one of the places you must visit for San Francisco's finest sushi. These guys have been around for a while and have it dialed!
author: C F.

description:
Sushi Bistro has moved! 3 spots over from where it was before, but yeah, still.

I'm not entirely sure what they're trying to do with their new space. For the first week or so, from the outside it looked nearly identical to Namu next door, doin that whole dark and sexy restaurantana (like a persona? making up words is fun). But when I came here with my roommates last week, it turns out it ain't so swank inside--there's hints of thought-out decorating here and there, but the walls seem unfinished and the floor looks like a construction site with paint splattered all over it (perhaps the paint that missed the wall?). Also, I think someone else clued them into imitating their neighbor's lighting, since it was pretty bright in there that night.

Despite my qualms about the interior design of Sushi Bistro, I still like the food here. I swear I've ordered at least a third of the menu by now, though I never seem to remember what is what since there are so many crazy rolls (similar yet different from one another) to choose from. But if you're looking for a suggestion or two, M&L this time around had a tasty crunch to it, and even their brown rice rolls (try First Crush) make you forget it's brown rice. The agedashi tofu is always a safe bet, too, especially as a pair to a solo roll. 

And parking still sucks. That hasn't changed.
author: Kate V.

description:
Lanjo and I stumbled on his place purely by accident and I'm glad we did.  We sat at the sushi bar at the back, which worked well for me, since I have hearing issues and the noise level was a bit high, primarily because there was mostly a young-ish crowd.  The place was full when we got there around 6:30 pm.

I started off with portabella mushroom appetizer then had the vegetarian udon, served in a metal bowl/pail that kept it nice and hot. It was filled with thinly sliced winter squash, green beans, mushrooms, a balanced amount of noodles and a very tasty broth. And Lanjo had a sashimi platter that had a wonderful variety.

Bancha, warmed sake and a dessert of green tea ice cream complimented the meal.  This place is "tucked away" on Balboa Street, a few blocks off Arguello Street, walking distance from the Upper Haight.

The wait service was excellent, by the way - attentive without being intrusive.

I highly recommend Sushi Bistro and will definitely go back again.
author: Stephen S.

description: The presentation of the dishes was great and the mochi was delicious. Only downside is that it feels a little crowded and the noise level is relatively high. Bring a sweater/jacket in case you sit near the door. They keep the door propped open since there is no centralized air system.
author: Gaby A.

description:
This place is amazing. Visiting Sf last week for some time off, I am very happy I added this place to my visit. 

MICHELIN RECOMMENDED, this place is superb for dinner. I highly suggest this place to anyone. It's a lil higher on the price scale but not too much. It is affordable. 

This place is a must if your visiting. I also drove past the restaurant the following day. It was full inside. There were many people dinning. I'm sure the residents of SF are a fan!
author: Jon B.

description:
The sushi rolls here are truly unique. I'm glad I came with a big group so that I could try a bunch of dishes! 

We tried the butterfish blasters, the african spider, the yellowtail basil, five wishes, omega-3 and crouching tiger hidden dragon. 

The dishes I liked the most: yellowtail basil and butterfish blasters.

The dish that I liked the least - fives wishes. It tasted like I was eating a tuna sandwich.
author: Margaret R.

description:
So first off I feel privileged to be writing the 1000th review.  With that said, the place was a good sushi restaurant.  The atmosphere is nice and it's super convenient since I live five doors down.  Laid back atmosphere with TV's for watching football.  We had the Rock n' Roll, Tuscan (veggie sushi, and some edamame.  The rolls were big and reasonably priced and the edamame was fresh.  Would I eat here again...?

I would.  It can get pretty packed so either make reservations or come early.
author: Lee S.

description: I had been meaning to go here for over a year, and I'm so glad I finally did. The menu is vast and they're creative--not the same 10 to 20 rolls you find everywhere else. The atmosphere is cool as well. We sat at the bar and it was bustling but not chaotic and service was fairly fast. I had one of the bowls and also tried the edamame, miso soup and various rolls. Delish!
author: Lauren C.

description: I'm not a big fan of sushi...I think it's a raw fish thing!  But my wife and kids love this place and the Butterfish blasters.  There's enough variety of other cooked items on the menu to keep me satisfied.  My son love the Udon soup!  My wife and daughters love everything else.  Definitely would come back to this place again.
author: M L.

description:
TASTE EXPLOSION OVERLOAD!!! ERROR. ERROR. TASTEBUDS... TOO... OVERWHELMED... CAN'T GO... ONNNNNN.

Sushi Bistro is the prime example of a sushi restaurant that's designed for people who do not like sushi. If you love this place, then chances are you're more interested in the sauces than the actual fish, because the fish here is really not that good. 

I have a rule and it's served me pretty well throughout the years: if a sushi roll has too much sauce, then they're trying to cover up the poor quality of the fish. In the case of Sushi Bistro, this is completely true. When you eat here, the actual fish is the last ingredient that you can taste in each bite. Every roll is drenched in, doused with, and dominated by so many different sauces that they could easily replace the salmon with tofu and you can't tell the difference. 

It is for this reason that I also ordered some of their sauce-free nigiri. The fresh salmon and tuna are mediocre at best, especially for the prices that Sushi Bistro charges.

Now, that's not to say that the different tastes weren't interesting. They do have some pretty unique and creative rolls here, like the New Legend Roll and the Butterfish Blasters. The only problem is that it's all overpowered by sauce, and way too much of it. The ahi tuna poke dish was probably the worst dish I had here, and I think it's because that's more of a dish with which you can't really hide the fish quality.

Bottom line: if you love fresh, quality fish, then stay far far away from Sushi Bistro. But if you want a cool place to hang out with friends over some sake bombs, eating creative & unique rolls, then it's definitely worth checking out.

For me, however, if the fish is raw, then it'd better be good quality. Otherwise, I'm sticking to the edamame all night.
author: Roy C.

description:
Sushi Bistro is not your average... actually it's not even a Japanese restaurant at all. It's more of a hip bar with that serves Japanese food. There's loud music playing so much that it's hard to have a conversation at normal loudness. The lights are really dim inside the restaurant so I would have to say this is an American-style sushi bar rather than a Japanese sushi bar. Not that it's a bad thing.

Sushi bistro has a lot of different special rolls they serve. There's also some regular nigiri pieces and Japanese bento dinner combos. The dishes are pretty much a hit or miss. Some of the ingredients didn't compliment each other well. All the ingredients was fresh and delicious though.

Miso soup was alright. There's nothing really special about miso soup. The interesting thing is soup is usually the first item to come, but it ended up as the last item. Did they run out of miso soup?

The Spicy Girl's pretty kicking good. It has small chunks of tuna gathered together to form an underside down bowl with a layer of avocado on top. The creamy house sauce didn't go great with the tuna and avocado. It was too creamy since the avocado was already creamy to begin with.

Otoro (fatty) tuna nigiri is awesomely delicious. It's such mouth watering good that it will send your taste buds to heaven the instant it hits them. The $14 price for two pieces is well worth the experience and the is pretty much the average price for two pieces..

The Caterpillar roll was a total miss for me. There was way too much cucumber inside the roll and it was drenched in the sweet sauce. The amount of rice and eel was really sparing compared to the cucumber. The avocado was nicely placed on top of the roll and they had two toothpicks that formed the caterpillar's head. I thought it was a nice touch.

Albacore Dream is a spicy roll with tuna and albacore. The ingredients mixed really well with each other and it had a really nice spicy zing at the end.

Nemo Found is really a unique roll that I didn't like. There was too many ingredients and different tastes inside that it just didn't taste good. A party in my mouth and everyone was invited is a good way to describe it. 

Overall, this is a nice place with fresh sushi. Parking in this neighborhood pretty much sucks so come early if you've made reservations.
author: Steven B.

description:
First of all I'd like to say, it was the worst negative restaurant experience ever. Second for those of you who have kids think twice before going here.

My friend actually recommended this place and we ( three couples and 4 kids) decided to give it a try. Now if you don't have kids you still might want to read on. ;-)

It started out very good, we had to make reservation and they gave us separate room in the back which was ok with us. Also provided high chair for one kid as we requested. So we ordered, we ate, and the sushi was really good and fresh. Kids also ate and then they started to hang out in hallway. The waiter came by and told us that the kids will get run over to one of us, not saying anything else. So we were like joking about it thinking the kids will run over them instead. After awhile, they asked to sit the kids, so we did. The next thing we know waiter comes with the bill and says we can't order anything else because there were many complaints about the kids. We asked why and then he started arguing madly with all the hate he had built up towards our table. We spoke with the owner and he basically told us the same thing to get out.... we were like wow, really? We actually had food on the table and drinks.... we paid and left in anger. 

Anyway, may be its not the right place for the families to have sushi at but the way conflict was handled by staff and the owner, tells me they have no customer service skills, rude talk manner as well as careless attitude towards the customers and apparently the business it self.

I will not be back to this place, sushi were good but the whole experience was horrible.
author: I R.

description:
I'm sitting at my computer in Los Angeles dreaming about getting on a plane to fly to San Francisco for dinner at Sushi Bistro. 

The last time I was there I got the ahi poke salad, the Dave's legacy and the fried green tea ice cream. 

All were so good I'm drooling.
author: Tina Z.

description: Amazing! Freshest, tastiest sushi in San Francisco! We know sushi and this is as good as it gets. Plus we loved everything about the place. The sevice as impeccable. The place was packed but they were friendly and the chef made a delicious roll I described that was not exactly on the menu. We got everything we ordered in a timely manner and no one bugged us to go after. You can't miss this place!
author: Margie T.

description:
This place is in my hood and I always take friends there to impress them.  I have tried almost everything on the menu over the past 7 years.  

They are the only sushi restaurant I know that will serve ikura (salmon roe) sashimi style.  I love how those little eggs pop in my mouth---the perfect way to get omega-3's.  And, their Omega-3 roll is good for that too.  

I docked one star because the restaurant is SO noisy!  It is really hard to hear the person across the table when the restaurant is busy (and it always is).  I leave with a headache from all the noise and having to scream to be heard.  

I love the sushi so much I dare go into this wild, loud restaurant in my neighborhood near and dear!
author: Nicki G.

description: Pretty good       Bartenders were quick to get you a drink, and suggest their best rolls.    The rolls were pretty tasty.   And the servings were LARGE.       Parking on Balboa is not bad (way better than Geary) and they have tables as well as the bar with views of TV's if you want to watch games, or just sit and eat.     It's not fancy decor but two can eat and drink well for $50-60
author: chris b.

description: Usually I run from places like this.  I prefer my sushi to be simple.  Hell I do not even like rice.  I only order Sashimi and when feeling freaky order a handroll.  However, SB'S fusion, artsy, non traditional sushi is damn good.  Big ups on the Sexy Scallop Roll
author: Chelsey G.

description: Food is not as good as it used to be even 6 months ago.  I had a feeling that the rice was from yesterday.  May be they hired a new crew or changed food suppliers.  This was my fifth or sixth time there.  During my last visit I felt the change but didn't pay attention.  Don't get me wrong sushi there still dissent but really nothing special any more.  They had a good start and customers accepted  their high prices but because they started to "cut corners" I will be spending my time and money somewhere else.
author: Avg G.

description:
If you scroll down the page of Sushi Bistro, you will read review after review lauding this place.  A weaker minded soul who left Sushi Bistro with a much to be desired palette may question if their taste buds were indeed defective, a genetic mishap of the 'ole factory sense.  However, I will have to agree with Roy C. in that this place is merely average.  I have avoided this place like the plague, much to KVu's haranguing.  I told her it was the modern day equivalent of this: http://starwars.wikia.com/wiki/Dark_Side_Cave and I dare not place the teachings placed upon me in jeopardy.  Her goading of "best poke ever" was weak temptation at best.  However, when I felt the time was ready, I entered this dwelling, ready to see if I could put past debacle behind me.  *inside debacle joke*

Coming with fellow statesman Le Chez along with our respective padawans, Lil Twist and semierectpenorsu, after a day of basketball, we arrived, underfed.  I had won a bet with Le Chez, calmly sinking a halfcourt shot, with Reggie Miller theatrics, much like Game 1 of the Pacers v. Bulls ECF.  I basically curled, shoved le Chez aside to create room, received an inbound pass and sunk a half court shot, then celebrated, hopping up and down on an uninjured ankle while the commentators bellowed, "you can dance brian, you can dance!"  What I basically mean is I sunk the half court shot first after 30+ attempts.  As a result, dinner was on him, $30 dollar minimum.  However, because he is a brother, we split 4 rolls, 2 rolls each of our choosing.

We ordered:
big island: 2/5 the big island was wrapped in cucumber.  while there was an assortment of fish inside, the taste was dominated by the crab.
omega 3: 3/5 a deep fried roll that tasted like fried tempura and sauce.  
rock n roll: 4/5 the best of the bunch.  it was basically a miniature lionking
new wave mahi mahi: 2/5 taste was again dominated by crabmeat

I believe that more people come here for the ambiance.  It is a place to be seen I feel.  It is a great date place for sure...unoriginal (it isn't a Marine World, where one can walk around superhero cape'd, that's for sure) but effective.  There is nice presentation to their dishes and the service is good, however, the food leaves much to be desired.  The portions are small and the best thing I ate that night was the cheapest roll - California roll with baked scallops on top and the miso soup.  The rolls don't taste like an amalgamation of taste, but instead, one flavour dominates the rest, The padawans even gave negative feedback.  Lil Twist's complained that his chicken was cold and semierectdicksu said his udon made him limpy.
author: Brian V.

description:
i remember coming here when the restaurant first opened.  the place was quite small...seated less than 20 people...and didn't have all the lights, tvs, and galore that it does now.  they were quite authentic at the time...but it looks like the restaurant and the menu conformed to all of the other hip sushi places in the bay area.  it's pretty difficult to find good, authentic japanese food nowadays...i'd normally be against this type of place...but hey, i have to say the food was quite surprising.  

here is a list of what we tried:
1.  hot love-lobster rolled with snapper...the best thing we had that night...a must when you come here.
2.  black & white-unagi and tofu...pretty good...i would order it again.
3.  sexy scallop-white tuna, salmon, and scallop...DELISH.
4.  spicy crunchy-yellowtail, salmon, snapper, and shrimp deep fried with macadamia nuts...sounds great but rather disgusting.
5.  12 piece sashimi-butterfish, tuna, hamachi, salmon, albacore, and i forgot the last one...good, thick fish but too big to enjoy the flavor of authentic sashimi.

i'm giving this place 4 stars for what it is...a bistro...not for authentic japanese cuisine like how it used to be.  the fish was fresh, the cuts could've been better...but the rolls were quite tasty and original,  the atmosphere was nice and like i said...hip.

i'd come back again if i head back to sf craving sushi.  but i'm curious about the place next door...TEKKA.
author: Jen W.

description: Great service! So attentive and polite. Sadly not something standard these days, but always welcome. Loved every roll. Everything tasted fresh and they don't skimp on the seafood. We found our new favorite sushi spot. We have been on the hunt for a long time.
author: Tim and Sam T.

description:
I've gone here twice and each time it was DELICIOUS.

I think the real catcher is that you can get rolls in BROWN rice. Not an easy task to find sushi with brown rice that is still delicious, and without sounding annoying to your waiter.

Had some great rolls (the omega one is my favorite!) and definitely worth the price. If i had remembered the names of which ones I got, may be a bit more helpful but rest assured that any roll you order will be great!!  I had something that was delicious and baked with a sort of cheesey-mayonnaise-y topping.. to die for. No, really. YUMM.

Friendly staff, clean and tidy place, definitely a cool vibe and atmosphere and best of all, I didn't feel rushed out or in a hurry to finish my food. Always a plus!

Only thing I wasn't a fan of was the day that I came here (and it was pouring BUCKETS of rain) was the wait. and then having to sit at the sushi bar in the back in the corner cuz it was full that night! But the service and delicious food definitely made up for that.

Parking really isn't that easy but its very accessible by the bus. Again, the quality of Sushi Bistro overrides all the little minor things  like parking or the wait.

Can't wait to go back!!
author: Diana R.

description:
I had mixed feelings after our recent dinner at Sushi Bistro. The service was impeccable: prompt, super friendly, efficient... the kind where you're engaged in conversation and your unwanted plates disappear without notice... excellent.
We stuck with sushi and rolls for our dinner. The fish was amazingly fresh: melt in your mouth delicious. Absolutely perfect.
But the fish to rice ratio, unlike a lot of other sushi spots, is way more fish than rice.  I'm sure this will be a huge attraction to folks who prefer sashimi only but a California Roll with a slender layer of rice and an overabundance of the crab is just too overwhelming.  The sushi slices were huge, exceptionally long but served with just a tiny pouch if rice. We prefer a balance of the two.
We ordered the Butterfish Blaster, the Omega, and M&L Forever. They were good, but too overdone: too many competing flavors, too rich, too much fish, not enough balance.
All in all, three stars for the food we ordered but definitely five stars for the service.
author: Jen N.

description: Don't ask questions, order the First Crush Roll and Mango Special (this one not on the menu).  You will not be disappointed.  I"m a creature of habit and I get this every time, and it's the best decision I can make every time.  The service is very friendly, the atmosphere is great.  Been coming here for years, and I definitely recommend it!
author: Jessica D.

description:
The signs were all there. Parking was a nightmare. We circled the neighborhood for a full 45 minutes before we parked in a 'not so legal' spot (No, it wasn't a handicapped spot, I'm a better person than that). The wait was another 45 minutes. I am not supposed to be eating Sushi, but after checking with the server and making sure that the fried rolls were cooked through, we placed our order for a Spicy Crunchy, an Asparcado and Albacore rolls and a veggie tempura appetizer. The tempura was good and so was the vegetarian Asparcado roll, but it was nothing stellar. The Spicy Crunchy was extremely fishy, and my husband said the Albacore roll was decent. 

After all the 5 star reviews we were expecting a lot from the place, our experience was just mediocre. The servers were nice, food not so! 

I think i'll just wait to fly to Hawaii and eat at Sansei in Maui...yummmmmm!
author: Ashwini S.

description: I've been to both locations but this one is closer to my house and I feel it may be better. Sushi bistro is definitely my favorite sushi place ever,hands down. I even prefer this over the more expensive and highly reviewed Ozumo. The reason for this being the creative ingredients used in the rolls and the freshness of the sashimi. My favorite rolls here is the Hawaiian breeze. Gosh its so amazing, tuna, apple, macadamia nuts, pesto drizzled over the top. It's thebomb.com. I also love the yellowtail jalapeno sashimi as well as the ahi tuna poke. Sheesh this place is good, go it's totally worth it.
author: Mila A.

description:
My draft review simply said "A bit noisy".  Yes, it was.  This place is more geared toward a date night kind of place.  With a bar being the prominent center piece in the main eating area, it was quite loud with people talking above the music playing over the sound system.

Lots of interesting special sushi choices.  But for the life of me, I can't remember which one we ordered.  It's been too long since I was there and am only now completing the review.  Probably won't return as I do remember it was too pricey.
author: barry a.

description:
Was brought here one night and I have to say, it's kind of nice having someone taking initiative for a planned night out.  Wouldn't say that I'd want it every time I go out but every now and then is a nice breath of fresh air.

Couldn't tell you what was ordered since, obviously, I didn't order, but sashimi, handrolls, and sake...a couple bottles of sake, actually.  Very nice!...Very smooth!  Great choices! Feelin nice! =)

This place is definitely modern and the butterfly symbol is close to my heart for personal reasons, but it IS pretty small.  I can imagine having to wait pretty long if you didn't have a rezie...lucky for me, that was already taken care of.  I literally didn't have to do anything this night but eat and drink!! Loves it!!

Service was attentive, food tasted fresh, company was great conversation.  Almost closed the restaurant down we were talking so long, so we decided to give the staff a break and continue our conversation at a nearby bar.

Not sure I would go out of my way to come here though.  The food and everything was good but I can also get "good" closer to home...or at least more conveniently located near home.  Glad I was able to experience though!
author: Ninja H.

description:
Wow, was I am in the same Sushi Bistro I have gone to in the past??  

Apparently no.  It moved a couple doors down.  

It was like a whole new Sushi Bistro.  Chic, minimalist, and just as good.  The fish is ridiculously fresh and the rolls are super creative.  I LOVE the roll made with cucumber instead of rice. From what I hear a classically trained sushi chef left another establishment and came here to get creative and have some fun.  Which I 100% appreciate.  They also serve sake in a box.  If you don't like creative, they do they traditional as well.   The menu is a good 6 pages and the staff is super friendly.  I will say I think the prices went up or maybe my wallet got lighter, I blame the economy.   Either way I think it is worth it.
author: Kristin Marie S.

description:
FOOD:
Sashimi plate = the sushi was good. Nice presentation of food.

SERVICE:
Not bad.


ATMOSPHERE:
It's nice decor, nice ambiance to it.
author: Angela L.

description:
Sushi Bistro was amazing!  The sushi was excellent, the service was fast and friendly and if this was in my neighborhood you better believe I would be here once a week.
