The prices were really reasonable as well.  We had Ahi Tuna Roll and a Veggie Crunch Role (tempura fried veggies inside a roll).
Overall, great neighborhood find that I would go out of my way for.
author: Melanie B.

description:
Size matters and the nigiri and sashimi here are the biggest I've seen in the city. The rolls and fish were high quality, not a total standout or ultra authentic, but on par with other solid sushi spots in the city. 

Since Sushi Bistro is often packed to the gills, I'd suggest going on the early or later side. I was finally able to get in after my second attempt, fortunately Namu (also quite good) is next door if you're too hungry to wait.

The staff is rushed due to the crowds, but seem to have a friendly disposition about them. Prices are cheap on the basic stuff, but it can get pricey as you delve into the specialty rolls. Similarly with drinks they have some higher end sakes, but also $4 beers so pick your poison depending on your budget.

Noise level is high and they pack it in, so I wouldn't recommend a first date here. The music and atmosphere do make this a lively and casual spot for eating sushi with a couple friends.

Disclosure: I work for Yelp and apparently Sushi Bistro is an advertiser, cool!
author: Jeremy S.

description: Great sushi! The portions of fish is huge and so fresh! The staff and environment is nice, the different kinds of rolls are very creative and delicious! I will most def be going back soon :)
author: David K.

description:
Not bad, not bad at all--but it wasn't anything special that I had to come home immediately to write a review for promptly. The menu is diverse, creative, expansive, and offers something even for the pickiest palate.

We began with the Butterfish Blasters ($13.50), which were delicious but different. I didn't expect the butterfish to be unmarinated and uncooked--searing it would've brought out its signature buttery taste at least. Anyway, it was a bit of a letdown since I love love misoyaki butterfish. 

Next up we had the Rock 'N Roll ($7.75) and the Spicy Crunchy ($9.75). I really enjoyed the Rock 'N Roll for the baked spicy scallops--can you say mouth orgasm? The Spicy Crunchy was good but tiring after the initial piece because it was deep-fried and on the dry side. 

Of course, we had to have Fried Mango Ice Cream because I'm not one to turn down ice cream, let alone fried ice cream. The tempura skin was very soggy, which makes me think this dish was pre-made. Sad story.

Overall a decent spot to obtain your sushi fix, but I wouldn't expect any oohs, ahhs, and oh wows if I were you. =P
author: Liz T.

description:
Sushi Bistro is more on the trendy side...I can see it catering to younger adults.  

I came to dinner with a friend and we got seated right away...beat the dinner rush!  The restaurant felt really cold inside, so be sure to wear something warm!  

We ordered 2 orders of the half shell oysters and the Sexy Scallop, Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon and the New Legend Roll.  

My favorite was the New Legend Roll.. Its taste took me by surprise.  It looked so simple, but tasted warm and had this special sauce on top that was nothing I've ever tasted before.  I'm sure the rest of the rolls were just as good, which is really creative.    

I'd say this is probably one of the better places for sushi for a good price.
author: Nancy S.

description:
My partner and I just got back from dinner at Sushi Bistro. We had never been before and reading the menu, thought it might be a bit too fusion for us. But it was incredible (and we are serious about our sushi!). First off the service was fantastic. Attentive but not in your face. Instead of an overwhelming table full of dishes, they brought each dish out at its own pace. When we finished one, the next arrived quickly. We ordered hot sake and it was there in literally a minute, both times. 

The fish was all very fresh and the portions were very generous. We had the African spider roll which was delicious. The batter on the crab was light and tasty. We also has the "hot love" and it was so delectable and incredible. The nigiri portions were large and the fish super fresh. Since we ordered mostly nigiri, after trying the one roll and appetizer dish, we found our selves wanting to come back to try more of their inventive rolls and dishes. 

And to top it all off, the prices were very reasonable. Cheaper for larger portions than at many other sushi places.

We were just really taken by this place and will definitely be back!!
author: Patti M.

description: Ugh. You know when sushi just has huge slabs of fish or a giant portion of crab and it just turns into a mouthful of gummy fish? The balance is what makes or breaks sushi for me, and this was just not my cup of tea. Expensive too.
author: Barbara S.

description: The service was Awesome!! And the sushi was unique, fresh and amazing. Huge portions of raw Sashimi soooooooooo good!!  I loved the individual lettuce wraps. :)
author: Elizabeth J.

description: I love both restaurants on Balboa and on 24th st (Mission District). I always have the consistent fresh and delicious meals everytime.  The rolls are unique and creative.  The servers are a reliable source of recommending items that you haven't tried or if you can't make up your mind.  They also have a great variety of sake from filtered to unfiltered (which is my fave). If you like the Balboa location, try going to the Mission location and try that menu...it has a slight different amazing flair!  I have been to many sushi establishments and this is one of my top 3 IN THE USA!!!
author: Jay S.

description:
I came here with a couple of friends on a Thursday night for dinner. Nestled in the Richmond on Balboa Street, you wouldn't expect to find a good sushi restaurant here. A solid 3.5 stars here and I would give it another try.

The restaurant is modern, it reminds me of Blowfish in the mission minus the loud music and anime.

The three of us ordered about 5 dishes: Ahi poke special, 101 Roll, Crouching Tiger Roll, New Wave Mahi Mahi, and the Yellowtail Basil.  Most of the rolls were pretty good but I would not order the new wave mahi mahi again as the flavors didn't blend well but the rest of the rolls were pretty good and the ahi poke special was different because it was spicy.

It came out to about $25 per person including tax and tip so it wasn't bad for sushi. There are innovative rolls and names on the menu so I would want to go back to try some of their other combinations.
author: Betty C.

description: Just a block away from my apartment, and couldn't be happier about it! Extensive menu with creative rolls and lots of other great dishes. Fresh fish and decently priced!
author: Bridget B.

description:
Love Sushi Bistro! I have been coming here for years and I have never been disappointed. Great atmosphere and friendly staff! The Sashimi is fresh and the rolls are very creative. I love all the rolls, but my favorite is probably the Yellow Tail Basil. Also, try the Caucasian Afro bowl!

Def. make reservations on weekends, it can get busy.
author: Drew H.

description: I was walking around then I stopped by at Sushi Bistro restaurant, excellent food, clean and tasteful, I recommend this place you won't regret, excellent service, friendly guys I will come back for sure.
author: Albert S.

description:
Solid food, service, and ambiance. 

Parking is not very good. Keep that in mind if you have a reservation.
author: Gloria B.

description:
If you're the love child of a yuppie and hipster's drunken tryst, this is the place for you, because:

-You can pretend the low-lighting presents a "romantic" atmosphere instead of hiding the horribly prepared "sushi."

-You can pretend your group's seating in the back room with sticky floors and people coming out of what looks like a sink/wash area is "cozy" and "private."

-You can pretend you're not eating sushi at a Chinese buffet by paying a lot more for it.

-You can pretend it's entertaining and not insulting when a waiter openly complains to another waiter about how his table is shafting him on tip (MAYBE BECAUSE YOU'RE AN ASSHOLE, BUDDY.).

-You can pretend you're cool and hip because all the fruit mixed with chopped up low grade fish, FRIED EVERYTHING, and exorbitant amounts of Sriracha hot sauce is original, instead of realizing it's all the creation of a 1st grader told to create something people would find cool to eat. 

Or, you can eat at a real sushi restaurant and enjoy your meal.  Unless, of course, you like blowing your money pretending to be enjoying your food at a pretentious joint where all your poser friends go; if that's the case, Sushi Bistro is your type of place, coolio.
author: Sam W.

description:
being a vegan/vegetarian is not so hard when you come to this place because they have vegetarian stuff, just ask the staff which one if you're not sure.
I ordered vegetarian dumpling, the skin color is green and they're pretty tasty.
i also got crunchy roll (8 pieces) it's made from lightly deep fried vegetables with crunchy tempura batter outside, drizzled with sweet sauce & they tasted also taste good.
i'm not really liking the tuscan roll, it's basically avocado and sun-dried tomatoes wrapped in seaweed, flash fried, and served with sweet and spicy sauce. i'm not buying that next time i come here... too much sun dried tomato, too sour, just not my fave type of sushi, it doesnt work with my palate.
staff are pretty decent, just right.
Nexttime i come back i'll order something else, they might be my next fave.
May i remind you that this is not a place to save your money, I ate with my partner and we spent about  around $70 for 2 people. My veggie rolls are 8.95 times two. So the expensive ones are the fish and some other meat dish that my partner ordered.
Oh also, when you order tea, it's not included like some other japanese restaurant, it'll be charged.
i had tried some japanese sushi somewhere else so it's more satisfying in taste & cheaper in price with the same quality. 
I'm not against this place at all, it's just maybe they're a lil' expensive and not for people who wants to save money. Maybe a good place to socialize especially for young peeps who likes to eat.
I probably will go back just to try some other veggies rolls i have not try.
author: Ms C.

description:
After an uhmazing sushi experience the evening before at Kabuto I was a bit underwhelmed by my experience at Sushi Bistro.  The atmosphere wasn't anything special and while the hole in the wall sushi spots tend to be the best places this wasn't the case for Sushi Bistro.  And our waiter kept ignoring half of our table of 8 peeps. Once everyone was FINALLY able to place an order the sushi came out pretty quickly.  

Since we had such a large party we did a pretty good job of ordering most of the menu.  A few of the specialty rolls were interesting (ex: the new legend and the sexy scallop), but nothing wow'd me and I felt them to be a bit creamy for my taste. And this is after asking them to go easy on the mayo!  Might be worth a stop if you live/work in the neighborhood, but otherwise I'd recommend Kabuto or Ryoko.
author: Andrea R.

description:
Happened to be in the area so I took my wife there for dinner.  Read a lot of reviews about this place so thought worth a try.  Only few tables were occupied at 7pm.  Mostly were non-Asians and this worries me a bit about the quality of this place.

We had:
Butterfish Blasters (ok)
Miso Black Cod (ok)
Hamachi Kama (not grilled, it was baked, ok)
Nigiri - Amaebi and Hotate (very good)
12 pc Sashimi (typical combo tuna, salmon, hamachi,not the best cut of fish, good)
Hawaiian Breeze (ok)

Warning for the unsuspected patrons:
- Wasabi was weak and didn't have the kick.  So our server promptly replaced it and charged us $1.50
- Our server asked us if we need another small dish of cucumber sunomomo and later we learned they charged us for $4.50

Seriously both of us spent $120 for dinner and this place -full of greed- is charging us for wasabi and pickled cucumber that other Japanese restaurants give away as condiments.  

We will not to go back and will not refer our Hawaii friends there when they are in SF.
author: Basil P.

description: Delicious! I'm not big on sashimi, but their albacore sashimi is out of this world!  Try the Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and lettuce wraps -- you will not be disappointed.
author: Lauren T.

description:
Ridiculously long lines for a late (9:30 pm) Friday night dinner even with reservations, but once you're in - it's DELICIOUS!  The star of the show at SB are their ROLLS.  Their menu offers up lots of choices both traditional and exotic.  My favorite would be the spider roll and their Hot Love roll.  We were a party of 4 and had 5 different rolls as well as edamame.  The prices were reasonable and the tight quarters makes this place very loud and exciting.  It's a small place and I wouldn't recommend going here with a party larger than 4.  (I admit, I might of given a couple of stink eyes to those parties of 6+.)  However, we left the place stuffed and happy!  

p.s. Parking is a nightmare here so avoid at all cost!
author: Lisa R.

description: Although I've never dined in, their service is prompt and the staff are knowledgeable with the menu. They're fast with their Togo orders and can accommodate with special requests.. They even serve brown rice!
author: Kevin L.

description:
I am hesitant to write a 5 star review because I am selfish and don't want this place to get too crowded. I love it here.  I go here 2 times a month and have never had a bad experience. 

Very good prices for the quality of sushi you receive - VERY attentive staff. Lets just say your beverage will never be empty unless it is your choice to have an empty glass.

Ambiance is nice - the food comes out quickly and before you know it, dinner is over. The whole thing seems to happen very quickly, which is great most nights. However, for more romantic dates where you want to spend some time to get to know someone, you may choose somewhere that slows the process down a bit.. Amazing couples restaurant - especially mid week when you don't want to stay out all night. 

Highly, highly recommend!
author: Matthew A.

description:
My sister has been raving about this palce ever since I moved here so we finally went. We were lucky to get a table for 2 without waiting but it was right by the door and we were pretty much ignored the whole time. I think we had to call someone over everytime we wanted something and also got jacked on our free cucumber salad.

OTHER than that, I was amazed at the variety and creativity of the rolls. I think we got the Sashimi Special(a roll) and the Sexy Scallop. Both came wrapped in soy paper(this kind of annoyed me, where's the seaweed?) but I couldn't complain because they were really good! You could tell the fish was super fresh because it had an excellent texture and flavor. This and miso soup filled us up.

They were also playing some really rad reggae music.

I definitely want to go here again-- hopefully on someone else's tab next time though =)
author: Rachel G.

description:
Came here under my friend's suggestion since I wanted sushi. 

Cucumber with Sesame in Vinegar. Little salad thing they gave us after water. I can't remember what they call it in Japanese but it was alright.

Aloha 101. Seared ahi tuna, cucumber and mango wrapped in seaweed, flash fried with a spicy garlic sauce. I thought this was okay because I love seared tuna. But I also did not taste any of the mango, I don't think the mango was ripe enough to add its fragrance to the roll. The sauce was not spicy at all, but I'll admit I probably also have a higher tolerance to spiciness than most people. 

Hot Love. Baby lobster, crab and avocado rolled in snapper and baked with a spicy sweet sauce. I think this was my favorite dish of the night. I liked the addition of the lemon to the bottom, gave it an additional tangy flavor. I liked the sweet sauce a lot, it added a lot to the flavors of the lobster, crab, avocado and lemon but it was by no means spicy so if you're expecting to get a kick from it, don't. 

Hirame Fusion. Salmon, cucumber and scallions topped with seared halibut sprouts and ginger-carrot sauce. This was alright, I think I liked it more than I would have just because salmon is my favorite sushi fish. I liked the halibut too since it was a more unexpected addition to a sushi roll, but definitely nothing to write home about. 

The service was really good however, they were very quick to refill water glasses. And I liked how all of our dishes came one by one, as we finished one another would come so it didn't hog up our small table space. 

Note: Do not come here expecting legit Japanese sushi, it's more Asian fusion than real Japanese cuisine.
author: Constance C.

description:
I really didn't care for this restaurant. It's not even worth reviewing this restaurant in complete sentences.

Trendy without purpose, unnecessarily crowded; poor service (they gave us someone else's table without cleaning it off first). Mediocre sushi- too much mayo. Fishy tasting... fish. Which I guess is better than fishy, I don't know, edemame?  

Star Number One is for creativity: the rolls were definitely creative. And not in a good way. More like in a "what weird combination is this???" way.

Another half star for the poke salad because it was fair.. Although it was over-dressed. But I can't give half stars, so I'll round up because it's the holidays.

Yeah... I'm not going back. Not even if someone paid me. Even though my boyfriend lives down the street. And he's not allowed to go back either.
author: Debora L.

description: Seriously, few things make me more cranky than the thought of having to go to the Richmond after work for dinner. When my friend decided to have his birthday dinner here, I was not happy. I don't even like Japanese food. Raw fish and seaweed? No way! How is it then, that weeks later, I'm still craving this place. They have a fantastic vegetarian selection and they can make all their sushi with a soy wrapper instead of seaweed. All of the rolls I tried were delicious! The tofu salad was unexpectedly refined. Their fried ice-cream comes with fried Oreos. OMG. SO AMAZING!
author: Vrushali P.

description:
Fresh Fish

Buttery Sashimi

Generous Portions

Innovative Rolls

Original Menu

Great Rice to Fish ratio

Reasonably Priced

Attentive Service


............................. definitely going back!
author: Sue Y.

description:
This is a completely Americanized Japanese restaurant. The first thing I noticed as I sat down with friend was they served ice water instead of the hot green tea. They actually charged us $1.50 for per cup for green tea. 

Price is somewhat above average Japanese restaurant or I should say falling into the $$$ range. The two of us ordered 2 rows of sushi (8 pieces), 1 udon, 1 sashimi combo (12 pieces of various fish), and the total came close to $80, or about $39 per person. 

Food quality and taste were about average while the portion was slightly less than what you would expect from traditional restaurant. 

Interior design and layout was good with dim light, so it might be ideal place for dating. 

I do not plan to ever go back. Overall, unless you have no budget issue, and you freaking love this style of Americanized restaurant, I would say think twice before going
author: Jun W.

description:
The best sushi place for me in town!
Amazingly fresh and fatty-melty yellowtail just does it for me. Also great unique sushi roll selection and not super expensive menu that's why I love to go there. 
I would recommend sashimi platter, with really generous fish cuts.
author: Anelya S.

description:
Best Salmon Sashimi in the city. . . hands down.

This place is so close to me I feel bad every time I try to 'explore' a new sushi restaurant in the city only to be disappointed.  

The staff is super friendly and always accommodating.  Definitely make the trek to the inner richmond to go here.  And get the salmon sashimi.
author: Matt D.

description: We were trying to find a good sushi place in the short time we had in SF. This one was listed on yelp and turned out to be walking distance from us (turns out parking sucks in SF). Well, it had mostly good reviews, with a few bad mixed in. For us it was excellent! Really good appetizers (lettuce rolls) and even better rolls. If I lived around here, I would definitely be a regular.
author: John Z.

description:
This appears to be a place you either love or you don't.

Clearly, Sushi Bistro is the doing something right for those who wrote rave reviews, but I found it completely underwhelming considering such positive recs.  

To demonstrate how "Meh" I felt about the whole dining experience, I'll embarrassingly admit that I haven't Yelped in over a year.  

A year, people!  To date, nothing has stirred me enough to log in until this meal.

We sampled fusion rolls and pure nigiri to feel out the menu.  The hamachi nigiri wasn't awful, but it wasn't fresh.  I don't mean gross-un-fresh, I mean it's tasteless and shouldn't be served as fresh, raw fish "un-fresh".

Ordered the Hot Love roll based on reviews. 2 pieces the size of filet mignon medallions drenched in mayo and ponzu sauce.  Liked the baby lobster pieces on top and the avocado slices were a nice touch, but I expected more.

Rainbow roll - Could have done with a lot less of the imitation crab in mayo. In fact, the whole roll was just imitation crab doused with mayo and then topped with paper-thin slices of sashimi. 

Sashimi Style - clean, but nothing fantastic. Kind of tastes like the granola version of sushi... and by that, I mean bland and boring.

Good ambiance and a clean, contemporary east-meets-west kind of feel.   Nice presentation of food.  Good ventilation and open space - I like.  The food is disappointing; factor in the price and it's awful.

Overall, a place to go if you enjoy fusion, a place to avoid if you're a sushi purist.
author: Melissa H.

description:
4 1/2 stars.  I came here years ago...but recently went back today with the boyfriend.  Things have changed since I was last here...they expanded or something (it was years ago and we were visiting our friends in SF before we moved here).

Anyhow, I ordered the Hawaiian Breeze roll.  OMG.  This may be the best roll I've ever had.  It was so yummy and tasty.  Mango?  Avocado? Macademia nuts?   Yes please!  Seriously, I thought ordering this was going to be a crap shoot.  It was either going to be really good or "wtf were they thinking?!?!"  So glad it turned out to be really good.  I really am not a big fan of seafood in general, actually...that's an understatement, I hate seafood.  I put up with sushi though because it's so fresh that it's not super fishy tasting/smelling (at least it shouldn't be!)  But I would definitely eat sushi/seafood more often if it tasted like this.

Yum.
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
Meh, Yes I've experienced WAY better!

And sadly enough it was so bad that I don't think i'm willing to give it another try. 
Two stars for good service and portion size otherwise the food was gravely dissatisfying. 

I'm a list-er so: a. all the fish was freezing cold-bleck. b. the filling in the rolls tasted like mayonaise-super gross! c. miso soup was average at best. d. sad looking salad with wilted lettuce  and e. lip stick on the pint of glass my beer was served with. 


I was expecting much more given the popularity on yelp, something with savage tasting sushi/sashimi. This left me feeling mildly nausea and disappointed to have wasted a Friday sushi night date. Next time I'll definitely go elsewhere. However if you're looking for Westernized sushi this may be your place. They have no problem putting nuts, watermelon, mushroom and mango between fillets of fish.
author: irisholive o.

description: Went here while on vacation with the family. Fun, young ambiance, and amazing and creative rolls.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I've gone to this location twice, and "Yay! I'm a fan.  It's pricey, $12 a roll, but if you want to taste some interesting, thoughtful, and fresh sushi....splurge! 

My favorites:
Monster In Law - I like a bit of kick, so I loved this roll. Definitely my favorite of the favorites. 
Volcano - kind of mayo based (dislike), but the flavor of the overall roll is great, it just melts in your mouth
Butterfish Blasters - holy flavor, its like a burst of flavor 

I asked the waiter for a good Salmon roll, he suggested Billie Jean. But I didn't love it. The fish quality was very good, but in comparison to the other three, it was kind of bland. 

Ambiance, its a tight space. And I always end up being seated next to the weirdest people. The first time I went, I sat next to a couple, the girl had her feet propped up on her boyfriends knee and he was massaging it (literally 1 foot away from me). GROSS. The second time, I had a group of 4 to my right, who were having a Russian style drinking contest. Being loud is bad enough, but when you're loud in another language, that's just irritating, because I can't eaves drop.  :)
author: Natasha K.

description:
I just went to this place for dinner! And horrible customer service! I asked the girl at the front desk how long the wait would be and she said oh 15-20.  So I put my name down and we were waiting for 40 min.  I went to the front desk again and checked in, I said where are we at for wait time because you told me 15-20 min, she said "well, I can't ask guests to leave"! I said to her..well, you shouldn't be quoting guest 15-20 min if that is not how long the wait is going for! I was shocked/surprised she said that! 

So we finally sit down and ordered food! We ordered for entree's which was okay..but we got our salad and catepillar roll..we finished our food and was waiting for our additional sushi for 15 min after we were done.  

I would never go back to this place again!!!!
author: jbm j.

description: Quality fresh fish. A wide selection of classic and unique rolls. My favorite "go-to" sushi spot after being here 5 years
author: Amanda C.

description:
The Verdict: Yes, I like them apples...in my sushi roll.

Unique rolls that mix modern California flair with quality traditional Japanese principles, Sushi Bistro is a must try and a must return to spot. Service is nice, fast and flexible. I like woolen who can think on their feet and make it happen! We ordered Crouching Tiger, Watermelon Man, and something with the word Breeze in it. They all tasted fresh and left me wanting more. The mango and apples shreds in the rolls further added to the freshness.

Would I Recommend It? Yes, great for small parties and regular quality dining.
author: Judy P.

description:
I came here tonight with Betty W. because celebrations were in order for what was a huge, impressive accomplishment on her part.  So proud of you, so incredibly proud of you.  On such occasions, eating lots of good food is a necessity.  

Well. I learned tonight that there IS such a thing as ordering too much food.  Because by the end, I didn't feel so hot.  Maybe it was also the things we ordered because everything started to taste the same after a while, which is why I'm giving the place a 3.5 now.  But, I think that the place still deserves anywhere between 3.5-4.25 depending on the day and what you order.  I see it as sort of like the scores you get for standardized tests, where they give you the range that you fall into, depending on the day and the particular test.

Anyway.  Here's what we ordered tonight.  The good and the bad.

TASTY:
+ C-2:  Always a hit in my book.  Lobster, avocado, and some other stuff, with shrimp tempura and eel sauce drizzled on top.  Tastes exactly like you think it would taste: pretty damn good.
+ Five Wishes:  I liked this one.  The snow crab in it was really creamy, and the salmon, hamachi, tuna, and some other fish that was on top of the roll was just really good too.  The hamachi was, as usual, the best. 

WEIRD:
- Magic Mushroom:  First, the name.  Magic Mushrooms make me think of two things: 1) Toad from Mario brothers and 2) drugs.  This one just tasted like weird mushy stuff wrapped in something else undecipherable.  Not bad.  Just weird, and a little unnecessary.
- New Legend: Um, this tasted exactly like the C-2 even though it was supposedly different.  Er, I guess that's a good thing, but there were only two of us, which meant we had to eat a lot of the same thing.  Again, unnecessary.

Final word:  So yes.  My range for Sushi Bistro is now 3.5 - 4.25.  A new way of reviewing things.  Maybe I should go this route more often.  Overall, a good meal, with good company, but I learned that there is such a thing as over-ordering.  I guess tonight it was really my fault, and not so much the food.  Next time, maybe not so much foods.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Holy SHIT this place was good !!

Came here for dinner, an early dinner, right after it opened for the evening. Didn't get any sashimi or nigiri, as the person I was with doesn't (think she) likes raw fish (but she's never tasted any, so...). We had several makizushi that were *out of this world*. We ordered from the "special selections" part of the menu (i.e., not traditional rolls, their inventions I would guess). Several vegetarian, one with cooked fishes. Yummmmmm.

Also had the sesame chicken (deep fried) and we HAD to order the cucumber salad after tasting the miniscule "free appetizer" they give you.

Seriously some of the tastiest rolls I've ever had in over 25 years. Definitely not traditional rolls that you would get in Japan, but very tasty. Dinner for two, with tax and tip was $50. A tad expensive (well, maybe not for sushi, and now that I think about it, not for SF). Let's say instead that it was not inexpensive.

I'll be stopping by again next time I'm in the area and want to treat myself.
author: Matthew C.

description: This is a 4.5 star rating. Really good service, food, drinks and a nice vibe as well. The crowd was young and chic. The sake the bar tender recommended was good and strong! The beef dish was surprisingly tender and tasty. The mango tempura ice cream was killer.
author: Sunil R.

description: I don't understand how anyone can give a bad review of this place.  The albacore melted in my mouth.... the magic mushrooms are delicious!!!  The butterfish appetizer is delicious... but for 14 bucks you only get 6... i would wayyyyy rather order a different fancy roll that comes with more pieces.  The other rolls we ordered were amazing... one with jalapeno and albacore DELICIOUS. Will def. come back!
author: Julie B.

description:
Pros:
- Cozy but not cramped
- Good for groups or date
- Pleasant and efficient service
- Nice plating/presentation
- Well sliced fish, Drunken Halibut was unique and tasty, Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon roll was good but nothing special
- Reasonable prices 

Con:
- Fish quality is so-so (went on a Sat night)

Pros vs con? Pro wins, but just by a hair.
author: Snuffles B.

description:
This is the kind of place that I would eat at twice a week if I lived nearby.  Sadly, I do not.  But you know what I order when I do go? The C-2, Ahi Tuna Poke Special, Double Jeopardy, some Miso soup, and a cold Sapporo.  

The service is impeccable and I love their reggae music selection.  It's like taking a little vacation.
author: Lindsey P.

description:
very modern style to this place.  the music can be played a little softer.

the following rolls are my favorites: C-2, RocknRoll, and sexy scallop

one of the best sushi joints in san francisco.
author: Kurt N.

description:
Delishh! 

I was told this place became popular due to a iphone commercial so I was expecting bad service and bad food. Why is that when some places become popular those things start to correlate? 

Anyway, I got both good service and tasty food. I wasn't disappointed at all, the prices are also reasonable. They had a wide variety of choices.

Only problem was there was a bit of a wait, but who would complain about that at a busy restaurant when we had no reservations!

Parking is also easy to find.

Enjoy!
author: Sunny D.

description:
no japanese! 
fish is just ok. but price is tooo high!!
author: A Y.

description:
When I used to live in the Richmond District, this used to be one of my favorite spots to get sushi.  The chef was very inventive and creative in making such wonderful sushi.  Good food in SF spreads fast and soon this place was hopping!  

I'm hoping with the 2nd location that the crowds are now evenly spread out and finding a table here wouldn't be so much of a problem.

Come here for the traditional rolls as well as new and more adventurous for your palate!  No matter what you order...an explosion to your senses of fresh fish, textures, spicy, sweet, crunchy, soft, cold, and hot  will be pure goodness in your mouth!

Parking is hard in the area and not recoommended for big groups because it's small.
author: JJAMZ C.

description: its a roll kind of place - skip the sashimi plate unless you like big bad cuts of fish.  didn't try sushi.
author: Wakako U.

description: The food here is to die for. Granted that I didn't eat too much because it got pricey fast (with the way I order) but I had the Big Island, (I believe) the Hot Love, Butterfish Blasters, and the M&L forever. Chopstick-licking good! SO GOOD! And the salmon sashimi was nice and fresh as well. I have to go back and order more! It's hard to try new things when you want to order old things too!! Overall, very nice and mod restaurant, good food, and very unique dishes.
author: Sophia K.

description:
5 stars
Butterfish alone is worth the trip!

Service was excellent. Nice lady (think her name was Mel) brought us our orders fast, place was packed, got sat down fast.

Got extra napkins when we asked (always a plus)

Sushi, sake bombs, and Japanese beer makes for a wonderful time here!

Will be going many more times. Maybe 5 more times. Definitely 5 stars.
author: James S.

description: I went here with a group of friends recently and loved it! Combined our small group probably ordered over a dozen rolls, so I can't get in-depth on everything I tried. However, a stand out for me, in terms of taste and originality, was the Hawaiian Breeze, which is ahi, mango, avocado and fuji apple topped with tuna, macadamia nuts and cilantro pesto... sounds strange but it worked beautifully. Overall I was very impressed with the selection and the freshness of the food. Great spot!
author: Ryan S.

description:
UPDATE + 1 star!

I gave this a second chance and ate in the restaurant. The food was much better (although a few pieces still fell apart). The atmosphere is nice and the food came out quickly. This is in my hood so I'll definitely make this regular.

______________

The sushi wasn't bad tasting but it wasn't rolled correctly and was falling apart. This was only my first time there, though, so this may not be usual. I also ordered the food for pick up, which may have been a factor. 

I'm giving it a 3 for now because I would be willing to give it a second chance!

I ordered an avocado roll, a crunchy roll and the vegetable tempura appetizer. The rolls were actually big enough that I ended up eating the appetizer later, which was good because all in all the meal wasn't cheap. However, the presentation did throw a thorn in the whole meal especially because sushi is that much more difficult to eat if not rolled correctly.
author: Brittany N.

description: Sushi Bistro is a fun and creative sushi spot. It's always busy, but there's always space to accommodate when I head over with friends. I like to try as many different things on the menu as I can because they have such fun fusion rolls. When you're craving a good sushi night, Sushi Bistro won't do you wrong.
author: Victoria F.

description:
Sushi Bistro is an elegant and intimate place for dates, or small group of friends without being overly pricey. It's located on Balboa Ave, among a nicely hidden little strip of restaurants in the Inner Richmond.

Hamachi - they have 3 kinds! Well, try all three and do a tasting. It was hamachi heaven. Ordered it as sashimi. I found the hiramasa the best.

Poke - Wow. Best poke I've had in the city. Better than some I've had in Hawaii. The key thing I liked is that they didn't smother the maguro in sauce. It wasn't overly salty. The seasoning was light, and it came on a bed of lightly dressed salad. Perfection!

Hot Love - their own creation. If you like crustaceans, you'll love it. Tasty.

Agedashi Tofu - always a standard for me. If you like it, get it.

Wide selection of rolls. Sushi comes in nigiri or hamachi. They have multiple kinds of hamachi and maguro, as well as daily selections. Lettuce wraps, salads, rolls, teriyaki, etc. the variety was actually a bit overwhelming, including a respectable sake selection, so check out the menu before you go. 

Service was attentive, fast, and friendly. They were very thoughtful and observant, which is always nice.

Parking can be a challenge on Balboa, but not terrible. It's a very quiet street in the evenings, and on a nice night, makes for a pleasant stroll.
author: Boris C.

description: I liked the place. The only reason I gave 3 stars is because this place is FULL of kids which is very very frustrating. I want to eat and relax and I don't want kids around me. So sad but I will likely not be back only because of that. :( great meal that is ruined by screams of children.
author: Elena E.

description:
WARNING. Do not come here if you are looking for traditional sushi. It does not exist at this restaurant. The dishes are all fusion/Americanized (read: deep fried, spicy sauced, avocado-ed, mango-ed, etc.)

That aside- the service, first of all, was very good. We got cucumber salad and waters and drinks as soon as we got seated (but charging $1.50 for green tea, COME ON). Waters and teas were refilled really fast, dishes were cleared promptly. 

Second- I made a mistake in thinking that this was a trendy but traditional place. Should've read Yelp reviews first! I ordered a king salmon nigiri, negihamachi roll, salmon roll and cucumber roll. The king salmon was delicious. Negihamachi had cucumber in it...doesn't negihamachi just mean yellowtail with scallions? I could not taste the scallions, could barely taste the fish...really just had the watery taste of cucumbers on my tongue. The salmon roll (I asked for just plain salmon!) had cucumbers AND avocado in it. Didn't I ask for plain salmon? What is up with the filler? Not really impressed as the fish was fresh enough (I think?) but was SO watery and not flavorful, the rolls were poorly constructed (wtf is up with them using almost no rice?) and fell apart easily. The seaweed was soggy in the salmon roll I got. Pretty gross.

My boyfriend doesn't really do the raw fish thing but even he felt like the "unique" rolls and dishes were way overdone. Too much sauce, too much fried stuff, too much avocado, too much spicy sauce that didn't taste like anything. My two American friends (whom he shared the dishes with), however, really enjoyed their dishes (hot love, aloha 101, albacore dream, african spider, Caucasian Afro, Spicy Crunchy). So if you're looking for traditional sushi, do not come here. If you're looking for a fusion meal or to start someone off on their first sushi experience, you're probably fine.

In the end, I definitely wouldn't come back. The meal cost me about $35 tax/tip without alcohol (2 nigiri, three rolls). I'm more of a traditionalist, but even with that in mind I'd be wary of fish that is tasteless/watery and possibly unfresh. Even if you cover it up with a bunch of sauces and deep fry it, its still not worth the price tag and possible stomachache.
author: Emily H.

description: I know I have another sushi favorite in the Bay Area, but Sushi Bistro just got first place. It honestly made me forget the name of the other place we have sushi. Recently it was recommended by Michelin star. Have you ever had anything so good you cried? Well..... Yes! I teared a little. The experience is great! Staff always super friendly. We are home in SF once a year and make a point to go each time. I mean I don't even know what to say! Expect a wait if you don't make a reservation on busy nights. We have come several times in the past and nothing has changed. They have a great variety of no rice sushi plates, and not jus sashimi. Great twists on classics. Very light and clean. Only issue is parking, but it's the Richmond district.
author: Cindy T.

description: The sushi here is over priced and has too many twists from original sushi places. I prefer the traditional sushi over this. Good environment, but often too crowded.
author: Courtney G.

description: Need to update to say: my favorite sushi spot in the city.
author: S. M.

description:
NOW THIS IS WHAT I CALL GOOD SUSHI.

Simply put, everything is fresh and they have some pretty unique rolls along with all the other recognizable stuff. The pricing is not as bad as some of the other nice places, but when we had dinner here, it felt like i was in a club, i wish they would tone the music down a little. Other then that, probably one of the best sushi places in the city that is reserved for introducing San Francisco eats to friends from out of town, or a place to drink Saki with the bros from work.
author: Rio A.

description: Taste was great, however I cannot say the same about the service. Let's put it this way, I created a yelp account just to show my utter disgust with the waiters that served me. Thank you for ruining my day in San Francisco and I hope this has repercussions for the two Asian male waiters that were blatantly gossiping about customers.
author: Gabriela C.

description:
3.5 stars. CK, MY and I have our own sushi crew. We seek untried sushi restaurants in SF, at least untried among the 3 of us. Premise is that there aren't very many good sushi places to go to in SF. Sad but kinda true. So our quest began to uncover the gems of the City.

Not sure Sushi Bistro falls into this category. But if you're looking for ROLLS in an unconventionally modern, dark and hip sushi restaurant,
then this is the place for you.

Listed in order of most to least fave rolls we tried:
1. Butterfish Blasters ($13.95) snow crab and avocado wrapped in butterfish lightly torched with a garlic-soy. Based on the description I expected this dish to be hot but it wasn't. Nevertheless, the fish was soft and it was really nice to bite into the crab and avocado rather than a ball of rice.

2. Hawaiian Breeze ($11.95). Mango, avocado and slivered fuji apple topped with tuna, macadamia nuts and drizzled with cilantro pesto. Totally unexpected flavors from the cilantro and pesto but it gave a very 'fresh' aromatic taste to the sushi. Admittedly I barely tasted the tuna. I caught more of the sweetness from the mango and fuji apples. But I liked the creative use of apples. It worked well with this roll.

3. Albacore Dream  ($11.25). Spicy tuna and avocado topped with albacore, served with house special and spicy sauce. This one had a nice heat to it from the spicy tuna, but the spiciness did overpower the 
albacore, which I typically like to taste and enjoy.

4. C-2  ($12.95). Baby lobster, avocado and cucumber topped with shrimp tempura, drizzled with sweet eel sauce. The shrimp tempura stayed crunchy on top of the roll but overall had a sweet taste. I couldn't even tell I was eating lobster, which was a shame.

5. Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon  ($10.95). Shrimp tempura, avocado & cucumber, all topped with unagi and eel sauce. This one was not memorable except that it was a little too sweet especially since it tasted similar to C-2.

6. Monster in-laws  ($12.95). Spicy albacore and cucumber topped with yellowtail, jalapenos, spicy and ponzu sauce. Visually pleasing with the delicate slices of jalapenos but honestly I tasted a fish that was a bit "fishy" and so I couldn't eat any more of it.

What Sushi Bistro does well is innovative roll names, easy on the rice (awesome), and heavy on the "stuff" to roll into the sushi. I could see myself coming back w/ a group of friends so I could try more of the inventive rolls. I wouldn't recommend this place if you're a sushi purist.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Best sushi joint in the city! Very hip and an awesome place to take someone on a date. They've got a sushi bar and a regular bar where they play games on a flat-screen. Ice cold beers on tap, a huge variety of sake, and the fooood!

My top 3 rolls : Red Devil Brown Rice Roll (butterfish/spicy tuna/chili sauce), Hawaiian Breeze (mango/avocado/tuna/cilantro pesto sauce!), and The New Legend (shrimp tempura/avocado/albacore/spicy garlic soy sauce!).

Must get appetizers : Ahi Tuna Poke Special, Double Jeopardy, and Butterfish Blasters.

It can get a bit busy on the weekends, so don't forget to make reservations!
author: Charles N.

description:
A very average experience, per se. However, for being in San Francisco and at these prices, I really should label the experience here as an injustice. The Teriyaki Chicken with Tempura was laughable at best in terms of taste and presentation, being served on a plastic plate. Yes, plastic. As far as portion size is concerned, it was an absolute atrocity. The chicken breast was the thinnest sliced chicken breast that I've ever seen. It was literally about 1/4 inch thick. It was just a plain, thin slice of chicken breast with teriyaki sauce drizzled on top. Needless to say it was under seasoned. The salad was mediocre and not worth the time to type this sentence. The rice was soggy. Yes, soggy rice at an asian restaurant. This is what Asians do best, folks, COOK RICE. Please don't embarrass yourselves any further and learn how to cook rice for crying out loud. The tempura was really the only redeeming factor in this dish, but it was not anything even close to stellar. For $16.95 the owners of this establishment should be ashamed to be seen in public. 

The nigiri offerings were adequate for human consumption, but that's as far as they go. Portion size was decent and more specifically the fish was of adequate to above average in size. It was sufficiently fresh and edible, but lacked flavor and refinement. However, the rice was utterly sub-par. I am left wondering if the rice even had any vinegar in it. The consistency was soggy and it had absolutely no flavor. The rice is not just an afterthought in sushi and isn't there just to have somewhere to lay the fish on, it is part of the dish and warrants just as much attention and execution as the preparation of the fish.
author: Aldo S.

description:
I'll start off by admitting that I had dinner here with a friend who swears by it... otherwise I never would have ventured in (Apparently this is a really bizarre characteristic, but I am not a sushi lover). I also happen to be vegetarian, and the limited veggie options at most sushi places generally fail to impress.

But I agreed to try it, and I have to give humble props to Sushi Bistro for the fan-freakin-tastic Crunchy Veggie rolls. I could not put my chopsticks down the entire meal... I don't even care that SB is totally overpriced because I actually enjoyed my food! Of course, I'm not running back... but at least I know I can eat something here.

3 stars on the basis that I've really only tried ONE thing. I assume it's good because it's always packed (and LOUD!), the interior is fun and modern, and it somehow remains a go-to dinner location among friends.
author: Sam S.

description:
A few friends and I were in the mood for some sushi and decided to check out sushi bistro based on the yelp reviews. We decided to share everything family style so we tried a lot.

First off, we started with a few orders of toro sashimi (special of the day). It had a great texture and good flavor. Definitely recommend it. The ahi tower was delicious. 6 slices of seared ahi on top of grilled cucumbers and asparagus. Highly recommend it! One of the rolls I'd  recommend would be the butterfish blasters. So much flavor and so delicious! You definitely need to give it a try. If youre into sashimi, the 12 piece $20 sashimi dinner was great. Good assortment of fish. Tasted fresh and had great flavors.

If you're in the area or are in the mood for some good sushi, stop by and eat at sushi bistro!
author: Robert S.

description:
There was a time when Sushi Bistro was our favorite sushi place in the Richmond district. A time where "neighborhood restaurant" meant something. A time when the sushi chef and wait staff would know your name. A time when you could get a true Japanese experience, be it from a Chinese Sushi chef and owner. A time that has come and gone.

The old Sushi Bistro has now been replaced by the new. A new clientele, that is young and hip, that desire the loud blaring music and dimly lit tables. Early reviews of the Sushi Bistro long ago would mention that the long wait for food was made up by the creativity of dishes and freshness of fish. I can only imagine the wait time with the new hipster packed restaurant. I say something has to give, and unfortunately, it is the quality of food. There is no way Sushi Bistro could meet the high quality that it once had and crank out the number of plates to meet demand. However, if the diners didn't know any better, then I guess it doesn't matter anyway.

I'm sad to post this, especially since we had been going to Sushi Bistro for over 6 years straight. Sushi Bistro has gotten too big for its own good, a dilemma that happens to a lot of restaurants. They are so good when they are small and quaint. But when they expand, the quality goes down and they lose their charm. Thank you Sushi Bistro for the 'good ole days', maybe we'll wave as we walk on by..
author: Mark M.

description: came here with 2 friends on a Fri because Tekka had a line for more than 10 ppl already at 540p!  So we got seated early at Sushi Bistro. I came here a long time ago, probably a few years ago and as I recall, it was pretty good. But this time, it was horrible. Service is okay, not great. Prices are high. We ordered one Sashimi combo-15 pices for $30! And on top of that, the sashimi was sliced so dam thin!  Ordered one of the brown rice rolls, mostly rice inside and out.  Ah, the Hamachi kamma- Dry and tasteless!  never again coming back here. WE ordered 2 rolls, 1 hamachi kamma, 1 sashimi combo (15 slices), 2 hot saki- total bill was about $100.
author: Alyce l.

description:
I started regularly going to Sushi Bistro about five or six years ago when it was at its old location down the street.  Frankly, this is the sushi restaurant that I rank all other sushi restaurants against. 

The fish is fresh, the rolls are creative (and too numerous to mention) and the chef is in a class of his own.  He may not be Japanese, but how can you knock a sushi chef that regularly competes in sushi making competitions across the state and wins! This drive for continuous improvement is what makes the food shine. 

Over the past few years, Sushi Bistro has received tons of critical acclaim and has ballooned in popularity.  The wait can be long and, to be honest, I sometimes miss the homey feel of the tiny old location.  It may eventually become a victim of its own success, but I'll still be going there, god-willing.
author: Bobby L.

description:
Only reason they don't get five stars is the bar. Beer WIne only!

Food was amazing. I think the best sushi Ive' had. We ate rolls that were really good.

The best stuff was not the rolls though. We had YT ( Yellow Tail ) with Jalapeno and lemon. Sashimi style that was off the hook

Also the Poke with fried potato vermicelli and salad was very very good.

When in SF we will make the trip for sure. Its a small place we got there lat after 9pm. I would say reservation would be a good idea.
author: Henry W.

description:
OMG!!!! I wanted to order the entire menu!!!!!! The quality of their seafood is excellent and fresh, delicious and unusual cominations of flavors for their rolls......I just moved to the neighborhood and this will most def be one of my new favs :)

yummmmmmmmmmmm.....can't wait to go back!
author: Nivliness S.

description:
Ok - this is by far my favorite sushi both because of the food and also the people.  Dave and his Mom are awesome.  Super friendly and helpful and always with a smile.  The place has grown super popular over the last couple years but they remain super nice and the food is as good as ever.

I especially like the private room in the back - great for parties of 15-20 and economical good time.

keep it up!
author: Noah W.

description: Excellent service! Excellent rice to filling ratio! Lettuce wraps to die for!!! Excellent house nigori! Reggae music in heavy rotation. Great ambiance! sake bar!!! What else can u ask for!?! *parking hard to find but worth it!!!
author: Irie H.

description:
Normally I'm pretty skeptical of any sushi place as it seems like sushi is something can easily be done bad... or well.

Thankfully the ol' SB does it well.  

Be forewarned this is a place for rolls.  If you're big on nigiri or sashimi you may want to check out somewhere different, which isn't to say these can't be had here but it would understate the beautiful plumage of the peacock that is the Sushi Bistro; it's awesome rolls.   The menu is extensive with it's roll selections with ingredients from your favorite fish to jalapenos to asparagus to brown rice rolls even.  The first two pages are just SB's creation while they have a small section on the back dedicated to "classics" (caterpillar, rainbow, etc).  First Crush and Nemo Found were delicious.

The selection can be intimidating and make your head spin but if you're like me, you'll just go down the list and come back until you've tried 'em all.
author: Steven R.

description:
Mmmmm, mmmmm, mmmmm, mmmmm.

Still fantastic.  Are at Sushi Bistro last night and found the "bistro" as wonderful as always.  I was actually surprised I hadn't reviewed it earlier.

My review: go!  

If I could, I would eat here multiple times a week.  Fish is fresh, the portions are large and the saki is flowing.  A true winner.
author: David A.

description:
My friend had a reservation for her birthday party here for ten people at 8:30 pm on a Saturday night.  We weren't seated until 9:30, and barely got served before the kitchen started closing. 

They were torturing us with bland, crappy ska and reggae music all night.

Oddly enough, the best dishes by far were both baked -- the Volcano: baked salmon with spicy aioli, crabmeat and avocado, and the Rock'n roll: baked spicy scallops served on top of a California roll.
author: Adam Z.

description:
This place has a great staff and great rolls.  I keep getting waited on by the same waitress and every time I am pleasantly surprised with the stand-out service!  

The only thing I'd warn is that it can get busy...  (but that's a good thing, right?)
author: Seton B.

description:
A bit pricy, yes, but totally worth every delicious penny.  I have personally witnessed people from all parts of the globe evolve from sushi skeptics into sushi lovers, all thanks to Sushi Bistro.  Once I even got paid for some gardening work in a gift card to Sushi Bistro. That's how much I love it. Great sushi. Friendly service. 'nuff said. 

Tip: If you are looking for a cheaper option try the crunchy veggie roll. It's aMAAAZIng.
author: Mel H.

description:
I'm giving this place 4 stars because the sushi here is amazingly different. Here's why:

-The menu is divided into veggie, meat and speciality rolls. There are a good selection of appetisers 

-The food really was delicious, and definitely played around with the 'sushi' label. Some rolls contained no rice and came wrapped in crunchy fresh cucumber rather than nori. Others were more normal.

-The servers are prompt and friendly but not overly zealous / ott (something i hate) 

-Fresh! 

-The hot food menu seemed really out of place but i guess was there to entertain those who didn't fancy sushi

-As much as i love 'sushi experience' places like this, i do wish they had a more normal selection like plain jane maki...but then again i doubt off menu orders would cause any fuss.
author: Rachel G.

description:
This is a pretty chill place with really good sushi.  I wasn't in the mood for raw fish this weekend so I ordered a crunchy roll - shrimp tempura, avocado, and eel sauce - and I have to say, it was my favorite un-raw sushi roll ever.

I like the shadowy atmosphere; the tables are pretty intimate, but still large enough to hold all your orders unlike some places where the sushi, sake, and empty plates are spilling off the table.  I had trouble finding parking on Balboa and in the surrounding area, but I would totally come back to Sushi Bistro with friends, just to eat the crunchy roll again.  Although, next time I might be more adventurous and try the delicious-looking sashimi.
author: Laura W.

description:
I can't believe there are reviews on here that are less than 5 stars - I think those folks must have gone to a different sushi restaurant.

Sushi Bistro has the best sushi in San Francisco - I love to take my friends here who are both local and from out of town - everyone LOVES it.  

The service is exceptional and the sushi is fresh and delicious!!  To top it off, it is owned by a family who lives right here in the neighborhood.

Fun bonus - if you go on a semi regular basis and drink sake - they give you your own sake box to decorate/use when you are there.  Delightful!

Love. Love. Love. Sushi Bistro.
author: Becca R.

description: Excellent service, cozy place, and best of all... everything is fresh with great flavors! Must get: Albacore Belly, Yellowtail Fritatta, Grilled whole squid, Yellowtail Jalepeno, Shima Aji (mackerel/yellowtail), Big Eye Tuna sashimi, Kanpachi (amberjack) Nigiri. Their Sweet Shrimp (Amebi Nigiri) was delicious (even the crunchy head part)! Nice thing is, they are very generous with their sashimi slices. Can't wait to try other things on their menu next time. Tip: If you like really strong wasabi, they have it!
author: Samantha C.

description:
My husband and I are Sushi snobs, we have spent time in Japan and have tried many of the great sushi places all around the Bay Area. This is a real favorite of mine!

You can't go wrong here, the rolls are my favorite and you can't complain about the prices. It's in my neighborhood so I love the convenience but it's well worth taking a trip out of your way for a meal here.
author: Katy S.

description: Honestly, this place has some of the best sashimi I've had in SF. I am really really picky with sashimi and if it's even the slightest bit fishy or slimy I will barf it up right on my plate in front of you. The 12 piece sashimi sampler, miso soup, house salad and red devil roll are my mainstays!
author: Carly T.

description:
It's a sunday night and I just landed in SF and have a hankerin' for some sushi to pick up on the way home. This place is not far from home and since Rumble Fish was closed I thought I would give it a try. I ordered the yellowtail nigiri, negihama, snow crab cut roll, amongst other things. I was very disappointed.

My BF and I eat quite a bit of sushi and we are both huge yellowtail fans. Let me tell ya.....the "yellowtail" we had from here was NOT yellowtail. Instead they tried to trick us with white tuna. SO NOT COOL. If we were dining in we would have sent it back instead of eating it at home and feeling duped. 

Also, the yellowtail in the negihama was pretty crappy because first off, it wasn't yellowtail, but white tuna. Also, it was also crammed with tons of cucumber. It totally overpowered everything so I felt like I was just eating a cucumber roll.

All-in-all....the sushi was sub-par. Just meh. The only thing that was really good was the snow crab roll which is just snow crab and avocado. At least I had that to fall back on after being disappointed with the other sushi I had.
author: Malisha J.

description:
For starters,  their miso soup was quite outstanding by itself. It has a "richness" as a result of high concentration of soybean material inside. I think it  may be the first time that way about a Japanese restaurant's miso soup which comes with an order.

I ordered the Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon  for the dinner .  The fish was very yummy and fresh.  The serving was good, 12 pieces of fish and two tamago (cooked egg) pieces, along with bits of tobiko (fish roe) and mushrooms. Also, I always order sushi and I like to analyze their sushi rice. The amount of vinegar they put in makes the  taste right, making the rice (oilse)  tasty also.

Definitely wouldn't mind coming back and possibly see what their Sushi Bistro is like.  At least I should remember how good I felt their miso soup and the sushi rice were and hope it's like that again.
author: Randal M.

description:
Great sushi. Had the C2 roll, an afrikan spider (my fav) and a few others. 

The fish was fresh. Had some nigiri with salmon, blue fin toro, butter fish, and unagi. I wish I had some uni, that's typically my litmus test for sushi restaurants. Sushi Ota down in San diego has, hands-down, the best sushi in California. All the nigiri was tasty (and no I don't drench my sushi in wasabi/soy sauce mortar sauce) - not chewy or stringy. 

They have a decent sake selection - hot, cold, and unfiltered. The sushi bistro in the richmond is definitely the better of the two (been to both). 

Will only take 2 credit cards per table, FYI.
author: David N.

description:
Pretty bad experience. We sat at the bar and actually weren't even intending on eating at this place. We were in the area trying to go to another restaurant where the owners had shut down to go on vacation. I used the Blackberry to search for a good spot and this one came up highly reviewed.

The sushi wasn't fresh and was flavorless. We tried 3 rolls (2 Something Uniques) and 1 bistro salad. I went here a couple months ago and forgot everything we ordered, but I remember that the serving sizes were so small we had to order 2 more rolls to not really even be full. Also, they forgot one of our dishes and didn't apologize. I'm really confused by the current reviews about this place, but it was over priced and over hyped.

On the slim positive note, the restaurant was nicely decorated and there was a good vibe. Our bartender/waiter guy was attentive and provided good service.
author: Katherine F.

description:
One of the best places to eat sushi in the inner richmond. I eat here pretty often and they have really good sushi rolls! 

Crunchy Roll & Veggie Crunch Roll- A M A Z  I N G 
Billie Jean- Great if you're a crab fan, but it's not my favorite 
Agedashi tofu- nothing special, it's okay 
Beef Teriyaki Set- Really tasty and great when you're starving 

 I love the aura of their restaurant. they have dim lights, great for a date! 
It's a bit crowded during late dinner hours so come a bit early to guarantee a spot. It's a little bit pricey, but worth to try if you're craving for some sushi!
author: Tessa A.

description:
We brought some friends here to try out Sushi Bistro and can't say it's the best Sushi SF has to offer. One of the draws for me was the large selection of vegetarian rolls, however, none of them were really good. (My fish eating friends weren't that impressed by what they ordered either, other than the spicy crunchy roll).  

I tried the crunchy veggie roll  ($8.95) which is made up of lightly deep fried vegetables with crunchy tempura batter outside, drizzled with sweet sauce. The vegetables in this roll were basically just yams and avocados. It had a strange taste of Thanksgiving as my friend pointed out. Disappointed, I pawned my veggie rolls off on the others and I opted for another veggie roll - the tuscan roll ($8.50) which was made up of avocado and sun-dried tomatoes wrapped in seaweed, flash fried, and served with sweet and spicy sauce. Another disappointment. As much as I love sun-dried tomatoes, they do not belong in a sushi roll. Furthermore, their sweet and spicy sauce belonged on chicken, not sushi. 

Bottom line, with good company, mediocre food doesn't really matter but I was disappointed in Sushi Bistro and think SF has much better sushi to offer. Their sushi is definitely innovative, they have good service, and a few large screen TVs with sports and music. So if you do opt to come here I'd go with ordering something super basic e.g., avocado hand roll, otherwise you'll probably be disappointed if you're looking for traditional sushi.
author: H T.

description:
Sushi Bistro is one of those trendy sushi restaurants which means unique rolls and good presentation, but it also means pricey small portions. I mean, you can get a roll for under 10 bucks, but you will not be full from it, at least a fatty like me wouldn't. Nonetheless it's all still very tasty. I had the Volcano roll (baked salmon with spicy sauce on top) and it was delicious. I had asked the waiter beforehand if it was filling, and he informed me it was because of the creamy sauce it came in. It's okay though, it's not his fault. He just doesn't know how much I can pack in. I also got to sample the Sexy Scallop which was yummy, Five Wishes, and Aloha 101. I wasn't a fan of that one 'cause I'm not the type of eater that likes to mix fruit with savory foods. 

I would like to come back here and possibly order two rolls next time when I remember to bring more cash.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Sushi Bistro is a cute little place to hang out.  

The sushi however, was just ok.  I had the "Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon Roll," which is a roll with sushi tempura toppped with eel.  The shrimp was sub-par, a little fishy tasting.  My sister had the rock 'n roll roll which was more wierd than rockin.  It was topped with some kind of cream like substance.  Not really recommended. 

The atmosphere was nice though, and will probably be the thing that brings me back.  The rolls were large, so I guess the value was alright, except for the fact that the sushi wasn't the best ever.
author: Alison L.

description: One of my favorites. Doesn't have the extensive sushi roll menu as some other sushi places do but they sure know how to make sushi. I love their rolls with mango and jalapeno. Their tuna appetizers are great and this time we had the veggie potstickers which were delicious. We didn't feel rushed and got to take our time eating and talking. I don't live nearby anymore but whenever I'm in the area, I know I'll be back.
author: Rachel F.

description: One of the best sushi places in SF. Another one of Richmond Districts hidden gems of SF. Its a go to place, and always at the top of the list when decided were to get sushi on a friday / saturday night. But honestly I liked it when it was next door in the location that was half the size. It was more intimate and personable. Still food is awesome!
author: Andrey P.

description:
HOLY SUSHI!!!!!

THis place is BOMB omg ... the menu.... how do you choose??????

Ordered: the Hot Love, Five Wonders, and Hawaiian Breeze
House Sake was good :))) .... but the food was so incredibly it killed any buzz we had going. Oh and they also give huge glasses of water!

Hot Love: such a good name, i won't say anything else
Five Wishes: Like a rainbow roll sans rice... even better! HUGE slices of sashimi on top, almost like ordered plain sushi, but getting it on top of surimi (imitation crab) instead of rice... hmm, what a novel idea! :)
Hawaiian Breeze: wonderful unique combination of fruits, fish, and nuts... like a cosmopolitan sushi roll!

50 bucks for 3 items, large sake, and tip... ain't bad for that incredible experience!... it's just really sad when it ends
author: Sofia J.

description:
what's the most important thing that people care about in a japanese/sushi restaurant?  FRESHNESS!!   (or at least that's my top concern) This is one of my fav. sushi restaurant in SF!  They have lots of CREATIVE/UNIQUE ROLLS that will give you a hard time choosing! They have brown rice rolls, which i haven't tried yet.  Their appetizers are all very interesting + the nigiri/sashimi are very FRESH too!  some people complain about the amount of rice they put on the nigiri, and i do think so too, but it doesnt really matter to me. 


Whether you like raw fish or rolls, this place got it all,  I have no complain about this place beside that it does get a little too loud and parking sucks ( i like vip parkings) but you can find parkings easily within 2 blocks (geary st). 

P.S. what i noticed about their rolls are almost every single one are somewhat spicy (spicy garlic sauce, spicy sauce, spicy tuna..etc)  but the funny thing is, its not spicy..
author: Anna W.

description:
When it comes to Sushi, it's really hard to answer "Where's a sushi place to eat?" This place had a lot to choose from, however, the quality of it was OKAY. Not sure if it was because it was late night, but the service was sub-par. 

Don't think I will return - I'm sure there are other sushi places in my beloved city by the bay. Katana-Ya is still a winner in my book!
author: Thao L.

description:
4.5* Monster in-laws
5* Baby Lobster
3.5* Beef Udon Noodle Soup
4.5* Y.T. jalapeno
author: Aaron L.

description:
My friend and I decided to go here after being told they had really good food.  I'm pretty picky about Japanese food and this restaurant just did not meet my expectations.  

I started with the miso soup and rice, which tasted fine but the tempura and gyoza that followed weren't as good.  The tempura was oily and heavy and the gyoza pi was too thick for my liking.  

Following that we got the tempura roll, which was good, but not spectacular.  

Service was good, our waiter was friendly, but it wasn't enough to make me want to return.
author: Marisa R.

description:
My bf surprised me and took me here for my birthday. He had made reservations yet when we told them they asked us if we would like to sit at the bar. If we wanted the bar why would we have made reservations? Anyways, we told them we wanted a table so they pulled apart a two-table arrangement into a one table. Perhaps a larger party had also made reservations and since the restaurant is pretty small they decided to give them the table. Ok.

I noticed that the waiters all worked together to tend to us during our meal. We may have had one main server but different people came around to give us our food and such so service was pretty quick. What else that was different was that they gave us each of our dishes as they were made rather than having all the different rolls on one plate. 

Here's what we ordered in the order of what I enjoyed the most: 
albacore dream   11.25
shitake veggie roll     8.95
crouching tiger hidden dragon   10.95
yellowtail basil   7.95

I really enjoyed the albacore dream. It was a little spicy but it was very good. The shitake veggie roll I liked too. The interesting thing is that it was made with brown rice. That was my first and it was good! They have a list of sushi rolls made with brown rice which I think is cool. What I like about the crouching tiger hidden dragon was that it was soft and seemed to just fall apart in your mouth but I also felt it was not as tasty as other shrimp tempera rolls that I've had before. I liked the yellowtail basil the least. I should have looked more closely and saw that it was deep fried because it was not good to me because of that. 

I did not notice that night but looking back on their menu I saw that they have chirashi for $16. So I'll have to try that next time.
author: Helen L.

description: Went here with my roommate who raved about this place all the time. Too bad I was very dissapointed. The service was really not that good (the cooks in the back were really nice though) and it's kind of pricey to get sushi. There are so many other places in SF and in the South Bay that are way tastier and better deals. I'm not coming back.
author: Irina L.

description:
I just remembered, I met up with some friends here last night after attending a fashion show event. After seeing skinny ass 6'2 models, I wasn't that keen on eating even though I've heard rave reviews about this place.  I was completely in "i'm never going to eat until i lose 20 lbs mode" and muttered that I'm just going to order a salad. 

My friend gave me a death stare and said, wth would you order a salad here! 

She was right, I ordered some rolls, the aoli sauce is excellent and I love how they add scallions in the sushis. Very creative indeed. I'm glad I ate the sushi and I learned that I have no will power to be skinny.

Excellent food, service, and overall casual trendy ambiance.
author: Kev C.

description:
Have I been here before?  Maybe twice before?  Geez, I don't remember and I guess that doesn't say much for this place.

But I came here with my BF for our first time together.  The restaurant decor is modern and fun.  The staff is nice and they have a lot of bar seating where I usually don't mind sitting at.  We went with Yelp recommendations and got the Hot Love, Magic Mushroom, some Hamachi Nigiri, and the Volcano roll.

They are definitely good at making very creative rolls.  Everything was delicious but rich tasting.  If you want something more traditional go somewhere else.  I didn't need to use my soy sauce, wasabi concoction once, which kinda made me sad.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
I went here last weekend. I'm a huge sushi fan and this place has some really amazing sushi!! 

Everything was fresh and delicious. My favorite was the "hot love" which is baby lobster rolled in snapper. SO GOOD! The service was a bit slow but we went on a very busy Saturday night, so perhaps that is why.
author: Shabneez M.

description:
I found this place via Yelp, since it was 4 stars with almost 1000 raving reviews. I really like the ambience of the restaurant. Fast paced, good service, neat, tidy, quick. The waiters work like ninjas!  Good place to bring your romantic date too. Now on to the food:

We ordered the Butterfish Blasters. A little bit pricey. Something about the name Sushi Bistro should've gave me the hint that there's a bit of american flare in this sushi. While the fish was good, I thought the dish was overly drenched in sauces/ mayo/ fatty butter, wutever it is. It tasted good for a bit, then it started tasting like i'm putting mayo in my mouth. Why is it so buttery????

Secondly we ordered the role with albacore. It was okay. I wasn't jumping out of my seat for it. again- very heavy with the sauces. Sometimes I feel like the sauces is over powering the fresh meat.

Now the winner, butterfish nigri. I agree with some other posters, perhaps try ordering just their fish to avoid all the heavy sauces, creamy, and fat. I thought the nigri was spot on. Nice huge thick slices, fresh, sweet, just the way butterfish is supposed to taste. Now I like. I might just come back for some beers and add some nigri on the side. 

Parking may be difficult. accepts reservation.
author: Juan C.

description:
I have this new thing where I'm trying a different sushi restaurant once a week and because one of my good friends live near, we picked Sushi Bistro as our first place.

It was kind of crowded when we first got there but were seated very quikly.  Drinks arrived promptly and our servers were very attentive and took our orders and the sushi came pretty fast.

We were trying two unique rolls and two traditional rolls but all the fish tasted very fatty that night.  Not sure if it was that batch of fish or if it's like that all the time but we were not happy with the rolls.

While the food was ok at best, the service was second to none and we left a 20% tip.  The staff there really got an extra star from me.  I may go back and give it a second chance because of that but overall the sushi was a little overpriced for what it was.
author: Steve P.

description: Love this place. Wish they were open for lunch too! My favorite is the 49er roll with lemon, salmon, and avocado. I'm lucky to have this place in my neighborhood, because its the type of restaurant I would drive across the city for!
author: Katja L.

description:
Is this place worth the price?
Definitely not...

Why?
I've had better and for much cheaper.  It's like a bottle of wine.  Not all great wines have to be expensive.  You just need to pick the right ones.

My experience...

We walked in.  It seemed more like this place was a bar, and the sushi is just to make a little extra on there side.  Even there menu said it.  The cover page was the list of types of drinks!  There sushi bar was all the way in the back corner.  And the bar is right there when you walk in.  So this shouldn't be listed as sushi bar on yelp... It should be called bar sushi.  I guess if you drink, the sushi might taste a little better.

Taste...

Sashimi Spirit - I was expecting more fish less filling.  That's what sashimi is...  More fish nothing else!  I was disappointed on this when the roll came out.  And the flavors really didn't pop much in my mouth.

Sexy Scallop - It wasn't sexy at all.  How can it be sexy when the scallops are frozen(sure tasted that way)...  This one stayed in my head just because it was frozen...  

Not sure what the last roll was, but this tasted like the other two rolls...  I'm not sure what they did, but the flavors tasted very similar.  I'm not sure if it's the sauce they use, but it was bled.  The only difference that the Scallop Roll tasted like it was frozen...

Moving on, Ahi Tuna Poke Salad - This was much better than the rolls and for a good price.  They gave gave you a mountain of Tuna!  And the dressing that they used on the salad was not that bad.  This is probably something that is a must try for you tuna lovers.  Fried crispy noodles layered on to of mixed greens topped with a mountain of tuna!

Tuna Belly! - That's what the whole rave was about.  Melting in your mouth.  But it did leave behind a layer of fat on my tongue.  

And then comes the service...  If you are working at the restaurant and you see a couple together.  What do you do?  Hit on the opposing sex?  No, but that's what my fking waiter was trying to do.  Should've left his ass no tip...  Yes, if you want someone that is serving you to hit on your lady, bring her here.

And this was after a good day at the CAS Nightlife...  Which is pretty much down the street...
author: Phung N.

description:
I came here recently with a friend when we had finally conquered a couple of epic hangovers and were able keep down some food. This isn't especially relevant to the review except I'm trying to convey that we were not looking for a special dining experience, just that we were really hungry and sushi was what we wanted for dinner. 

We chose this place because of the proximity to J's apartment. When we stepped in I was really surprised by how dark it was, and that this unassuming sushi spot was actually a lot nicer than you would think. I immediately felt self-conscious in my scrubby attire as I surveyed the nicely dressed clientele. We were already feeling like a couple of degenerates, it did not help to be cocooned in an atmosphere of intimate maybe-on-your-second date/girls dinner out. (That said, this could be a great place for a date!) Had I been prepared for this I wouldn't have felt so caught off guard.

The service was really fantastic. Prompt, courteous, etc etc. Couldn't have asked for anything better.

The reason why I am giving this place only 3 stars, even though their food is good? Because when I go out for sushi, it's because I freakin' want raw fish. Raw. Fish. That's it.
