Sashimi combo (12 pieces) - The fish definitely did not seem fresh and tasteless.  But the pieces were HUGH.  It took me at least three bits to finish one piece.  I think if the fish is fresh, I don't mind the piece is smaller.

Then we ordered some of the dishes from their "Something Unique" section:

1.  Double Jeopardy - Chopped Jeopardy - Chopped Salmon, Albacore & Avocado served spicy sauce
2.  Hot Love - Baby Lobster, Avocado and crab meant rolled in Snapper and baked with special sweet sauce
3.  Butterfish Blasters - Crab Meat and avocado wrapped in Butterfish with soy sauce
4.  Spicy Girl - Avocado wrapped with spicy White Tuna, Macadamia nut served on sauce
5.  YT Jalapeños - Slices of Yellowtail topped with Jalapenos and Lemon Juice
6.  Scallop Supreme - Seared Scallop served with Edamame Sauce

**The presentation of the dishes were all nice but they were all tasted the so-so, nothing was special.  I don't recommend any dishes from here.

Since we wanted some rice so we ordered some Nigiri Sushi and a roll, we ordered Hamachi, Uni, Salmon and Couching Tiger and Hiding Dragon Roll.  Again the fish did not seem fresh and the piece was HUGH on top of the tiny rice.  Actually I should not complain with that but I think the proportation of the rice and the cut of the fish should be well balance.  It was just too off here!  The CTHD roll was actually Dragon Roll.  The rice was too sticky (too much water) and too much sauce, nothing special on this one! again.  

Another thing that made me dislike the place was the service.  In the beginning, the service was pretty good.  Fast and Friendly.  But later we felt like they were trying to rush us out to give our table to the next group.  They even gave us the bill while we were waiting our last dish...................
author: Liza T.

description:
I've since come back here, and now it IS Americanized cheese-on-your-rolls crap.

Sad.
author: Eugene F.

description: One of my favorite sushi places I've ever tried, but I hate that it's so far away from me! All three times I've visited I've enjoyed incredible fresh fish and I love that they have some very simple rolls as I'm not a fan of tempura or cream cheese in my sushi; in my opinion the cream cheese and crunchy things are way to disguise disgusting fish. I also love the cucumber they serve prior to your meal and the staff is incredibly friendly as well!
author: Natalie M.

description: The service at this place is outstanding and the quality of the fish is very high. Only complaint is that it's pretty noisy. However, I'll definitely recommend it and visit again.
author: Christian Lind H.

description:
I must say that I was surprised.  At the look of the place it would seem like a very upbeat modern looking sushi restaurant, that doesn't smell authentic at all.  But I was surprised.

We had ordered the Agedashi Tofu and Butterfish Blasters to start.  The tofu was okay, I've had better.  The Butterfish Blasters were great.  I highly recommend these.  As our main rolls we had the African spider (just a tad too spicy), Big Island (which was good a slightly different twist as it was wrapped in the cucumber), and the Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon (just like any other dragon roll).  It surpassed my expectations but they weren't too great to begin with.  In terms of pricing it was too bad.  I would probably come back if parking in the area ever gets any better!
author: Clifford C.

description:
I enjoy Sushi Bistro for the delicious sashimi and the reasonable price.  I've recommended the place to all my SF friends shortly after discovering it.  (Better value for freshness only comes in Vancouver).

They have fancy rolls here which people seem to like but for me, I much prefer the sashimi.  I really enjoyed the ocean trout sashimi - it tastes like salmon but way better!  Salmon, Yellowfin, Saba were awesome too.
author: Thu N.

description: I remember coming here, ordering a buncha rolls, and sharing a bento box and I was still hungry! Yea it's a bit on the pricy side....not really worth it to me though.
author: Diane L.

description: Fancy and creative names for sushi. Has almost a club like ambience to it. Gets packed towards the end of the week. Parking is horrible unless you live in the area (like I do!) so, it's like a hop-skip-jump away. I am a fan of their lettuce wraps and their spicy tuna handrolls. It's just too pricy for rolls that aren't that great. Portions are big, though. So, that's a good thing.
author: Shall P.

description:
I decided to get dinner here with my family while visiting SF since we've been wanting sushi for the longest time. I found this restaurant on Yelp based on its rating and high number of reviews because it must be super good if a thousand people gave the restaurant an average of four stars right?

To be honest, I was a bit disappointed when we got our food. We ordered 4 different rolls: Albacore Dream, Aloha 101, Hawaiian Breeze, and M&I Forever. My favorite of the four is the Albacore Dream mostly because of the spicy tuna, albacore, and sauce. The Aloha 101 came with six pieces and a dipping sauce. I wasn't much of a fan of the slightly fried outside of the roll, so I thought this roll was just okay and that there was not much flavor to it even with the dipping sauce. The Hawaiian Breeze was quite interesting as it contains three types of fruits (mango, Fuji apple, avocado) with tuna and some kind of sauce. What was unique about this roll was that there were also macadamia nuts on top, but I guess I was not used to all these different flavors combined together. The M&I Forever had much more tuna, crab, and albacore, but the crispy exterior made me tired of the taste quite easily and the pieces were not that big.

Normally at other sushi restaurants we have been to back home, four rolls of sushi are enough to feed the whole family because we are a family of skinny people. Unfortunately, we left the restaurant feeling just content and could still eat more. The prices are a bit pricy for somewhat smaller rolls compared to what we are used to. I think we finished our meal in like half an hour and wandered through SF looking for desserts and snacks to fill the remaining space in our tummies. 

Unlike the majority, we were not quite satisfied with our experience food wise. As for service, it is actually really fast and friendly! Maybe we ordered the wrong thing? I guess this restaurant unfortunately isn't our cup of tea. (We actually got tea afterwards. Teehee. Get it? Not our cup of tea, so we went to get actual tea. Okay, I'll be quiet now)
author: Julia N.

description:
Change of locations appears, for the most part, to be a good thing for this neighborhood favorite.  

Likes: 
- Bigger capacity (meaning not only more seating, but also less fried food stench)
- Nicer bathrooms (no amount of cleaning can really make an old place look clean)

Dislikes:
- Cold inside
- Hard surfaced interior makes for a giant amplification system, rendering conversation between one's dinner companion(s) a veritable NBA coaches' shout-off

Consistent goodness:
- Excellent sashimi (Hamachi remains my favorite)
- Weird and interesting rolls, mostly fantastic, though on my recent visit I wasn't a huge fan of the Five Wishes (sneaking suspicion that the crab was mixed with devil cum, you know, mayonnaise. Blech)
- Decent selection of sake, insofar as my untrained Western tongue can discern - which may not be very far at all
- Oh, and a new favorite appetizer: the Black & White (Silken tofu + unagi wrapped in seaweed and flash-fried . . . melts in my mouth)

Parting thoughts:
- Make reservations during prime dinner time (regardless of day of week)
- Does anyone know which is more authentic: giant cuts of sashimi, or delicate wisps?  I've heard arguments from both sides.  Personally, I don't really care much, as long as the fish tastes good.  But there certainly is a lot of poo-pooing from both sides of the matter, including frequent star reductions one way or the other.  For the record, this place serves the largest slices of sashimi I've ever seen.

Do not fear change.
author: Ravena F.

description: This place definitely changed alot food wise.  Seems like a major improvement.  I enjoyed the rolls and nigiris.  Great service new faces.  WIll be coming back soon!
author: Demanding T.

description:
Okay... for you die hard "sushi" fans who like the quality of the fish and hates it when people say they LOVE sushi.. then order a California Roll.... this is not the place for you....

I love a good experience, and I also love good quality sushi... but here at Sushi Bistro, my feelings of the restaurant encompass the following ideas:

Fun and Upbeat Atmosphere, Mid-20s Crowd, Creative Dishes and "Rolls" (note that I didn't say sushi Or sashimi)

I came here and ordered all rolls and I was satisfied with my experience because everything tasted different and unique, the crowds that surrounded us were all around the same age and it wasn't all the "typical rolls" i.e. Rainbow, Caterpillar, etc (although they do have those too) We had this one riceless roll with butterfish (yum) and it's been so long that I honestly don't remember the names of the other ones.. haha sorry. :(

I would definitely come back to this restaurant (esp. now that they moved a few doors down to a bigger spot)-- it's pretty loud here too.. so if you're trying to have an intimate meal, this isn't the joint for you.. better to bring your buddies!
author: Kristina L.

description: Good solid sushi and scores extra points for brown rice sushi. Flexible and will customize your order. Only down fall is the wait if you don't have reservations.
author: Christina F.

description:
Yummy and amazing sushi in a really cute neighborhood restaurant.  

I wish it was closer to my house!
author: Denise B.

description:
I hate sushi with too much rice.
I hate sushi when it lacks taste or texture.
I hate sushi that is smothered in some kind of creamy sauce or another.
I hate sashimi when it's not fresh or been frozen too long.
I hate sashimi when it's poorly cut.
I hate sashimi that are sliced teeny tiny.

I love snow crab in my California rolls.
I love when the fish is the highlight of its roll.
I love large, beautifully sliced sashimi.
I love sushi that hold none of the properties on the list above.
I love Sushi Bistro

Each visit has been an awesome experience. The wait can be long, but avoid dinner time and you'll be alright. The staff works hard at keeping a steady and efficient flow of food, service, and turnover without being pushy, overbearing, or neglectful. Everything is uniquely presented and the quality of their ingredients are definitely transparent in its taste. 

Great tasting and smart crafted rolls; fresh, generous slabs of sashimi; comfortable, yet fun atmosphere; all moderately priced for quality of this caliber.
author: Deanna T.

description:
If you are craving for sushi, head over to the Balboa Street in the Richmond district in San Francisco.  Here, you'll have numerous sushi venues to choose from.  But we decided on Sushi Bistro because it was the only one with people waiting outside which piqued our interest.  We were seated right away because we had a small party.  I'm not sure if they take reservations because they get very busy and seating is limited.  

However, they do turn over their tables quickly.  It's almost like a fast food sit down restaurant.  We ate our meal and left within 30-45 minutes.  If you're looking for a place to chat while nibbling on food, this is not the place for you.  It's way too compact and narrow, the tv/radio is fairly loud as are the patrons.

But their is to die for.  They have a rich selection of rolls, of which we only ordered 4...Sexy Scallop, Spicy Girl, Hot Love, New Wave Mahi Mahi.  I enjoyed our choices except for the mahi mahi, but that could easily be substituted with another roll.  

The likelihood of me coming back is 100%.  Hopefully, this time with more people so we can order more and share???
author: Kevin C.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this sushi place!

Every roll I've had here has been DELICIOUS!  One of my favorite rolls is the C-2, which has lobster on top - yummy!  Their pieces of sashimi are HUGE and so mouth melting!  The staff is super nice and super quick.  They have TVs, so they'll always have music playing or a game on.  One thing I would recommend is making reservations, it's always super packed!

I'm trying their new location tonight in the Mission, I can't wait!
author: Jessica W.

description:
I pass by Balboa St every night, can't help to notice this place and have always wanted to try. Finally, a few nights ago two hungry Asian girls were craving for some Japanese food. 

There was no wait on a Tuesday night, awesome :) 

We had:

M&L Forever, my favorite!
HOT LOVE, very good but wished there's more.
Sashimi Spirit, not a big fan of sashimi but good sushi.
Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon, definitely the best.

In the end, it was four rolls two cups of tea, total was about $50.
Well, we thought it's pretty pricey for what you get, it is good, but not heavenly good. 

Atmosphere is really nice, our waiter was a cute hunk too :)
author: Marlis T.

description:
Pro:  The lettuce wraps are totally inspired and totally amazing. 

Con: I am utterly disappointed and utterly confused why so much of the menu consists of rolls with cooked fish. 

I loved my meal.  I just didn't want to get anything with cooked fish and didn't want to get sashimi -- when I want sashimi I go to yum yum fish and get sashimi -- and found the menu lacking in choices.  So, one star off for that.
author: Nora B.

description:
I'm happy this place moved into a bigger space and they still stayed in their local neighborhood spot (they moved literally two doors down!)

We got there around 6:30 on a Monday evening and avoided the dinner rush (whew!) because it did get quite busy. 

The taste and presentation of the sushi is exactly what I remembered and even better! I discovered a favorite roll here- the Nemo Found- salmon, unagi, cucumber and avocado, wrapped in soybean paper.

They even have a section on their menu of brown rice sushi that I'm going to try the next time I'm back.
author: Lisa C.

description: Great sushi and atmosphere. It was more of a modern sushi restaurant. Not your typical Japanese sushi restaurant. I'd say they are kind of Americanized but it was still good. Although our waitress did forget to put in one of our other rolls, I forgive her as she was very kind. My girls and I stayed for a good 1.5 hours talking so it was nice that they didn't give us that "please leave already" vibe, lol. They were closing though so we had to leave either way, haha. But I don't think there's too many good sushi spots in San Francisco but this place is good, though parking does suck but that has nothing to do with Sushi Bistro! I can't quite remember what rolls we got but I think one of them were called G-2 or something but it was really good.
author: Jessica R.

description:
I was here for New Years Eve '08. Though being hung over from The Eve of New Years Eve '08, I managed to squeak out a high level of satisfaction from the fare. In fact, I was pleasantly surprised at Sushi Bistro's deviation from the traditional stylings of most sushi bars. 

But that's point-in-fact of my review herein (does that make sense? I blacked out). This is not your traditional sushi spot. If you're looking for authenticity, this is not where I would go. But if you're looking for a fresh take on traditional, or a well-played adaptation, this is it. 

The rolls and salads are unlike anything I've ever had. When I was there, they features a number of rolls with baby lobster. I'd never had a baby lobster before. I felt kinda bad, but it tasted so good. I like to believe the good and the bad balanced itself out. If it tastes so good, it can't be bad. 

And if I remember right, which is highly questionable, their Sake selection was pretty respectable. I seem to remember having a couple of new bottles there. But who knows...it was so long ago!!! Wait, that was only a year ago...uh oh. 

The point is, they present their sushi well, they have created something different and their fishies are choice. I say give it at least one try. It's not your daily sushi spot, but it's definitely one to try when you get tired of the same old maguro nigiri and whatnot...if that ever does happen...does that ever happen???
author: Joseph S.

description: Really great bartender and polite service all around. Quick service, open late-ish, and most importantly they have delicious sushi. Highly recommended.
author: Charles G.

description:
What can I say about Sushi Bistro. It is like a relationship. You start to trust it, and once you realize how wonderful and special it is, you don't want to mess things up. You begin to cherish the moments you spend together, the way you feel as you bask in the bliss of the sexy scallop roll.  You can think and look at other sushi places, but the warmth and comfort of Sushi Bistro gives you such pleasure, you'll never go in and actually order sushi from anywhere else. 
Whenever I even consider taking up a friend's offer to eat sushi somewhere else, I begin feeling guilty and dirty..almost like I'm doing something wrong. Even if no one will find out, it'll be on my conscience forever, just like cheating.
author: Dasha V.

description:
One of my favorite sushi places in the city! The rolls are amazing: good variety, interesting ingredients, and wonderful presentations. 

I couldn't give it five stars because the parking around it sucks big time, which isn't their fault. But, I also have had to wait for at least 15 min every time I come, even when I made reservations! Still the place is amazing and I will keep coming back.
author: Diana H.

description:
This place gets 5 stars all around from me, and I can be quite the critic!!! I came here having heard great things and I was not disappointed.  Service was beyond excellent (10 stars if possible).  I spilled soy sauce and before I could put my napkin on it to wipe it off they were doing it and had brought me a new napkin.  We had drinks on the table within a minute of ordering them.  Our water glasses never went more then half way down without being refilled.  Our plates were cleared within 15 seconds of finishing the last bite.  

Obviously, service is not everything..... The food was also right on point!

C2, Monster in-law, crunchy roll!! Those were the three rolls my boyfriend and I got, and we both thought they were all different and tasty in their own way.  Fresh and quality fish you could taste in every bite.   Though the rolls are on average $10 or a little more, you get what you pay for in quantity and quality.   

I would recommend this place to anyone looking for very tasty sushi!! And I can't say it enough, amazing service
author: allison s.

description: Probably one of if not the best sushi places we've been to in San Francisco. Just went here last night for dinner and it was great! We really liked the New Legend, the Yellowtail Basil and the Red Devil. The waitress' recommendations were spot on. Great neighborhood place for sushi and I'm sure we'll be back!
author: Anne D.

description:
A modern Japanese fusion spot to get your sushi on!!

So I've heard the hype of this place, and judiging by the number of yelp reviews..I have to try this place out.  We went on a Friday night and the wait wasn't too bad about 20-30 mins.  Ordered a pitcher of beer and a large Sapora to start the night off.  Then we got the oyster special and some sushi rolls; average price ($9.00+up).  The sushi did taste fresh and filling! 

YUM!
author: Elliot Y.

description:
Yummy in my pregnant tummy.... 

I was craving sushi on a Friday night so the hubby and I went out into SF to check this place out. I've made it a point to start checking out restaurants that I've been wanting to try in the city a lil more often now because I'm 5 months pregnant and when the baby arrives I don't know if we'll have the time, money or energy to do it as much. 

So here we are at Sushi Bistro after circling the 2-3 blocks around the restaurant for a good 10-15 minutes. The hubby is a bit grumpy at this point. It looks like the place is packed but they were able to sit us at the bar. I didn't mind since I was hungry and just wanted to sit and eat already. I took a look at the menu and searched for some yummy rolls that didn't have anything raw in them. Here's what we ordered: 

Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon (Shrimp Tempura, Aioli, Avocado & Cucumber, Topped with Unagi & Eel Sauce) - Soooo good! 2 Thumbs Up! 

C-2 (Baby Lobster, Avocado & Cucumber Topped with Shrimp Tempura, Drizzled with Eel Sauce) - Even better that the Crouching Tiger! It was my favorite among the 3 different rolls that we ordered. The hubby agreed and said that next time he wants a a whole roll just for himself. 

Rock'N Roll (Baked Spicy Scallops Served on Top of a California Roll) - Came out last and was probably my least favorite. It came out piping hot! I was kind of full after the first 2 rolls at this point but managed to squeeze in a couple of pieces of this one. They were difficult to pick up with chopsticks...probably because the pieces were warm and a bit mushy. The scallops had a nice spicy kick to them. I don't think I really liked the combination of the 2...and not really liking the taste of warm california roll so I probably wouldn't order this particular one again. 

Overall, I CAN'T WAIT to go back again...even more so after my baby is born so I can try the other raw rolls on their menu that sound super yummy!
author: BrElla4eva H.

description: I love sushi, and this place is awesome. We ate the african spider and the omega 3 and it was delish. They played regge the whole time and the staff was really nice. Would recommend to friends!
author: Eric D.

description:
I don't think I'm cool enough to appreciate this place.  The venue is crazy loud (people + club music blaring), the line by the frontdoor and seating in restaurant were jam packed.  Worse yet, the food was meh.  The service was friendly, but also was rotating in a non-committal "I'll be YOUR waiter/tress" kind of way.  Who do you turn to?   Who tends your hot tea cup when no one waiter/tress claims you as their patron?

The menu is nouveau sushi - read more rolls and deconstructed roll plates then traditional sushi.  I'm fine with that, I like a nice spicy tuna roll with mango and crunchy tempura bits.  No one in Japan is going to claim that as authentic but I claim is as yummy.  That said, Sushi B is pushing the limits.  If you are someone who likes to yell "X-treme" before you do some retarded physical stunt equally likely to make you infamous or earn a Darwin award, Sushi B might be the place for you.  I for one like my bones hole and my skin on.

To be fair and to the point, the cardinal sin for this place boils down to the fact that the food was really unimpressive.  Nigiri portions were huge, dare I say "X-treme!," but the fish was either frozen or of poor quality.  A couple of rolls were hits but nothing stands out in drawing me back.  

For that I write this neg-review.  Clearly I am in the minority of Yelpers on this one, so I pre-concede that my review might not be informative for all.  My one bit of advice would be to say that if you like this kind of environment and sushi style, Blowfish is of the same vein but does a much better job of it.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Some of the best sushi I've had - really nice balance of fish and rice.  The Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon rocked my world.   BF was gaga over his Salmon Teriyaki with Tempura.  The veggie gyoza was yummy and had a great texture (I often find gyoza to be too oily or drizzly or mushy, but not here!) 
The only thing that was a little eh was that the music was loud and the clientele was...well, weird.    It was like Jersey Shore did a road trip.   Can't fault the restaurant with that.  We'll come back and see how the people watching is another night.
author: Maria C.

description:
Excellent service, fresh sushi, reasonable prices

We were visiting from another state and read good reviews and noticed alot of the locals come here.  We decided to eat here for my husbands birthday.  Parking in this area is frustrating and we tried the night before to find parking and gave up.  We came again the next night deterimined to either find parking or order to go.  My favorite thing about this place was the service.  EVERYONE was friendly and helpful.  I didn't even know exactly who our server was because we had 5 to 6 people coming up and checking on us and bringing our sushi out and taking away dirty dishes.  I am thinking because the place is small they are very efficient in an effort get people in and out but you can't tell this because they are so nice and go out their way to make experience great.  I liked all the rolls and the prices are reasonable for fresh sushi (very fresh tasting). I also liked the fact that the menu is not overwhelming---they have their signature rolls and dishes and they do them right.  I thought the rolls portions were large compared to other places we have eaten.  We had our two kids with us in the restaurant but no one seemed to mind.  They brought out some green tea ice cream for my husband which I thought was very nice of them.  It was also tasty and not too sweet.  I can now see why this place is packed and has so many reviews.
author: S. J.

description:
If you like sushi, this is one of the places to go.  The sushi is delicious and fresh.  Everyone is started with a cucumber salad.  Best cucumber salad I ever tasted.  The sashimi is not your typical 2 to 3 inch fillet cut.  This place is about 3.5 to 4.5 inches in length.  The rolls are also delicious.  

The ambiance was great.  It was dim but dim at a level where you can see what you're eating.  Reggae music was playing.   

Parking was difficult on the streets.  I would recommend carpooling. 

Overall, this place was great and highly recommend.

*Review will be updated based on future experiences.
author: Victor W.

description:
Drawn here by the raves about the rolls and the iphone commercial fame. It is a small space but done with a modern lounge feel.

I'm a bit experienced  as a sushi eater so I have appreciation of both quality fish and innovative sushi roll creations. Started with the butterfish blasters which were tasty, a smoky grilled butterfish served as the wrap to a crab meat center. Hot on the outside, cold on the inside...a tad disrupting.

The famous rolls, crouching tiger hidden dragon, albacore dream and C-2 were next. The albacore dream was oversauced and the tuna was slightly spicy, slightly warm. The crouching tiger rolls were delicious, the unagi and avocado combo was yum. The C-2....could have sent this back. Topped with a massive batter chunk of shrimp tempura, just ruined the roll. Incidentally, the tempura was literally a massive fried batter chunk with a iddy-biddy shrimp hidden inside. Disappointing. 

Overall, not very impressed. Toronto and NYC have much better, tastier and inventive rolls. Maybe the locals are impressed because they don't get much of this. The sushi and sashimi wasn't particularly outstanding either. If you happen to be nearby, perhaps it's a good stop but otherwise, no need to go out of your way.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
The lettuce wrap was really interesting.  Unagi, salmon, and hamachi in a lettuce leaf, with mayo and eel sauce.  Really delightful.

We also had the "hot love" roll (spicy sauce on a crab and lobster roll), and "red devil" (spicy tuna).  Both were very good.
author: Niniane W.

description: Would give a negative if I could. Service was absolutely horrible and my food came out 20 minutes after everyone else had finished. The manager and server kept sating, "It's coming" and not even going to look for it. So ridiculous. The bill comes and I asked if he was seriously charging me for a cold roll, he has the audacity to say there was nothing he could do but take off some rice and a soup charge. Whaaat. I was a server for 6 years and my manager would absolutely never allow for that to happen. Just lost a great customer. The manager will  be hearing from me again.
author: Alexis F.

description:
Great place. Food was great, and the decor and cleanliness was outstanding. My girlfriend, who is very cautions of where she puts her purse, said, "I would've put my purse down on the bathroom floor." That's how clean it was. 

You get large portions for a great price. Definitely try it.
author: Skylar W.

description:
Has this ever happened to you?  You pay a bill for a party of 5 and tip $20, and then after your party leaves the restaurant, the cashier at the restaurant comes OUTSIDE and asks you for another $4 in tip?  Well this happened to me!  The gentlemen (and I use that term loosely) came out and said that we should have tipped 15% and asked for another $4 in tip!  The bill with tax was around $150, before tax it was around $137.  I thought a $20 tip was fair for our fine waiter.  Nope!  It was not good enough!  The cashier, not the waiter, came outside the restaurant after  we had left and asked us to come inside and tip some more!  An argument ensued and he started telling me that I lived in America and  since they are all paid minimum wage at the restaurant, I should tip more!  I will admit that $20 is not exactly 15% of $150 but since when is a 15% tip required?!?!  A tip (also called a gratuity) is a VOLUNTARY extra payment made to certain service sector workers in addition to the advertised price of the transaction.  It is actually supposed to be 15% before taxes, not after.  This would mean that I was more than fair, since 15% is around $20.xx depending on the exact total of my bill before tax.  So I actually shorted him less than $1.  Never in my life have I ever had someone chase me down and ask for more money (for tip!!!).  For goodness sakes, he was not even the waiter.  He then started yelling and pointing at me asking if I lived in America.  Well since I was born here, I suppose I am a citizen, and being a citizen of these here United States, I know that a tip is OPTIONAL. 
         Now if you want good sushi and good food, please go here.  I have no complaints about the food or the service from our wonderful waiter.  

***This is a true story...this is not made up...I know it may sound made up but it is not...I ate here with my wife and good friends on January 8, 2011.***
author: T.  A.

description:
I have now tried Sushi Bistro on five or more occasions and I have to say that the quality of their Sushi is average at best. Their Miso soup is terrible and this is one of those restaurants where the non Japanese Sushi chefs are not working. They have a great bar and play pretty good music but their food is definitely suffering. The entire block is non occupied restaurants that have either moved or have gone out of business. Sushi bistro's declining food quality will make it the next business on this block to go out of business. The area is predominantly hipsters and young couples who must be from North Dakota because any Japanese sushi enthusiast or chef would give this restaurant a D grade for the quality of their food. No taste, no creativity, quickly made Sushi that cannot be Japanese owned because the fish leaves that  not fresh taste in your mouth and another key to their declining food quality is the fact that the chef's do not realize that you cannot put a small amount of rice in your nigiri sushi...Sign that the chefs do not know how to make sushi. Very Americanized sushi with horrible parking in this neighborhood would not make this a recommendation for anyone looking to experience all the wonderful places for Sushi in the San Francisco Bay area. PASS ON THIS PLACE TAKE MY ADVICE. WAIT STAFF HAVE TURNED OVER QUITE A BIT LATELY AS WELL WHICH IS NOT A GOOD SIGN. 

Works for neighborhood folks too lazy to go to a real sushi restaurant...
author: Reynold B.

description:
If you're looking for a sushi spot that has tons of fresh rolls and all sorts of other dishes to boot, Sushi Bistro is where it's at.

I had no idea that this spot was so hot. It was packed to the brim on a Friday night w/ ppl in every square inch of the place!

We went for their Black Weeds signature roll (lightly seared baby tuna seasoned w/ black pepper & sesame oil, topped w/ seaweed salad & spicy albacore), which didn't sound that appetizing right off the bat, but ended up being our favorite roll. I'd definitely order it again. We also ordered Butterfish Nigiri, which was gigantic! If you're into equal fish/rice ratio, I'd order up a side of rice since the fish dominates- there was just a small bit of rice to accompany it. The Caucasian Afro starter dish (spicy tuna mixed w/ guacamole served w/ onion & tomato sauce garnished w/ crispy potato vermicelli) was tasty and fresh. It made for a great app.

If you don't have reservations, be prepared to wait awhile. Service was lightning fast, but since they were churning out so many rolls, the servers kept on serving us dishes that weren't ours. They also kept pouring us cold tea to refill our cups. Hopefully this isn't a regular thing.

Overall, I'd make a point to come by here if you're really into sushi. Bring the health fanatics & vegetarians too since they have special brown rice and veggie rolls!


Sidenotes: 
-It's a shame that their logo doesn't reflect its clean & modern interior. It seems like it's meant for a daycare business!
-Namu is conveniently located next door if you're in the mood to drink afterwards. They've got a late night happy hour.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
LOVED this place! I went last night with a girlfriend and I thought it was the perfect spot. Fun and lively (the Lakers game was on too, so that added A LOT of noise :)), and the food was really fresh, delicious and affordable. They have a pretty large selection of rolls and nigiri - and stuff that's not offered everywhere (like butterfish - my favorite). Our dinner, with drinks, was just over $30 each, and we were pretty full. Be sure to try the sexy scallop roll!

I agree with others that if you just want to chill at a little quiet sushi joint, this probably isn't the place - it is pretty loud and a tiny bit swanky; but if you're in the mood for a lively, snazzy place and you don't feel like trekking down to the Marina or the Mission, this is your place!
author: Kate S.

description:
Amazing.

Best-known for the rolls, I can't go without grabbing some nigiri or sashimi as well. 

Couldn't live without Sushi B.
author: Tommy M.

description:
A group of friends and I went here to tell our stomachs to shut the hell up after an entire DAY of rediscovering San Francisco and playing tour guide to a good friend visiting from out of the country... and she had NEVER had sushi before... aside from a California roll, I am sure.  

We arrived to discover a cute little neighborhood joint that was dimly lit...  The staff was pleasant and accommodating when my tourist friends went to the sushi bar to watch the chef at work...  Our food came out quick and we were attended to promptly when our dishes were empty and we were ready for more...

Now for the food... it's not that it wasn't good - I've had rolls of the same quality before.  I overlooked half the menu though, because I noticed many were "fusion" type rolls.  I'm all for artistry and creativity, but when it's come to sushi, I've lucked out with finding anything good in the "fusion" department.  I usually steer clear of those, because I know that it's just a bunch of fluff that will confuse my tastebuds more than satisfy me.  

Moving on... the spicy tuna rolls were super.  I had something with Yellowtail in it, but I can't put my finger on the name because it's been a while since my visit, and it was ok.

My guests had the spider rolls, and apparently, my friend from Turkey had never known that soft shell crab existed...  The idea of eating the whole damned thing boggled her mind., but once she got her first taste, she quickly made haste to flag down a server and make sure I order her another portion.  That MUST mean something.  

My native SF friends helping me play tour guide had the sashimi plates, and they looked incredibly good.  Thick, fatty morsels of vibrant bits of fish... I had to look away while they ate to make sure I did not commit the sin of coveting the contents on my neighbor's plate.  I'm definitely going to try what they had if ever I am in the area again.

3.5 stars... good and fresh, but I really have to work the "fusion" idea into my head one more time to be adventurous here, and the staff did a wonderful job making sure we had everything we needed for the night.  A small part of this rating could have been higher if it weren't for the smell that I noticed from the paint off-gassing.  Overall, I had a great time here, and I wouldn't mind it if someone persuaded me to come back again, with a fat plate of sashimi!  =D
author: Sharon T.

description:
So it was my fiance's Birthday and we were looking for a nice joint to eat at.   Since, we love to eat sushi... we thought we would try out Sushi Bistro. I mean over 600 reviews, how can you go wrong....

Oh did I mention, we went with her family.  Her two brothers tend to be quantity over quality type of eaters.  Needless to say, they were not too satisfied with the size or portions.  But oh wells.. you can't win them all Sushi Bistro.

As for myself, I was quite surprised by the quality and promptness of the service.  The waiter even asked stopped by to check if we had accidentally parked in the bus zone.   Needless to say, if every place had service like this.... I would be one happy camper...

The rolls themselves were a little on the small side.  I noticed that they didn't have as much rice.  But the amount of filling and quality of fish definitely made up for the lacking rice.   I would recommend the black and white appetizer, a unique spin of traditional Japanese.  I got the C-2, which was another hit for me.  Fiance got the Samurai "something or other' roll. which was definitely on point.

Definitely, will want to stop by again... this time we'll take people that appreciate finer tastes....
author: steve c.

description:
The fish is very fresh and tasty; the rolls are creative and also very tasty.  The service was attentive and the orders come out lightning fast.

But SWEET JESUS!  Must you play the club music so loudly?  I get it, you're a hip and trendy place.  I know, you were in the iPhone commercial and you have to satisfy the hipsters' idea of what constitutes a place worthy of their patronage.  But you don't need to prove that you're too cool for school by blaring thumpa-thumpa music.  If I want that, I'll go to Badlands.  It would be nice to sit and enjoy the fresh fish and creative roll creations that you serve up without having to scream across the table and cup my hand over my ear so I can hear the person sitting 3 feet away from me.  Next time, I'll bring my earplugs and my mad skills as a pantomime.
author: B D.

description:
I wasn't prepared for the ambiance (or relative lack thereof) but my wife said her co-workers told her to expect crowded and loud.  This place is a little off the beaten path as well.  Also coming from South Bay I had my normal hissy-fit of trying to park (anywhere) in SF.  We had to wait a bit even though we had reservations--and with the crowded conditions it was a little annoying.

All this said, the inconveniences were worth it!  Fresh fish and fast service made up for the adventure getting to our table.

We had the following rolls: 

Monster-In-Law (whitefish roll, chili sauce, and jalapenos, spicy!)
Watermelon-Man (a derivation on spicy tuna roll)
Big Island (mixture of sashimi rolled in a artistic cucumber slice)
Rainbow (classic california roll with assorted sashimi on top)
Crunchy (classic tempura roll)

We also had salmon sashimi, pot-stickers, miso soup and edamame--which were each excellent in quality.  

Our favorites were the Monster-In-Law and Watermelon-Man.  My wife liked the Big Island but the cucumber roll threw me off a bit--not my thing.  The other rolls were high quality and tasty.

I would definitely go back--but maybe with my motorcycle to ease the parking issue.  Great sushi!
author: Christopher Y.

description:
Although I appreciate the effort that Sushi Bistro puts into their rolls, I think that they try to distract from their lukewarm and funky tasting fish with over-drenched sauces and mayonnaise! It was just an overwhelming creamy and soft texture that I don't believe belongs in a sushi restaurant.  Turn off.  

I did think that the soft shell crab that I had was fried and seasoned very well, and the tempura/eel wrap that my friend had looked really fresh and simple so if I go there again I would probably try that.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Get the ahi poke salad!! It's amazing.

Overall the food is quality and delicious. But it is a bit pricey.
author: Casey V.

description:
The World According to Noelle
~Allergic Girl's Guide to Life~
Issue 181

                                                       d e l i g h t f u l l y 
         
                                                         d e l i c i o u s


noe tunes
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E3NnewTgQDY&feature=related

Eating with me is difficult because I am allergic to so many things. I'm always looking for the next Noe Friendly Restaurant. Sushi Bistro is a cozy restaurant. It was packed inside, people were waiting outside and to go orders were promptly being filled. It was a good thing we had dinner reservations. We were seated promptly. I decided to go with a safe allergy friendly dinner plate- beef teriyaki and tempura. My dinner came with miso soup and salad. The beef teriyaki was delicious and the tempura were deep fried to perfection. We also had edamame- yum, one of my favorites! We also ordered sushi (I'm not a sushi expert) so I cannot remember everything that was ordered (too many things to count!). My favorite sushi of the night was the halibut and the salmon skin roll. The halibut was the best I've ever had- it was smooth, delicious and in one word: AMAZING. My taste buds were wowed by the salmon skin roll- it was so, so, so very TASTY =) 

The service was prompt, friendly and overall great! This was most definitely an allergy friendly place. They play good music, albeit a bit loud. It was a perfect October evening. I've never been one who liked fish but I believe its all in the way its prepared. I can honestly say after eating the sushi here I will most definitely be back to try more. My days of ordering boring gyoza and teriyaki are officially over! It was a perfect October evening. Weather was balmy- no need for the coat I brought just in case. After a nice stroll, I had a craving for sweet salted caramel ice cream...

sushi ~ 

               sweet tarts ~ 
 
                                         sweet salted caramel ice cream ~ 
                                                                                                     
                                                                                                         for life =)

Noelle's Notes
Allergy Friendly, Noelle Approved.
Who knew- I LOVE sushi =)

Noelle's Post Secret
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BEOj3_frvyk
author: Noelle J.

description:
This restaurant's menu is primarily composed of various not-so-fresh fish items placed randomly on top of california rolls to create the illusion of variety.

Some may be fooled by the dim lighting and the Kirin on tap, but this is not authentic Japanese, just yet another non-Japanese-owned restaurant in SF that adds to the ridiculousness of SF being perceived as a diverse place to enjoy authentic "ethnic" food (especially Japanese).

They also served frozen maguro that seemed to have been thawed shortly before our consumption.

Our order (2 rolls and a salad) came out in about 3-4 minutes, leading us to the assumption that they had been either magically produced by Sabrina the Teenage Sushi Chef, or they had been pre-made prior to the beginning of the shift.  In this situation, speed was not a virtue, but rather a cause for concern and suspicion.

Even though my coworker recommended this place and my friend works here, I will pull no punches by saying that this did not live up to my expectations and I will probably not come back.
author: Peter L.

description:
Sushi Bistro has always been a place to go to grab some good yummy fresh sushi.. AND it's in my neighborhood! Their menu items are so unique and different from a lot of places in SF. 

Some rolls that I have tried from when I first started coming here and love are:
African Spider ($12.50)-salmon, soft shell crab, Cajun flavored albacore, sprouts, avocado served with a spicy house sauce. One of my favs since I love soft shell crab and they always serve this with a huge one crawling out and it's fried to perfection.
Big Island ($13.95)- Salon, tuna, yellowtail, snow crab meat, avocado and sprouts wrapped with a thinly sliced cucumber. Fish is always fresh and it's just so refreshing to eat a sushi with cucumber instead of the usual.
Spicy Crunchy ($9.75)- Yellowtail, salmon, snapper, shrimp and macadamia nuts deep fried and is served with spicy house sauce... Who DOESN't like deep fried sushi? I know I do!
Rainbow roll ($9.75)- The usual rainbow roll is always a good choice!

If you want to try something different, give the lettuce wraps a try. They are super delicious and sounds healthy! Equinox ($4.95) is yummy! Shrimp tempura, unagi, avocado, sushi rice with eel sauce.. The Solstice wrap ($4.95) is my fave... Yummy diced ahi tuna seared, avocado, crunchy flakes and Tabasco sauce...

They also serve healthy options like brown rice rolls for you healthy eaters. The usual dinner combos are also served here. 

Service is always friendly and fast.
author: Juliane N.

description:
We came here by accident, looking for Namu, and what a delightful surprise it was. The sashimi roll and the African Spider roll were fantastic.  The fish on the nigiri was pretty huge, but I thought that was a good thing!  

The food here rocks, and the prices are right.  It was the first time I'd eaten sushi without spending a fortune.
author: InannaMouse M.

description:
Went to Sushi Bistro for the first time the other night with a party of 8 people. The place was jammin so it took a little while for our table to be ready but once we sat down we were doted on hand and foot. We had several different waiters that were bringing us our drinks and food. All 8 people were happy with their food, and most dishes were beautifully prepared. YUM. Also a huge plus, the bill wasn't bad at all. 

Sushi Bistro is my new favorite spot for sushi.
author: Billie S.

description:
Okay... I feel SOOO bad for giving it such a low rating because I haven't given it a good one yet... which I will have to do when I come back next time and get the good quality sushi again.

The 2 Stars is solely for the food that night.  Their service is usually pretty good and they are super friendly.  This joint is owned by a Taiwanese lady with her son there all the time.  There is no difference from sitting at the sushi bar or sitting at the table.  I would recommend you call or come early because there is often a wait since it's a small place.  Parking is really hard to find in that area because it's mostly residential.

First off.. they did NOT have Toro that night.  OMG! The sole reason I come here is b/c the prices are cheap and the cuts are HUGE! Yes, they are extremely generous in portion.  There is usually little to no rice under that chunk of fish.  Sadly, I kept my whining to myself and we ordered.  I felt that the fish that night was not fresh at all.  We had the Hamachi Belly, Albacore Belly, Ocean Trout, Uni, Hotate, Wild King Salmon, and more.

The wild king salmon was atrocious... the color was faded and texture was weird.  I thought the albacore belly was fishy.  This is where the big portions are bad because I had to eat it! =X 

I thought the Hamachi with Jalapeno was pretty good that night, but overall the food was mediocre with a lot of downsides.  My sister felt really bad because she knew that I was looking forward to getting my sushi fill and I was so let down.  I warned her that when we go to Sushi Sam's... http://www.yelp.com/biz/sushi-sams-edomata-san-mateo#hrid:I1XYj9PMoVKpUN2sg-ri4Q  .... she better watch out because I am eating 5 orders of Toro to get my fill and she can't stop me! ^_- I am an unsatisfied Sushi Monster now ... looking for my next victim! I need it!

I will be going back to Sushi Sam's tonight and hopefully the streak of bad sushi will be over! =P
author: Kat L.

description:
In a drunken conversation with some fellow yelpers it was discussed whether we would be giving this place 4 stars or 5. The conversation went something like this:

Starla: "I am rewriting my review, it isn't funny".
Amir: "Drue, are you going to give this place 4 stars or 5?"
Me: "4"

Yeah, so then we went and had a few more drinks, which made me wake up with a hangover, which made me re-think my loose reviewing ways. Which brought me to a 3.5 star review, which I rounded up to 4, since yelp continues to make us compromise our ratings with the lack of half stars. But, really I downgraded to 3.5 in a sober state, so keep that in mind as you read this, m'kay??

The service was slow which gave us lots of time to critique the decor, because, obviously, 3 people who are not commercial interior designers have every right to judge the cheesiness of the ocean theme paired with this quasi-industrial modern thing they have going on.  

The fish they use for the nigiri/sashimi is excellent quality, the correct temperature, good sized portions, and, if it is a winner of a spot on the special board, ridiculously overpriced. 

Good sake selection with accurate descriptions of the flavor and body of each sake. This is fantastic, because I am an ignorant white chick who is easily confused and who thinks all of the bottles look the same so I can never remember which kinds I have tried and liked in the past. 

Weird rolls. Rolls with fruit and fried stuff and odd sauces and odder combos of ingredients. Plus, for some reason that does not transcend into the nigiri/sashimi, they serve some of the fish at entirely the wrong temperature. I guess they assume if you are ordering something with the name watermelon in it, though mango, not watermelon, is one of the key ingredients, that you too dumb to know what the proper temperature of your dish should be anyhow. 

All in all a nice, lively place to eat with fresh ingredients and a good selection, but I will be sticking to the basics in the future because even if they call the scallop roll sexy they are not fooling me.
author: Drue C.

description:
What's better than chill reggae beats playing as your eating yummy fish? 
This place was amazing and I can't believe I waited so many years to try it out. Fresh delicious original sushi rolls and a wide variety of sake to chose from. The portions were enormous. Not too much rice wrapped around the rolls, rather large portions of raw fish. Also this is one of the only sushi places where you can request brown rice instead of white. Nice!
I am so happy this place is only a short walk from my house. Can't wait to take friends here.
author: Kehaulani K.

description:
If you want real vegetarian sushi. you've come to the right place. They have an entire page of options.

the summer roll with mango, avocado, and tofu wrapped in inari-- was vegetarian sushi genius. 

its cute and cozy, but really busy so you'll probably have to wait.  so worth it.
author: Liz S.

description: If you are a sushi purist (nigiri and good quality fish) don't go here. Don't believe the hype either. Nice interior decorating and hardwood floors does not compensate for lack of taste. My boyfriend never tried toro so I was so excited to introduce it to him. It was frozen in the middle. The hawaiin poke, BLEH.  Grainey and not cut well. I give credit to the spider roll because it had a good portion of crab in it and low rice ratio but that's about all. I was pissed and still hungry during the middle of our meal so I ordered sesame chicken as filler. It was as try as the styrofoam packaging you use to pack boxes.  I would rather eat Safeway sushi than at this place again.
author: Leslie L.

description:
AMAZING.

Sushi Bistro and Sushi Raw are on equal footing as the two best sushi restaurants in the Bay Area. Fresh ingredients, beautiful presentation, great taste, reasonable prices (albeit on the pricier side, but still affordable and well worth every penny). 

I may even dare say Sushi Bistro is slightly superior to Sushi Raw, because Sushi Bistro's rolls were so unique! I thought Sushi Raw was unique already, but Sushi Bistro stunned me with their creations. I tried at least 8 different rolls (I was with a group of friends) with an appetizer and everything was delicious!!!  

My favorites (even though everything was yummy):

Albacore Dream
African Spider
Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon
Sexy Scallop

Even the names are cool. I can't wait to go back. 

Two thumbs way up!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Well I was going to take my friend Megan to try out Tekka down the street but it was packed with a couple hours wait so we walked down to Sushi Bistro which is her favorite sushi place that she's been going to for years.

I hadn't heard of it but it looked a little too trendy and hip for my tastes, but I was willing to give it a try.  Then I heard it was on an iPhone ad and was even more disheartened but when the sushi chef and the owner lady (oops forgot her name) both said hey to Megan, I figured it had to be a pretty cool place to at least recognize and welcome their regulars.

Anyhow, the portions of the fish here were the first thing I noticed with pretty big slabs of tasty fish on each piece of nigiri - score!  Then the flavor of the fish and freshness was also spot on.  The shiro maguro I got is always one of the two fish I order to see how good the fish is at a place and it was deliciously melt-in-your-mouth.

Megan and I agreed that being toothless old people, we could still eat that here... 

The rest of the meal was great too.  I'm not as a big a roll guy, but they had some pretty interesting and tasty ones here.  I prefer straight up nigiri and on that they are great too.

Pretty reasonable prices too for what you get.  Definitely a good spot for dates too as we saw many happening around us.  To my left was an awkward couple talking about those boring things you talk about if you don't have real chemistry but even that just added to the ambience and our amusment...
author: Gene X.

description:
I don't have any more time here in SF to give Sushi Bistro another chance. Twice is enough. Jill K. wrote the review that I wanted to write. Like her, I just don't get it. 

I also had the crab-filled Rainbow Roll, and while it had some very good slices of fish, the crab in the middle was overwhelming. There was too much, and it was too heavy. The second time I went, I had some tempura and various handrolls, which I actually enjoyed very much (Summer Roll).  Their tempura was OK but not as light as I like. I cannot recall exactly what else I had, but I also recall the cuts of fish on the nigiri to be much too thick. WTH is with this place...it's like sushi gone Costco. Sometimes bigger is better, but that is not a prerequisite for sushi. Now if we're talking "unagi..."
author: Steph P.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco for about 7 years and I had never been to Sushi Bistro until last Sunday and I can't believe what I was missing out on!! This is such a little gem in the Inner Richmond.  I would always see tons of people outside the door and never bothered to try it out - and boy did I recently find out what I was missing out on!  

The rolls are unique and very very GOOD. I really liked the C-2 and the Hawaiian Breeze (Pesto drizzled on top of sushi rolls? Brilliant!)  There is a perfect rice to fish ratio in each piece of sushi.  

Price wise - I thought it was very reasonable for the quality of fish they serve - everything is very fresh and well presented.  

This is definitely a place I will be visiting again very soon :)
author: Cherlyn M.

description:
Mmmmm the selection. I wanted to come to this place last time i was in SF but never got around to it. My boyfriend and i planned on coming here for my  birthday lunch but ended up getting distracted and spending more time at the conservatory than we planned...and 'lunch' ended up being at 5:30. Oh wellllll.
the place was packed, as we expected. But we grabbed the last 2 seats at the bar. I got the Big Island to start, and it filled me up a lot more than i was expecting it to, considering there's no rice in it. tonssssss of fresh fish though.I asked for it with eel sauce, because i think eel sauce makes everything better. I ordered a dragon roll also, but i was so full i could only eat half. Huge portions of eel though. And really cute presentation. C-2 was delicious as well. 
I was so full afterwards, i didn't even have a bite of the green tea ice cream they brought my for my birthday. haha, i felt bad.
And i was too full to go to the Crab House for my birthday dinner like we had planned. So my boyfriend's wallet lucked out haha. It was worth it though. We didn't mind.
there's so much more stuff i want to try though, so next time i'm back in SF, this is on the top of my list.
author: Amanda S.

description:
This place was recommended since I'm such a sushi lover.  I ordered the 12 sashimi combo (tuna, salmon, yellowtail, butterfish, and two types of albacore) and three different rolls (sashimi spirit, nemo found, and hot love).  The sashimi combo was worthwhile because the slices were huge and nicely cut and didn't have that "frozen" feeling like some other sushi places.  However, I still think the fish tasted better at Zushi puzzle in the Marina than here... Sorry.

I like the Nemo found and Hot love since they were tasty...full of flavor.  I wasn't too hot on the sashimi spirit because of its lack of taste?  The menu offered a lot of rolls, ranging from your standard to "something unique."  

The place is in the inner Richmond...good luck finding parking.  The restaurant was quite dark (hence, club-style?).  Looked like a great place to take a date to... 

Overall, I'm mixed about Sushi Bistro because of the overall ambiance and the creative rolls.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I am in the minority, but I am going to give Sushi Bistro 3 stars not because I dislike their food, but because I never have a craving for this place simply because every Japanese restaurant (along with, to my dismay, some Korean joints) provides rolls.  Thus, why circle Balboa like a vulture in order to find a parking spot to squeeze my non-Mini car into?  If I want rolls, choices are aplenty.  Many do them just as well as Sushi Bistro and you get much more bang for your buck, too.

Luckily, in my case, all of this is moot because I do not even care for rolls.  They are okay, but I do not ever have a yearning for them.  I almost exclusively eat nigiri and sashimi because I want to taste the fish.  I want to savor the ocean freshness of naked fish.  When fish are drizzled with, soaked in, overwhelmed by sauces, my poor taste buds, for all their sensitivity, cannot find the fish even with state-of-the-art GPS.  This is always a bad thing, in my opinion.  Not only is it frustrating to be unable to experience that freshness, in the event the fish is not that fresh--chances are it is not--I want to know instead of be suspicious as I plow through the mayo.

Back to Sushi Bistro, their fish is hit-or-miss, in terms of freshness.  Some of the sashimi salads are quite nice with delicious sesame ginger dressings.  The rolls' fish do not impress, however.  Also, prepare to spend, on average, 20 minutes to find parking during the weekends.  They do not take reservations.  The interior is colorful and aims to be hip and modern.  The service is on point.  Do not skip the green tea ice cream.  It is house-made and tastes like really good matcha.
author: Dee C.

description:
If you're a sushi snob, you'll know what's up with this place.

Nigiri: nothing to write home about

Rolls: innovative, good to the untrained palette, and seemingly fresh when you drizzle everything with kewpie and terriyaki sauce

Hot food: decent

Simply put, if you want to introduce sushi to someone and don't want to risk scaring them, this is a good place to go. If you're a snob, I suggest you go elsewhere.
author: Jason C.

description:
I've come here for dinner a few times and it's always packed! It'd be good to make reservations prior to trying this place out.

They just moved, but the newer place is a little bigger, definitely hipper, and it's a place for the youngsters. Good for small or somewhat large groups (like 6-8pp). 

The sushi here is delicious! Can't go wrong with this place!
author: Jennifer H.

description: I'm so torn about this place because I've had such mixed experiences here having dined here about 6 times. This week was one of my best experiences in terms of the quality of the sushi- the uni, butterfish, salmon, amaebi, and other nigiri was so fresh and tasty. The albacore dream is my favorite roll here- delish. The agadeshi tofu appetizer and sea bass was also delicious. Be warned that parking is a nightmare and is never easy. The service was a little spotty this week- not very attentive and just seemed rushed, although the server was patient with us. In the past, my issue with this place has been the quality of the sushi. I remember one time my fish was still a little frozen (ick!). But we went on a Tuesday this time so maybe Tuesday sushi nights is the way to go.
author: Inna L.

description:
Rents have gone up, so I've seen prices go up; still, SB is yummy phenomenal. First off, they'll let you know when Sea Urchin is fresh!  Roll options are delightful, and yes, they're beautiful & tasty.  Great veg. & vegan sushi along with unique, boutique options on dishes: try em out if only for variety.  If you're a purist, you can get it done right here; but if you like flavor collisions, even better.  

We do group buys of different rolls, sashimi, and a few sides. It's when the saki gets added that we get in trouble. 

Among SF sushi options, SB ranks high; the consistency of fresh, quality fish & aesthetic choices is praiseworthy.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Yummy, Yummy. Fresh. Yummy. Yummy, Yummy! 
VERY reasonably priced
Diverse menu - lots of options.  
**Not a lot of table and no real "waiting area"
Call ahead and make a reservation**
author: Lacee K.

description:
Huge portions & extremely generous cuts of fresh fish in a small space in the Inner Richmond.  Some fish were served a tad colder than I like and the sushi rice was underdressed.  The rolls were a nice size though, easy to eat.  

We had toro, kanpachi, hamachi belly, tekka maki, ahi poke, and the "black weed" roll.  Highlights were the toro, hamachi belly, and ahi poke.

Parking is insane in this neighborhood!
author: Derrick V.

description:
Man this placed sucked. I went here two times, and it was two times too many. Service is slow as molasses. And then when you get your sushi you'll wonder why they call it Sushi bistro. Calling this sushi is sacrilegious. For that you should go do a 100 Hail Marys' inside the backroom of a Chinese Fish Market.

I think there should be a rule. Like you can't call it sushi if the fish comes from a Costco freezer. I got the "Catch of the Day" Sashimi combo or whatever it was and it was more like the "Catch of Last month." The snapper tasted like fish flavored gummy bears. The tuna looked like a block of lego and tasted worse then one too. The only thing they didn't mess up was the salmon....but no one can mess that up. Not even Kitaro. 

Only good thing I can say about this place is that a few of the hot appetizers were pretty good. Hot Love, Lava Flow I think. But they had like 3 gallons of mayonaise and eel sauce or something all over it, so they could have wrapped the roll in newspaper and I probably still wouldn't be able to tell the difference. 

My girlfriend who's from Japan almost kicked me out of the house when I brought this stuff back home for dinner one night and tried to pass it off as sushi. Note to self: Don't do that again.
author: clint t.

description:
Wam bam thank you ma'am! I was stoked to go out with my peeps this past evening, but I was not stoked to go here. And not because of the wonderful recommendations or the awesometown company. This place was just eh.

The service was bad and I am hoping it was just a crowded night for them. The dude didn't even say hi, then walked off forgetting to take a couple of our other guests' orders. Um hellloooo? 

I ordered the Caucasian Afro thinking it was a roll, but it came out as a dip looking dish with crispy thingers on top. It tasted like a bowl full of squishy guacamole. We ordered about 40,000 different rolls and nothing stood out to me. I remember the fish being fresh, it just was cut to thick or mixed with the strangest of ingredients. The Miso soup was good especially when we were given spoons to eat it with... Also the edemame was tasteeee. Try the weird green tea ice cream dough dessert. Colleen C and I decided it tasted like donuts, and donuts are NEVER a bad choice.

I wanted to like this place because it has a cool neighborhood feel, but if the weird green tea ice cream dough dessert and edemame are the best things on the menu... I durno. Check it out for yourself. 

Notes: There were cute mini babies eating with their parents, and it seemed a little tight for a big party.
author: Melody L.

description:
Everyone seems to love Sushi Bistro. It's so close to my home, it would be very convenient if I could also love it. I don't love it - not at all.

There is a gigantic television that projects baseball games from cities I have never been to. The waitstaff are irritable and look improperly nourished. The lighting and acoustics are very harsh.  They play loud reggae music, music which once symbolized rebellion, class struggle, and faith - but here here it just means that it's time to get drunk. 

Many of the maki have overly cutesy names. I don't like cutesy, it usually borders on inappropriate. Lucklily, they have covered that as well. They offer the stunningly named "watermelon man," "caucausian afro" "spicy girl" and "red devil." If the sushi were at least good, maybe I could eat it and feel horrifically guilty about eating food made by bigots. But it isn't good. It's so-so. 

I found that an inordinate number of grossly-named menu items contain eel-sauce. Perhaps this is why - though separated by epithet -  they all taste the same.
author: H G.

description: Their sushi was very fresh.  Love the rock n roll, it was nice and warm, very different from other rock n roll.  What captured my heart was their "Scallop Special with Uni".  I normally don't like the taste of uni, but with this one, it was exquisite,  a little pricey though.  Will definitely come back
author: C L.

description:
On a leafy street in the Richmond district, Sushi Bistro serves Neo Sushi. A form of Japanese cuisine mixed with a modern twist. The hamachi (yellowtail) nigiri is buttery in text and melts in your mouth. Try the African Spider roll. Crispy delicate soft shell craft, salmon, and albacore with a spicy sauce. It is a great neighborhood restaurant meaning you get a chance to know your sushi chef and where servers will know you name as a regular.

Neo sushi can be best exemplified by the grand daddy: Nobu. Chef/restaurateur Nobu Matsuhisa show off his well presenting delights with influences from Japan and Peru. So what is the dam fuss about this place? A few years ago, I flew down to Los Angeles to try the food myself. In his Beverly Hills location, the modest decor triggers no excitement. Sitting at the sushi bar, I view the assortment of fish. Without wasting a Hollywood minute, I order his signature miso black cod. With a crispy skin, the cod combines sweet miso with mirin. Arranged with a selection of enhancers such as coarse salt, the shrimp tempura has a crispy light batter but far from exceptional. The yellowtail (hamachi) is buttery and sea sweet. I spend a total of $80.
author: Rayfil W.

description:
Disclaimer: this restaurant is TINY.  Do expect a wait, and don't expect to bring a big party.

I love, Love, LOVE the names of their rolls and other dishes.  You can't go wrong with "hot love", "spicy girl", "aloha 101", "crouching tiger hidden dragon".  Oh my gosh I can go on, but I better not for fear that my mouth will water onto my keyboard.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Perhaps my taste buds are/were having an off-day? Does that ever happen to you? Things that you love just don't taste quite right? Anyway... I will allow for that distinct possibly

HOWEVER...

I gotta say, people... I feel like something is wrong with me that I didn't enjoy the food here! I was really looking forward to it. Tons of sushi aficionados had recommended SB time and again, telling me amazing things of innovative rolls such as spicy tuna with jalapeno in it.

Decent decor but nothing particularly memorable. We arrived at 7:30pm on a Thursday (party of 2) and there were several empty tables. We were seated immediately, which is always rare -- dare I say, alarming -- for a good sushi joint.

I started with some miso soup, which I wasn't crazy about. That was worrisome to me, since miso soup is one of those standard things that is usually good if not delicious. I didn't even finish it!

First up was some kind of Hawaiian-themed roll with ahi, mango, and cucumber which was okay but kind of bland. Next we had sake (salmon) and maguro nigiri. I am no expert on sushi preparation technique, but the slices of fish on the nigiri were huge and thick, and sliced in a way that left them tough and chewy. They were also lacking in the rice department... each piece of nigiri had about a tablespoon of rice attached, and there was no wasabi in them!!

Finally, I had a roll which is not on the on-line menu, and I can't remember the name of it. The waiter helpfully suggested it when I said I wanted something with crab that wasn't too mayonnaise-y. He described it, quite accurately, as a Rainbow Roll filled with crab instead of rice. It arrived in a beautiful presentation, the slices of the roll arranged in a circle around some dressed mixed greens. I enthusiastically took my first bite and was saddened, then sickened by the plastic, manufactured taste of imitation crab. I know that many MANY rolls are made with imitation crab, but this just had a disgustingly distinct and fake flavor to it. I truly couldn't eat it. I would have sent it back but I was on a date and didn't want to seem overly fussy! :) I simply ate the fish around it but was decent but still not very well sliced.

I would CONSIDER giving this place another go, but I'd have to be convinced by someone who loved it and would order the right things for us!

One extra star for the "Sushi Not Bushi" bumper stickers (and shirts) they produce! I proudly sport one on my car!

It's always comforting to know that you and your restaurant share the same political agenda...
author: Jill M.

description:
Yummy Fresh Tasty Sushi!  What more could I ask for?! 
 When you visit here I highly suggest that you try a few items off their "Something Unique" page of their menu.  I don't think you will be disappointed.  And for those less adventurous they also have your "standard" rolls and nigiri's on their menu.  
I suggest you arrive early or make a reservation.  Even those with reservations had to wait for their table.  In the end it is always worth the wait.
author: Frances T.

description:
Hungover and seeking a cure, I had my heart set on a hearty bowl of noodle soup. Sushi Bistro came through in the form of beef udon.

The gf had a generous feast of tonkatsu.

We shared a couple of sushi rolls from the extensive menu of inspired creations. I say "inspired," but a sushi purist might think it a bit overboard. Lots of rolls wrapped in soy paper, cucumbers or simply more fish. Some served in a bowl of greens. I too tend to favor sushi places with the sparest of menus - Sushi Zone in the city, or Uzen in the East Bay for example - but it's good to have options at the other end of the spectrum.

For the record though, they have the basics down. My hamachi and saba nigiri featured HUGE pieces of fish, masterfully sliced and laid atop tiny morsels of rice. Amazingly fresh. Far better than I expected on a Sunday night. Even the rice was perfect - in temperature, texture and taste. Too many sushi places undervalue the rice.

Next time we'll go just for the sushi. Not because the udon and tonkatsu fell short, but because the fish was so delish.

Minus one star for using imitation crab meat in the rolls.
author: Shawn S.

description:
Upon getting many recommendations of being the best sushi place around, I went along with a group of friends to indulge myself in some fresh flavorful fish! 

Now, being Japanese..I have become a total sushi snob. This ranks in my books average, maybe slightly over average. Flavorful, and definitely fresh. A bit pricey for what you get, but I guess that is the price that comes with a bistro. I ordered the Sexy Scallop & Toro Lime (?). I was a bit disappointed with the toro because it didn't specify that it was cooked! I wish I was aware of that because I am a HUGE fresh toro fan. Regardless, the cooked toro was pleasant...warm & cuddly, and full of flavor. The bf surprisingly liked it, since he is a hater of seafood..so to him, that says a lot! Not bad, topped off with some sake & pitchers of beer! They do have other menu selections such as teriyaki beef, chicken, tempura, etc. and daily specials. 

The dining is modern & ambiance is enjoyable. Great selection of music playing! Just be aware that SB is not a huge place; so for larger parties be aware, but no worries, they take reservations. We had a party of 7 & playing puzzle with the plates to fit on the table was fun filled. The service was average, not sure if it was because it was busy, but one of the servers seemed a little rushed, other than that they were on top of it. 

Well nothing fishy here but the smell of sushi itself! :)
author: Catherine O.

description:
Wow - what great little place! Too bad it is constantly packed and you should just always make a reservation.

Had been meaning to try this place for a long time. Finally had 'sister night' there. It is small and packed inside with a little sushi bar counter in the corner. Service was fast and fine - nothing spectacular. 

There is a good selection of beers and sakes. I am in love with the Hawaiian Breeze roll. The Monster in Law was good too. They have lots of good "Jive Ass" rolls for white people here. Their brown rice rolls are not made with traditional brown rice - so do not be surprised when it comes and the rice looks white. They do use a form of brown rice but with the sugar and vinegar added it bleaches it out.  The Hot Devil unique app dish was Not good. I can't wait to go back and try more rolls!!
author: Jessica L.

description:
My wife and I went last night. She ordered the Crouching Tiger, etc. Roll and I ordered the Hawaiian Something Something Roll. Both were excellent. Very fancy (i.e. spicy mayo and garnish everywhere). Think we paid $35-40 for the two rolls, two drinks, and tip. Was a very positive experience except for the loud/shitty music and the drunken sorority girls at the table next to us. Will def go back. Hopefully they won't be there. If they are... trouble. 

Oh. And because the music was so loud, the waiter messed up my wife's drink order. Didn't bother me, but I bet the waiter was pissed. 

Maybe he wasn't. I don't know.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
Sashimi & Nigiri = Fresh & generous!
Sake = wide selection!
Waitstaff = friendly, despite their HUGE crowds!

Always busy when I go, but somehow I've gotten lucky and haven't had to wait too long for a table!

Butter fish is TO-DIE-FOR.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
off the "something unique" menu:
7 flavor albacore
magic mushroom
pepper lime toro

bistro signature rolls:
monster-in-laws
yellowtail basil

First off, I love their signature logo. IT'S SO SUPER KAWAII!~!~!!!
Okay so it's a bit tricky finding parking in this area and the restaurant is UBER cramped. Not too great for groups. It's also SUPER FREAKING LOUD IN HERE. MY THOUGHTS ARE IN CAPS LOCK.

Okay and now, on to the food. 

7 flavor albacore - I think it was seared a little too long because it made the fish a bit dry. Usually, I prefer it more raw. But it was okay..
magic mushroom - DELICIOUS. perfect blend of nutty crunchiness and the sauce was tangy and finger lickin good. 
pepper lime toro - this dish packs a little heat. it doesn't seem spicy at first, but keep eating it and eventually the heat resonates in all over your mouth. 

the rolls.

monster-in-laws: ha ha ha witty name. loves it. The fattiness of the salmon and hamachi goes great in this roll with the coolness of cucumber. The thinly sliced jalapenos on top cut the fatty goodness just right. 
yellowtail basil - the richness of hamachi is complimented beautifully with the earthy spicy bite of basil. 

I have no clue how much the bill was, but thanks for dinner Balalallalalalalalalalalalalalala.
author: Susy C.

description:
My friends and I actually wandered into Sushi Bistro after feeling unwelcome and uncomfortable at another sushi bar down the street.  I was happier here at SB because I can be as loud as I want when I'm enjoying my friends' company.

The portions are HUGE for the price they charge.  I was so happy and surprised to get a huge ass plate of sushi, with salad (great dressing), and fruit!  It's like the entire food pyramid was in front of me.  I just had an overall great experience here.
author: Grace M.

description:
8/15/2006: Met a fellow Yelper here tonight...he's a cutie and a waiter at Houston's. He was on a date with a very cute girl (I think it was a date). Anyway, we were talking about how great Sushi Bistro is...then I actually got to have a full conversation with Xin and Debbie (the owners)...I love this place. It's really the only Sushi restaurant I ever want to spend my hard earned money at. They know what I like to order too! I'm a regular now and I could not be more pleased. What an amazing, amazing place. I love you Sushi Bistro...Xin...you are a true artist...keep up the great work.


7/31/2006 Try the caucasian afro...it's so good, it's so original. I love it!



5/5/2006
THE BEST SUSHI IN THE ENTIRE CITY....ok...The BAY AREA.
THE Sushi chef/owner is an outstanding artist.
Toro, hamachi nigiri belly, lettuce wrap-Summer, Watermelon Man Roll-a must.!!!!
Make a reservation...you will thank me later.
************************************************************************

OH-MI-GAWD! This is THE ONLY PLACE for sushi. WHOA. I am completely and utterly blown away. The nigiri sushi is rockin. You get a bit...I mean a bit of rice and 3 bites of fish. Sushi Bistro has definitely upped the ante when it comes to sushi. The tastes, textures and freshness is amazing. I tried the ocean trout from Australia and thought ok for 5 bucks what the heck (first I really though eww trout). It was like salmon rollin on E.
