The rolls are good...but if you are a sushi purist you will love the nigiri sushi. The service is spot on as well. WOW. I never would have known if it were not for the amazing Yelpers on this site...thank you for making my birthday dinner something special. 

****

I've been back once every week or every other week  and it keeps getting better! The toro (belly) is orgasmic...it's super huge and melts on the tounge. mmmmmm.
author: Sherie R.

description:
Yet another great sushi joint here in SF!  The place itself is quite small and loud but that aside the staff is quick and ready help out at a moments notice.  me and the wifey met up w/ some family friends and we all enjoyed our meals.  The none-raw folk had some chicken katsu and teriyaki and were quite satisfied.  An appetizer called Hot Love (baby lobster, avocado, crabmeat wrapped in white fish) was ordered and this thing was crazy good!  

For the sushi, the fish all was so fresh and flavorful!  This what was ordered:

The New Legend - Shrimp Tempura and avocado, topped w/ seared albacore and a spicy garlic sauce....  hit roll for all of us!
Stinky Salmon - Can't remember exactly how this was setup but tons of salmon = happy goodness!
In-Laws - Chopped yellowtail, cucumber, green onion, topped w/ more yellowtail...  can't go wrong w/ yellowtail...
Napoli - Shrimp, salmon, tuna, tobiko, albacore all wrapped in soybean paper...  this is what i call a GREAT sampler platter :-)
Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon - Shrimp Tempura, avocado, topped w/ Unagi...  YUM!
Toro Sashimi - WOW... like butta!
Crunchy Veggie Roll - deep fried veggies w/ additional cream cheese...  good good stuff!  the cream cheese and the sweet potatoes just tasted so nice together!
Classic Veggie Hand Roll - The blech roll of the evening...  just a bunch of leaves and rice...

Definitely would recommend and would easily go back here!
author: Swarup B.

description: I went back a handful of times now and I am never disappointed. The fish is always fresh (I almost always order a plate of sashimi), the ambiance is somewhat fancy and the dishes are well presented and timely served. Nothing to say about the service. It is what it is supposed to be.
author: Cemeldosce M.

description:
Best sushi in San Francisco?  I certainly think so.  Even being from an island where the sushi fish is always alive 20 minutes before eating.  And not merely alive in a tank or something, but in the ocean - swimming around with a little fishy smile on its little fishy face.  This has been my standard for fish for years.  Sushi Bistro lives up to this quality.

I recommend:

The Big Island Roll:
Named for my homeland, this roll comes with what seems a half-pound of fish wrapped in slightly sweet cucumber sheets.  Simple, carbfree, and delicious

The Double Jeopardy:
I'm not sure what this delicacy has to do with double jeopardy, other than the fact that I would gladly get convicted twice for the same crime if they served these in San Quentin.  Its a mound of chopped tuna and salmon held together with avocado, and a delicious sauce drizzled over it.  It comes with shrimp chips for dippers.  This mound of omega-3-rich deliciousness is only $10 or so dollars!  Cheap!

Come down to Sushi Bistro, but get in before the dinner rush starts, or you'll be waiting out on cold windy Balboa all night for a table.

Sushi Bistro, you get all "5".
author: Thomas M.

description: Very unhappy with the service. Waitress didn't make me feel welcome at all. Never returning here and I don't recommend. Pricey as well.
author: Rai V.

description:
I have searched far and wide for sushi in San Francisco, and have finally found one worth returning to time and time again.  I've been three times now, and have been impressed every time.  The fish is fresh, the rolls are creative, and the staff is very friendly and helpful.  The wine selection is decent.  The beer is better.

For those of us who don't live nearby, parking can be difficult in the Inner Richmond in the evenings, but parking on Balboa seems to be the way to go.
author: Kelley W.

description:
Once upon a time, I lived on 5th and Balboa, and Deep Blue Sushi was reincarnated into Sushi Bistro. The transformation was slow. It probably went unnoticed to those who did not live within a one block radius. The place was delicious with that fresh from the ocean taste from the get go. I used to walk over for their bargain lunch specials and quick dinners at least 3 times a week. I knew that the tides had turned when I saw the owner shopping in Union Square toting a very nice LV bag.

Years later, the place closed for lunch, appeared on a national iPhone commercial, and has re-located to bigger digs just a few doors down. And it's still just as delicious. Although, you have to wait a while for a table. Well... maybe not as long now that they have more space?

Big ginormous glasses of ice water, actual low-sodium soy sauce (and not just regular soy sauce with a green lid), and an occasional scoop of green tea ice cream for dessert, when your waitstaff remembers. 

I like the 49'er roll, Philly roll, and everything butterfish. My fave sushi place in all of San Francisco based on both quality of food and environment. Still a biatch to find parking though.
author: ms n.

description:
Love love love The New Legend Roll here.  I have yet to try every single one of their Bistro Signature Rolls, but so far, The New Legend is my favorite.  I always come in thinking that I will try their sashimi and nigiri, but I always succumb to their extensive list of fancy schmancy creations.  It takes me a long time to decide on what to get, so if you're the wishy washy type, don't come here!

I like the fact that you can make reservations for this place, but I do not like the fact that you're always bound to wait for your supposedly reserved table.  And be sure to get there no later than 15 minutes after your reservation time, or they will give away "your table" to the next patron.
author: Diane L.

description:
My friend picked this place based on Yelp reviews! I'm glad that I suckered her in! Hahahhaa!!!

She made a reservation and I'm glad she did coz the place was packed when we arrived and literally the same guys who waited for the table when we arrived, got seated when we left! Poor thing. We were tempted to ask them to pull a chair right by us and have dinner with us....We had a nice corner table and another table of 8 were celebrating someone's bday with their party hats on! Can't miss them!

Service was fast eventhough it was ridiculously packed! Everything was so tasty and the presentation of each dish was really nice! Most importantly the rice to fish combination was excellent, not too much rice and it wasn't packed solid! 

Agedashi tofu, soaking in the broth, delicious! The Maui salad was fresh and yummy avocado, mango, macadamia nuts to its mixes! We had a bunch of rolls to share and all were unique and just very different! Hawaiian, Omega 3 with all kinds of fish, Volcano, Waikiki, Yellowtail Basil, everything was just heavenly! 

Parking was a nightmare but it's worth it, we'll be back!
author: Yan M.

description:
I've been here twice after hearing a million recommendations and am mad at myself for not coming sooner considering I've lived 4 blocks away for a year and a half! This is really good sushi! I will say that I am not a fan of a couple of the dishes I've tried here (Sexy Scallops weren't my thing although appealing in the name and neither was Hot Love (what? I was on a date with some dude who liked those names, I just went along)) but the Hawaiian Breeze, Watermelon-Man, and Caterpillar Rolls have kept me craving more! They are going to seriously have to ban me from the restaurant now considering I'm going to go in debt eating dinner there!

I dined in one Sunday around 6 and was seated promptly and service was excellent! We got our food really quickly and it was great! I'm not too great on chop sticks and had a slightly difficult time eating in because the rolls are really big and I was too embarrassed to ask for a fork, I made do though, can't complain too much about a generous piece of food! The second time my friend and I ordered to go and once again we were given our food quickly and headed back to my house to feast over a glass of wine, this time I cheated with the fork and was in heaven! I ordered two specialty rolls and had enough food for two dinners for only about $22. Not bad for walking distance!
author: Amber E.

description:
Sushi, once such an exotic cuisine, has lost its "newness." The rainbow rolls are tasty, sure, but it would be nice to have more exciting options once in awhile (and I don't mean ordering a spider roll instead).

Sushi Bistro tries to bring that "newness" back by Americanizing the menu  and introducing unique roll combinations that actually taste pretty good. In fact, most of their menu consists of their own creations..with the "typical" sushi restaurant findings tucked in way at the bottom of a back page. They are saying to you, "Get those traditional rolls somewhere else."

I came here last night for dinner. A last minute decision only because our original destination was closed for vacation. The place was packed, but we still managed to snag 2 seats at the bar. Service is quick--almost a bit rushing, as in, "let me rush you right out of here so we can have a quicker turnaround." I don't like that kind of rush...minus one star. 

The food, however, was decent. More for the creativity than the taste. I ordered the Sexy Scallop. My friend got 5 Wishes. Both were relatively tasty and a nice attempt at introducing something different. Not authentic, but hey, you get those traditional rolls elsewhere, remember? 

Between getting the bill and paying for it, we probably had a 5 minute lag time (during which we were once again rushed by the waiter). Afterwards, they practically threw the unsigned credit card receipt at us. Didn't like that move much, but at least they had good aim. 

Not a bad meal, but I still suffered indigestion afterwards. Only this time, it's not from the fish--it's from the service.
author: Rona J.

description: Based on location the prices could/should be much better...it's in the Mission! The real Mission mind you, not the Valencia/Guerrero hipster area. The rolls were descent, the best by far was one that had seared albacore on top of it, forget the name - that's how memorable this place was. Service was good, food ok, prices are expensive for the area.
author: Fernando E.

description:
sushi is my FAVORITE food!!!
i went here on a friday night, my brother had made reservations. . .
it was packed!!! 
First thought of the place was probably your typical sushi lounge. . .modernized inside. . .parking sucks (i think its because i'm from socal/OC not from the bay)

As we walked in, the sushi chef whom was all the way in the back spotted my brother and greeted him. . .i thought was pretty cool

We ordered sashimi sampler, dragon roll, crunchy roll, tempura, karaage (fried chicken), and my brother's gf ordered the chicken terriyaki. . .

I would stick to the sushi and seafood. . .the chicken was dry and over cooked. . .sashimi platter the pieces were HUGE!

Even though it was a really busy night, the service was sensational!

i would definately come back
author: Remie M.

description:
Holy Hamachi Batman, this place is awesome.  I've worked in the restaurant industry some and I usually have a rule about three things...never ever order the special, never go to a buffet brunch and never order fish on a Sunday.  This is my rule unless it's a really nice place, so nice they get shipments daily or at least on Saturday, otherwise you are eating whatever didn't sell from the Thursday or Friday shipment.

Now, this place must fly to Hawaii, go to the fish market and get back on the plane to serve dinner that same night because the fish is always soooo unbelievably fresh (and yes, I know I spelt "so" wrong, but I don't care!) it just melts in your mouth.

Their dishes and rolls are very creative with some incorporating macadamia nuts and mango without over-powering the taste and texture of the raw fish.  

Prices are pretty much what you would expect for a nice sushi place, not Ozuma prices, but not Fune Ya (see my other review).  The only issue here is the place is pretty small so you may have to wait for a table. (If it's too long a wait, try Namu next door--review pending--that place is awesome too...maybe I should move!)

The other great thing is I went here one time and called ahead to find out about a corkage fee, it was $5!  I brought a beautiful bottle of Sake I had gotten as a gift, it was heaven.
author: Kanoa B.

description:
A favorite of ours,  sushi that even my new palette can appreciate. Place is always packed, even this past Sunday evening. Wait can be a bit long but worth it. There are always seats opening up at the bar/counter where you can see the chef(s) creating their masterpiece rolls. Order from their specialty section of the menu. Mango inspired sushi roll is a favorite, Hawaiian Breeze. Odd how they come up with some of the names of the rolls? More reminiscent of a line of soaps from a shop.

Place is small, so it can get crowded and loud. Reggae music is always spinning in the background. Actually good recognize the artist for once in my life. Not a bad choice.

Service here is attentive but hit or miss. With such a busy place you might have two different servers. And both will ask if you have ordered, and you will have to ask for something more than once on occasion. They will eventually get it right. The runner at Sushi Bistro was on top of it all though.

And the door is broken. It closes so slow letting lots of cold air in. Bring a sweater.
author: Ryan G.

description:
AWESOME... just awesome! 

Hand roll sushis are twice the diameter of most hand rolls I've seen. And the specialty items are unlike any sushi I've eaten. The ingredients are fresh, the concoctions are creative, and presentations are inviting. 

This visit we ordered... 

***** Agedashi Tofu: likely fried tofu which has a soft film around each piece topped with dry bonito flakes and scallion and served on a sweet soy broth bed. I saw surrounding tables with this plate thus I ordered it. 

***** Ahi Tuna Poke Special: Good size cubes of fresh Ahi tuna marinated and served on a bed of baby greens. Portion is big! 

***** African Spider Roll: Cajun flavored albacore, salmon, soft shell crab, sprouts, tobiko roll, avocado and a spicy sauce. 

***** Five Wishes Roll: Snow crab meat, salmon, tuna, yellow tail, albacore and avocado roll served on a bed of greens and sauce. 

The wait people were attentive, paying attention to our tea cups always being filled. The bistro is clean and contemporary. As I understand it, the bistro recently moved here from a store front a few doors down the block. By 7PM until we finished the bistro was pretty full and noise decibel was high.
author: Nanette L.

description: SO GOOD!! I dont remember names, but had a fried roll with basil (amazing) and another roll with brown rice and sliced apple (sooooo goood!).  I cant believe it has taken me this long to try this place!  I will be back, and soon!
author: Justine S.

description:
Delicious! Scrumptious! Absolutely divine! Sushi Heaven!!!!!!!! 

Came here last night on a whim with my bf and wow...this is now my new favorite spot in the city. Sushi Bars are like Vegas to me...a natural high like no other! Happy environment. Friendly staff! Super clean! 

We started with the Bi Sho Nen sake. My ultimate favorite sake ever and I'm so excited they serve it as I haven't found it anywhere! 2 pints of draft Kirin! Chilean Sea Bass and Soft Shell Crab appetizers were the best! BF had the Chicken Terriyaki and Tempura dinner. Tasty! I had the 10 piece Sushi Nigiri. WOW!!!! And unlike another review of SB, the fact that the fish was larger then the ball of rice is definitely a plus in my book! HUGE pieces of fish. Lovely taste and very fresh! Who wants rice really anyway????? 

YAY for SB and all of it's yumminess! Got to love it!
author: Ayrn H.

description:
1) The food was good, we had some first timers with us and they liked it :)
2) The pricing was OK, around 20$ each
3) the service very good, the waiter was very tentative and friendly and he didn't give me a face when I change my order after he had taken it.
3) the environment, I was really satisfied. Since we had reserved a big table, it was in the back, which was very small, so the tables were so close to each other and the music was so loud that we could hear each other at the same table!!!!
SO I might give them another try, but probably a smaller group to sit in the front, maybe it'll be better...maybe then I'll become a fan ;)
author: Gnaz A.

description:
I've been wanting to check this place out for a while, and I am happy to say that it was well worth the wait...

They have officially opened their new location, and though I can't compare it to its previous home a few blocks away, I can say that it looks cute and trendy, but not over the top... is dressed with warm colors and mood lighting... feels cozy, but not claustrophobic. 

As for the staff, they were very friendly and attentive. Perhaps the new place gives them more to smile about.

Now, the sushi.... let's just say, my belly is smiling. I'll admit I'm not a fancy sushi eater, but my crunchy roll and rock n' roll were delicious. My friend had two vegetarian rolls which she said were also pleasing and filling to her tummy. They have an extensive and creative list of rolls that I am looking forward  to trying during my next visit, which I can already project will be within the next 2 weeks.


$$... After 4 rolls, 1 tea and 1 diet coke, our bill came out to $36 before tip. Considering I am full and happy, I think that's well worth the visit.
author: Kirsti P.

description: I'm not the type of girl to be a regular anywhere, mostly cause there ware too many good places to eat at in San Francisco, but if I was to list my most frequented restaurant, it would probably have to be Sushi Bistro.  Their sushi is consistently good - fresh, innovative, and delish.  One of my favorite things about SB is that they use a thin layer of rice in their rolls, not the huge gummy layer that fills you up.  You really get the chance to taste the deliciousness of their rolls this way.  Every time I come, I wonder why I don't come back more often.  I think I will make it my goal to get my own personalized sake box by the end of next year.
author: Sheryl D.

description:
Good, solid American-style sushi joint, meaning big rolls slathered with avocado, macadamia nuts, creamy sauces, and the like. The fish isn't extraordinary but they dole it out in big thick slices. Bring some friends and try out a bunch of different rolls. 

My favorite menu item is the Summer wrap, a big drippy collection of sushi rice, unagi, salmon, tuna , and avocado served in a lettuce cup.  The sushi combo is a great deal as well-- six big pieces of nigiri, california roll, soup, salad, rice for $13.50.

Based on the reaction of my more gastronomically traditional Japanese friend, I wouldn't recommend this place if you're looking for pure raw-fish-induced nirvana. But I like it fine.
author: kennon l.

description:
If you want authentic japanese food - DON'T GO HERE.

If you want japanese food with a twist on it - DON'T GO HERE.

What the heck is everyone thinking? We saw all the reviews on yelp, and even had a recommendation from a friend to come here.  BIG MISTAKE. 

We ordered the chicken teriyaki on steamed veggies, the 49er roll (salmon, lemon slices, tobiko, and avocado), and the spicy crunchy roll (i forgot what's in it).

First of all.  the chicken teriyaki?  It's like peppered bland chicken with a few sesame seeds and a watery sauce (the consistency was really like water) that i guess is supposed to be teriyaki sauce.  how can you mess up on such a standard dish? I mean, maybe it doesn't have to be outstanding, but at least it can be decent.

The sushi - nothing spectacular. it was so not worth the money. i think the spicy crunchy roll was around 11-12 dollars and we got six pieces. SIX PIECES!!!!  i can understand if the sushi is outstanding or the fish melts in your mouth... but no, IT DIDN'T!!!! The 49er roll had no taste to it.  the only flavor i tasted was the soy sauce i put on it and the thick slice of lemon.

This is one place where it actually hurt and pained me to pay for the bill... and i've NEVER felt that way about a restaurant and it's food before.

do not come here if you are at all interested in eating good japanese food. service was crap. we were totally rushed.. i mean, yes it was busy, but don't rush me out the door or when i'm paying my bill.  right when they took away our plates he came right back with the bill like speedy gonzales.  so, i took out my card, and then the bf was discussing if maybe we should leave cash instead... it was so apparent that we were not ready to pay our bill.  i had my card out and some cash... and up comes the server "are you ready?"... like.. UH.. NO.  sheesh... gimmie a minute at least!  can i at least chill for a minute???

it's a no go for sushi bistro.
author: Kimberly F.

description:
Places like this make me question my sanity in having left san fran to go to boston. I tried this place last year and my heart was thumping as I drove up to it today. Who puts fuji apples in their sushi? Sushi Bistro. Who uses soy paper to wrap their sushi? Sushi Bistro. 

Come here ready to eat. M&L Forever, Nemo Found and Black Weeds. SO good. Black Weeds was by far my fave. Ahi with black pepper and sesame oil, topped with seaweed salad and albacore. 

Not only are their signature wraps to die for, but they offer a really cool array of veggie wraps(not just he boring cucumber...asparagus...) The sake list is awesome as well. Their actual dinners are really wild too. 

This place kicks ass if you are getting tired of your regular run of the mill sushi/japanese places.
author: Spencer N.

description:
Recently I was craving some sushi and sashimi in the inner Richmond area. I had a couple choices.. head to j-town, stay in  the Richmond, or go to Irving. I weighed my options. Did I want to drive 15 minutes to j-town? 20 minutes to Irving? Or stay in the Richmond? We decided to go to Sushi Bistro.

Sushi Bistro was quite good. We had the hamachi kama, uni, big eye tuna nigiri, toro sashimi, two signature Sushi Bistro special rolls M&L forever  (spicy tuna, crab meat, cajun flavored albacore, avocado, and grilled big eye tuna inside a crispy exterior drizzled with bonito sauce.) and the sashimi spirit (shrimp ebi, salmon, ahi tuna, butterfish, tobiko and avocado wrapped in soy paper topped with scallions.) yum yum. As usual, I also got the agedashi tofu. I think I can now openly say that I am an agedashi tofu connoisseur, every Japanese restaurant that I go to, I experience their agedashi tofu. 

To go along with the meal, we got a bottle of Aladdin, a nigori sake that is in a pinkish bottle that reminds you of Aladdin's lamp (woohoo go Disney!)

The service was great,  the food was brilliant, and they have very innovative sushi rolls. The only downside was portion size for their signature sushi rolls (there were around 8 pieces.. small pieces) and the big eye tuna nigiri was a bit odd, the tuna was a bit torn up and seemed to be stretched on the rice. The toro however was great and melts in your mouth like it should. 

As most good food is, the tab was relatively hefty for the amount of food I ate. BUT I left happy and satisfied with the fish and tofu in my belly
author: Tony W.

description:
Yum, this place was good. I was pleasantly surprised to by how good the sushi was. Fresh and delicious. There was a thirty minute wait for 2 on a saturday night around 9pm. It was definitely busy and the tables were a little close together. Other than that it has hip cool vibe with black walls and hipster music.

We started off with a large house hot sake. The sake was good and warming on a cold night, but this was one of the smallest "large" sakes i've gotten at a restaurant. I'd call it an average or a small. There was only about 4 or 5 shots in the whole thing.

Food:

MIso glazed chilean sea bass: I order this dish at almost every restaurant that i go to. it's a solid dish and i've never had a bad miso glazed fish. I prefer it with cod though; it's a richer, silkier, more buttery fish. This dish was good. Solid. But i prefer the miso cod i make at home.

Drunken Halibut: Alright, but probably wouldn't order it again. Not particularly memorable. The sea bass was better.

Hawaiin Breeze roll: Delicious!! I highly recommend this. I loved the mango and apple in the roll it was so refreshing and tastes really good with raw fish. The flavors compliment each other and don't compete. Also i've had macedamia nuts on a few other rolls and it always goes well with fruit and adds a nice texture.

I can't wait to go back and try some more of their creative inventions. They have some really interesting rolls with fun names. A bit pricey but the fish was fresh and the dishes well thought out.

PS - i looked at the pix and the portions for the nigiri sushi look very generous!
author: Aleyna S.

description:
The best sushi in the Richmond. Who knew there could be so many more variations of rolls?  Lobster.  Macademia Nuts.  A drizzling of mystery aoili on top. The sushi selection is huge and the sake list is even bigger.

And so far my sushi pet peeve is no where to be found.  When the rolls are so big that you can't fit the whole thing in your mouth, thus leading to chucks falling out into the soy sauce creating a splash up effect.  I have damaged many a white blouse this way.
author: Starla D.

description:
i LOVE sushi bistro. I haven't been there in a long time, and I hope that I eventually get a chance to.

This is a great little spot in the Inner Richmond that my friend and I discovered about 2 years ago when we were looking for great sushi places. the one we used to frequent in West Portal (Hinabi) had been stolen from our japanese food happiness.

Anyways, what can I say? This place is dope! The portions given are more than enough for anyone. One of the rolls I tend to get is the Summer Veggie roll, and Finding Nemo Roll. My friend usually get the chicken katsu dinner which is way too much to eat! Let's put it this way, when we order...it doesn't all fit on our table.

The place is cute and small, so it should be best known to come during non-peak hours (usually 730 - 930pm), and that parking can be a pain to find as well. It's in a residential neighborhood with very few neighboring shops, so if you come and wait to be seated...bring something amusing to do or bring good company. 

My favorite night to go is on Friday nights...why? because they play reggae music on those nights, and they turn up the volume loud! (Well, they have played reggae music on those nights i've gone...) 

Take a chance on sushi bistro. It will forever be on my list of great places to go in the city of SF. and it's not too badly priced either. I wish i could go there now...=T
author: J D.

description:
OK not the greatest but certainly an entertaining meal. IF you want to try something you never thought of... at least you will only get 6 peices at most. we stuck with just rolls and manage to put away 5 different rolls. Each something unique.

We had the rainbow roll and unagi atop a California roll, small pieces; ho hum fair. 

We also ordered from the special rolls menu which i have to has some pretty daring stuff.

Apples!? Who has apples with seared tuna? and pickled onions on top? is it even sushi?? well maybe not but its not bad, kinda interesting... 

There was a crouching tiger hidden dragon kinda roll, a bit exotic in name but nothing fancy going on.

And the best roll was wrapped in thin soy sheets! 

Aside from the oddly named movie titles that we consumed i have to say they have a good selection of sake.... but extremely over priced... Who pays 16.5 for a box of onikoroshi??? I mean you can buy the whole bottle for twice that much!

Daily specials looked good, Ankimo was available but i am always hesitant ordering that because i can never tell if they have clients that knows good ankimo from bad... cause i have yet to learn that myself!

I would go with a minimal appetite and a large group, get the most bang for your buck, that is assuming you manage to find parking... Its just horrid at night when everybody is back at home...
author: Brian Y.

description: Fish tasted very fresh and ambiance of the place was nice.  I tried four different types of rolls and all were good but serving size was small.  Left feeling unsatisfied.
author: L E.

description:
Now, I have yet to have any bad experiences with sushi, no matter how many seedy or posh places I have been to, expensive or not.  But the Bistro has done it in ridiculous fashion.

Major props to this intimate place.  I have never been let down, no matter how high my expectations have been.  There isn't a bad, mediocre, so-so, OK, or good item on the menu, because everything is excellent. 

Nigiri? Got it covered. Sashimi? A+. Seaweed salad? Good lord, order me two bowls at a time and keep 'em coming. 

To the rest of the competition in the city: IN YOUR FACE!
author: Zo L.

description:
Reggae + sushi = greatness.

What more can I ask for?

I'm a big sashimi fan, so I'm very particular about my sashimi. Their sashimi is fresh, delicious, a melt in your mouth experience. It's something that is definitely worth your money.

I live a block away, so I'm a regular, the service and atmosphere is great, though the music can be a little bit to loud when talking with your friends. 

Still, great food.
author: Carissa E.

description:
It pains me to do this... maybe I just came on a bad night? But I have been reading the reviews and the menu since last december and I was looking forward to coming all the way to san francisco and then to sushi bistro just to finally have some awesomenes....

I was so disappointed... but heres where my adventure begins..

The place was super crowded, and we finally got seated next to this other couple who got menus right away. We still hadnt gotten ours so when they set them down, I politely took one of the menus for my friend and I, which led to a convorsation with them, and 3 or 4 rounds of sake bombs between us 4. Even though I was disappointed in their sushi, this couple and the sake bombs made everything better. And made everything a bit more fuzzy, hahaha. 
The waiters and the chef were friendly and nice. Very attentive considering how busy they were. But we did come on a friday night at around 9ish.
I did like the yellowtail basil roll though, it was very good. But I must say, some of the hawaiian type rolls were not impressive at all. It made me sad. (but the sake and asahi made me happy... very happy) :)
author: Katie P.

description:
I GOT SO LUCKY THE DAY I CAME HERE! Found parking in 3 mins and got seated right away at 7pm! PEAK DINNER TIME! GOOD DAY! GOOD DAY! 

OMFG! SOME OF THE BEST SUSHI/SASHIMI I'VE EVER HAD! The sashimi was really fresh, and the waiter recommend a few that were so buttery, that it literally melted in my mouth! 

The Sushi are very innovation and trendy, yet original that it doesn't go way over board like the new trendy sushi places that are around. They give you an ample amount of fish, so that you're not just eating a mountain pile of rice! 

The price is reasonable for what you're getting and service was great as well!
author: Brian P.

description:
OMG!!! I think I'm in LOVE with this place!  For Japanese restaurant, Sushi Bistro is on top of my list! I love almost every single sushi roll Ive tried here!! Most of their rolls are completely unique/original and you cannot find it any place else.  

What i love about the rolls is that they put a very thin layer of rice but just enough to cover the whole roll without the seaweed showing.  Unlike other sushi restaurant that put loads of rice to get you overly stuffed.  Even though they put less rice, they put more fish, vege etc.. inside the roll.  They also have a selection of brown rice rolls.

I also enjoy the Tuna Delight which have great seasoning and crunchy crispy string things on top.  YUMS!

The prices are VERY reasonable for the quality of food you get.  I've went to sushi restaurants where I paid the same amount as I did in Sushi Bistro and got mediocre to crappy sushi before.  

Sushi Bistro is hands down my most favorite sushi/Japanese restaurant!
author: Jannifer H.

description: Poke Tuna Salad is my favorite here! Very fresh, light and delicious. It was fabulous!
author: Charlene K.

description:
I came here for an early dinner with my boyfriend. He wanted something sort of healthy to eat after running 10 miles earlier in the day. We ended up getting The Big Island roll, which is a big roll wrapped in thinly sliced cucumber, instead of nori, without any rice. The roll was huge, and stuffed wit h the freshest fish. We also tried the Stinky Salmon, which was great. My boyfriend got the appetizer dish called Double Jeopardy, which basically was a mountain of fresh salmon, tuna, and avocado to spread all over his shrimp chips. Also, the extremely fresh yet detailed sushi rolls came out in less than 10 minutes. 

We ate a lot, and the damage was under 50 for the both of us. It's usually pretty crowded at night, which is the only time they are open. We came right at 5, and beat the rush and found great parking and didn't have to wait at all for our food. After trying sushi bistro I am not going back to any other sushi restaurant. This place is the best.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Atmosphere: Casual and Loud but not annoyingly Loud, expect a wait (but you can get lucky due to location)
Sushi: The rolls are delicious and creative..safe to assume that this place has your "dream roll"...they got just about everything.
They have some rolls which they wrap in lettuce, a nice touch..
HUGE nigiri's (a little smaller then sushi zone, though)..
Quality: consistently fresh and delicious
Music: Always playing reggae..i love it!
--had a not so good piece of albacore nigiri here, stringy and chewy..hmmm, i had to remove one star...:(
author: CadoBaby P.

description:
This place is just phenomenal, best sushi I have ever had. The rolls are unique, full of flavor and do not have a lot of rice wrapped around them. It does make it harder to eat since they're full of fish with little rice so be careful not to break them. The sashimi is amazing, fresh and the platter comes with a huge variety with two of each, perfect for sharing. 

They just moved to a new location so it's not as packed as it used to be. Parking here can be a pain and there are no garages nearby. It is well worth it though. This place is nothing less than phenomenal.
author: Ahmed S.

description:
It is only fair that this place makes my list because I have had blast here every single time I've eaten here. Several factors that keep Sushi Bistro in conversation with Sushi Zone. Wait time is fair. Saki list is a killer. Hip music and young crowd. Fantastic Sashimi fresh as the ocean. Portions you actually get full from. 

Saki+Jalapeno Yellow Tail. Done.
author: My T.

description:
San Francisco is full of great sushi, so it's hard to be impressed by any old place with fresh fish, non-traditional combinations of ingredients, etc.

Sushi Bistro is amazing!!! Now I know what I have to aspire to at my next sushi-making party.

I love the reggae music and the signature rolls with less rice and custom sauces. Fantastic. Be sure to try the roll with yellowtail and basil.
author: Ellie P.

description:
UPDATE: Wish I could add more stars. Mad love for the hot love.

Went here on a first date. My date actually introduced me to the place... he  proclaimed it was his favorite sushi spot, regardless of the fact it was also his go-to, uber-convenient neighborhood sushi spot a few blocks away from his house. 

That night we started with the miso black cod on special (a dish I would not normally order) that was like a savory piece of heaven on a plate, lettuce wraps (a choice of "seasons" which contain different flavors) and a couple rolls.

I can't say I remember which rolls we got that night, but I've been back several times since I'll just go ahead and list my favorites: Albacore Dream, 49er, Nemo found, Omega 3. There are a ton more, and they are all wildly creative and fun so best bet is to go out on a limb and try something new. And when in doubt, order a roll with avocado.  We joke that there must be a secret avocado orchard oasis in the back of the restaurant because the rolls are literally bursting with the fresh avocado on too-consistent, suspicious basis.

The sashimi is fresh and the pieces are extremely generous. Ask for a sake recommendation - we got a cold bottle of something I don't remember, other than it being delicious. (This is the kind you won't necessarily want to yell "sake!" and slam a beer with, you actually want to take your time to enjoy.)

The atmosphere is extremely comfortable and friendly. And added bonus, they serve you a scoop of free ice cream to cap off your meal. Flippin' sweet. 

I wouldn't recommend going here with a group larger than 4 people, since it's a small place, but regardless of party size, you will most likely need reservations any day of the week. The fare is extremely reasonable, so if you want to go nuts on some great sushi and not feel totally guilty...you totally can.

Even if I had a horrendous, mind-numbing, run-away-screaming-and- lighting-my-hair-on-fire sort of date, I would still risk coming back again and again for the amazing sushi. But fortunately for me, I did not, and my boy and I make it a habit of spending a lot of quality time here.
author: Kelly R.

description:
After reading our trusty Yelp reviews, a friend and I decided to try this place. And as if the 350+ reviews wasn't enough I thought I would add my two cents. 

1¢: A whole vegetarian menu with things other than the same old, avocucumber roll. I felt like a real sushi go-er!

2¢: While they gave me the wrong order at first, the waitress totally didn't care and took it back with out a glare or the "i'm going to spit in your sushi when you aren't looking" under the breath comment.

I was happy. And full. And the tea was free!

Ok that was like 8¢....woops
author: Molly W.

description:
HAWAIIAN STYLE SUSHI

You'll find ingredients such as mango and Macadamia Nuts on your rolls at Sushi Bistro. Sounds sacrilegious, doesn't it? Give it a shot because you won't be disappointed.

I've had sushi for breakfast at the Tsukiji Fish Market in Tokyo and people would say that is the freshest sushi you can get. I left Japan craving creative rolls though. I've had fresh fish--I want creativity. 

Sushi Bistro's rolls are very creative. My favorite is the Monster-in-Law roll. Everything here is really good though. Parking is a bitch. It's not a restaurant I would take more than 6 or 8 people to though. It's cozy and quite popular. The price is quite reasonable also.
author: Cindy P.

description:
I just had dinner at this place of newly found fame thanks to the iphone Urban Spoon spot. It was a Sunday night so not totally packed but still had a good crowd and vibe. 

I have to say, I was completely overwhelmed by the menu! Over five pages, and when you're talking sushi...well that's a lot of fish descriptions to get thru. I left most of the decisions up to my dinner partner cuz I just couldn't wrap my head around it. 

The space is cool with nice vibe, but be prepared no one server assigned to you. It's a free for all with servers. I think we had six in total. But you are never left waiting long and everyone is kind and attentive!

What we had - What I thought

Hot Love - my fav. Totally different and tasty
Big Island - sounds delightful and ends up a little bland...lots of wasabi to spice this one up
Spicy Crunchy - my dinner partner's fav. lives up to its name...it's spicy and crunchy
Sesame Chicken - OMG fried chicken with sesame sauce...how can you go wrong. YUM! Perfect starter.
author: Jacqueline M.

description:
Of the rock n' roll sushi ilk.  Busy, loud, small, crowded.  Background music went from ibiza mix to depeche mode to journey, but thankfully no mash-ups.  So, not the place for a contemplative solo experience at the sushi bar, but the crowd seemed pretty upbeat.

Sushi: The salmon nigiri was very average, a bit tough and not that flavorful.  Hamachi nigiri was decent though not divine.  Same with the C2 roll.  The fish seemed unexceptional from a freshness standpoint.  I agree with the other reviewer who said that the fish/rice proportion for the nigiri was off.  I'm not an advocate of getting full from rice, but there just wasn't enough of it.  Priced a bit high for the quality you get.

Service: They need to hire a couple of extra people to achieve reasonably attentive service.  It looked like only two servers were handling the entire place.  They were hustling, but I went long stretches without hearing from anyone, especially at the end when I needed the bill so I could roll out of there.  It would have seemed even longer had I not struck up a conversation with the friendly couple sitting near me.  Once I got the bill, it charged me for an extra beer - a bit odd but I'll chalk it up to all the commotion.
author: Leon R.

description: this place is pretty americanized for a japanese restaurant but who cares, its a great restaurant! I ordered three rolls, C-2, crouching tiger hidden dragon, and the butterfish blaster. ALL WERE GOOD. I liked the butterfish blaster and the crouching tiger more than the C-2 but they were all good. Try the rolls here, theyre pretty good. The rolls are pretty pricey but the restaurant is pretty damn amazing!
author: Ryan L.

description:
I really enjoyed the ambiance of this joint. It's fun and hip in a non-pretentious way, and it draws a diverse crowd that is here with a similar purpose: to gorge on mounds and mounds of fresh sushi.

The service here is borderline rude in some instances, but I can overlook that 'cause they were so damn speedy.

The not-so-good: skip the nemo roll---cute name, not so cute presentation.  It looked like they just schlopped it on a plate haphazardly.  The taste was 'meh' as well.

Now for the really good: the sashimi bowl here is divine!  Sometimes you simply want to stuff your face full of mercury and Omega-3's and not mess with that other stuff.  Tried my friend's tempura, I'm a huge fan of kabocha squash and it was d-e-l-i-c-i-o-u-s (thanks for teaching me how to spell, Fergie!).  

Overall, it makes for a wonderful and memorable dining experience.
author: Manny P.

description:
YUUUUUUUM! this place is the sh!t. 

I finally tried this place out today (after living in the richmond for like a million years)! Great god this place is deeelicious. I ordered the "African Spider" and "The New Legend" and I was beyond satisfied. Every bite was filled with great flavor and excellent texture. The fish was so fresh! The only downer was that the pieces were kind of small for the price..maybe I'm just use to Sushi House(located in Alameda)-sized rolls. There was three of us and our bill came out to be 98ish bucks. Boo! We're broke little college kids!
author: josephine n.

description:
This is my favorite sushi dive! This place gives you a taste of what LA sushi dining might be like. They don't go too crazy with their special rolls like at other places where it gets so crazy you forget that you're eating at a sushi place. Their rolls are perfectly portioned and the fish is always their main star. Not the deep-fried batter surrounding, over-mayoed crab salad or disproportionate cucumber/avacado - its their fresh fish. And prices? Wellllll worth. Not too high and not jaw-droppingly low either but worth every penny. 

The New Legend, my favorite roll is a must. Their salad wraps are super yummy as well though filling (go for the Equinox). Wait staff friendly though often very frazzled because there is usually a line out the door no matter what day it is (reservations are recommended). Sushi Bistro is located in a good neighborhood, a few blocks away from clement. So it is a little ways walk if you want some crepes or boba tea for dessert. Since it is in  a residential area, parking may be difficult.
author: Tracy N.

description: I was just talking to my colleague about the most recent restaurant I have been and this place was the first thing that came up from my list. I eat out sushi a lot. I just love fish. When my friends and I came here to celebrate a birthday, I was blown away by their sushi and sashimi. They were so good. I had the uni and I thought it was so fresh. Their rolls were also great. I think this place lives up to the good reviews that they already have. I am most definitely positive that I will be coming back here again.
author: J C.

description: This place is awesome. Really good sushi and really nice people work there.
author: Simon S.

description:
Sushi Bistro, of iPhone commecial fame, is a winner!  Clean, modern, hip atmosphere (no rotating sushi boats here!), excellent service and a great variety of unique rolls and dishes that are well prepared.  The price was also very reasonable.  Two appetizers and two good size rolls for about $28 before tip (we didn't have any alcohol).  We were lucky enough to get two seats at the bar right away eventhough this place was jumping.

I'm not sure if this place is really loud or if it was just the 3 women at the bar next to us that were doing saki bombs!  My dinner partner, D. (female), also gave manager (male) high marks for cuteness!

Good date place or to go out with groups up to 6 people.  I definitely recommend this gem in the Inner Richmond.
author: Richard F.

description:
I'm weirded out that Sushi Bistro is on the most recent iPhone commercial. Yes, it's totes them.

Anyway, I went to SB technically two more times before I left the neighborhood. The first time we walked in, it was pretty busy like usual on a Saturday night. In the past, I'd walk in and get an acknowledgment and asked how many in my party. This time, no eye contact, nothing. When a table opened up, the guy gestured in our direction so I started walking over there but the host gave me a dirty look and I realized it was for another couple. The host then said, "Did you put your name on the list?!" And I was like wtf, there was never a list before, even on their busiest nights. I said, "No..." and he gave me serious attitude. He must have realized he was being a total a-hole because he seemed to soften and said, "How many?" By that time I was on my way out the door.

The service has never been super warm or friendly so I understand it could have been a real off night. It just left a bad taste in my mouth because I'd dined there many times before.

The second time I met there with a few co-workers and it was OK, now colored by my former experience. The food was also just OK. The fairy tale has ended for me.

Farewell Sushi B, you ain't that worth it.
author: Salina Z.

description:
God must have sensed my passion for sushi when he blessed this great city with Sushi Bistro.  Not only do they have the standards and classics, they offer new innovative rolls that are as unique as they are delicious.  I've never spent much time in the Inner Richmond area, but feel like it's my new hood because I've been spending so much time at this incredible place.  Try their sake - I love unfiltered sake and they have a fabulous selection.  The people are friendly, and the fish is more fresh than any other local sushi joint.  And if you're still not sure you want to go, then go with me and God help me if you're not licking your plate, I'll pay for your dinner.  Promise.

Oh and one suggestion: MAKE A RESERVATION!  I'm not the only one who knows how fantastic it is...
author: Whitney H.

description:
Very very good. My friends swear by this place and we finally came on NYE. Yes, it was hard to get a table, but we were so lucky to get one right by the window. It does live up to the hype. The fish is fresh and plentiful. The rolls are delicious. I particularly liked the aloha 101 and waikiki rolls. In fact we ordered several of them. We also ordered a chicken teriyaki with tempura which was also very good.

The only hard thing -- parking!
author: Natalie S.

description:
Need some "Hot Love"?  
Well you definitely can get it here...as well as a Caucasian Afro and Nemo Found...don't get me started on the C-2 (recommended by unanimous number of Yelpers)
WOW!  Went to this place just because I read awesome reviews on Yelp, and we were ALL impressed.  Great quality sushi, delicious, and huge portions!  And reasonably priced.  
Too bad it's so far from downtown, or maybe that's a good thing, cause I would be there every night.
It was very busy on a Wed. night, good thing I made reservations, especially for a group of 5.
author: Gemma P.

description:
It's really a haven for roll-lovers.  Each of us were blown away with our rolls; the "classic" ones like simple spicy tuna rolls were markedly well done (and would've been remarkable in any typical sushi joint) but kind of paled to the "performances" of the special ones. 

The grilled butterfish starter salad was super yum too, would've easily sufficed as a meal.
author: enmi k.

description:
Really good sushi, some very creative rolls, at a decent price.  Also, the service at Sushi Bistro is amazing - I really could not believe how fast they brought our food to us.  

I had a deep fried tuna mango roll which had amazing sauce and a fat piece of tuna in there.  Yuuuuuum.   The baby lobster handroll was also delish.  I wish Sushi Bistro was in my hood.

The only drawback is that parking is a little tight.
author: Sara M.

description: Good but they took forever to bring us our check
author: Y S.

description: One of the best sushi restaurants I've been too.  I always order M&L and New Legend rolls and beef udon. Tempura ice cream with tempura oreos is amazing.  Everything here is really fresh and high quality.  Great service too!
author: A C.

description:
I knew from the moment our server brought out the edimame that the sushi was going to be delish.  Seriously, after extensive research at many-a-sushi-restaurant, I've found the quality of sushi is directly correlated with the quality of edimame.   master of the obvious? perhaps.

But I digress...

The sushi is awesome... Huge, delicious pieces of nigiri, all very fresh.  The rolls were interesting and plentiful.  This was my first visit and I definitely plan to visit again.  Service was quick and friendly.   I imagine the place gets packed during primetime dinner hours so get there early!
author: Kristin S.

description:
butterfish blasters!!!!!!!  omg so heavenly!!!

we also ordered the african spider, c-2, crouching tiger hidden dragon, five wishes, and rock'n roll.   the c-2 was our favorite, and since i love baked rolls, the rock'n roll was super delicious too.  this is definitely a place to go splurge a bit - with a lot of their special rolls from 12-15.  the two of us easily spent over 100.  

i'm not too crazy about the restaurant itself.  since its super small, people are constantly crowding around the waiting area and entrance.  the wait seems super long.  also, the tables are squished extremely close together- so much so that you almost feel like you're sharing a table with people next to you and you have to literally move your table over when someone needs to get through.
author: Irene W.

description:
3.5 star restaurant, but not quite a fan just yet...

I made reservations for 9PM, but still had to wait about 20 minutes for a table for 9, which was somewhat ok considering it was a Friday night and our large group.Service was good as they were pretty attentive to our requests, but not so personable. Tables were a little smaller and hard to put our orders on the table in addition to our soy sauce plates, water cups, sake cups, sake bottles, and beer bottles. It was like a puzzle.

Sushi was really fresh, a BIG plus, but I do not see myself driving all the way out here for their sushi. My favorite:
Albacore Dream- spicy tuna topped with albacore. SO good. 4 stars
Butterfish Blasters- warm butterfish and then a cool center of snow crab. Very interesting. 3.5 stars
Hirame Fusion- Really bland and my least favorite dish. 2 stars
Black weeds- nothing spectacular. 2.5 stars
African Spider- crunchy soft-shelled crab, but couldn't taste the albacore. 3 stars.
Hot Love- pretty good. 3 stars.

If I happen to be in the area and craving sushi, I would give this place another try, but it is a little* bit pricier than other sushi places for the taste of the sushi, not the quality.

Note: I would make reservations especially on busy weekend nights or if you have a large party.
author: Ling H.

description:
Yum Yum Yum.
This is my new sushi spot.
I was surprised at how big the nigiri servings are.
My favorite roll was the Big Island roll.....
Service was quick and friendly.
I can't wait to go back!
author: Karlee D.

description:
I dig sushi bistro and it's one of my fav places to go on a week nite. Good sushi, fairly priced, creative rolls and good tunes. But I just noticed that they are moving 4 doors down the block!? I'm hoping it's b/c the place down the way is larger. Not sure how it will impact the ambiance and feel of the place but I am still down for at least 3-4 times a month. 

Stay tuned......
author: Brian C.

description:
GREAT SUSHI!  One of the best places for fresh, new, interesting rolls and a ton of sashimi.  

We came here in the middle of Heat Wave 2K8, so it was incredibly hot and stuffy inside, but since that's not normally a problem in this city, I'm willing to overlook it.  

The staff is friendly and helpful and if you sit at the sushi bar, the guys making the rolls are awesome!  I'll be sure to come here everytime I'm in the area.
author: Kathleen B.

description: This place is AMAZING! This is my first review and this place got me to write it, so that says something.  If you want great customer service, phenomenal sushi and a great atmosphere for a great price then you need to come here.
author: D D.

description:
Another yuppie restaurant with those for no true appreciation of good food. One lesson I've learned in life about Asian restaurants... When you walk into an Asian restaurant and the place is chock full of white people, the food is likely not going to be good. This was definitely the case with Sushi Bistro. The second I walked in and saw the place teeming with white people I knew I should've turned around and walked right out, but I was with 3 other friends and didn't want to make a scene. We ordered Monk fish Liver and Kumamoto oysters for an appetizer and the one thing I can comment on is that the oysters did not taste very fresh. I'm not very big on liver so I couldn't tell you if the monk fish liver was good or not, but my friend who does eat quite a bit of fish liver said it was definitely sub-par.. We proceeded to order 3 rolls including the African Spider, Monster In-Laws and the Sexy Scallop. The Sexy Scallop came out first and the scallops tasted like they had just been defrosted and were still soggy with a hint of mush. The Monster In-Laws arrived next with jalapenos on top that were so unevenly cut that some were a couple of mm's thick and others were so thin that only half the jalapeno cross section was there. Anyone ever heard of a mandoline? The fish was also clearly old, not to the point of being smelly yet, but enough that the fish mushed in your teeth. Then came the worst crime of all, the African Spider roll. To qualify my next statement I have to tell you that I order spider rolls almost every time I go out for rolls. This spider roll was the worst I've ever had. The only detail we need to get into is the soft-shell crab because that is what makes a spider roll a spider roll. I'm not even sure that there was any soft-shell crab because there was so much batter on the alleged "crab" because all I could taste was the fried batter. They left a couple pieces of the fried soft-shell crab on the plate outside the roll which was a nice thought, but I was extremely disappointed when all I tasted was extremely over seasoned deep fried batter. 

Now that we've covered the food I can talk about something that I rarely talk about at a restaurant, the service. I don't mind service that isn't great, after all I keep going back to "The House" in North Beach, but Sushi Bistro was downright horrendous. The first sign that the service was going to be bad was when they asked if we were ready to order and when we told them that we needed a few minutes. The server calmly walked away and 10 seconds later walked back to ask us if we were ready to order. But to be honest, I don't even mind that. What I mind is when the server clanks your water glasses and plates down on the table so loudly that you probably could have heard it across the room in one of the noisiest dining rooms I've ever been in. What was even worse than that was that is that instead of moving existing plates on the table to put new plates down the server took the new plates and pushed the already existing plates out of the way after clanking the new plates on the table. Terrible.... 

Needless to say we walked out after just 2 appetizers and 3 rolls and went next door to finish our dinner. 

I hate to make racial comments, but I'm a Korean who has grown up in SoCal and I've come to learn that a majority of non-Asians have no idea what Asian food is about regardless of how cosmopolitan they think they are. Point and case is that most rolls in America have mayo and or avocado.. Neither are used in Japan because they don't need the fattiness of either item to hide the taste of bad sushi... 

Word to the wise, if you ever walk into an Asian restaurant full of non-asians, walk right back out...
author: Joe Y.

description:
I kept telling my friends good sushi doesn't exist in San Francisco because every place I've ever been to just never worked out for me.... UNTIL I found sushi bistro!  Best sushi I've ever had in my LIFE.  I had the crouching tiger hidden dragon roll and it was amazing.  Perfect amount of rice, sauces, presentation, crunch... oooooooh delicious.  Spider roll looked good, and everyone else I was with LOVE LOVE LOVED their food.  Want good sushi? Go here!  Prices are reasonable too.  Yes, do make a reservation... it is necessary.

The only downfall was lack of good service and the restaurant was WAY TOO SMALL.  They need to expand or something.

Overall -- best sushi I've ever had EVER!  4 stars!
author: Shali N.

description:
I have been here many many times over the past four years and its a great place for a decently sized meal, particularly the teriyaki chicken/beef dinners. Some of their specialty rolls are also rather generous. Its important to keep in mind this place is fusiony. definitely not a place that would be on my list for traditional sushi. plenty of mayo and hot sauce splashed over the rolls-but tasty.

Summary: Good portions, non-traditional. Solid choice.
author: Randy K.

description: The sushi is still great, but the atmosphere has gotten cold and dark. Not like it was in the old days, with the whole family greeting you when you came in, everyone happy to see you. I miss that "Cheers" vibe it used to have, and my own hand-designed saki box waiting for me.
author: Yodel A.

description:
UPDATE:
It turns out the Sushi Chef earned the Michelin rating apprarently when he worked in L.A.

We went in for the first time and ate at the sushi bar. VERY friendly service and fast. And the sushi tasted better than ever. I don't know WHY they are located here - that said, this is a hidden gem.

OLD REVIEW:
I almost had a heart attack when Kate and I passed by S.B. and saw it was closed. Gosh golly, I had just discovered it. Then I found out on their website they were just closed a few days. Phew! I mean we have Shimo's and Minamii (see my other review) all within a chopstick grab of our home, and yet, thanks to reading about Sushi Bistro here on Yelp, we decided to see if it would be good enough to become part of our Saturday night sushi picnic tradition (which for Kate is truly fun!)

Well, it did. Kate thinks their maguro and tuna rolls and edamame and miso soup is just fine. I LOVE the roll with tuna and mango in it. The quality of the fish is excellent and there are some other creative rolls too.

One question: I see a Michelin logo on a little diploma like piece of paper near the cashier every time I go there. Is the chef rated?

In any case to quote a neighbor "There's actually an excellent sushi place on BALBOA in the early Avenues?" By jove there is!
author: Dennis S.

description:
Oooooh yes I think I've found my new favorite sushi place in the city. Even though parking is impossible I have a feeling that will be the only thing stopping me from going all the time. It's a teeny tiny place but luckily we made reservations and were seated right away. 

Our server was very friendly and helpful especially when suggesting his favorite sake. And he was right.

As for the sushi ... oh man I wish I had the stomach and the funds to try every single thing on the menu. But what I did try was amazing. The Spicy Crunchy was by far my fave and the M&L Forever and C-2 were easily tied for second. The Black Weeds I'd probably not get again but still, totally unique and yummy at the same time. Plus, you get so much food in just one roll and the prices are awesome.
author: Lauren B.

description:
After hearing nothing but praise about this place from several different people, I finally decided to give it a try as my college room mate was back in town and we wanted to both eat japanese and try something new.

The sashimi here is exceptionally good.  We tried the butterfish blaster (butterfish wrapped around crab meat), spicy tuna roll, tempura roll, and tuna, trout and ebi sashimi. The sashimi slices are very generous portions -- not your standard sushi joint sizes. Overall, the meal felt extremely authentic.

For price and quality, I give this place 5 stars.  The only downside was the ambiance.  We were trying to have a discussion after having not seen each other in a while, and the music was so loud that we had to almost yell to talk to each other.
author: Jenny S.

description: I am not a raw fish connissuer (too lazy to look up spelling,sorry), but i llike cooked rolls. The Stinky Salmon was one of the most unique ones I had in a while. It is a rice/seaweed roll with asparagus and mango in the center and cooked salmon and carmelized onions on top. It has a slightly sweet and spicy garlic sauce, so I can eat it w/o the soy and wasabi. Others at the table had traditional bento box/tempura fare. They weren't impressed, but seriously why are they ordering that stuff when there are so many interesting items on the menu. Definitely want to go back. Price was average for a Japanese restaurant. The place is a bit dark and the chairs are hard to sit on.
author: Stan P.

description:
3.5 stars actually. I was taught to round up. 

Looking for a place to eat around my new apt because I didn't want to lose my parking spot on the street. Waited for about 10 mins on a Saturday night before we got seated. The restaurant is pretty dark  and looks like it'll turn into a night club after 10. Music was loud and reggae mostly. Minor details. Down to the food.

We ordered tempura as an appetizer, because we wanted fried food. It was not so different from any other tempura out there. Shrimp though had too much breading. Then we ordered two rolls-Billie Jean and Hawaiian Breeze. Billie Jean had lobster in it. It was good but the aioli sauce was a bit too creamy for me. Hawaiian breeze was delicious. Fuji apple and nuts in a sushi roll....who knew it could be such a good combo? That's the great thing about this place, they are quite creative. The flavors of each roll was subtle but go very well together.  You can tell serious thoughts were put into the menu. Also, very fresh fish.

I'd probably come back here again when I do mind doing circles for a parking spot on any given night.
author: Xiaoyin W.

description: Expensive, but good decor.  The food is alright, but it's not authentic japanese food.  The chefs ARE not Japanese.  The biggest thing for me is that one time I found plastic in my salad and instead of giving me a free meal, they gave me another salad.
author: Alex G.

description:
Yum. Man, I love this place.

I was so psyched to discover this place on yelp and head over to check it out.  I moved to SF from LA and have a sushi place I absolutely love in Long Beach, and this is the only place thats up to par with incredibly amazing rolls.  The combos and mix of different flavors is so unique.  I've never had anything that didn't taste awesome. It's fresh, tastes great, and the ambiance of the restaurant is nice. They used to be in a much smaller place next door, but moved over to a bigger space... thank god, because the wait was getting longer and longer.

Ive got a couple favorites, but the one I've been craving for a few days and I would highly recommend is the Volcano roll... it MELTS in your mouth. Definitely check it out.

The only downside is that the sushi adds up and your bill can get a little expensive. I wish they had a happy hour on their sushi.... that would ROCK.
author: Shafaq C.

description: They're open (relatively) late during the week, our large group was seated quickly without trouble, and the food was pretty good. The rolls were a bit too goofy for me, and they really dominated the menu - there wasn't much sashimi and sushi selection (and only a few hot or soup options). Also, the servings were really large - I would have preferred smaller portions for less money. The pieces of nigiri sushi were easily twice as large as I'm used to!
author: Lisa K.

description:
My new Favorite Sushi place in the city. 


Nice, great portioned nigiri on top small amount of rice. I recommend the Butterfish and Albacore Belly(Toro)

Extremely innovative menu. "Something Unique" is an entire section on the menu where you see traditional go contemporary. I wanted to try everything on the menu, and given enough time, I will.

Rolls: 
Spicy Crunchy  
Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
both excellent.

Oh yeah....it's price is right too. You can't beat this place. I love it so much i have debated even reviewing it, so as to not be part of the reason this place blows up. But after reading the reviews, it seems everyone is pretty much on the same page.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Pros: Very Friendly Staff, Quickly Seated, Servers very attentive, Interesting selection of rolls, Menu gives full detail

Cons: Miso Soup, Parking and Stnky Salmon roll, shoulda known from the name that it wasnt gonna be a good roll, but i had to try it haha
author: Hanna T.

description:
Wow, this place gets packed!

Sushi Bistro has interesting, modern twists on sashimi and sushi classics. I recommend the lettuce wraps - so good!

While I think Sushi Bistro offers a fresh take, I do think the flavors need some refining. I would go back tho!
author: Joanne T.

description: After an exhausting day of shopping with a friend, we were really starving. Having sushi seemed to be a great plan so we opted for sushi. I had absolutely no idea of where to go and it was pretty late already (10pm). As usual Yelp was good advice. I had sashimi and my friend had rolls. My previous favorite sushi place was in Madrid but got wiped off by Sushi Bistro. It's the BEST sashimi I ever had (so far, of course). My friend enjoyed his rolls a lot. Very fresh fish, they even warn you for the last call for sushi before closing the kitchen.
author: Guillaume R.

description:
So I forgot that on Yelp it said that this place was bad for groups. Bc I walked in here with a party of 8. Yipe. My memory has not been too great recently, which causes me to think that I should lay off on all my smokey sessions. But that's another story.

It's one of the few sushi places in the Inner Richmond that closes past 10, bc apparently the owners realize that there are actually younger people in this district that want to venture out past that time. 

The servers were very friendly and accommodating of our large sake bombing group, which I appreciated bc as a server I know how large groups can sometimes be a pain the ass. I had one of their lettuce wraps (love the seasonal names, but I'm cheesy like that) and a salmon roll and was surprised at how sizable it was (that's what she said). And they didn't pile on the rice on the cut roll like some places do (which I hate), so that the focus of the roll is on the fresh fish inside. 

Great servers, delicious and fresh food, super hip and intimate atmosphere with a seemingly hip clientele. Obviously I say the word "hip" too much but as I mentioned before, my mind isn't what it once was. Thanks for understanding, though.
author: Bel P.

description:
If you're the adventurous sushi type...this is the place for you!
Fun sushi place...super fresh and innovative dishes!!
Its definitely not cheap but it is well worth it...
When i first ate here they were playing reggae music...reggae music at a sushi restaurant...that's my kind of restaurant!


Go have an uni shot on me!!
author: Steph S.

description:
Flippin' amazing...I could eat sushi every day, but this place is far and above other local favorites.  It's definitely pricier than others, but you get what you pay for.  

Parking is non-existent on Balboa, and it's a smaller place, you may have to wait a bit.  But I've tried every 'Best' sushi spot in the Bay, and this is definitely #1.  

When Jesus comes down to run Bay2Breakers, he stops here for Sushi.  Do it!
author: Brian H.

description: Better than average sushi.  Very good sashimi/nigiri, but the ahi poke salad is a meal by itself.  Comes on a bed of greens with fried noodles to boot.  The butterfish sushi roll is good, but needs some "spunk" to make it really great.  Prices are decent.
author: Joel M.

description:
We lived out near Sushi Bistro for a while and went there almost every week for our sushi-fill. If you are into fresh unadulterated sashimi - big chunky melt in your mouth pieces of sashimi, then this place is for you. The sashimi servings are extremely generous for the quality of the fish - which is excellent - comparable to much more highly priced places such as Tokyo-a-go-go and Sushi Groove South. The albacore is my favorite in the sashimi department - always a flavor implosion as it melts onto the tongue. The rolls are also very creative and delicious - you'll see mostly Sushi Bistro's own creations on the menu with some favorites thrown in - definitely try The New Legend. 

I did consider giving Sushi Bistro 4 stars due to the ambiance (not much of one) and the service being somewhat slow when its busy, but then I realized - when I want ambiance and "How would you like your arse kissed Your Highness?" service, I go elsewhere and pay top dollar.  But when I'm interested in sushi and only the sushi, then this is where I head, and in that department, Sushi Bistro gets 5 stars hands down (or up if you will).
author: Nam D.

description:
Creative, fresh, tasty, and traditional all rolled in to one place!

Not a huge dining area, so the line can be a bit long...but it is amazing for take out.

I had a tea and sushi gathering for some girlfriends and I trusted sushi bistro with the large order, and they had it ready exactly on time, and they even called me when it was almost ready so I could head over.

I'm so glad you're in my neighborhood, Sushi Bistro!
author: Chris L.

description:
I had a craving for California Rolls last night and searched for sushi places that opened late---I found it! Sushi Bistro!

Prices are a bit high but hey, that's what you have to pay for good sushi. My California Rolls were $3.95 for 8 pieces and the Spider Roll (deep fried soft-shell crab w/ avocado and cucumber) was $7.95. It was the best Spider Roll I have had ever so far. 

Decor was nice. Lighting was a bit dim sorta mysterious. Drawback is that this place is really small. There were probably about 10 tables or so. I wouldn't suggest big groups but if you would like to come with 2-3 other people that would be fine. 

Staff were mostly guys in their 20s. Nice. 

I would revisit again when my paycheck is a bit bigger. Seriously.
author: Van D.

description:
Third time there and still a winner.  This trip was maybe not quite as good as the first two, but I think we just didn't order quite as well this time.  There's so much to try that sometimes if you're branching out you might choose something that's not right up your alley.

As always, the fish was fresh, the portions generous, and the flavors intriguing.
author: Greg H.

description:
This Place was awesome! I haven't ventured out towards the richmond district much for dining but my firne Lindsey insisted on us going to Sushi Bistro in the Inner Richmond. It was Fantastic!

We started out with the Ahi Tuna Poke Special which was out of this world. It was so good that I tought about ordering another one. We followed this up with a African Spider Roll, A C2 Roll, and a Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon Roll. It was delicious!

To my surprise, my friend ordered the Green Tea Ice Cream Roll which was fantastic. The best desert that I have had a sushi restaurant by far!

I would recommend this place to anyone!
author: Brian C.

description:
Sushi Bistro gets 3-stars because of their inconsistencies.  There are some nights we go and we remember why we keep coming back.  And than there are other nights where the avocados are hard, scallops are over-cooked, shrimp tempura tastes old and we wonder why we keep coming back.

If you don't like sushi restaurants that use a lot of mayo/sauce in many of their rolls, SB isn't going to be one of your favorites.  Their sushi is more Americanized.  And if you like ginger with your sushi, you'll probably have to ask for more ginger at least five times as they are for some reason really stingy with their ginger.

Our favorite rolls here are the Albacore Dream and the Crouching Tiger.

I do yearn for the days when SB was a couple doors down.  Before they were featured in the iPhone commercial.  In their new location they seem to have gotten too big to handle the new crowds and their consistency and quality has taken a hit.
author: RICOLE P.

description:
I am a sushi whore.  There I said it.  One of my new years resolutions is to try every sushi place in SF and I'm working my way down the list starting with Sushi Bistro! Given the fact that I live five blocks from here, I figured I had to try it.  It's been rated in the Michelin Guide which is a great sign.

Made a reservation for 7:15 on a Tuesday night and they were actually pretty busy for an early weekday night.  Great location, great ambiance and really great service overall.

My friend and I ordered some beers and three rolls.  We had the sexy scallop roll, the crouching tiger hidden dragon and another great one with a clever name.  Very fresh fish and just really good taste all around.  I will definitely be coming back here very soon.  I'm wondering if they have a happy hour here too, would be amazing if they did!
author: Brittney R.

description: This restaurant is AWESOME!  Though it's tucked away in a mostly residential part of the Inner Richmond, this place was hoppin' when we walked in after 8:30 pm on a Sunday.  Even with a reservation, we still had to wait 15 min for our table...but it was definitely well worth the wait.  The decor is very modern & hip...and the food was just oh so delicious!  We sampled some of the specialty rolls (ie Aloha 101, New-Wave Mahi Mahi, Mr. Brown) and they were all super fresh with a good use of various complimentary flavors including sesame, mango, chili & avocado...Each roll was like a rainbow of taste explosions.  All I have to say is this...Taste the Rainbow.
author: Justin L.

description:
hmm. i drove all the way from san jose to try this place, &... it was alright.

i guess i didn't like this place as much because this place doesn't have the comfortable & cozy japanese feel, but rather, a clubby atmosphere.  

don't get me wrong, the food was good, but not spectacular.  me & my cousin ordered the C-2 roll which had lobster in it (which really excited me) and the hawaiiian breeze, which had mangoes, avocado, apples, tuna and pesto in it.  

i wouldn't order the C-2 roll again because lobster is pretty flavorless inside the roll. it tastes like nothing pretty much.  the hawaiian breeze was pretty good & it was better than the C-2.

anyways, the food was good enough i guess... it didn't live up to my expectations & what really irked me was just the environment i was in.
author: Dominique L.

description:
I have never felt the need to submit a rating until now. I would love to rate this place with 1 star to make the overall rating more realistic, but I'll keep it at what I feel this restaurant deserves.

Made reservations for a table of 4, got there 10 minutes past our reservation time and they said we had to wait for a table. KNOCK A STAR OFF for not understanding what "reservation" means.

We were asked if we would like to wait at the bar until a table opened up. To the bar we went. When we saw a table become available, we asked if we could be the next party seated there. A man who seemed to be a higher-up told us no. KNOCK A STAR OFF for not appeasing customers.

He then told us the reason why we couldn't move to a table: "I already told them to send your rolls to the bar." KNOCK A STAR OFF for either a manager who is not confident in his workers, and/or servers who are so inadequate that they do not know how to bring food to a table 4 feet away from where they were told.

Out of the 8 or so things we ordered, I enjoyed the African spider and C-2 rolls the most. ONE STAR for each.

Maybe I'll come back and have a better experience next time. Maybe I won't and my rating will stay at two stars.
author: Crystaljoy B.

description:
Definitely one of my favorite sushi places in the city.  AND, its close to home.  The environment is a nice lil lit up shop with some unique wall decorations as to your usual sushi restaurant. 

The food is pretty awesome.  Fresh fish and all.  I've actually been here about 3 times and every time, i leave well satisfied.  And a plus, their bathroom is nice.  

I don't think the service is rude but i've had to wait a few times.  definitely, if you can, make reservations.  on a side note, if they don't get you your food right away, they could throw in some appetizers on the house.  This place may be on the pricier side, but for flavor/taste and freshness, its well worth it.  

So onto the food.  
I've always ALways, stressed getting the lettuce wrap and the Summer in particular because i like raw fish and they put in a good dice up of yellowtail, salmon, unagi, avacado and some filling.  very delicious

Sometimes i want to be adventures with the rolls, but you always want to keep a safety.  so try one?  order an old favorite.  So far from what I remmeber, I recommend the following:

OMega 3 - lots of fish and the filling is good
African Spider - tastes like catepillar with some crunchies and an extra kick.
author: Vincent K.

description:
