I'll start with the positives, because I'm a positive kinda girl.  They have a creative menu.  I was totally stoked as I read through all the appetizers and the "Something Unique" rolls, etc, etc. BUT the execution totally failed.  

The nigiri sushi were cut really large (larger does not mean you're getting "hooked up", okay) and looked thrown together.  The rolls mostly fell apart - dunno if the rice wasn't sticky enough or they were poorly made.  Most of the creations had too much of whatever the special sauce applied on top, so they turned out mushy.  Our salad was totally overdressed I could barely eat it.  On a good note, the Udon was pretty tasty - albeit a bit too salty (and I like salt.)

Another BIG annoyance was the crowd, I could have sworn we walked into Fraternity Happy Hour.  Nothing like dining next to loud-talker Jock Boy that Mommy never taught any manners to.  I'm all for a fun and hip establishment, but this place just had a fauxness about it.  I don't know, maybe I came on a bad night.  It was like one of those movies that people keep telling you is SOOOOO awesome and you must go see it!  And when you finally do - it's nothing short of a let-down.
author: Tracey E.

description:
A friend took me here this weekend and I was blown away by the freshness and quality of the fish..and creativity in the rolls. Our group of 6 ordered a large number of rolls and each one was better than the next, and we didn't think that would be possible. Order anything and you won't be disappointed. I love that each roll has 8 pieces-- plenty to go around..

And the prices are reasonable given how good the food is (and how big the portions are-- the sashimi platter is HUGE).  I really enjoyed my dinner here- it was perfect for our group of 6 (we lucked out and got a reservation on a busy saturday night.)..the line looked long as we were leaving..and our waiter did gently remind us that there were people waiting for our table..so this isn't a place you linger after your meal...keep that in mind. 

Order anything, you can't go wrong. (If I could remember the names of the 9 different rolls we all ordered, I'd list them out..but they were all so good, I can't pinpoint just one).
author: Sonia S.

description:
I came here around 8PM and we were able to get a table for two relatively easily, because a 4 person table was opened and the waiter split the table into two for us and another couple that walked in afterwards. I can't say the same after we were seated, because a line started to form outside. This place is very small and tables are close together. Holding a conversation without repeating myself at least once  was just impossible without letting our neighbors in on our gossip. I caught myself trying to raising my voice over people from my right and left. 

Onto the food, the Five Wishes had fresh fish along with a mini little mound of mixed greens in the middle with special dressing. The African Spider was okay, but the spicy house sauce was a bit too spicy for me. The Hot Love roll was some HAWT stuff, not too spicy, but the best roll of the night. I liked the spicy sweet sauce that it came with, because I found myself scrapping the sauce off of the plate with the rolls. 

P.S. I like the mini dish of pickled cucumber that they provided when we were seated. It went really well with the rolls.
author: Tracy T.

description:
There is no doubt in my mind, being that of a great sushi connoisseur who has scoured the states for the best sushi.  Not only is Sushi Bistrouuvh the best sushi experience you're uu www can have, the music is great as well.  They play reggae.  The sushi concoctions  are amazing.  Nothing like you wouldadsaew okay
LSws get a cSushieeqMlau Rowzck.  The meats are so fresh and sizable.  You get a huge bang for your buck.  If you go, try orders under Somethin Unique.  You ug hi to qme kmewon't be disappointed.  I've been going here for a couple of years I hinow and every time is like the first.  They also have the best green tea ice cream.y
author: conrad s.

description:
Sit back with the locals and enjoy, fresh generous portions of fish, warm Sake and assorted reggae jams.  Recently featured in an IPhone app. commercial, this place has gone from a local Inner Richmond gem to a San Francisco hot spot. Notable rolls include the Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon (Shrimp Tempura, Aioli, Avocado & Cucumber, Topped with Unagi & Eel Sauce) and the Rock' N Roll (Baked Spicy Scallops Served on Top of a California Roll).  Try the Ahi Tuna Poke if you know what is good for you!

The best part...I live 5 blocks away!
author: Jessica J.

description:
I can agree with most of the reviews, but I have to deduct a star for an over use of mango in a bunch of their rolls. Mangoes are great, but come on.

Otherwise the place was great. Snuzzin and I walked in a little after 10 and had a range of great rolls and some really big cuts of tuna and albacore that were both very fresh.

Seemed like everyone was having fun. All in all, a really good Yelp find. 

They were playing Sublime and as Snuzzin pointed out, "Are they really gonna play let this track (the "Date Rape" song) play right now?" They did and we laughed a little, and left full.

I had no idea there was so much happening on Balboa.
author: Jason R.

description:
First time here, and I think we ordered the wrong things.  I'd like to go back and give it another try, but with so many other restaurants to sample, I'm not sure when that will be.  

It's very crowded on a Friday night, but the kitchen seems to expedite well (our food came out very, very quickly) and our wait was only about 1/2 hour (after spending another 1/2 hour looking for parking in that area of the Richmond).

If I could I'd give this place a half star more just for the glorious freshness of the fish - the butterfish and hamachi belly simply blew us away.  They give you these great slabs of fish which hang almost precariously over the teeny tiny fingers of rice as nigiri.  If I do manage to get back next time I'll focus on nigiri and sashimi rather than taking chances with the rolls.

The rolls.
The boy gets to pick two, and I get to pick two.  He opts for the Yellowtail Basil -- chopped hamachi, mixed with garlic and italian basil, deep fried and drizzled with chili oil and eel sauce.  The roll itself was very small and thin, and fried almost to oblivion.  I could not recognize or taste anything beyond the crunchy-hard fried tempura texture and the gobs of sriracha sauce glomped over the dish.

Spicy crunchy -- hamachi, salmon, snapper, shrimp, lightly deep fried,  topped with macadamia nuts and served with "spicy house sauce." Again, very heavy handed with the fryer. I could not discern the 4 different types of fish in the roll and sriracha once again made an ubiquitous and gloppy appearance.

C-2 - the most decent roll of the evening - baby lobster and avocado topped with tempura, and drizzled with eel sauce.  Eel sauce = sweet teriyaki.

My biggest disappointment was with our pick from the "Something Unique" section of the menu -- I don't remember the name, and it appears to be a new item that's not listed on the website -- basically billed as tempura-fried oysters with tasty sauce... When it came out, it was impressive indeed - served in a huuuuge 6-inch long giant oyster shell.  The portions are fairly generous - 4 individual oysters with onion and other sauce fillers.  Despite the really great presentation, the oysters were buried in too much batter, which was soggy to boot. The sauce tasted like regular teriyaki.

We'll make attempts to go back and just focus on the raw fish offerings.
author: Claudine C.

description:
Tied for #1 best sushi in SF. Maybe even better than sushi zone because the wait wasn't too long. 

Chef Shin is amazingly artful. If you can, sit at the sushi bar and watch him work. The fish & vegetables are exquisitely fresh. A lot of things integrate a slightly crunchy texture -- delicious!
author: A R.

description:
Cute little place.  I have walked passed it on numerous occasions but had never given it a second glance, until recently that is.

It's really small, limited seating at tables and at the counter.  There are only a handful of people running it so service can be slow at times.  The sushi is good, and the hot ones are interesting...like a hot lil' crabcake or something.  I enjoyed it.  I think the monster-in-law, the spicy crunchy and the volcano were my favs.  There is definitely a lot to chose from and I'd definitely come back.

P.S.  Hope you don't get some loud and obnoxious person sitting beside you, as the sound just bounces of the wall due to the small space.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
We went to sushi bistro on a Sunday night. Parking was horrible but we didn't have to wait at all for a table so that definitely made up for the 30 minute circling of the Richmond area.

We ordered several rolls and enjoyed them all. The First Crush roll was supposed to have brown rice but came out in traditional white sushi rice, but was still tasty. The Crouching Tiger Roll was delicious and ALL of the fish was super fresh!

I'm a HUGE sushi eater (lover of specialty rolls) and have to say that their food was excellent. Especially considering the rolls were a decent size and rather inexpensive (in sushi standards). The service was good too.
author: Stacie G.

description: Sunday we were in the mood for Sushi and wanted something close to our daughters place.  Three blocks away Sushie Bistro on Balboa was the choice.  What a great spot. We had parking in front and the service was excellent.  Very clean, and a good feel to the place.  Delivery and presentation were right on.  Will be back for sure....
author: GREG C.

description:
Unique sushi place out in the Richmond (and right next door to Namu, another fave of mine). Not for traditionalists but if you are looking for a huge selection of different, funky rolls, you can't go wrong. The waiter was helpful in offering his recos. After staring at the menu for 10 min, I ultimately ordered:

Equinox lettuce wrap - interesting concept, I enjoyed the different textures and tastiness.
Butterfish Blasters - crab, avocado and wrapped in butterfish; sriacha hotsauce on the side. solid.
Sexy Scallop - decent but not amazing.
Uni (nigiri) - overflowing uni = goodness.

Dined on a Friday night after calling ahead for a reservation, which I'd recommend. Line was long but having a reso got us quickly seated. Nice. The rolls came super fast and we were so hungry, the food was gone in 15 min max. I am still full. Oh, and parking nasty...gotta get lucky. 

I'll definitely be back to SB to sample more of the menu.
author: Michael S.

description:
Mr. Brown is a must !
Baby Lobster salas is a must !
Miso seabass is a must !
African Spider is a must !
most of the roll are original and innovative.. 
the only complaint i have is PARKING !
author: sherly A.

description:
I went here with a friend for a saki tasting. It sounded like a good idea, and the place had good intentions, but there were eight saki's and after two hours we had only gone through 4 of them, and yes it was informative, but damn that's a long time. And the speaker was so monotone, it was hard to pay attention. 
Anyways we ended up leaving the tasting to go out front and eat, and the food was delicious, and the service was good. I would definatly go back for the food but not another tasting
author: JIll H.

description:
Excellent specialty sushi, sashimi is fresh and beautifully colored, and the batter on the agedashi tofu is not too thick.

The space is relatively small, but they make the most out of it. You could go on a casual date there.

Prices are reasonable for a sushi restaurant. Especially for the quality of the sushi here, it's definitely worth it.

One weird thing is that there was hardly any ice in my water... it was room temperature when the server gave it to me.
author: Le V.

description:
This place knows how to make sushi. It's fresh, colorful and very tasty. 
The sashimi was incredible! And the Ikura was delicious (it didn't have a bitter taste to it like some other places do)! The agadashi tofu could use some more sauce, but other than the food was awesome. 
The atmosphere was so nice too, everyone was happy, in love, talking, and generally enjoying the place. The decorations in the place are cute too, I love the fishies on the wall (they looked delicious too!). 
Everyone should try it out, it's awesome! 
Oh! And right across the street is a Russian bakery so if you want dessert... =D
author: Allie W.

description:
Sushi Bistro is the best sushi joint on the planet!

I've grown up eating sushi, my whole family is obsessed with sushi and I have always said that if I was ever on death row my last meal would be sushi. Well me tell you I would definitely have it ordered from Sushi Bistro. 

Everything they serve is great! It can get a little crowded in there so you should make a reservation if you can but I would wait all night for a table of that delectable stuff. Oh yeah and don't forget to say hi to Dave when you're there.
author: Nelly W.

description:
Best. Sushi. Ever.

Love, love, love this place.  The owner (Sheen) is SUPER cool and hand selects his fish every morning.  The quality is amazing and the sashimi and nigri are cut perfectly.  Plus, Sheen is a genious when it comes to making his unique rolls; always perfectly packed and all sorts of special creations.  We always go "omakase" (Japanese for 'chef's choice') and let the master work his magic.

Only two downsides.  First, this place is ALWAYS packed.  Call ahead for reservations or be out of luck.  Second, expect to drop $50 each easily (++ if you are drinking).  But, you get what you pay for...
author: Naeem I.

description:
Thank goodness Sushi Bistro doesn't know the meaning of "stingy," as they serve up generous portions, unlike 99% of the other sushi joints. This place had the biggest sashimi sampler I've ever had. The "Stinky Salmon" roll is amazing, despite the odd name. Monkfish, one of my favorites, is served in a large pile, and the toro comes in extra large cuts.

Sushi + reggae + sake = good times. Don't forget to make a reservation. Sit at the bar and drink with sushi chef Shin and his co-workers for the full experience (he'll even bust out his favorite sake). Awesome.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Sushi bistro.....wow.....Amazing japanese restaurant.
The Udon is sweet but tastes very delicious, as good as it gets.
the sushi tastes fresh and better than most places around the city,
especially the C2 and the sashimi spirit roll. Of course, they have all the original local sushis such as dragon or california, which also taste great.
However, the restaurant is very compact and kinda noisy at times, otherwise it is a great restaurant with amazing food.
author: Dylan T.

description:
My very, very favorite all-'round sushi place in SF.  I absolutely recommend that you order omakase and allow the chefs' imaginations to cater to your taste buds.
It is clear that passion for food is a top priority in this lovely establishment, and service is consistently solid (although not memorable... but I don't think of that as a necessity for this place, either).  Their menu's offerings can be categorized as nothing other than sushi, yet a sushi purist will be frustrated by the out-of-box thinking.  I mean, I don't recall anywhere else I've had parmesan in my sushi... and for the record, cheese in my sushi is wonderful!  Flavors are fine-tuned: I want to lick the plate but recognize that's maybe not so appropriate in public.  I have never once left the table without a grinning face and a grinning soul, satisfied by my indulgences.  And unconflicted about the caloric and monetary costs I've just incurred!
I know I'm an eco-asshole by eating some of this fish, so I'm trying to pare it back and choose off the menu wisely at sushi houses in general.  I suppose that's the only true criticism I can fathom about this place.
author: Rachel S.

description: Sushi Bistro was my first sushi experience. Ever. I let my friend order and we ended up having the Albacore Dream, Billie Jean, Watermelon Man, and Magic Mushrooms. They were all so good! I've been scared for years to try sushi and have stuck with veggie rolls until Sushi Bistro. I ate everything!!! yummmmm.
author: Maja Z.

description:
So it seems weird to be writing about the amazingness of tofu at a sushi restaurant. But when you have a best friend who graduated from the Culinary Academy take you to a restaurant for tofu, you tend to not negate anything she says. 

Order. Agedashi Tofu. 

Yes, do it. You will get four silken innard crispy fried blocks of soy - sprinkled with nori, daikon and other fried (possibly fish based) sprinkly things. But it's the accompanying broth that soaks into the crust around the tofu that you're after. Satisfying, sweet, salty, umami. 

Yes, yes, then get onto ordering lettuce wrap rolls (Solstice is a good one), mango chicken salad, ahi poke, karaage...etc. All freshly prepared, delicious, and innovative. Gyoza are small, but plump. 

However, let it not be said the place is without it's faults. First of all, parking is the biggest bitch I've ever faced. The Richmond needs to lick some yelper's sweaty n*&sack for some better parking. Second, I remember taking my friend Nick here and saying:
"I thought you would like this place, it's hipster and you're kind of hipster. " 

it nearly ended our friendship. The place is often packed, so your best bet is to go on an off night or only go with your best friend/sig o. Problem solved. Try the stuff on the board and don't forget to order one of the special rolls.
author: Alexis W.

description: A+ for their creativity and originality.. A lot of their rolls were unique with combinations I hadn't seen before. They even have brown rice rolls. But in delivery.. not as impressive. My friend and I ordered the aloha 101, crouching tiger hidden dragon, and the M&L forever. The crouching tiger hidden dragon was the best roll of the three. I love mangoes.. but the mangoes didn't sit right with the tuna in the aloha 101.. The M&L forever was almost just plain gross. The grilled big eye tuna was overcooked and way to dry. Once you picked that out though, the roll was decent. Maybe we just ordered the wrong things.. but I wouldn't come here again.
author: Sophia B.

description:
This is the best sushi place I've eaten at so far!

It's not a traditonal sushi place, their special rolls are unique and delicious! Try the Aloha 101 and the Big Island.

Also, the Spicy Girl (under small plates) is sooo good!

Service is friendly and pretty good, but you have to flag them down when they're busy.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Sometimes I find myself craving Sushi Bistro. I've been coming here for a couple of years and the food continues to put a smile on my face. Creative rolls, good service, and complimentary ice cream to boot!  I love it so much, I have brought my non-sushi eating parents and pretty much all my friends here. Since it's become a hip, happening joint there is sometimes a wait which I don't mind that much. I'm glad the tables are packed and business is booming for the owners.
 
Had my birthday dinner here a few months ago with about 10 people. The servers were very accomodating and didn't mind puting candles on a cake and serenading me. awww.

Favorite things to get:
Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon
Spicy Tuna (melts in your mouth)
Watermelon Man
Y.T Jalepeno
Agedashi Tofu
My parents loved the Sea Bass Dinner
author: Christine M.

description:
This place seems out of place compared to the surrouding businesses in the neighborhood.  The owners must be doing something right for me to come from the Mission District just for some sushi. I've been here about 5x and so far I haven't gotten sick...that's good!  

I always order different rolls, so far it's pretty good. I LOVE LOVE the sexy scallop..raw scallop is the way to go! The sashimi however is cut too thick for my taste.  

I sugguest getting here before the dinner rush.  Parking sucks, but it's worth the hassle.
author: Dee S.

description:
Good feel. Good vibe. Good staff.

Rolls are definitely quite different compared to the norm.

C2 (includes baby lobster)
What? In a sushi roll?? MUST try. Good stuff.

Double Jeopardy
The more normal roll. Still good.

Always a good time out at Sushi Bistro.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
i freaking love this place.  generous slices of sashimi, creative roles.  delicious sexy scallop rolls.  do it do it do it

oh, and why the heck are they only open for dinner??!!! :( feel like i should dock points for that.. :(
author: Alias A.

description:
This place is great, casual and clean. Reggae beats are a plus!

5 stars
author: John M.

description:
Sushi Bistro is as good as they say for one reason.... the sashimi platter. I went twice w/in 3 days ordering the same. 

If you're the type of person that needs large, fresh, thick, flavorful cuts in order to justify the prices you pay for sashimi nowadays, this is your place. The pieces are so large you might have eat them in two bites. This well-portioned platter sets you back $17ish and worth every friggin penny. Got a hefty appetite? just order a side of rice with it and you're set. 

There is a large selection of rolls. Most have some type tempura battered deal in it and gets confusing. My first visit we made the mistake of ordering so many of these rolls the flavor profiles all started to taste the same. My advice?  Order one or two max w/the tempura deal (I loved the african spider) so you can appreciate the roll on its own and balance it with other items.

Other things to note: 
Nice staff, nice vibe, nice music 
I was surprised by their logo design, simply out-dated esp. for such a edgy town.
author: C T.

description:
Sushi Bistro was alright. I ordered the Supreme Scallops-- which I thought weren't that fresh but was tasty anyway. Couldn't figure out the red string garnish that was super hard & plastic-esque. The crunchy roll is very sweet, very.. Americanized but it was delicious nonetheless. If you like sweet sushi. Overall the food was 3.5/5. Ended with mochi which looked & tasted like they were ice-aged frozen but ice cream's better hard than soft I guess. Well, to me and at that point, I really wanted dessert so mochi's better than none at all? I guess? 

Service was good too, our water & tea cups were never empty and constantly refilled. The place filled up quick. The place had a nice dining atmopshere--oh, and the bathrooms were cleaned. That's always important! 

I almost feel like people like the restaurant because there were people filling up the place quick making it feel like "Oh it's a good place,all these people came here to eat, we're here too! It's good"
author: Sarah U.

description:
I'm so glad I waited until my second time around to review sushi bistro! 

My first visit wasn't too memorable, but my second visit rocked! We ordered shrimp tempura, along with the Stinky Salmon roll (highly recommended!) and the Monster In-Laws roll (also very good, the freshness of the fish could be tasted). 

Again, another sushi restaurant that was practically MADE for me! The creativity and originality of the specialty rolls really works! And I am dying to try the little lettuce cups, too, they look amazing. 

Also, did you know that they serve complimentary green tea ice cream?!?! I certainly didn't until the sushi chef mentioned it to me while I was sitting at the bar...it doesn't seem like it's something they necessarily advertise, but he clued us in, which was super cool. 

The line to get in can move kinda slowly...esp. in the chilly richmond district! Bring jackets or plan to grab a coffee at Javaholics next door while you wait.
author: Shannon R.

description: This is totally a great place when you're with a group and the group is feeling sushi. There were about six of us trying to grab dinner before going to a movie - we got here around six and were seating almost right away. We ordered a bunch of rolls to split. Nothing was particularly spectacular, but when you need to please six palates, it is not worth the effort.
author: Todd H.

description:
Came here with a date and was not too impressed. 

first of all, service was great. The place however was a little too loud for me. but that's not why they only got 3 stars. 

The fish was ok, some were better than others. My problem with the Nigiri is the size. way too big. Don't get me wrong, value wise, it's great, you get a huge, and I do mean huge piece of fish with very little rice. But that throws out the balance. 

I don't like biting off a piece of nigiri, the whole thing goes in, and that's it. Maybe it's because I don't like putting something I've eaten half way back on my plate. 

Probably won't go back again, there are plenty of sushi places I haven't tried yet.
author: Jin S.

description: I like this place a lot! Cute little restaurant with friendly staff and excellent sushi. You gotta try the sexy scallop roll, my fav by far. I'll make this place a regular dinning night out. :)
author: katrina w.

description: I often get mean sushi cravings. This day was one of those days and since we were going to explore the Academy of Science: Nightlife, it was a good idea for us to chow down on some good sushi. Sushi Bistro had good customer service and a clean environment. I felt the sushi rolls were pretty good I believe we got one called the "tiger roll" I went with what I always get "shashimi combo". I was not to big on the miso soup there was really no flavor. Whatever the case this is a good place to get your fix at.
author: Valerie G.

description:
This is really a 3.5 review. Darn no half stars available.

After my first experience at Sushi Bistro, I was in no hurry to go back. But a couple of years have past, and I was ready to  try it again. I had friends in from out of town, and SB is right by my house. Off we went. 

First off, the service is still pretty erratic. The servers are friendly, but things are a bit off. We had to ask for somethings multiple times, the table next to ours was delivered the wrong check. Nothing major, but just . . . not quite right.

The food, however, is great. My friends all loved their sushi rolls and sashimi. I ordered udon, and I liked it. We got there pretty close to closing, so we couldn't linger, but overall we had a good experience.

I'll go again.
author: Kristen H.

description:
First visit to Sushi Bistro and we were not disappointed.  We called at 5:45pm while en route to the restaurant and asked for a reservation for two at 6:30pm - well, no tables, but they were able to put us down for the sushi bar.  When we arrived at 6:30, they opened up a table for us instead!  The service was very good - prompt and attentive, water always filled, beer glass never empty too long, plates cleared quickly, and importantly the servers were not intrusive or too involved with chatting up the clientele. 

I agree with previous reviewers that this is not your typical japanese restaurant.  It definitely has more of a sports bar/lounge vibe with dark ambiance (too dark for us), flat screen tv's, and LOUD music (turn it down a little so we can enjoy the excellent food please).

The food was quite delicious, and average to slightly above average in price.   Butterfish blasters to start with (crab meat, avocado wrapped in butterfish and then seared - served with a spicy soy glaze), damn good.  Nigiri sushi next - hamachi, toro, uni, and amaebi (with deep fried shrimp heads with ponzu dipping sauce); huge cuts of fish, tiny ball of rice. Not really your classic ratio of rice:fish for nigiri, but I won't argue with the generous cuts of fish.  Very fresh and tasty.  The toro was too chewy (we've had much better toro at Ozumo) due to presence of some of the tough connective tissue.  Next we had rolls - in my opinion, this is their forte and what most people come for.  Creative, flavorful, and definitely off the beaten path.  We had the First Crush (spicy albacore tuna, fuji apple, topped with salmon and ginger cilantro ponzu sauce with brown rice), mouth watering good.  We followed this with the Sashimi Spirit (ebi, salmon, ahi tuna, butterfish, tobiko and avocado topped with scallions); a mouthful of flavors that blended together well but lost the individual characteristics.  Washed it down with a couple ice cold draught Kirins, perfection.

I'd come back to try the other rolls and "unique offerings" on their menu, and perhaps sample something off their extensive sake list!
author: david l.

description:
Great sushi at a decent price. Along with the usual rolls (California rolls, unagi, sashimi etc..) they have specialty rolls that make the mouth drool. So far I've had the 'C-2' roll (lobsters+ tempura roll), 'Hot Love'(another lobster roll), Volcano Roll (spicy!), Yellow Tail, and some others  that were all tasty. 

Do yourself a favor and bring more friends in. It's a lot easier to taste all these terrific rolls.

Parking can be a little problem. Try Geary st or a little further up near Fulton. Come before 730pm on weekends and come before 8pm on weekdays.

-----------------------------------------------
UPDATE- May 8th 2007- REDUCED 1 STAR

As much as I love this place it's gotten so popular to the point of "just walking in" is near impossible. I went there on a Saturday at 630pm and couldn't get a table. 

Actually there were plenty of tables available BUT they were all "RESERVED." Can you imagine a party of two who can't get a table at 630pm with about 20 seats sitting empty? We waited 45mins to sit down and even then these reserved tables were still EMPTY!!!! The only way to eat there now is to make a reservation or wait until the 10 seats at the sushi bar are available.

In my humble opinion, I don't think they need to reserve that many tables. It's a small place and they should just have a waiting list like any other small restaurants. 

It's unfair for the people who comes here early and are ready to eat. They can lose plenty of business by shunning away loyal customers.
author: Bert T.

description:
I normally try to stay away from places that have "bistro" in their name.  Not sure why, but there is something that turns me off about it.  Maybe it's because I think bistro is an ugly word and I really don't like things that are ugly.    Luckily for Sushi Bistro, and especially myself, they are really pretty and nice and not ugly at all.  After seeing that they had 4 stars after about 250 reviews, I decided that I should try to infiltrate this den of deliciousness and see for myself what I had been missing.

It was super busy when I walked in but was seated right away due to my impeccable timing (a couple was just leaving and there was nobody in front of us).  The service was great.  My "date" (I use the term loosely because she wasn't really a date, just an old old friend whom I secretly want to marry) knocked over our sake and they quickly replaced it with a full one free of charge even though we had drank almost the whole bottle by that point anyway.  Awesome.  The nigiri was good.  Huge pieces of hamachi over a smidgen of rice.  The large amount of wasabi on the side the size of a ping pong ball was exactly the size necessary to satiate my sinuses.  

The rolls were inventive and delicious and super huge.  I think we had 4 rolls and a few orders of nigiri and were totally stuffed.  oh yeah, that was on top of the fried oysters and gyoza, all of which disappeared rather quickly from the plates.  

Before long, we had both noticed that the itamae was drinking with some of the people sitting at the bar and we both felt a pang of jealousy take over our hearts.  I, too, want to become a part of the inner circle and drink sake with the man making my stomach grumble for more.  It was then decided that we would return here until, much like a gang, we were jumped into the inner circle.  Until then, I shall return time and again to try everything on the menu.

oh yeah, dessert was fucking ridiculous.  Tempura fried ice cream that was more like an ice cream filled donut.  I could have ordered it three more times before we left.
author: Charley B.

description:
I don't really get why this place has an average of 4 stars.  The food is very, very, very average.  The menu looks great and all but the taste and quality of the food is not as good.  Don't get me wrong, the food it's edible, but seriously, very very average.  I don't know how much else to explain it.  But for 1, I would not wait in line for this place.  

The place is small, seats about 40 people.  There were people waiting for a table continuously but there's no room for people to wait.  We had a table by the door and it's cold with the door opening and closing.

I wouldn't recommend this place given all the other great restaurants in the city.
author: Irene C.

description:
Ok I haven't tried many sushi places in SF yet, but I do love love love sushi, every since I was like 8, so I have had a lot of sushi in my life. The location of this place is strange, I think it would have so much more success if it were in a more happening area or even a couple streets up on Clement, but maybe that is the beauty of this place... its a little hidden.

It so happens, that I tried this place the night before I moved out of the Richmond district :( oh well, I would have spent way too much money here anyway. But seeing as it is wonderful sushi, I will trek my way back here for sure, now that is saying something cuz I like to walk to my food, not bus.

Anyway, the food, it was awesome. Some very original and inventive rolls, if you are a classic sushi lover you would probably still really like this place because they have AMAZING sashimi and the fish is just so fresh. The thing that I love about their sashimi is that they give you HUGE pieces. 

I am in love with sushi restaurants that like to try new things. Sushi Bistro has cold rolls, warm rolls, saucy rolls, rolls with fruit, spicy rolls, deep fried rolls, big rolls, small rolls, seared fish rolls, yummy yummy yummy rolls! Mmmmmm! I will be back
author: Jen S.

description:
Lordy. Perhaps I just like the IDEA of Sushi Bistro, but alas, SB is falling apart on the execution of decent neighborhoody sushi.  This is what happened:

- jalapeno hamachi - carpaccio excessively thick, as were the jalapeno, but the fish was fishy, and not in a good way; we couldn't force ourselves to finish the serving

- solstice lettuce wrap - again, ahi was fishy and the crispy bits stale

- volcano roll - WAY too much mayo with the faux crab; overall too heavy and rich for my palate

- salmon, hamachi, maguro nigiri - we didn't order sashimi!!  the rice was about a pinch worth, and lost in one gigantic piece of fish; while some folks might think this is a bargain, to me it's like giving me a cow instead of a steak.  

Overall, the freshness of the fish was questionable, and NOT what you want when eating raw seafood. Perhaps Tues was a slow night, and we ordered late so they were trying to pawn off any fish in the fridge, or maybe bec/ we had take out they weren't so worried about the funny faces they would have normally had to deal with in the restaurant.  

Anyhoo, I'd worry about this place.  Fusion should be fun, but here, expect heavy sauce, heavy aioli mayo, fishy fish, and otherwise, heavy combinations of ingredients.  It was the antithesis of light, balanced and delicate, a choke-down kind of experience. Maybe we'll just restrict future visits to *select* lettuce wraps.
author: Conifers J.

description: I was introduced to this place by Poker Face. It's a hole in the wall in the Richmond District in San Francisco. The whole set -up is pretty much like any other Japanese Restaurant. BUT the food is amazing. I'm not of much of a roll lover but here I would totally eat them. I'm a sashimi lover and they have a platter of different sashimis to die for. My favorite Saba Sashimi was fresh(the only way to go). Parking can get a little dicey in the area-just be patient it's worth it. Money is not an object if food is this great.
author: Janet D.

description: Best and most creative rolls in the city. My favorites are: Rock n Roll, Spring Handroll, and their white fish sashimi.
author: Wren C.

description:
There are a few items that warrant a five star review.  First, this place serves rolls in a style that is unique to any other sushi restaurant I have ever been to.  I recommend "Dave's Legacy", a roll that is not listed on the menu, but offers such ingredients as deep fried Japanese pumpkin amongst other ingredients.  They are always on the search for interesting ingredients.  

Second, they are a small family run business who offer a great environment.  I have been lucky enough to get to know them quite will and they always treat me like family.  I live in Southern California and often frequent the Bay Area; after "stumbling" on this place, I have a hard time going out to sushi in my own area.

Lastly, go for the Butterfish Blaster.  I should not have to say anything else about this.  Just do it.
author: Brandon E.

description:
Some of the food I've had here = Better Than Foreplay.

I'm surprised and thankful Sushi Bistro hasn't blown up because the food is four star level for half the price.  Still the place gets pretty busy and there can be a short wait in the entry way that is murder because you're basically forced to watch the other patrons feast while trying to hold your hunger together.

To be honest, I've never had any of their traditional sushi rolls because I never make it to that part of the menu.  Mainly I can't get passed the "Signature Rolls" and "Something Unique".  The Ahi Tower with spicy dipping sauce, the Hot Love with baked crab and lobster, the Caucasian Afro with spicy tuna and gaucamole, OMG the Drunken Halibut, and the C-2. I die.

Don't miss out on the fried oysters either.  SO GOOD.  Decent alcohol prices too so don't be afraid to come here for a pre or post celebration.

Still, I get the feeling that this is the kind of place that you either love or hate, and you sort of need to know what to order.  Parking is miserable but that's SF.

So the moral of this story is the decor/vibe, whimsical sushi names and deep flavors may definitely make the panties come off.  The owners of Sushi Bistro put a lot of time and effort into this setup and I love them (and their food) for it.
author: Margaret L.

description: I order take-out dinner from here seriously three times a week. Best sushi ever. Even the wraps and veggie rolls are awesome.
author: Erica A.

description:
An old friend that I had not seen in about 7 years was in town and wanted to meet up for dinner. I was quick to think of all the GREAT restaurants in the city especially by me so I didn't have to travel so far living in the mission in all. Well, turned out they also knew someone in SF that was joining us for dinner that had ALREADY chosen Sushi Bistro (ummm a couple of blocks where he lived...guess we were thinking the same). So I went on to my trusty YELP to see what this place was like and see what you guys thought. I must admit I was a bit skeptical reading some of the reviews saying it was overrated. But to my surprise dish after dish was AMAZING! I couldn't believe it. We had the following (at least from what I remember);

The new legend - A MUST!
Sashimi salad - we were licking the plate on this one
African Spider (which apparently won some award...yeah whatever its DAMN GOOD!!!!)
And some sashimi a la carte...which was also really good but definitely not the highlight.

And the prices were just as great! I am so in love I think I have to go there again tonight.
author: claudia o.

description:
I liked this place when I went there for takeout. After several dinners there, I can safely say I love it. Their classic rolls are good, but their creative combinations really stand out. Give them a try -- you almost certainly won't be disappointed. The place is tiny and a bit cramped, but it's a fair trade for the great food. OK, this is probably not your best choice if you're a purist, but if you're willing to take risks (the fun kind, not the will-this-make-me-throw-up? kind), the payoff is definitely worth it. Delish!

EDIT: They've just changed/expanded their menu, which now includes some yummy-looking brown rice rolls. I did not order any of them because I forgot to bring my gluten-free tamari sauce, but as I was chatting with the waiter after dinner, I mentioned that and he said, "Oh, we have tamari sauce you can use." I hadn't even thought to ask because nobody ever has it. Awesome! I might have to go back tomorrow to try the new rolls.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
The best in the city. 
My only regret ? I left this neighborhood, 14 years ago!
Parking sucks. Park on Gear-age  walk the 2 blocks. 
The food is great. Licking the "wasabe/soy sauce" dish good. "The dog dont want it after your done" good.  
Pricy dont try to bring a dinner date here to show off. Your gonna pay if you do. Maybe stick to BK or something?
4 rolls and $80 later I was amazingly satisfied.
author: William H.

description:
I'm very much the sushi snob since I basically grew up on Maui.  I'm just gonna jump to why I liked it so much.

Hamachi  sashimi was very fresh and the portions were twice the size you would normally get at other restaurants!

Tuna poke was a ... SALAD!  zomg, i should read before assuming it was poke that i grew up eating on Maui.  Anyhow, the Poke salad was good, creative textures kept it interesting, but a tad to sauced for my taste ... but the girl luved it.

Service was great, all the wait staff were very attentive and polite.  

Basically, one of the rare places in the City that actually has very fresh Hamachi and that is actually sushi grade fish ... (did you know, only 3% of the fish caught is sushi grade and most restaurants here serve stuff that isn't sushi grade, other 97% is used for steaks and shit)

********* 09/24/09 **********

I'm heart broken and left lost, struggling to find a good sushi restaurant that maintains consistency ... sigh ... stuff i said before was true but I don't know if it is the recession or what but the quality of the fish has taken a dive and must've taken the sushi chef with it.

My Hamachi sashimi wasn't fresh and when i at the pieces, 2 of them still had the bone and the not good sushi grade fish smell that i dread.   the mackerel wasn't sitting in the brine long enough and that's a hard one to mess up unless you don't care if the fish is too oily and smelly or just ... don't care.

I don't think I will come here again because I'm not a 3 strikes guy, I'm a " do me wrong and I'm gone"  

Trust me, I'm hurt that I have to rewrite this review and I'm crying on the inside Q_Q
author: Sam K.

description:
We had reservations but still had to wait a half an hour to get seated.  The place was bustling.  It had  a good vibe. 
Sushi rolls were excellent as were a lot of the appetizers.  Drinks were good too.    We had a very good time... looking forward to coming back.
author: Lizete S.

description:
Sushi Bistro was one of the most mediocre sushi experiences I've had.  I ordered a roll for $12 and they used fake crab meat.  If I wanted that crap I would've gone to Kitaro or Ichikaru.  My friend had the chicken teriyaki and it was nothing to write home about.  We had to wait quite some time for our orders.  I will NOT be going back.

I live 3 blocks from Sushi Bistro and I'd rather drive 30 minutes to Alameda for real sushi from Yume.
author: Jorge M.

description:
2.5 stars

This place is overrated, rolls are SMALL and a bit pricey for what you are getting.  I noticed they use very lil rice in their rolls compared to other places.  Food seemed fresh and the restaurant is small but clean.  Dunno maybe we just ordered the wrong things?  
Double Jeopardy ($9.5)- chunks of tuna, salmon and avocado.  Looked a bit messy but tasted good.

Big Island ($13.5) - This one was TASTY and a good size roll with salmon, yellowtail, tuna, crabmeat and avocado wrapped inside thinly sliced cucumber and no rice.

Sashimi Spirit ($10) - SMALL roll: diff raw fish and avocado wrapped in soybean paper.  This roll was so small you need a magnafying glass to see it.  It was like 1/2 the length of a normal size roll cut into 6 itty bitty lil pieces.

Yellowtail Basil ($8) - SMALL roll: yellow tail and basil rolled in batter and deepfried...topped with spicy sauce.  Yuk.  All you can taste with was batter and spicy sauce.  Where's the fish?

I like Taraval Okazu Ya or Ebisu much better.
author: Serena H.

description:
Since Yelp doesn't let you do half-stars, I need to clarify the rating and say that I give this restaurant 3.5 stars. Further clarification on how I feel about sushi. I'm less interested in the debate between "authentic" sushi and "neo" or "nouveau" sushi. If you're one of those sushi purists/traditionalists, this probably isn't the place for you. That said, I feel a little let down after eating here. All the glowing Yelp reviews and personal recommendations from friends got me excited to come here and try this place. This excitement was further compounded when I read over the menu online before coming here and saw the different takes the chef had on sushi. Perhaps my expectation was too high, but still I haven't felt this let down since I found out Jennifer Garner married Ben Affleck. 

We went on a Sunday night around 8 and walked in with no reservations, there was some space at the bar so we were seated immediately. The first thing I noticed was the din. People were conversing loudly to try and be heard over the pounding music. Even sitting in a tight knit group at the bar, my companions and I had to huddle closely to hear each other. No biggie, I've been in loud places before. I liked that they had a decent selection of sake, including 2 of my favorites, Karatamba and Otokayama. I especially liked that they served the sake in wooden boxes, as it should be served.

On to the food, I had a hard time deciding what to eat, all the descriptions in the menu made everything sound so tasty. I eventually settled for the Spicy Girl (avocado wrapped with spicy white tuna and macadamia nuts), African Spider Roll (Cajun flavored albacore, salmon, soft shell crab in spicy house sauce), and Monster-In-Laws (spicy albacore, cuccumer, onion, topped with yellowtail, jalapeno, and ponzu sauce). I also ordered the yellow tail belly, toro, and kanpachi nigiri. My first impression was that everything was extremely fresh. If nothing else, you know this fish hasn't been sitting around all night under ice like the last kid at dodgeball waiting to be picked. The cuts on the nigiri were large and very clean. The rolls too were very fresh. I especially liked the African Spider Roll, the avocado and fish inside the roll made a good contrast to the perfectly fried soft shell crab (nothing worse than an overly greasy soft shelled crab that tastes like it came from a KFC fryer). The spicy house sauce had a nice little kick to it. The Monster-In-Laws was also good and the jalapeno provided the right amount of heat in each bite. 

Now the bad news, some of the plates my companions ordered missed their mark. The Caucasian Afro (spicy tuna mixed with guacamole, onions, tomato sauce, garnished with fried potato vermicelli) was not spicy as advertised and tasted more of avocado than anything else. The Sashimi Spirit (sushi ebi, salmon, ahi tuna, albacore, tobiko, and avocado wrapped in soy paper) was again fresh, but seemed like it was trying to do too much at once with all the flavors. They all kind of muddled together and you didn't get a sense of what the flavor profile was. My companions also ordered the Aloha 101 (Ahi tuna, mango, and cucumber, flash fried and served with spicy garlic sauce), which on the surface sounds really good, but I didn't taste the mango and when you dip it in the garlic sauce, it kinds of kills the other flavors. They also had the Sexy Scallop and Spicy Crunchy rolls. 

My biggest complaint has to be after eating half of all our rolls, they all started tasting the same. You could literally close your eyes, pick a roll at random and eat it and have no idea what you just ate. Herein lies my disappointment. With so much fresh fish at his disposal and so much obvious creative aptitude, the chef could have really come up with some distinct flavor profiles. If anything, I thought he was a little heavy-handed with the sriracha. I love this stuff, but when it gets thrown around too much, everything starts tasting like it. 

So if you come here, stick with the nigiri for the most part. Order one or two rolls to get a sample, and wash it all down with sake from a box.
author: Tony V.

description: A very good place! Freshest sashimi! Have been going there for 7 years! A bit pricy though.
author: Lev R.

description:
The new location suits Sushi Bistro.  It's a trendy place that serves up very non-traditional style sushi-the kind of sushi people who claim to like sushi would eat when their only foray into the sushi world consists of California rolls.  Sushi Bistro justifies this sushi "abomination" by purist standards by doing it all really well.  I haven't even come close to trying even half the rolls on the menu but have been impressed with all I've tasted.  I'm not much for rolls in general so this says something.  Nigiri is great too.  The fish is always extremely fresh and the pieces are enormous, like 3 or 4 bites huge.  

Sushi Bistro is not my favorite but it is overall a very solid spot for both sushi pros and novices and everyone in between.
author: M M.

description:
Excellent Quality, lively atmosphere, huge portions, reasonable price.  I have a new local favorite sushi restaurant.

We used to go to You See or Kitaro for cheap local sushi but never again.  Sushi Bistro is the new king.  We brought some friends used to the LA sushi scene and they were very impressed.  Last time we took them to Tsunami and I was almost embarrassed by the quality and service.  This time I was proud that SF "local" sushi held its own.

Bravo Bistro!
author: Aberdo G.

description:
FANTASTIC!!!!!

After our bad sushi the night before, we needed to try out another sushi spot. After yelping for a bit, we picked this place. It was PERFECT.

We had:

*Agedashi Tofu (appetizer)

*Monster-In-Laws Roll

*Mont Blanc Roll

*Spicy Girl

*African Spider Roll

*Sashimi Spirit 

Cannot wait to go back and try more. Seriously, this was some of the best sushi we have had in the City. And the flavors were so clean and inspired!! Absolutely fresh, loud atmosphere but we loved that about it, and the service was just lovely.

Apparently they are opening a second one in the Mission right near Humphry Slacombe Ice Cream!
author: Abby Z.

description:
I'm going back for the sashimi and nigiri! The portions are larger than most of the other sushi places I've been to, and they were actually pretty tasty. I'm not typically a big fan of Saba nigiri, but the Saba here was fresh and wasn't over salted. I also really enjoyed the yellowtail nigiri and the negihama roll. The service was friendly and surprisingly really fast. We got our nigiri 5 minutes after we ordered.

I wasn't a fan of the Nemo Found nor the First Crush. I found the sauce to be overwhelming and could not taste much of the fish, especially with the First Crush. The place was a little louder than I prefer, but that's not a big deal.

All in all, it was pretty good experience and I will be back for more.
author: Gretch F.

description:
Yes, it is 5 stars, even in their new location (which is twice the size, but 1/2 the ambiance of the old location).  

This restaurant was recommended to us by sushi aficionados from Long Beach, CA (pre-Yelp days).  The chef is originally from a popular Long Beach sushi bar.


The owner/main chef is a master of sauces.  Make sure you order stuff that features the creativity of their chef.  If you're at the bar, go omakase.
author: Lee B.

description:
Don't be thrown off by the name.  Then, don't be thrown off by the sketchy looking exterior.  DO observe the line of people out the door, willing to brave the cool Richmond district elements in order to eat here.  That's because this place is amazing.  I've never had such fresh and high quality cuts of fish in my life - the sashimi melts in your mouth, and barely requires chewing - and is served in VERY gererous portions and for a reasonable price.  We found the service to be speedy and thorough (though it's true - they are a bit rushed because of the crowd), and they made great efforts to make sure we were seated (although I recommend making a reservation if you can).  Have to wait?  Simply sip your draft Sapporro outside...or get a pitcher!  Two reasons not to drive to this place if you don't have to: 1) pitchers of Sapporro and 2) a definite LACK of parking.

I highly recommend the butterfish - sashimi or nigiri, and the tuna was also amazing.  If you are a mackerel fan, go for it!  Make sure to eat their ginger - it has a unique taste, and makes the sushi even more delicious.

My boyfriend got the Udon soup (chicken) and spoke highly of that as well.  We really want to go back and try all the other specialty rolls - there are many!

The ambiance leaves a little to be desired, which is the only reason I"m giving it 4 stars instead of 5.  You kind of feel crammed in there, but if your focus is on the beer and food, you hardly notice it.
author: A G.

description:
I rarely give 5 stars.  I think this place deserves it.  It's not much more expensive than any other random sushi joint and the quality is top notch.  The salmon nigiri indeed melts in your mouth -- it's my favorite bar none.

The special rolls are great, i love the billie jean but you almost can't go wrong with any of them.  The service is good as well.

The ONLY complaint I have is that the place is a bit boisterous.  It's not the same "chill out" sushi experience that you can get elsewhere.  However, that's the price you have to pay for anything that is as epic as sushi bistro at this price point in this city.
author: John K.

description:
The fish is fresh, the rolls and appetizers are unique, and the food for the most part is very flavorful.  If you're looking for a Japanese restaurant that places a large emphasis on traditional preparation, presentation, and flavors then this is not the place you want to eat at. If you're looking for a Japanese restaurant that walks a fine line between traditional and new school then Sushi Bistro is the place you.

This place is almost a must for uni fans. The portions of uni are large, abundant, and the most important FRESH!
author: Phil Y.

description:
Sushi Bistro's logo reminds me of Microsoft Windows.

I've been here before with my family, but I decided to come back for a little Valentines Day eve action. 

I was pretty confused trying to get there cause I guess during the time since my first visit, they had moved down a block into a new building. After finding the spot, we were slightly early for our reservation and only had to wait about 10 minutes for a table to open up.

The atmosphere here is nice, albeit a little cliche if you know what I mean. It just kind of looks and feels like how I would expect a restaurant of this type to be. They always play reggae here so I guess that's nice.

But onto the food. We shared the Hot Love, Magic Mushrooms, New Legend (i think this was what it was called), and another roll I don't remember the name of. 

The Hot Love I've had before and it's pretty scrumptious, with baby lobster and avocados and other shit I can't think of. It was really good though, definitely recommended. 

Sadly, the Magic Mushrooms really weren't that magical to me or my date. They were good, but nothing to bust a nut over. 

The New Legend (roll) was good! This is pretty much all I remember because it's hard for me to distinguish between this and the other roll we ordered. Sorry.

I think the other roll we ordered was called Crispy something, and crispy it was. They also put pistachios in it which is an interesting move but it works.

Basically, get what I got but maybe not the mushrooms. I think I will return here to try their other stuff. If I could, I'd give this place 3.5 stars.

edit: I changed my mind, 4 stars is an apt rating. Yay! I'm a fan.
author: Edmund C.

description:
They even have vegetarian sushi!!!!!!!!  i got a roll "in the sun" with sliced tomato on top, avocado, cucumber, and mango, and it was AMAZING.

i also really like the mango ice cream tempura for dessert-it's warm and cold, crunchy and smooth, and not tooooo sweet.
author: asia c.

description:
It's rare when I will take 3 precious minutes of time to write a review that nobody cares about but I had to let anyone who is on the fence about trying this place know that this place has the best sushi in the city.

I've lived here 12 years and can't believe I am only now finding this place. I have missed out.
author: Bradley T.

description:
One of my favorite places (when I have the money) to go for sushi rolls. I've tried other things on the menu, but nothing seems to match the rolls. They are creative, yummy and aesthetically appetizing. 

Do yourself a favor and make reservations. It's like an hour wait if you have a party of 4 or more. Parking can also be a problem.

The reason why this place is not a 5-star is because of the inconsistencies in food and service. Sometimes the food is incredibly super incredible, but sometimes the ingredients are just not fresh enough, leaving the rolls just mediocre. The waiters seem nice, but sometimes they can be everywhere, and sometimes give off this greeting attitude that is inconsistent for different consumers.

Oh, I'm iffy about the atmosphere. I like it because it's fun, but sometimes it's so loud you can't hear the person next to you... which might be a good thing at times. :) Guess I'm not iffy afterall.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I'm not huge on sushi, but Sushi Bistro is great.  They offer a lot of variations on sushi so that the non sushi lover can still enjoy sushi.  

I like to think of myself as a gringo sushi lover because i have texture issues, but I'd go to Sushi Bistro at the drop of a hat!
author: Heather S.

description:
Friends: Let's get sushi!
Me: SUSHI BISTRO!
Friends: That's in the Inner Richmond! So far!
Me: SUSHI FREAKING BISTRO! 

Since I only live a few blocks from here, this is my standby for sushi. They have really great creative rolls (Watermelon Man - spicy tuna, mango, macadamia nuts, whaaa?) and the edamame is the freshest I've found in the city. Every time I read the words "Caucasian Afro" on the menu, I laugh. Inappropriately.

Sushi Bistro has gotten really popular recently so it can be a long wait for a table and your food but damnit, it's great sushi.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Sushi Bistro is the most vegetarian-roll-friendly spot I've been to thus far. I am not actually a vegetarian - I just don't like seafood. Consider it my contribution to you, the seafood eater; I'm just leaving more fish for you. 

Anyway, if you're a vegetarian (or just don't like seafood), you won't have to stick to veggie tempura here (though they have that too). With an actual section for veggie rolls, not just one measly roll of carrots and cucumbers. We're talking crunchy rolls, shiitake mushroom rolls - even rolls incorporating fruit! I had the crunchy veggie roll and the shiitake mushroom roll, and both were stellar. I was full after 2 rolls, both in the stomach and in joy. 

My only reason for subtracting a star was that the service was kind of out of it when we went the other night. They put a roll in front of us but didn't tell us what it was, and when I asked, he had to take it back to the kitchen to find out. For the last 20 or so minutes that we were there, we were trying to get a check, and then trying to get someone to take our money, so there was a little more sitting around happening for us than was really necessary. 

Other than that, I'd definitely come back here to go through the list (of veggie rolls).
author: Kat E.

description:
"One Visit, Five Haiku"

Edamame should
Be served hot, lightly salted.
Bistro got it right.

Cucumber salad
Chilled in vinegar dressing --
I asked for seconds.

Fresh, tasty, well-made
Sushi rolls and nigiri
Just as they should be.

The veggies with my
Unagi donburi had
Too much black pepper.

But the eel!  The eel,
Smoky-sweet, surrendered to
My chopsticks. Perfect.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
I dont hand out 5 stars so easily but I will for here. 

Great food, great service, and great prices! It sounds like a bad radio-pitch for one of those "El Taqueria (Insert Name Here)" type places but it's true. We were seating immediately (and keep in mind this is V-Day) and then we got our drinks within a matter of seconds, I ordered the Nemo Found or something like that, and it was such an odd-looking, but incredibly tasty sushi thing. Then my friend ordered the Sashimi Bowl and I got the beef teriyaki. So the plates are massive. And when I say massive I mean like they had issues shoving everything onto the table. Which was like "Woah"

Overall, very cozy and cool with great prices and fun to hang out and eat good Japanese :)
author: Dustin H.

description:
Certainly not offensive food, but average at best. 
Nigiri and Sashimi not super fresh. Some of the fish slices were shredded as opposed to a nice slice cut. Had a couple of rolls which were all nondescript in flavor. 
Service was ok. Many better options at $50+/pp (only had one beer and a tea).
What's up with the bussing station out in the open at the end of the bar???
author: patrick l.

description:
I may be too generous but I like creativity. This colorful bistro has fun with sushi and that translates into happy customers. The place really  thinks outside the bento box.   The few tables filled up quickly. And the service was poor. But the ingredients are very fresh which is obviously important.  But I just couldn't stop craving for more traditional flavors.

My party ordered "something unique" and three rolls.  First up was  Double Jeopardy ($9.5) from the something unique section of the menu. This sushi salad was served with a side of shrimp chips. And after I added some wasabi and soy sauce it was good. But not special. 

Next was my pick and it turned out to be the best selection of the night. Big Island ($13.5)  This huge roll has salmon, yellowtail, tuna, and crab meat wrapped in cucumber. The menu claims to have avocado and sprouts. Very little avocado and no sprouts! Regardless, this one was great. 

The Yellowtail Basil($8) I cant even review this little thing. I feel sorry for him. All I can say is I hope he was having an off day, and if not, he should just end it and jump off the menu.

Sashimi Spirit ($10) This guy did have lots of spirit. But he just doesn't have the talent to make the big leagues.
author: Scott D.

description:
Its my standby sushi place.  When i want as good a fish as i can get for the money.  plus some flavor profiles that are a little different.  The quanitity is good, the wait is manageable, the music is good, the chef is having fun.  Service is usually understaffed, but bearable.  They mean no harm to you.  
My favorite is the albacore belly.  but there is always something new to try with such a big menu.
author: Christian W.

description:
Came in at 8:20 pm on a Saturday night.  Got a seat for 2 immediately at the bar.  

The bar is nice because there's actually a lot more room than other bars.  BF and I ordered:

10 piece nigiri combo ($18) - Mmmm!!  HUGE slices of fish with teeny tiny balls of rice (which is how it should be).  Most of the fish was fresh.  The only one that was slightly questionable was the Hamachi...but maybe it was only that one piece that I had, since the other Hamachi was fine.  Great deal for the amount of fish you get!  I would definitely order it again.

Hawaiian Breeze roll ($12) - the BF LOVED IT! it had a nice clean, crisp taste to it.  It was a good kind of different.

Negi-Hama cut roll ($7?) - Unlike many other places, we got BIG pieces of hamachi in the roll.  With a little cucumber and avocado. 

Spider Roll ($9 i think) - It was okay.  Not the best.  Over fried...a little too oily.  I think it's best to stick with their fresh fish here.  Wouldn't order this one again, but it wasn't bad. 

Oh and you get a small dish of cucumber salad (pickled cucumber)...i love that stuff..just like how my mom makes it!

After all that, a cup of tea ($1.50), an large order of house sake (7? or 8), the bill came out to be $58 (post tax, pre tips).  Not bad.  Not bad at all.
author: Emily C.

description: I can't describe the sashimi in any other way other than it melts in your mouth because it is that good and fresh! The service is excellent. My friend always gets the udon and even that is excellent! Overall, my favorite sushi place!
author: D Z.

description:
I picked this place out  this place to get sushi w/ my bf  after looking at the reviews on yelp. 

I guess I can see why people would give 4/5 stars for this place: 
-It's trendy, with a modern vibe, 
-they use really fresh fish
- and its OK priced for being a snazzy place in SF.   

I've eaten at a lot of sushi places, and I think this place is def overrated for all the hype. I give it a 3 and not a 2 b/c  the fish was amazingly fresh and they had good service. BUT: 

Cons: 
-As good as they sound on the menu, the rolls are overcomplicated with too many ingredients. 
-The place is overpriced IMO b/c the portions are ridiculously small.  I really hate how they don't tell you there won't be any rice on the rolls and when there is rice, there's so little you can't event ell. 

We got 3 rolls. 

The five wishes roll was like any rainbow roll.  However instead of seaweed they use soy paper.  The slices of fish was really fresh, but there was no rice in the roll and the imitation crab was way too runny and had too much mayo.

the African Spider Roll alright.  They try to make it sound exotic in the description on the menu, too bad, it tasted as good as any typical Spider roll, and prob would be better if they didn't put 2304389 diff ingredients in it. 

The sexy scallop was kind of gross.  They put some weird milky, sweet sauce mixed with the scallops that made it taste overly fishy.  I'm not a very picky sushi eater but i scooped off the scallop topping on entire roll after trying one piece.  THey ruin the consistency of the albacore by chopping it up.   It also had barely any rice.
author: Tammy W.

description:
I'd like to start off by saying that I'm a little spoiled and pretentious when it comes to sushi AND I'd like you to know it's not my fault.. I grew up in Hawaii where I was basically raised on fresh fish and sushi. 

THAT being said, I'd have to say that Sushi Bistro has some of the best and unique sushi that I've had in the city! Their creative rolls and generous proportions definitely keep me coming back. I've been here a few times and I always try to order something new because they have so many options!! Not only are their rolls great but their entree dishes are amazing as well.. I really love the Ahi tuna poke, where I'd have to say they DO NOT skimp out on the pieces or size of the Ahi tuna! A definite plus!! 

Sushi Bistro just moved from it's old location, literally one door down, to a bigger and nicer spot! I'd have to say that they are much speedier at seating you then at the old location ( it was a little crammed and smaller,) and the space is much nicer. 

Their prices are average for sushi, not extremely cheap but not overpriced either.. I'd say it's a little on the cheaper side when you consider what you get for how much you pay!

I'll keep coming back here for awhile, not to mention it's in my 'hood! Such a bonus!!
author: Sarah T.

description:
This place didn't just go downhill, it's fallen off a cliff. 

This is very disappointing, but I cannot recommend this place anymore.  Their price to quality ratio used to be amazing.  Now the rolls are expensive but the fish is either tasteless or fully cooked or masked with spicy sauces or jalapenos.   The California roll was just disgusting, a fat sausage of surimi with an overpowering mayo taste.  I've had better CA roll at Safeway.   Unfortunately, the bistro appears to be resting on the laurels of its glory days.  Check out Tsunami Sushi at Divisadero and Fulton for a far superior experience.
author: Localista I.

description:
Probably the healthiest cuts on nigiri you'll ever see, and some the tastiest, most enjoyable as well.  Great rolls, and some special items as well, like sashimi with jalapenos and chili sauce (I liked Kabuto's version better), and the blue fin toro was fantastic.

Service was friendly and prompt. I'm not a huge fan of the ambiance and waiting area (outside).

4 1/2 stars.
author: shaun l.

description:
Solid. Fresh fish.
complimentary green tea icecream.

get reservations.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
The presentation of our rolls was impeccable and the service was fantastic. We left our selections up to our wonderful waiter/ owner Dave who kept our tabe full of exciting dishes. The sushi was fresh, and the sauces were fantastic.  The dining experience was one of the best I have had in a long while, and I think others at my table would say the same. 

It also has a really intimate feel, as the place seems far away (for us Marina/ Pac H/ Russian Hill folks) and is a welcome chage from being 'on campus' 

Go there.
author: Danielle V.

description:
i love the mix of classic and nouveau, and SB surely does it right.  you can get your traditional japanese fare, and also their twists of japaense fusion.  they are very inventive with their mix of sauces and ingredients, which i would have never dreamed up with sushi.  

i'm not much for crazy rolls, so we mainly stuck with sashimi and one nigiri.  we ventured out to try their "something unique dishes" and had the drunken halibut and butterfish blasters.  i really enjoyed the butterfish blasters between the two.  also the servers didn't miss a beat...water was always refilled, and plates were taken away promptly.
author: Sheri N.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE! I've been a fan since their first location. Ask me which restaurant is one of my favorites and most likely I'll say this place first! Their food and service is always excellent and consistent. Although there are a few selections I never leave out every time I go (ie:the amaebi nigiri), the menu is full enough of variety that I'm pleasantly surprised with something new. I'm a sahshimi connoisseur and their fish is always fresh! Great specials as well... Go check this place out! To top off your meal, order the black bottle sake- you won't be sorry. Everything's yummy! i heart sushi bistro.
author: Kaliah C.

description:
If this is the little Japanese restaurant I'm thinking of it is great.  They have some great sashimi.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
This place is awesome and the lady (i forget her name) rocks!  My advice, don't go.  Leave it for me and my friends.

Went there again last night and I am a sucker for the lettuce wraps. Imagine your favorite spicy, crunchy, delicious sushi roll wrapped a perfect little lettuce food tube.  All for you, you don't have to share!  Awesome!  And they are named after the seasons-Spring, Summer, winter, etc... The fish is super fresh and the chef is a wizard with his CA inspired creations.  

If you go, ask for the SARA sauce.  It's nothing more than Siracha chili sauce but my friend Sara started using it and since my large group of friends has been given our own bottle.  We use it instead of wasabi and soy and have written our names all over the bottle.  write yours and make mention you read my review on Yelp!
author: J P.

description:
This place really made me miss the city.  Sure, we have great food down here in the South Bay, and we have places that are even hip, too, with charm--and parking....and oh who am I kidding?  So many places up in the city just have a 'vibe' or a 'soul' that is lacking here in the heart of the silicon valley and Sushi Bistro is a great example.

I solo-dine more often than not and sitting at the sushi bar gives me something to do instead of read a book like the lonely dork I am.  

I scored agadashi Tofu, an African Spider roll and hamachi sashimi before heading out to see Diving Bell at the Embarcadero.  

The Tofu was ok.  The tofu itself was very silky, which made eating the giant cubes impossible.  I have a surgeons touch when it comes to using chopsticks and I still made mush out of it.  A tofucidal STAB STAB approach worked the best.

The African Spider Roll was very good.  The soft shell crab was perfectly cooked and seasoned.  Unfortunately the sashimi that was inside was all but obscured by the crab.  Still, it was good.

The Hamachi Sashimi was a highlight.  Most of the time quality is inversely proportional to size....not here.  They served up two very large slices of sashimi to my surprise.  But unlike every other sushi joint I've ever been to that serves up massive pieces, Sushi Bistro slices it THIN instead of big-chunk style.  

The Reggae music they had going on was a great relief.  For some reason most Japanese places either play glam rock or - even worse - maudlin R&B songs.  I never knew how well Reggae went with hot sake, but now I do!
author: Nobody M.

description:
Have to agree with Ray L. on the fish-served-too-cold-hence-lacking in flavor.  Experienced this with the Ahi Poke.  Last time i was here the Five Wishes was totally inedible.  You know those times, as a carnivore, that you can't help but be reminded that you are eating a dead animal?  Yea, basically that was it.  images of dead fish, cartoon XX eyes and all, then washing it down with sake.  Kinda like this:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HPSVY_CQknc

First time I ate at Sushi Bistro at the old location i loved all the food, not sure if it was just an off night.

The Hot Love is still pretty awesome tho (Baby lobster, avocado and crab meat rolled in snapper, baked with spicy sweet sauce.)
author: Vivian T.

description:
Everything was great.  I highly advise you go here.

I lived in SF for 2 years and this was the best place for sushi I found.  Not only is the food great but the price is very reasonable.  

Every time I visit Sushi Bistro is a must!
author: Dan E.

description:
3.5 stars. This place was just okay. The food was mediocre. The service was nice. 

Came for dinner. We were seated right away for 4 people. Ordered the chicken teriyaki with vegetable tempura, the udon, the california rolls, and 2 other rolls (halibut and salmon). The food came out really quickly, but nothing spectacular about any dishes. However, I don't think the price was really worth it for the food..I've definitely had better.
author: Claire F.

description: I ordered take out from here...what a mistake!!!! i ordered the albacore dream and omega 3. first of all there isnt enough rice so the stuff inside it is over powering. the little rice that was on it was mushy. The rolls itself tasted gross! never again...i wasted 25 dollars on two disgusting rolls.. i didnt even finish them!
author: Josie M.

description:
There is no doubt about the proclamation that I am going to make -- Sushi Bistro is the best sushi spot in San Francisco. Been a regular here for years. 

All the rolls are unique and flavorful; my personal favorite is the Hawaiian Breeze. The Chef's Special is also an incredible roll (though not on the menu). 

One should always end with a Fall Lettuce Wrap. It's one of the best tasting food items on the menu.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Today was my first time eating at Sushi Bistro. Of course, my first instinct was to go on Yelp.com to look at the ratings and then I went to their website. At first I thought it was a little expensive for my usual sushi eating. But when my friends and I went, it was one of the best sushi places ever.

I recommend the Sashimi Spirit, Spicy Crunch, C2, and the Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon. 

My friends and I ordered 6 different rolls, 2 small plates, and had ice cream just for $72. I was so full and very pleased. This is now my new favorite sushi restaurant.
author: Danna D.

description:
I signed up on yelp to leave this review. Husband and I got take out here last night and it was awful.  (I'm leaving 2 stars instead of 1 to give them the benefit of the doubt, since it was take out)

Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon -  the front runner  the as one of the "top 10 worst things I've ever eaten" .  The unagi was so fishy and smelled really off.  And the texture of the avocado was like mush. Granted, shrimp tempura can soft after a while, but it was like a mush fest with this roll. And I can't stress enough how off the unagi tasted.  Took one roll each then threw it out.

Miso Glazed Sea Bass - the miso glaze was so thick and totally overpowered the fish. We scraped off most of the glaze and combined it with rice to tone it down a bit. But after all that the fish was really rubbery.  Was it truly sea bass?? not sure...

Salmon Nigiri - Mine was okay. Nice large piece of salmon, but my husband couldn't chew through his. gross.

Pork Gyoza - good, but pretty hard to screw up.

$40 later, and we're still hungry.  Maybe they don't value the take out orders? After all the great reviews, this was surprising.  I think they need to simplify the menu a bit - too many sauces and combos.  That could tell you something about the quality of fish.
author: Mary C.

description:
This sushi place has delicious sashimi and so-so rolls.  

For some context, the other places I really like in the bay area are Sushi Tomi in Mountainview (good value, tasty salmon), and Sushi on the Run in Los Gatos (the guy is from Kagoshima and has hockey memorabilia everywhere... awesome?)

I give it 5 stars because of the delicious sashimi in a city where that shouldn't be hard to find... yet is.

Ocean Trout = yum, but get the Salmon its cheaper and tastes same
Salmon = yum
Yellowfin = yum
Saba = I don't like it but I never did and those who did like it liked it.

Not overpriced, and quality fish.  I wish there was a place like this in SOMA.  

The rolls we ordered (african spider, something about butterfish, and sexy scallops) were mediocre at best - just a mash of flavours.  I'd like to order the hotate and tae next time.

That's just how I roll (or don't roll... stick with nigiri/sashimi OK?!)
author: Rob S.

description:
Went back for another try, fish  was more thawed out, and had a bit more flavour...still lacking a fatyness, toro nigiri was  good, but not fish butter good.  Uni was delicious
Looks like this place more for rolls, than nigiri and sashimi, but still can not complain about their jumbo size

really enjoyed the FIVE WISHES roll, unique flavor, roll without any rice

Still 3 stars ish, prob 3.5...fresh fish, decent flavour
author: ray l.

description:
It has been a long time since I have been so pleasantly surprised by a sushi restaurant.  CAVEAT: I'm preggers and did not actually eat any fish!  

If they treat their fish the way the treat everything else though, it must be good.  And it was packed, so others must agree.  

First, on the "ambiance".  It's definitely NOT one of the big, hip sushi joints.  I.E., no DJ, no mood lighting, no modern decor, etc.  The room is tiny, in fact, and rather plain.  BUT, they do take reservations, and we did not have to wait but a second for our table. BRING YOUR JACKET!!
