They have one those doors that opens automatically, but also closes automatically, which means it takes ages.  However, watching people try to close the door is excellent entertainment.

Food and drinks arrive quickly.  If you order some dishes that are cold, and some that are hot (with tempura, for instance) ask for the cold ones first, so you don't feel rushed.  Everything was delicious.  They heat the edamame in butter (always good in my book, but I'm from Alabama), and use plenty of salt.  The veggie sushi list actually had more on it than plain avocado rolls, and the in rainbows roll was YUMMY!  

A very nice sake selection rounds things out.

The fried ice cream was my least favorite item of the night, but I am picky about the grease my food is fried in.  (Alabama, remember?)  And I swear I tasted a little tempura in my mochi.  

I don't know if I would hustle over to the richmond JUST to eat here, but if you are anywhere in the area, it warrants several visits.
author: Amme P.

description:
Yeah, you need a reservation. It's a small and busy place. No, there's no parking. Take the damn bus like everyone else.

My roommates took me here for my birthday dinner. It was AMAZING. The fish was delicate and fresh, the service was good, and the sake was strong. 

I highly recommend the Spicy Crunchy, Watermelon Man, Fortune roll, 49er, and the Bistro Brownie. We also had a plate of sashimi--the salmon and butterfish are the best. 

I was stuffed after so much sushi and so many sake bombs, but then the restaurant went dark and they brought out fried ice cream with candles in it and sang happy birthday to me. I was both humiliated and touched. And I did manage to choke down the fried ice cream :)
author: Aunt B.

description:
I am 10 years San Francisco / Richmond District resident and sushi lover.
I've been at many sushi restaurants internationally, yet Sushi Bistro is a leader in my rating table.
Nice atmosphere, quick professional service, amazingly tasting sushi.
Good: food, location, service
Bad: usually no parking around, music can be too loud.
author: Sing T.

description:
Sushi was AMAZING! I had been eagerly trying to find a sushi place in the city that i really loved, and i finally have! THE rolls are DELICIOUS and they have a lot of different and innovative options on their menu. 

The service was fast, but sloppy. It was busy, but not so busy that they should have had such a hard time figuring out who was going to get us water. Our server was impersonal and by far our least favorite part of the meal. 

If it wasn't for their food, I would not be interested in going back.(the foods that good)
author: Sharon C.

description:
I just came back from eating at Sushi Bistro for the first time and I'd like to think I'm a fan. The place is small and cute, I really like the set up of this restaurant.

So my boyfriend and I ordered the Hawaii 101, 5 Wishes, and Volcano roll along with pot stickers for appetizers. The pot stickers were delicious, one of the best I've tasted surprisingly and I didn't think pot stickers could get any better than they already were. As for the sushi, it was surprisingly good. My Hawaii 101 wasn't OMG good but for something with mango and for me being a person who isn't a huge fan of raw, I liked it. The 5 wishes dish was really good too and surprisingly both of those rolls had no rice in it what so ever so if you're on a low carb diet it works great for you. We also ordered the Volcano roll as a safety in case we didn't like the different rolls and found ourselves still satisfied. I really wish I had a huge stomach to try everything else on the menu though. This place has a lot of new things that sound really good and I can't wait to go back.

P.S. The music was really good too.
author: Janell Y.

description:
Horrible attitude by the owner/manager.  My friend was having a birthday dinner there last Friday, so I called ahead to ask about the corkage fee for bringing our own sake.  The person said that "they have their own sake for purchase, but the corkage fee is $15".  Since I was bringing an oversized bottle, I specifically asked whether it mattered what size it was and the reply was "it doesn't matter".

So at the end of the meal, the manager or owner, I don't know what she is (but she's the older Asian woman) came over and gave us crap about bringing our own sake.  When we explained to her that we called ahead to ask about the details, she retorted that "we trying to do business here" and told us that next time we call, that we should "ask for the manager".  I told her it was her responsibility to work these things out, not ours.  All-around, very poor attitude, and if she really had an issue with it, she should have come to us at the beginning of the meal, not at the end.  It's not like the big bottle of sake wasn't in clear view.

The impact of the pissy attitude could have been lessened if the food was spectacular, but I found more novelty sushi roll items than authentic Japanese fare, with names that are playful but oddly reminiscent of sexual maneuvers taken from Urbandictionary.com.
author: Dai D.

description: My hubby and I dined here a few weeks ago. It was a bit pricey for us but the few rolls we tried were pretty good, my favorite being the sushi with the spicy scallops and the crab and lobster special house roll (not sure what they were called) anyway, we didn't exactly get full and the wait in between rolls was a bit long but their rolls were definitely inventive and tasty. Although, unfortunately, I don't think the hubby will be dining there anytime soon because somehow he felt really sick and his stomach hurt all night after he ate there, so I'm guessing it was some kind of food poisoning that night. So one star taken off for the price and the second for my hubby not feeling so good after we ate there. Other than that I did enjoy the rolls we ordered, but we probably wouldn't dine here on a regular basis due to cost.
author: Petra S.

description:
I thought coming here a second time would change my mind about this place...it did. Slightly.

My best friend, a total foodie, LOVES this place. The first time I came here, I ordered the teriyaki chicken with mixed veggies and rice. Ehh....I've had better chicken teriyaki. I thought the chicken was a little too hard to chew and the meat wasn't tender. The veggies were mushy...I like mushy veggies but not too mushy. The amount of teriyaki sauce on the dish was way too much as well so it was pretty salty for me. I didn't particularly enjoy my dining experience...it was crowded, we sat by the door so the cold breeze kept blowing at me and I was sick. My best friend commented on my lack of knowing what good food is. I thought to myself, "Maybe I ordered the wrong thing? Maybe I should've tried a roll instead? Maybe then I'd think the place was good?" Hmmm...

Came here the other night with a date and I finally tried the sushi...it was pretty good. It's not the best that I've had though, unfortunately.  I had the "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" roll and the "Crunchy" roll. My date ordered the "Albacore Dream" roll and the classic, "California" roll. The waiter didn't really pay much attention to us. I was dying of thirst by the time the waiter refilled my hot water.

Again, I couldn't stand the cramped restaurant with everyone violating my personal space. They're moving like two or three spaces down and my best friend says it's a much bigger restaurant. Let's hope so!
author: V M.

description:
Serving up oversized pieces of the tastiest fish around!  The salmon was so fresh that it literally melts in your mouth.  (Fish that good is hard to come by).  It's between $30 and $40 per person for dinner, depending on the amount of alcohol that you order.  I consider this a steal based on the A+ quality of the fish.  They have a large selection of novelty rolls.  Try the Big Island roll - tuna and other goodies wrapped in cucumber instead of rice.  It will make your eyes fall out of your head.

I haven't tried many non-sushi items, but the ones I have tried have all been quite good.  I go to Sushi Bistro again and again.  It's totally worth the ride all the way across SF.
author: Leigh S.

description:
Mmm, agedashi tofu! I could eat five servings of this myself. The YT Jalapeno practically melted in my mouth, very fresh yellowtail. The Watermelon Man roll was unique but the avocado/mango mix seemed to overwhelm the rest of the flavors. Nice to try but not a re-order. The Big Island was also delicious, the combination of salmon, tuna & crabmeat wrapped in cucumber slices instead of nori was a nice change of pace. 

Service was friendly and water glasses were promptly refilled. The restaurant was empty since I was there right when they opened so there was no wait. Parking was also a breeze. Great experience overall!
author: Nathalie L.

description:
Update 2/22/08:

Whoa there pal. Suddenly, you're not so hot to trot, Mr. Bistro. The service was off the last couple of times, and this last time I went in, everything was pretty sucky. The crab was still great. The fish was sub-par, particularly the albacore, which I typically love anywhere. I had it as nigiri, and the fish was so sinewy, so full of tenuous bits, that I literally could not even eat it (and wow, I didn't even go into the fact that he doused the whole thing in a much too powerful spicy something that was craptacular). That's nasty folks. Also, I asked for no sauces on my fish because I'm going to sushi for sushi and not for some overabundant masking mayo sauce. The chef was kind enough to refrain, but on a dish like the five wishes, which comes with a tasty little salad in the middle, he omitted that as well. What gives? Dropped from four to two. Ouch.

**********
Perhaps I'm a ridiculously lucky person (though many recent events would contradict this thought), but I've never had a problem sliding into a pair of stools at the bar upon the moment of entering Sushi Bistro. While it can sometimes be chaotic (being yet another hole in the wall), I've found the staff to be pretty darn attentive, albeit forgetful. Personally speaking, there are too many cooked rolls on their menu, and they up the sauciness a bit much at times. On the wonderful side, their cold sake list is amazing, and the quality of their fish, when it's good, rivals the best sushi around. Their crab meat is quite superb, and so I end up going for rolls that include it (and adding it to rolls, like the 49'er, that don't). Parking's a bitch, welcome to San Francisco.
author: Shannon F.

description:
I love Sushi B! They have very interesting rolls, fresh fish, great and prompt servers, and a really fun atmosphere. 

Not to be missed:
  -Butterfish sashimi (simply melts in your mouth)
  -C-2 (lobster and avodaco, don't mind if I do!)
  -Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon (yum)
  -Monster in Laws (always love jalapenos with fish)

Try it, you will be a convert.
author: Nadia K.

description:
This is one of the best sushi place to go if you are looking for decent sushi but not like top of the class sushi.
Butterfish blaster is by far the best 
and we also like the 5 wishes.
author: weili c.

description:
In the spirit of jumping away from our comfort spots, some girlfriends and I tried out Sushi Bistro last night. 

My review is this...I am normally a fan of Zushi Puzzle in SF and Coach Sushi in Oakland...I still love them, truly, but Sushi Bistro was awesome. Lets face it, most sushi restaruants follow similar rules on portion size and such, so we had not expected the massive pieces of fresh nigiri that landed on our plates. I gobbled them appreciatively, happy to be tasting the big tender pieces of fish with just a hint of the rice below (Just how I like it!). 

My Nigiri Picks: Hamachi and Albacore shown the brightest, but Sake and Maguro were good to! 
My Roll pick: We didnt try the more festive rolls, opting for the traditional. My fav was old trustie: Negi-Hama (hamachi, green onion, and cucumber)

Only hiccup, hence the 4 stars...we ordered edamame as we waited, which didnt come, ordered it again, still didnt come, finally on third try got those salty beans after our many plates of sushi showed up. Big deal, nah.

If your in the city or looking for yummy fresh sushi...this is the spot. Try it, try it now!
author: T L.

description:
This place is really yummy and has a great vibe, and the new location looks really good (and no longer has the freezing-draft-area of the old location three doors down). 

I highly recommend that if you're trying their specialty rolls for the first time, you ask the server for recommendations. Every time I did so they gave me an amazing roll, but each time I tried to figure it out for myself, it was usually weird and felt like the roll was just there so they can claim to have a huge variety of rolls. 

The prices are a touch high, so the main reason I still eat here is because I find myself constantly craving their ahi tuna poki salad, which is a must try for anyone who enjoys spiciness. The monster-in-law roll is spicy and delicious, too.
author: A. A.

description: I really really like their spicy tuna rolls here!  Good price and nice portions as well!  The place itself is a decent size for a sushi place and we've not had to wait long for tables though it is usually pretty full.
author: Hui C.

description: Easily our favorite sushi in San Francisco. It's a shame it's so busy now, but they deserve their success! The salmon sashimi is to die for.
author: Bryan K.

description:
I discovered this gem only last night...a little disappointed as I've lived 3 blocks from it for 5 years!!!!

The Service: Top Notch. It makes a difference people...i asked for a Sapporo and it was there in less than 30 secs. We waited a while for our last roll and decided to skip since we were full, no big deal...i got smiles all around and no dirty dishes left on my table for longer than 2 min.

The Sushi/Food: Really good. Everything seemed fresh-we recommend the 49 roll...i love those tiny eggs at the end that pop, really yummy.  Nothing special about the tempura or other sides, but still really satisfying, fresh, and delicious.

Make sure to wear layers when you come here, it's hot inside and so s the sake. Also, I had read that sometimes the wait is long, we went around 8:45 and were seated immediately-we had a choice of bar or tables. You can also make a reservation.

I will definitely return again, perhaps this week.
author: nina B.

description:
More like 3.5 though.

The sushi is pretty good. They have unique rolls and brown rice rolls are available for the healthy people out there. I would recommend the tuna delight. The prices are quite reasonable as well. 

It is always crowded here and there is usually a wait. So, I would recommend a reservation. The most annoying thing about this place, the reason why it merits only 3.5 stars, is the complete lack of parking in this area. Argh, so annoying. Makes it difficult to bring myself to come over. Usually, I'll settle for calling in for the food and taking out.
author: Angela L.

description: This was a pretty good place to get fusion rolls until they decided to turn their restaurant into a fusion of lounge and restaurant. Their food quality has gone down and now they thump distracting techno. I miss the good old days with you guys.
author: Andrew H.

description: a really close 4 star rating, but no cigar. i wasn't blown away by the sushi. the garlic sauce on the roll i had was BOMB.com, but i forget the name of the roll. apologies. we had the monster-in-laws, nameless roll, agedashi, soup, salad, and sashimi combo. the agedashi portions were VERY healthy. i appreciated that the rolls showcased the seafood rather than the rice ;) butter fish sashimi itself was worth the trip. it had really interesting after taste i've never had before. if you're in the neiborhood, you'll be pleasantly suprised.
author: Isabel N.

description:
My friend and I came here on a Saturday night from looking at Japanese restaurants on Yelp. I always eat at the restaurant next door (Namu), but never really noticed this restaurant whatsoever. I'm really glad I found this place!

Once I stepped in to this restaurant, you can tell that this place is very American. The majority of the waiters/waitresses were Caucasian and had no Japanese decor, but we let the food decide if this Japanese restaurant is worthy or not. We heard the butterfish was really good here, so we ordered the butterfish blaster (snow crab meat and avocado wrapped in butterfish torched with a garlic-soy), crouching tiger hidden dragon roll (shrimp tempura, aioli, avocado & cucumber, topped with unagi and eel sauce), and C-2 roll (baby lobster, avocado and cucumber topped with shrimp tempura, drizzled with eel sauce). When you come here, you HAVE to order the butterfish blaster! It's the most delicious thing EVER. That was my favorite out of the three things I've ordered. My second favorite would be the crouching tiger hidden dragon roll because it resembles the dragon roll, and I LOVE dragon rolls. C-2 was very good too.

This restaurant is a bit pricey on the rolls, but definitely worth it. Parking may be a problem during the evening time. I will definitely come back to try more rolls!
author: Vivian L.

description:
The docor is ok. The food has good presentation. I would recommand to try their salads. All of them look pretty good. The baby crab salad looks and taste equally good. They have some special rolls that I don't see at other places. They are worth trying. The taste of the rolls are varies. A lot of them have spicy sauce in it, so you would not be able to taste the sashimi.

In conclusion, it's a good value.
author: Benedict C.

description:
What I experienced last Thursday: humiliation, indifference and disrespect!
I went to Sushi Bistro with my husband on Thursday 10/17/13 . This is not my first visit to this place and i have never been disappointed till yesterday evening. What is the most terrible thing - I was communicating and dealing with the owner of SB himself (which i realized later). When I entered the restaurant there were 2 tables unoccupied - for 4 people each (created by putting 2 tabled for 2 together). Both tables had the sign "Reserved" on them.
Answering that there are 2 of us I was told that the waiting time is 20 minutes. In the line there is only my husband and I - no other people. We waited for another 5 minutes, then 3 people showed up from behind and the SB host (owner as I learned later) asked them the same question  he asked me "How many of you?". They answered: "3", and he replied: "You can occupy this table" and he removed the sign "Reserved" .  I then proceeded to ask this guy "Do these people have reservations? ", He said "No". My question was "then why did you seat them before us, and we have to wait 20 minutes?" He answered "Yes." 
Whatever questions I would ask him he would just simply answer, "Yes" with the nicest smile on his face, as if he wasn't even listening to me. I then asked him again, "Why did you seat these 3 people before us?" He smiled and just pointed his finger to a sign reading, "We reserve the right to refuse service to anyone."
I felt humiliated and completely disrespected.  I am a good customer of this restaurant and just wanted to enjoy a night out with my husband. I just don't see why this man, who is the "owner", would disregard his customers in such a rude manner. I generally loved this restaurant, but after being mistreated like that in front of all the other customers, I don't think I can ever enjoy myself here again.
author: Helen T.

description:
The Sushi:
Very innovative rolls!  Use of things like macadamia nuts or cajun spices were a nice change.  The tempura in the rolls was actually still hot and juicy when served.  There was something off with the actual fish.  It wasn't that it was low-quality, it looked fabulous and was tender.  It's more that it seemed like someone watered it down like a poorly made cocktail.  I'll try it again on the chance it was an off night.

The Bad:
The miso was a bit bland.  Sake selection was a bit limited and overpriced.  Decor is a bit on the tacky side and the tables are a little too small to fit your dishes.  

Other Good:
Service was attentive and the sushi chef was interactive.
author: Michelle P.

description:
Overall, this is still my favorite sushi joint in the city.

They have super-creative plates and it's all ultra-fresh.

This is a great place to take people who say they don't like sushi. They will almost certainly discover something they love.

This place is a good deal relative to other quality sushi places. It ain't exactly cheap, but it won't cause you to default on your mortgage, either.

Here are some items I'd recommend:

- YT Jalapeno - Ohhh man... Sliced yellowtail with japaleno and lime juice
- Stinky Crunchy - Do I even need to describe it?
- Omega 3 Roll
- Lots of stuff off the "Something Unique" menu... I remember the oyster plates being especially good.
- Yellowtail belly. Anything with yellow tail belly in it.


Warning: They're often under-staffed, so service can be an issue.
author: Angelo B.

description:
This place stands out because of it's inspired menu.  Their rolls and specialty salads include creative names like The African Spider, The Watermelon Man, and The Caucasian Afro.  But don't let that distract you from the fact that the food here is delicious.

The fish is of top quality and the presentation is top notch as well.

The downer ,through no fault of their own, is that parking is often difficult to find in this area.  Also, I used to be able to come into this place without having to wait, but with this place becoming quite popular it's harder to come here without having to wait these days.  Service has usually been great as well and I especially enjoy the Reggae that often plays during business hours.

It's a great atompshere, with a great menu, that truly delivers.  My favorite Sushi destination in the City.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
8 o'clock reservation for a party of 4. 

WHY DID I HAVE TO WAIT an additional TWENTY MINUTES for my table?!?!?

Jam packed. Super busy. Usually a good sign, right? 

We all read the reviews on the person who gave it a star. That is what I guess we spent our entire day doing at work, reading Yelp reviews... hmmm productivity level -- zero. 

The sushi was ok. (Very cool names like Nemo Found - heehee) The waiter, kinda cute. The music, a little loud. And the room, very crowded. 

Still looking for a "REALLY GOOD" sushi place in the city. Haven't found it yet...
author: Lisa L.

description:
Ahi Tuna Poke, Butterfish and the unagi are super fresh and delicious. All very generous portions and fast service. 
The unfiltered sake is cheap and the Asahi is cold. Done and done. 
This is now my new go to sushi joint in the hood.
author: Stacy T.

description:
I feel lucky to live within walking distance of this place.  I love sushi.  To me it's one of those things I could eat everyday and not get tired of it.  My wife, however, is not a fan.  I'm s-l-o-w-l-y getting her to like it (I've been working on this for over a decade) and while she's pretty much stuck on only ordering vegetarian rolls she loves coming here.

The first time I went, they passed with flying colors my test for every sushi place - the negi-hama roll.  It's good here.  I usually order one roll of that plus whatever else meets my fancy.  As of late it's been the sashimi bowl.

The fish is usually fresh so I keep coming back.  But what initially made my wife like the place were the non-sushi items on the menu.

Oh, and do call ahead and make reservations.  The place gets crowded fast.
author: Ben C.

description:
I've been craving for good sushi for weeks! Maybe I was expecting more but I thought this place was only OK.  Ordered a sashimi bowl which was fresh and really soft but I just didn't like the huge slices.  I love sashimi but for some reason hugh slices of sashimi makes feel rather nauseas.  The rice with the sashimi was sweet and delicious though.  The Wakiki roll was too soggy and mushy, Butterfish Blasters was tasty but also mushy (Zushi Puzzle's butterfish is so much better!), and Super Dynamite was not a sushi roll that I was expecting so that kind of bummed me out.  

In the end when we got the check, they actually charged us one extra dish we never ordered so I had to have them fix it.  Luckily my boyfriend saw it, otherwise we would have paid for more.  Although I was rather disappointed at the food we ordered, their menu holds a variety of interesting things to try so I would come back here again to try their other stuff.
author: sidney c.

description:
If you are interested in eating very tasty, not ordinary, fresh and delicious sushi - this is the place to go!
located in a great location (but not great parking) in the middle of a residential neighborhood, the people in sushi bistro know what they are doing.

I came here once a month for the past two years, and they still did not disappoint me. The decor is amazing, the atmosphere is young and classy, I never had to wait more then 10 minutes for a table for 2 and the food is wonderful.

I love their creativity of the sushi; hot and clod, spicy and sweet, crunchy and smooth in the same time.

All of the sushi rolls are exotic but I highly recommend the crunchy roll and the C-2... it melts in your mouth!

So if you want to experience a sushi bar (not really authentic Japanese, however more California style) and not come out with a very high bill, COME HERE! you will fall in love with it, just like I did!
author: A C.

description: This place rocks for the simple fact that they have a substantial vegetarian sushi menu.  Of course I ordered the roll with fried vegetables and sweet sauce drizzled over the top, but there are healthier options to choose from.  The main part of the restaurant was a bit noisy but our group had a table in the very back, where it was pretty easy to hear everyone.  Rolls came out quickly, waiter was friendly, and the complimentary cucumber and sesame seed salad was pretty bomb.  Everyone else liked their non-veggie sushi rolls, but to Eugene's point (below), the rolls did look pretty non-authentic, and each roll was sort of slathered significantly in some kind of sauce or cheese.  So maybe that's your thing.  If not,  beware...
author: LaSha G.

description:
I was amazed by this sushi place. Even though it's not your usual attempt of being an authentic Japanese restaurant, it gives a contemporary and trendy approach to this traditional cuisine. They have a generous sake list and large sushi menu. The main sushi chef is extremely fast and skilled and their fish are really fresh. One advice, if you're planning on ordering more than 2 items, I'd suggest you to sit at a table versus the bar. 

Only bad thing about this restaurant is parking! I had to park 3 blocks away. Once I got out of the restaurant, it had already began to rain again. 

Sushi Bistro is the only busy restaurant on that street and there are 2 reasons for that: parking and contemporary sushi!

4 stars!
author: Ray W.

description:
Sushi bistro! Sushi bistro! Sushi bistro! Sushi bistro! Sushi bistro!

Seriously, it's really that good. Whenever I have friends and family visit from out of town, they pretty much unanimously vote to go out to the Bistro. 

Creativity, flavor, mood, price- all great.
author: Bill F.

description: This is one of those places were I feel like I shouldn't like it (because that's cool), but I really do. The fish might not be that great, but the sauces and other fillings make up for it in spades. I've been here a number of times and it's probably the sushi place I go to most often. Most of the rolls have some sort of twist to them and are usually pretty great (excluding a few duds like the over sauced Rock'N Roll). I've never bothered with a reservation because the wait time isn't usually that long. Last night seemed pretty busy but even then it only took them 15 minutes to seat my girlriend and me. They also let you call in orders for pickup, which I've been meaning to try. There is another, smaller location in the Mission, but it's a bit on the loud side.
author: Jeremy J.

description: fresh sashimi, the lettuce wrap thingy was really delicious. very creative and tasty sushi rolls.
author: Long C.

description:
okay warning!!! 
this place is not a place for a die hard true japanese cuisine. so take it for what it is. i wish there was a point two five or point five available on here because i would give it a 3.25-3.50.

this place is amerikuh! + japanese confusion....but somehow it kinda works.

all the rolls and items are crazily stuffed with a million things accompanied by funny names.

if  this place is trying to be elegant & bourgey-sophisticated this would be an epic fail.
but if it is trying to be an american fusion full of overkill and fun then yes, it wins.

it is like a mc donald's value meal trying to be elegant...each roll & item is like a burger, pickles, ketchup, fries & a coke....super satisfying with fumbling flavor but a hot mess. hahahah....i mean this in a good way.

all the crazy rolls were muddled in a bunch of different sauces & things but still yummy.

the uni was fresh & tasty.

the service was great.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description: I'm not sure what the hype is about this place. Went there last night and was disappointed. Their sushi is making an attempt at being unique but it is really just lacking taste and rice (seriously, who makes a roll without a good amount of rice?!). Regardless, draft beer was overpriced and I'm surprised this place had 4 solid stars when kitaro is less than 20 blocks away.  I would not come back.
author: Robert H.

description:
This is absolutely my favorite sushi restaurant in all of san francisco.  Fresh fish, great service, good value, creative rolls selection with complex flavors.

I've been going there for years, I just wished that people didn't discover it over the last few years cuz now it's hard to get seats sometimes!

I highly recommend it.
author: Ingrid Y.

description:
I LOVE Sushi Bistro. It is my favorite place in SF. Their rolls are so creative, David is always so helpful. I never order from the menu, I just tell him "no mayo, no fake crab and no tempura" and he brings us what he thinks we'd like. He never disappointed me or any of my friends. I love going back and do so often. 

Yes, it is loud and the wait can be long, but I forget about it with the first bite.
author: Jana C.

description:
Let's make this easy and prefaced with the fact that I love both traditional and fusion/American style sushi. 

The good: 
Unique rolls. The ones I had-  the African Spider, Crouching Tiger and Sexy Scallop were all pretty good and I would only come back for these.

The bad:
**Chicken Teriyaki. You're thinking to yourself: "What!? No way! Chicken teriyaki is good everywhere!" Well, let me tell you. NO. SB's version of chicken teriyaki is a dried out chicken breast from safeway with black pepper all over it. Fusion? NOPE. Just bad.

**Nigiri. It's really not nigiri. HUGE pieces of fish (which were fresh btw and tasted good) with a small bit of rice - About half the size of the average American's pinkie finger. FAIL. I don't mind the huge pieces of fish, even though that's not the right way of cutting it, but the rice under it was a joke. A big reason why I'm giving only two stars is because there was a scale on my salmon which ended up in my mouth... To me - this just shows careless preparation...and when I'm eating raw fish, I think care is pretty important ;) First scale I've gotten anywhere in a LONG time....disappointing.

**Service - It just wasn't there. Not professional. Most were friendly but still not professional. I'm not talking 4 star service or anything, just simple, straight up good service. The waiters all struck me as bar tenders, not as waiters in a Japanese/Sushi joint...MEH.

**FLIES - There were flies...Buzzing around while we were eating. We were sitting closer to the kitchen than anyone else so not everyone would notice this but they were definitely there. Flies = dirty kitchen. I can't remember the last Japanese place I went to that had flies...Well, I can...But let's just say that I haven't gone back to it...

So all in all - Good rolls but none that blew me out of the water. Would have been a 3 star place but the chicken teriyaki, service, fish scale and flies made a bad first impression and left me without a burning desire to go back. Too bad. My search for great sushi continues...
author: Con L.

description: Love this place when the sushi craving hits! Butterfish blasters are amazing! Super great date spot, they don't rush you!
author: Marianne D.

description:
Sat at the bar in front of the tv, Friday around 6pm. Loved the dark lighting, watching the Giants, and agedashi tofu. Sake, nice and hot. Waiter seemed friendly to all other couples eating... but not to us. Maybe he wanted a sake bomb, too?

The nigiri was very fresh but the cuts were too generous. Sushi should be eaten in one bite and chewed minimally which were impossible with these. 

So if you're looking for a fun atmosphere with inventive rolls, this is a good place. For those looking for more traditional sushi, go elsewhere.
author: B W.

description: I look at these latest reviews and really have to chuckle.  Seriously, one lady took pictures.  It's funny to read so many eviews that are trying to come across as qualified food critics.  Just because the taste threw you off doesn't mean it's a bad place to eat.  This place utilizes creativity.  If you want a cookie cutter sushi place then don't come here.  They have great rolls and large portions when is comes to sushi and sashimi.  Bottom line is Yelp is designed for people to give their opinions on their experiences, not use this as a platform for their future food critic career.  BTW my new favorite is the Albacore Dream
author: Brian V.

description:
I eat a lot of sushi, almost an unhealthy amount.

This place is just, hands down, the best sushi spot in the city. The prices are great for the product served, and the atmosphere is something youre not going to find in any other restaurant in town. 

If you're looking to get laid, introduce someone to sushi, or reveal an undercover gem to someone--this is the place to do it.

Recs:  Tuna Poki salad  or  Crouching-Tiger
author: bm b.

description:
I live in a few blocks away from Sushi Bistro and it's the first time for me to dine in there.  Actually, I heard 2 young ladies talking on a bus and one mentioned that SB is a very nice restaurant.  When I and my husband sometimes take a walk around the blocks during my pregnancy, we have seen it crowded and we just wonder if we should try it some time later.

We finally have our first dinner there for our anniversary.  On such a rainy day, we don't want to go too far away from home and decided to give SB a trial.  It turned out to be a good decision.

The place is nice, just the music is a bit too loud for talking.  And, since we sat near to the door (the place was packed and we did not have choice or we wanted to sit at the bar), it's so cold and the door was frequently opened and closed.

The food is good.  I ordered a 12pc sashimi; it's so fresh and big in size.  It becomes my hubby's favorite.  As a sashimi fan, I would say that it worths the price $16.99 for that kind of quality and quantity.  The 2nd thing I ordered was Agedashi tofu, it's okay, not outstanding but hot enough when it's served.  The spider roll was good but not distinctive.  I should never ordered the chicken teriyaki and tempura.  The chicken was so dry and the sauce was so salty.  Tempura was good, shrimps were quite fresh, the pumpkin was tasty as well as the yam and potato.

However, the beer was really expensive, $6 for a bottle of Asahi.

The service was not impressive though all the waiters and waitresses were nice.  They were a bit understaffed and my hubby asked for a cup of tea which never came.  It really made my hubby pissed.  He did not want to ask and ask, just for a cup of tea and he really wanted to give a small tip.  Our bill was $52.41 and we gave $7 tip.  It's a very good dinner for our anniversary and we certainly will come back.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
So, four of us show up to an empty restaurant on a Tuesday night, and don't get our food (which was supposed to be hot, but arrived cold) for a half hour? Give me a goddamn break - I'm paying for this?

At least they gave us a "Sushi Not Bushi" bumper sticker on the way out the door. That was kind of fun. Oh, and I got the satisfaction of leaving no tip... which really is the only redeeming factor of getting piss-poor service.

Go to Osaka (across from the Castro Theater) - it's the best Japanese place I've been to in San Francisco.
author: Alex C.

description:
I might be a bit biased since the Chef is a friend of mine (what up Xin?), but the Bistro is dope! I recommend that you get a seat at the bar so you can shoot the shit with Xin (provided it's not a busy night and he's not busy slicing a slab of fish up into 36 pieces). You'll be entertained!

Oh, and order the Crunch Roll. Sooo good! (best eaten with an oversized bottle of Asahi or Sapporo) The hand rolls are no slouch either. (interestingly served in something that looks like a test tube)

You pretty much can't go wrong here. Everything is tasty and well-prepared.
author: Vince M.

description:
My favorite Sushi restaurant!

Sushi Bistro serves non-traditional sushi rolls that are amazing! The prices are a little higher than normal sushi joints I go to but the higher price is due to the higher quality and taste! It is definitely worth it.

SB is a small place but the atmosphere is great.  They have a good selection of Sake. 

Oh and fun fact-- the waiter told me that Mary Kate and Ashley Olson actually dined here one night. 

PROs--amazing, delicious rolls. great service.

CONs-- parking is hard to find sometimes
author: Mandeep D.

description:
The good:
-no wait for a table
-music... they played DMB while I was there
-quick
-big glasses of water
-lots of wasabi 
-tempura was fried well

The bad:
-small serving of rice
-parking is dumb
-chicken was about the same quality as a McChicken sandwich!
-Pricier, especially for being in the Inner Richmond
-rolls are small

Sushi Bistro is overrated.
author: Lee M.

description:
This has always been my favorite sushi bar in the city, and I've always recommended them to my friends. However, it's gotten really busy as of late and my "experience" has not been the same. Two years ago, I would had definitely gave it "5 stars".

My fave dish was a special that I always try to order if it's not too busy. It was called "New Style Sashimi". An assorted plate of sashimi that has been "scorched" a bit with a blow torch. Not cooked! The flame brings out the oils in the fish, and it's served around mixed salad greens and a special sauce. Yes, no need for shoya for this one.

...damn, I guess it's time to move on.
author: Ted P.

description:
Deliiiiiiiicious sushi at Sushi Bistro, a very small, casual sushi bar that doesn't attract much attention unless you happen to know about it from word of mouth or you live in the area.

The portion sizes are definitely large, so it's a good idea to share different rolls amongst friends. 

Sushi Bistro is a very relaxed little restaurant with great service and fun music. Oh and you can't forget those colorful cups! Unlike many upscale, trendy sushi restaurants in more glamorous parts of town, Sushi Bistro delivers for your dollar.
author: Sophie D.

description:
Since these things seem to be all the rage these days, a 6 word memoir for my dining experience: "YUM," said I, while chewing pensively.

My friend and I ordered the Miso Glazed Sea Bass and the Sesame Chicken off the small plates menu, and then we got the Rock n' Roll and the Aloha 101. I'm a California Roll kind of girl myself, which, okay probably just voided my two cents, but these rolls were quite good. 

The Rock n' Roll was more or less a California roll with spicy scallops & some orangy sauce on top. Like brown paper packages tied up with string, these (California roll + scallops) are a few of my favorite things. And when the Aloha 101 first arrived at our table, I was a bit skeptical because I saw a whole lotta raw, but the soy wasabi (?) dipping sauce was flipping fantastic. The sesame chicken was a disappointment (v. bland), but not too shabby when dipped in the Aloha 101 sauce. And the sea bass was okay. Not the House (North Beach restaurant) good, mind you, but still tasty. My only complaint was that it was too small - my own fault, ordering the sea bass as an appetizer rather than an entree.
author: Erika C.

description:
Very creative rolls, good service, and gooood quality sushi! Now if only the parking weren't so bad around this area, I would come here so much more. But it is definitely an endearing little restaurant. Favorites include the Albacore dream, Chilean sea bass, Omega-3 + loads more that I can't even name here due to their uber-creative names. 

I would definitely go far ahead of time to this area so you can scour endlessly for parking though. Maybe it's just my experiences so far, but it's definitely tough.
author: Nebula H.

description:
Reservations recommended! Else you'll be waiting. This place is very popular. We walked over from our apartment. 

The sushi was great. This is the place to go if you feel like rolls, especially really creative rolls. We ordered the M&L Forever, the Sexy Scallop and the no frills spicy tuna and unagi rolls. My favorite was the M&L Forever. Spicy tuna, crab meat, tobiko, avocado and grilled tuna encased in a crispy exterior? I am there! 

The atmosphere was good in an exciting sort of way, music in the background, people chattering. The waitress was nice and very prompt in refilling our hot teas.

Great neighborhood to stroll around in before and afterwards.
author: Helena H.

description:
Great sushi and a great price.  

I love the ambiance, the music, and the food here. 

Come here, you will find a hidden treasure!!!
author: Mike L.

description:
Sushi Bistro makes me proud to live in I.R. It is the most delicious place I have ever been too...of any cuisine. If Dave is there, ask him for a recommendation if you're not sure about what to get (the menu is extensive and constantly offering new and exciting creations)

Personally, my favorites are the brown rice rolls...with spicy tuna and butterfish tempura...hot damn! sashimi bowl is fresher than fresh...top pick in this category being, once again...butterfish (super white tuna) The Ahi Poke Salad is a must. My roomates love spicy crunchy.

My landlord should also be happy that Sushi Bistro is located 3 blocks from my house...I can never move away as long as I live in sf! I am addicted to this place.

Methinks many others share my amor for this place AKA there is always a way-too-long-to-wait-for-something-you-gotta-have-NOW kinda wait, if you go anytime after...6pm? 6:30? It's worth the wait, but I like ordering ahead for pickup if it's just a regular night...yum! I think I will go there tonight :)
author: Stephanie M.

description:
First off... parking in this neighborhood is absolutely horrible... unless you get lucky.  Not me, but not complaining too much about that...

Ordered the sesame chicken which had no flavor at all. Just fried chicken basically. The agedashi tofu was good. Then ordered 3 rolls which were decent, nothing special. If i remember correctly we had the dragon roll, the crouching tiger, and the spider. The spider only had 6 pieces. The other rolls had i think 8.  IMO the rice was not that flavorful and the roll itself was ok... 

If i was in the neighborhood i would probably go back, but i would not go out of my way to come here. I feel prices are a little pricey...

Service was good, and we did not have to wait. Overall, it was ok.
author: Shelley N.

description:
This place is a bit out there.  But I like places that are a bit out there, because it forces me into new neighborhoods, and to new streets and ALL sorts of ways to get from point A to point B.  Trip planner on 511.org anyone?

My friend brought me here--she raved about the place!  It's small, no frills.  The food I had was delicious.  Especially liked the appetizer at the beginning that was a mix of tuna, (I think) avocado, etc. and came with crispy chips.

Which leads me to what I'll say next about it.  The food was great, but not super hard core.  Which isn't a bad thing.  I'm just saying.

What the heck do I mean when I say hard core?

I mean that most of the rolls have avocado.  You're actually hard pressed not to find a roll with it.  Guess it's good for California, but if you're looking for straight, unfiltered rawness, you have to stick to sashimi (which is excellent, and HUGE here, by the way).  And there are tons of tempura roll options.

So, there might be 2 camps of sushi lovers:

1. hardcore: raw, raw, raw!  Don't dumb it down by flash frying, breading, adding avocado, warming it up, etc.  I just want fish flesh.

2. occasionally raw: yes, raw fish can be good.  but it's better when diluted with avocado, flash friedness, and other delectable veggies or warmth to hide the rawness.

I fall somewhere in the middle.  This place leaned toward #2, but it was all well done for what it was.

Service was friendly and efficient.  Yay for that!

PS--sorry for the all-over-the-placeness of this review.  Guess I didn't organize my thoughts so well.  :)
author: Lori G.

description:
The fish is fresh and the design is great.  When I bite on the roll, I can literally feel all kinds of fish in it, and also amazed at the taste of the combination.  Besides, the food is visually enjoyable as well.  The way they present it is creative and artistic.

The appetizers are simple and nice, too.  Good service.
author: YQnancy W.

description: Awesome trendy sushi.  The rolls at this place are as creative as any place I've found and they're all done to perfection.  They've also got some other creative non-roll plates as well.  This is always one of my go-to spots.
author: D D.

description:
Sushi Bistro, you rock my world!

The Albacore Dream, is amazing!
I've come here many times and have never EVER been disappointed with anything I've tried. :)

The staff is friendly and always there when you need something.

My only recommendation... 
Make reservations if you're going in a group of more than 3 after 7pm. It can be a little crowded. And the wait can range from no time to almost forever (45 minutes? More?).
author: Cindy M.

description: Omg! Big island & Spicy Crunch were delicious!!! And they offer brown rice options- great, will definitely be back to try more things. Nice atmosphere. Even some house specialties :)
author: Angelic S.

description: I gave Sushi Bistro 4 starts so please dont be put off by this review, i just wanted to let people know what to expect and give constructive criticism to the restaraunt. The atmosphere is great, modern, sleek, and well sectioned with  a bar, sushi case seating, and regular tables. The menu has edgy and creative dishes. The miso was not my favorite and was too sweet for my taste. I ordered the "double jeopardy," a spin off of chips and salsa which was a great dish to share. I also ordered the omega-3 roll which was awesome. My biggest complaint was the order in which the food was received. My order came immediately after my soup, and my girlfriends came out 20 minutes later... a pretty serious error in execution. I will give them the benifit of the doubt and assume it was an abnormal mistake. I will go back again, and will definitely try out sitting at the bar.
author: Ashton S.

description: Two-thirds of the more exquisite rolls are either baked or tempura fried and smothered in thick sauce. I prefer my sushi raw and simple, not cooked and drowned in dressing. Also, rather expensive for the quality (upwards of $10 for their specialty rolls), although the rolls are larger than normal- eight pieces instead of six. . Good atmosphere for a date spot, just don't let them put you in the back room (a claustrophobic and run down area versus the front end of the restaurant which has romantic dim lighting and swanky decor). On a positive note, the staff is super friendly but I think I'll stick to sushi zone, even though it's more of a trek.
author: Robin L.

description:
First off, to all the people complaining about wait times and how crowded it is all I have to say is, it's obviously worth the wait.  Why else would there be so many people lined up to eat here?  If the wait is really that big of an issue I'm sure you can find a crappy fast food chain nearby with no crowds.  If you want the best most inspired sushi in San Francisco eat at Sushi Bistro!  

I came here with a party of 4 on New Years Eve!  It was the perfect experience.  I can't even remember all of the dishes we tried but everything served to us was phenomenal and mouthwatering.  I don't have one negative thing to say about this place.  Yeah there are crowds, but for good reason.  Think about it, they could take away more tables and it could be less crowded, but then the wait would be longer.  The food is fantastic!  And I'm sure those of you whining about the wait are also the ones who sit at the table hours after you've finished eating.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
This is my favorite sushi place now. The rolls are inventive and delicious, and the nigiri melt in my mouth. (I loved the scallop nigiri. yum.) I don't think they take reservations so go early and expect to wait 20-30 mins on a weekend night. Good news is they're moving to a bigger space just two doors down. And vegetarians need not fear: Sushi Bistro has a great vegetarian menu that's not just cucumber and avocado rolls. Although those are great as well. :)

Just one minor thing: they need to adjust their wait system: upon 5 minutes of sitting down three separate waiters asked if we wanted something to drink. Hard to fault them for such attentive service though. Plus the food is simply great!
author: Susan H.

description: Not feeling the love at this place.  It was reccomended by several friends not sure what they were thinking.  It could be an ok place to drink some beers but there are so many other great places to do that.   If you like true sushi and sashimi don't bother going here.  There are too many other great places to have Japanese style sushi in the city.  I ordered the Toro -Maguro and it came out white looking.  I think it was albacore tuna.  I've eaten sashimi all over the world and even in Japan and had never seen anything like white Toro Maguro (Blue fin tuna).  The miso soup was actually decent.  We also had the Teriyaki with steamed vegetables and it was lame and bland.  Place was understaffed too.
author: Hawk M.

description:
soooo i started this review about 18 months ago, whoops! and i havent been back until a couple of weeks ago. not that i havent been wanting to, its just the damn economy etc, you know the drill.

so anyways, this place is still as delicious as i remember it the first time. i came on asaturday afternoon around 6, and it was not crowded, the perks of going early. 

highly recommend the yellowtail basil, i could eat like 4 of those. 

delicious sushi, bob marley on the speakers and a giants game on tv, what gets better than that. i mean really.
author: Carrie G.

description: Would definitely recommend the philadelphia, rock n' roll and magic mushroom dish! Absolutely wonderful. I've eaten at hundreds of sushi joints so ill give them another try but unfortunately their seaweed salad was mediocre and the rainbow roll was absolutely awful! The worst take on on a rainbow roll, even for a modern bistro it's pushing it! Too salty and dry.  Ambience is nice and fun.
author: Maddy B.

description: Only thing I did not like: My friend ordered some sushi and so did I. I was waiting and waiting for my rainbow roll, wondering why it was taking so long. My friend was done with his california roll. He had said I could have some but I was saving room for my rainbow roll. Well, the server comes over after my friend finishes, and says he was waiting for us to finish the california roll before he brought over the rainbow roll. WTF? Although the server had placed the california roll in the center of the table, we weren't sharing, so meanwhile I am starving! Bring everything at once please! As soon as it is ready!! Thanks.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Love it. 

BTW- This is Anna's favorite sushi place in the area.  :)

For more information read other yelpers comments.
author: Marcelo B.

description:
I went here on a Friday night with a group of 7. My friend, Liz Q made reservations so we were seated right away. This is her favorite sushi spot and told me about it awhile ago so I was finally happy I was able to check it out. We basically ordered a bunch of their rolls and shared it. So it was nice to be able to try a little bit of everything. Here's a list of what we ordered, but I swear I'm forgetting something.  
Ahi Tuna Poke Special- marinated ahi tuna cubes served with organic greens and topped with cruncy garlicky noodle things......so delicious!
African Spider- Soft shell crab, with albacore and salmon and spicy sauce....this one was my fave since I LOVE soft shell crab! 
Billie Jean- lobster, avocado, cucumber wrapped and topped with salmon...good!
Sexy Scallop- spicy white tuna, salmon, avocado and topped with chopped scallops and scallions...tasty!
49er- avocado and tobiko topped with salmon and lemon...pretty good!
Caterpillar- unagi and cucumber topped with avocado with eel sauce
Cruncy- Shrimp tempura wrapped tempura batter, avocado with eel sauce...can't go wrong with fried shrimp tempura!
Dragon- crabmeat, avocado topped with eel....nice version of regular unagi
Crouching tiger hidden dragon- shrimp tempura, avocado & cucumber topped with unagi and eel sauce...this was pretty good, but basically a fancier crunchy roll.
10 piece nigiri- I ate the salmon sashimi off my friend's plate since he's not a salmon fan. The salmon was pretty fresh and tasty. He seemed to like all the other sashimi.

Overall, everything was delicious and I definitely got my sushi fix. Maybe next time I'll try their signature brown rolls. Also service was great, our server was good but the owner was even nicer and always checked in on us. I will definitely come back to this place next time I'm in SF.
author: Corene B.

description:
i only give this place a four because it was extremely $$$....spend about 30 dollars a person and still wasn't full....=( had to go finish up at Jack in the Crack....=(

However...they do get four stars because this is a super super delicious sushi place...here they reinvented sushi and its extremely refreshing to eat as well as tasty.  i will definitely go back when i have the money.....ANd if you're super hungry....don't bother waiting...service here sucks.  they make you wait and wait.....and they take forever to seat you...
author: Shirley H.

description:
After reading highly rated Sushi Bistro reviews on Yelp, I decided to take my family here for dinner. There is a wide selection of special rolls, but I felt most were either fried or had pretty much the same ingredients.    I'd rather go to  Kitaro for special rolls at half the price. However, if you want to eat the authentic sushi such as sake, uni, etc. then I recommend Sushi Bistro over  Kitaro. I tried the Sake Sashimi and it was really fresh and tasty.  For those who know me, I usually don't eat raw food, but after my experience at Ryoto's last Friday, I think I'm starting to acquire the taste of raw salmon! 

My bf ordered chicken teriyaki  dinner with vegetables which was not so great because they served white meat instead of the usual dark meat on this dish.  Lets just say it tasted like dry grilled chicken breast. He thought it was kind of dry.
author: Lily T.

description:
the fish was all very good, as was the other standard sushi stuff like miso soup and such. Got the 8 piece nigiri special, which was a nice deal, but obviously 8 pieces isnt enough to tame this beast, so we got some special rolls too. C2 and the new legacy, both were the bomb. 

and wow they were huge, most places only give you 6 pieces per roll but there were 8 on these, and the end pieces were enormous. 

toss in some ice cream to finish, and i left feeling like a champion.
author: Dan M.

description:
The calamari plate is a face slapper (it's good). Strips of crisp-on-the-outside-soft-on-the-inside fried battered squid along side 3 dips: a wasabi sauce, a tatar sauce, and... a curry powder! Yes curry powder, I didn't know you could dip stuff in that. I've tried curry chicken, but this is ridiculous. Yes I am a curry noob.

Anyway, 3 stars because I ordered an expensive sashimi plate which ended up having only 5 pieces on it. BUT... it was face-slapping good. I won't be going back again though, I love sashimi and I get mine cheap at Yokoso Nippon in Pacifica. Ambience may suck and you don't get fancy shmancy plates but it's sashimi damnit!
author: Albert B.

description:
Upon recommendation of Brian P's sister Diane.  My friend and I who had yet to find a good sushi place in the city were pointed in the direction of sushi bistro. (Warning: It does get crowded) And after being seated we selected from a  very diverse menu 2 of the salad wraps and 3 sushi rolls. (Summer/Winter Wrap and the African Spider, Yellowtail Basil, Nemo Found)

Don't let the small sizes of the rolls fool you, they pack a large amount of flavor (soy sauce is optional). The servers are very attentive and always checking up on how you're doing as well as taking plates out of your way. 

Desert consisted of a tempura green tea ice cream. "Stellar"

A good end to a delicious evening.
author: Dan N.

description:
You know how your tongue just keeps telling you "DON'T STOP!" and so you comply and then 4 sushi rolls between you and your boyfriend are gone faster than you can breathe. 

We came here on a Wednesday and this was the only restaurant on the block that was packed. We walked by 4 or 5 restaurants with no one it and when we get there (thanks to Yelp), we're lucky that 2 seats at the bar just opened up.

Its a nice lively spot with some fresh sushi going on.  Everything came to us in a timely manner despite these sushi chefs being freakishly busy.  Its a loud, "lets treat ourselves after a long day to some good food" kind of spot. I can see why its a neighborhood, if not SF gem. I really enjoyed my butterfish blaster roll. I even saved some for my last bite.  Highly recommend coming here if you can park and find a seat!
author: kim l.

description:
This place is unbelievable. First, make a reservation if you don't want to wait a while because this place is always busy and very popular. The sushi is fresh and the dishes are unique and distinctive. The prices are very reasonable for the quality. Our server was quick and helpful. My favorite was the butterfish and the house sake (go big and get the $32 extra large bottle).

This place is so amazing that we definitely won't think twice about making the long trip from SOMA to Richmond.
author: Courtney D.

description:
I admit, I was skeptical - I ate in and around this place for many years, never stepping foot inside.  I was still skeptical when I went inside to see who was behind the sushibar, but boy, really my loss. 

The nigiri here ROCKS!  Very fresh, HUGE cuts, larger than the sashimi slices at other places.  My only complaint is that they use so little rice for their nigiri here that when you dab it in soysauce, it's easy to lose it.  Would be nice if they pre-added some wasabi too, but those are trivial details.  I particularly liked the butterfish and the yellowtail belly.  They aren't stingy with their toro either, it was the same size as everything else.  Very well priced, I was caught off guard by their sushi combination, which left me pretty full.  However, as all the other yelpers say, do get the tuna poke salad, the tuna is ordinary but the sauce is zesty and they add these little crunchy salty things that adds a ton of flavor and texture.  The hamachi kama was not nearly as good as the other stuff though.

The only thing holding me back from a 5star rating is the in/out nature of this place.  The wait (as you might imagine) can be quite long for the value of the sushi, and it takes awhile to be seated.  While the staff will never ask you to hurry up, they do little things like asking to take away your plates, slipping you the check to try to rush you out for the next table.  The decor is pretty whatever, but that's not why you come here.  However, while I was dining, there were two blackouts - this place needs a bigger fuse.  But overall, Yay for Sushi Bistro!
author: Jim W.

description:
Small Small place...but those are the best right? RIGHT! 

I came her thanks to some great yelp reviews. I picked it because it had good prices and it had  beef teriyaki and tempura! The sushi  is off the hook here! fresh ...super fresh! The Sake could be stronger but that could be the lush in me speaking. Customer service was just okay...lol.... but what can you expect from a place as big as your bed room. But i like it because  a lot of locals come here and I met some interesting people. I will be back for more...maybe this weekend..lol
author: Natalie F.

description:
Friends live right down the block so we decided to hit this Bistro around dinner time.  The place was packed, so the waiter took our number and we went back to the apartment for another glass of wine.  Sure enough, the water called and we walked in and sat right down, laughing at the riffraff that waited outside.

The sushi itself was alright.  Decent fish--including acceptable uni.  Too much fish to rice on the nigiri, though.  Not the normal complaint, but I ordered nigiri, not sashimi!

The other stuff was fine as well.  If I return and it's consistent Sushi Bistro might get a fourth star.
author: Stef A.

description:
I would give them 4.5 stars if I could. The restaurant itself could use some atmosphere changes, and its usually pretty loud. 

However! Best sushi I have found in this city. And I have tried a lot of sushi. I am also pretty cheap at times, so I avoid the places with $16 rolls across the board...so I guess I should say best sushi in the city for the price. I spent last year trying one place after the next, only to discover about a month before moving that this place was 2 blocks from my apartment. Depressing. It's honestly incredible sushi, very creative rolls, and always fresh. GO!

Parking sucks - take the bus. You should anyway.
author: Ali W.

description: Since their move up the block by 2 doors, the whole vibe has changed, and for the better! This place is EASILY the BEST sushi in the city of San Francisco in my opinion.  The fish is fresh and delicious, the menu is creative and full of insanely tasty options, the price is worth the quality and quantity and the service is great.  I have been to Sushi Bistro more times than I can count and have always left feeling great...the talk on the way home every time is of the Butterfish Blasters...I could eat these all day, every day! I cant wait till the next visit...it will be very soon.
author: Nilu r.

description:
I wanted a sushi place that was decently priced, and had fancy rolls.  A place that gave me something different, aside from the usual godzilla, san francisco, and nemo rolls.  Sushi bistro, a quaint little sushi house was a great find.  It was already pretty packed the day I went(thankfully i made reservations) and the ambience of the place reminded me of one of those fusion sushi bars.  They definitely had a great menu that spoke to me cuz they didn't just lay it out like normal; they gave u recommendations if you wanted something unique.  

I got the "double jeaopardy", which tasted kinda like avocado dip with sashimi(which I loved).  I also had the 'sashimi spirit', which was a bit on the puny side but it was really tasty and fresh.  I had a side of salmon sashimi, which was huge!  The pieces were definitely huge, and tasted so fresh.

We also ordered a combination beef teri + tempura just in case we don't get full at the end.  It was alright, but definitely not their specialty.  Nothing special.

Overall, although I disagree with the prices, i kinda expected it for such a fancy place.  I wasn't completely thrilled with the fact that my hot sake was done in the microwave in clear sight of my table.  Also, i know more customers mean more business, but they seemed a little pushy there to get me to finish my food right away and out the door.  The service was just a bit impatient, but still polite and warm.

It's not a place I'm going to frequent as a regular, but its definitely worth the occasional trip.  Everything was fresh, so I guess you do get what you pay for :)
author: Evan T.

description:
My boyfriend took me to this restaurant for my birthday.  I heard a few people mention positive things about it so I was hoping for good sushi.  What I got was OK food.  First off, we ordered the seared halibut marinated in some miso sauce (Drunken Halibut?).  I was expecting a little fillet of halibut, but all i got where 8 measly slivers of halibut in some oily miso sauce.  The fish and the sauce didn't work well together which resulted in bland seared halibut.  I kept re-dipping the sliver into the sauce hoping to taste something.  Next I tried their Mackerel and Yellow-tail Nigiri.  The Nigiri looked weird in that the fish slab was HUGE compared to the rice which made the fish look kind of gross.  I enjoyed the Mackerel Nigiri which was tasty, the Yellow-tail however was bland and served too cold.  I had to eat some ginger just to warm my palate back up.   Afterward, the rolls we ordered came in.  First was the rainbow roll.  Looked like your typical rainbow roll however, for 9 bucks, i was expecting some imitation crab meat with cucumber and avocado on the inside of the roll.  What we got was a massive amount of imitation crab meat in a roll with with the diameter of a half dollar coin.  I felt like I was eating at some sushi buffet and tasted like it too!  Next came in the Spicy Crunchy roll.  This was a deep fried roll (which we didn't expect).  It arrived on a plate drizzled in some Mustard sauce and Hot sauce.  To put it briefly BLAND and boring despite their sauce efforts.  Last came the special roll of the day which had marinated seared fatty tuna on top with tempura asparagus, and other stuff inside.  It was presented on a plate with pesto sauce.  I was looking forward to this roll because it had Fatty Tuna, but it turned into a disappointing mess of flavors -- I had no idea what I was tasting.  All that flavor made it pointless to use fatty tuna on top -- they could use halibut, or yellow tail and it would taste the same and the roll would've been cheaper.

Anyways, summary: I felt all there rolls were too done up with sauces.  Most of their rolls are cooked too so if you're a fan of raw fish and subtle taste, I recommend K's Kitchen on Monterey which has unique and fancy rolls with flavors that actually work together without being overpowering.  You'll be spending the same for better food.  If you prefer more cooked rolls, I think Kiki's or Kitaro's or a sushi boat have similar stuff for half the price.  You're basically paying for the atmosphere and better grade of fish (if you order the raw fish).  

Atmosphere:  to loud.  Even the servers couldn't hear us.
author: Connie C.

description: This place is a fun and exciting sushi place! The environment is good, and the food is even better! I recommend the African Spider Roll and Dave's Legacy! If your looking for a fun night in SF, Sushi Bistro is the spot!
author: Ryan E.

description: Quite good, this was our last meal in SF, and the family had a good time, I had the noodles with shrimp, egg, and broccoli, very tasty. My younger daughter had eel roll, she loved it. My older daughter had mango tuna with Fiji apple macadamia nuts and basil, she liked it as well. My wife had a assortment of salmon and tuna sushi, she also liked it. Overall a nice place!
author: Vic N.

description:
Two stars because the food was good. Wide variety of sushi rolls presented in an attractive way, service was fast and attentive.

But only two stars.  They seated us at a table right next to the front door. It was the only one available. Lots of cold air blowing in. Lots of hungry people in the lobby crowding our table. 

I take some responsibility for this. I should have known better even though there wasn't anyone waiting when we got there. I should have recognized from the grim face on the otherwise smiling staff that they knew they were seating us at a table that would soon be in the middle of their waiting area.

But Sushi Bistro, you just moved to a new location! You know there are people waiting out the door for your restaurant. Why would you place a table right next to the door when you know it will be crowded by your waiting buyers?
author: David C.

description: I had the pleasure of eating the Sushi made by Xin when he used to be a chef at Sushi of Naples, he was the only reason why I went to Sushi of Naples. Xin now started this restaurant and was preparing Sushi the three times I've eaten (since then he opened another restaurant). I am never disappointed by the Sushi/Sashimi he selects and prepares. I eat nothing else so can't comment on that. Great!
author: Michael L.

description: This is my new place to go for rolls. The quality of the fish they put in their roll is definitely above average. I also tried their sashimi and it was quite good. My only complain is that their menu is really extensive and this is one time I wish there were pictures. I went with one other person and it was impossible to enjoy the rich variety. I would suggest going in a group though a table may be hard to come by.
author: Lisa C.

description:
this isnt a fair review, but well, the euge reviews from way back when  started off on yelp as harsh reviews of sushi and korean bbq joints.

i was looking to have dinner at okina one night, but they were beyond full. found myself thinking, hey, ive never tried sushi bistro, might as well give it a try. 

first bad sign, wow, there sure are a lot of white people here.... nothing wrong with white people, not saying they dont know food, hell white boy dan v is one of my goto source for all things japanese cuisine, but all thing equal, its usually a bad sign when you enter a sushi joint and theres more round eyes than slant eyes. 

second bad sign, when i asked for omakase, the server said they didnt do that. a person who seemed like the floor manager/owner floated by and said they will do something for us. 

stringy fish? grossly over sized cuts for no reason then being grossly oversized? stringy fish? though i have a new appreciation for grilled tuna sinew, please no sinew in my sashimi please.

i just didnt like anything. i know its my own fault expecting an omakase experience at a jive ass place, but that was my experience. i should honestly come back and try out the jive ass rolls experience, but more than likely, i wont. i have plaenty of jive places in my rotation already.
author: Euge L.

description:
I've always been somewhat of a sushi snob because I used to work in a sushi restaurant so I was very reluctant about this place when my boyfriend took me here for our anniversary. He had yelped the place and heard of some great reviews. 

Like always, we sat at the sushi bar because I love mingling with the sushi chefs. However, they were a little too busy to be chatting with us. I didn't mind because we were able to spend the evening to ourselves. The range of items on the menu were overwhelming. I didn't even know where to start. I'm a huge tuna/toro fan and so I picked out a few tuna dishes. We also got a sashimi plate and the cuts were BIG. I really liked that because they weren't being shady with their fish cuts like A LOT of restaurants that I've been to.

The only reason I would give this place 4 stars and not the 5 would be because the parking was ridic. My boyfriend had to circle around the place for about 30 minutes and we almost missed our reservation had I not gotten out and went in while he searched for parking. We ended up parking 4 blocks away from the restaurant. -_-

But for any sushi lover who is looking for some new creative dishes in sushi, this place is a must. They are certainly unique in their rolls and it gives you a fresh perspective on sushi dishes. 

The restaurant itself is fairly small so I would recommend trying it out with no more than 2-4 people.
author: Laura Y.

description:
Went in to get our "Japanese" fix and came out hearing my husband say that he felt depressed - that's how bad it was. Service was terrible, they were understaffed and our brown rice came AFTER we were finished with our meal (they still managed to charge us for the rice too of course).  Our beef teriyaki was cold and really, really fatty and the toro was just not great either.  The potstickers were just OK.  

Overall the food and service get 1 star. It's a bummer because we were really excited to try this place as it's in the neighborhood and close to home.  Usually my husband and I give each place a second chance but I think it's safe to say we will not be returning.
author: Chrissy M.

description:
This is the most unique sushi place in San Francisco, for sure. The fish was fresh and melting in the mouth, good and friendly service and great sake (thank you guys for not charging us for our 2 other large sakes!). We love, love, love this place! It is better to come early, because even at their opening time they get pretty busy, the food is the freshest and it is easier to find a parking spot.
Oh, and just a bit of advice. Guys, if you come here, don't waste your time ordering original rolls (California? no way, you can get the same anywhere else), try something unique and new. Trust me, this is THE PLACE for unique and new japanese food.
author: Ksenia B.

description: One of the best sushi places I have been to in a long time. They have some very unique and taste rolls. They do wander far from the traditional rolls, but that was okay. Give it a try!!!!! You will not be disappointed.
author: Kevin D.

description: Went after 8 on a Monday night and it was still pretty packed. I think the servers were overwhelmed and short staffed so they running around like crazy. Sashimi was awesome. Great roll selection. The boyfriend who isn't a big sushi fan really liked it too. Looks like we found our go-to sushi place :)
author: Amy S.

description:
My first review of 2011.

First of all, I solely believe that Sushi Bistro would do something what T.A mentioned in his yelp review. 

Today, my bf and i went to Sushi Bistro because we saw that after 900 reviews, it still remains 4 stars. We got there as soon as it strikes 5 o clock and was seated by a host, who was very kind and polite. Ehh.. prolly not what i thought. 

Let's skip to the service! Anyway, SB gives you this complimentary cucumber salad thing which is in the same amount as the pickled ginger. Well, i finished mine and wanted some more, the host straight up was like uhhhhhh well do you want to buy a side order of that... in my mind, I am like WTF, a side order of what you give for FREE????? uhhhh, my bf was like go ahead just order it. A huge bowl of cucumber salad comes out... and I am like UHHHHHHH, I honestly did not need that much CUCUMBERS, but okay?? 

Anyway, if I asked for some more, just give it to me, what did you expect? I was gonna keep asking all night for 5 more pieces of your damn cucumbers.. goodness! Perhaps, before you make that type of judgement, see how much food we ordered. As for the service, I felt like I was being served by robots. It was way too monotone and not as expressional.  The food?

The monster in law was like 3 stars 
Rock n Roll- 4 stars 
Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon 3 stars. 
Yellowtail- 5 stars 
Unagai- 4 stars 

I think if they weren't so cheap about the cucumber salad pieces (5), i would have given 4 or 5 but because its so lame, I do not think i'll return because the flavor is not to die for!
author: Mai H.

description:
Sushi Bistro is a Richmond neighborhood gem. Not only is the restaurant staffed by attentive and responsive servers, the fish is fresh, the portions generous, and the price of admission won't break the bank.

I visited this sushi spot for the second time just last week. A word of caution: parking around this area can be a lesson in futility. You can easily circle like a hawk for that elusive parking space for a half hour or more and find nothing. Don't let this deter you! Sushi Bistro is unarguably worth your patience.

Also, MAKE RESERVATIONS. This is a popular sushi spot and regularly draws a respectable crowd who can't fit in this modestly sized eatery. The result? Oftentimes a considerable wait just without, in the fog and cold.

Our party ordered virtually all the signature rolls during our last visit and the standouts are the "Hawaiian breeze," "new wave mahi-mahi," and "watermelon-man," all of which contained a surprisingly refreshing burst of various complementary flavors. Sashimi is extremely fresh and served in good sized portions.

To sum it up, Sushi Bistro is well worth your money and your wait, though the latter can be minimized if you plan ahead and make reservations. Recommended without reservations.
author: Danny H.

description: My 2nd favorite sushi restaurant in the city next to Wayo Sushi on Van Ness.
author: Tiff T.

description: Ug. Though I dined with a real Sushi snob, it didn't take a fishy lover to realize that this sushi was not up to par. The menu has what you think would be an incredible choice of rolls given their sassy names: crouching tiger hidden dragon, sexy scallop, and magic mushrooms, etc. Other than Crouching Tiger, the other three rolls we tried were simply bland. They were beautiful, but wasn't anything to write home about- literally. My sushi snob was equally unimpressed, but still hungry! So we walked two blocks to Uncle Boy's and order what ended up being an incredible sandwich! With only a dozen items on the menu, who would of thought this hole-in-the-wall was the real night's success!
author: Allison B.

description: Volcano roll FTW. Seriously, just get that. Lots of that. Baked salmon with special sauce.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
This is magic sushi.  The kind about which totally inappropriate noises are made in public places.  The stuff that wet sushi dreams are made of.  (Yeah, I know...eww.  But seriously...that good.)

It's ridiculously fresh, totally inventive, and one of the very few things I actively, sorely miss about living in the Richmond.   The albacore and salmon sashimi, anything made with butterfish, the Spicy Crunchy Roll, the C2 Roll, the Double Jeopardy...it's all divine.  We even had our rehearsal dinner here the night before our wedding and it could not have been a better experience.  Xin and Debbie are the real deal...the portions are generous, the service is warm, and the fish is pristine.

Get there now!!
author: Melissa C.

description:
This place is so yummy I decided to have my birthday dinner here!
The place is very cozy, and full of energy. I LOVE the 49'ers roll ( Salmon, Slices of Lemon, Tobiko, & Avocado), it is simple but full of my favorite ingredients. I would never turn down the opportunity to go to this sushi place.
