author: Shannon C.

description: What a great find. Had a feast last night with my sexy husband and the bill came to: $58.! WTF!! When does that happen anymore? If you like sushi: Go.
author: Neile R.

description: This is definitely one of my top 3 favorite sushi places in SF.  Great quality and variety of rolls, many of which feature non-traditional ingredients like mango and baby lobster.  Sure, it's out in the richmond, but it's worth the trek.
author: Rego S.

description: Outstanding creative rolls with large pieces of fresh sashimi.  A bit loud.  Enjoy the music every time I go. Good place to go for casual sushi at a great price.  I have been a couple of times.  The service is were Sushi Bistro loses stars with me.  The place is small and always packed.  The last time the servers forgot our drinks and the edamame was sprinkled with sugar not salt.  The food is excellent and the atmosphere is good.  Highly recommend Sushi Bistro.  Highly recommend a reservation as well
author: Siamak S.

description: After discovering Shimo, I didn't think it was possible to find another sushi spot that gave it great competition. Sushi Bistro is mouth watering, and I highly recommend this place.  I happened to go days before they moved to their new location, very glad I did.  My boyfriend and I decided to try lots of different items, as they all looked great.  We ordered the Yellow Tail jalapeno, crazy tempura, and the M&L roll. These 3 items were nothing less than perfect.  The flavors, texture, and spiciness in some just all worked for us. Another plus is they server pitchers of beer, perfect! I have yet to dine at the new location, but pass it every day on the bus.  It is a lot bigger and looks really nice inside.  If your taking the 31, it drops you off right in front.
author: Samantha R.

description:
well i think i finally found my sushi spot! i just moved to SF in september and since I live on clement I didn't think it would be difficult to find a good sushi place...but i found that most of the places weren't fresh nor had a fun modern atmosphere...a friend from work told me about his place so i thought id give it a try....

i loved it! new location so has really good reggae-ish music and fresh food with a lot of choices. plus the price is welllll within reasonable for good sushi.

Crunchy roll had scrumpscious plump shrimp. Spicy tuna (only 4.95!!) was an 8 piece roll. baby losbter roll, DELICIOUS also i tried my friends philly roll so good. 

However the people next to us ordered a few "unique" rolls and they looked delicious. i think this is a place to try the specials and "detailed" rolls cause not only do they look interesting but pretty damn good.

PS house saki is inexpensive and not bad!!


love this place...also reservations recommended on weekends!!
author: Katie D.

description: I've lived in San Francisco for 10 years; have eaten lots of sushi at different places, and this place serves the freshest sushi I've tried in the city for a fair price.  Make a reservation, because otherwise the wait can be up to 40 minutes.  I had the 4 piece salmon sashimi, and the portions were so big - it was like eating 8 pieces; and the drunken halibut - which was fresh - not as flavorful - but good.  For 2 folks the cost was $40 for a full meal and drinks.  I was happy with fresh fish in my belly.  :)
author: Audra E.

description: Sushi Bistro is one of those hidden gems not too many people know about.  If you're wanting some of the best sushi in the city, make it a point to check this place out.  If you're looking for a scene, this is not the place.
author: k. w.

description:
second time back to visit, food are still as good.  
fish are very fresh, many varieties for sushi. if you love sashimi, this is also the place. 
friendly waiters, nice and clean dinning environment.
very satisfied, sure will visit more often.  one of the very few good Japanese restaurants found in town.
author: Bei K.

description: DELICIOUS! The prices aren't terrible and the food is great :) This is truly class sushi. The ambiance is nice - very date-esque. The presentation is fantastic - the 'stinky salmon' is actually delicious (don't let the name fool you) and they rip out a flame for it. The service is great and overall, it's a cute little joint. Note, you will likely wait in some sort of line for a table so get there early.
author: linda t.

description: The sushi was great.  I especially liked how, with the rolls, they used very little rice.  I felt like I was really getting my money's worth.  Though fairly small (only a bit bigger than sushi bar size), they do have a full menu.  The food is, in general, some kind of weird Japanese/hawaiian/American fusion.  We stuck with the sushi.  Some of the rolls are quite creative, as has been mentioned.  They have a lot of different sake.  Um, that's about it for this very stream of consciousness review.
author: Dave M.

description:
mellow vibe in this 'lil sushi place in the inner richmond with reggae music.  came here about 3 times......never had a long wait,  was seated promptly each time.  has extensive menu w/ fun, unique rolls & dishes............
had the following appetizers & sushi:

these were ok, but won't come back for 'em:
- aloha 101, spicy girl, watermelon man, in the sun & miso glazed chilean sea bass, butterfish nigiri, whole hokkaido sea scallop nigiri, albacore nigiri, sesame chicken..........      

enjoyed these & will definitely come back for more:
- agedashi tofu -- lightly fried batter,  just the way i like it
-  lobster salad --  they don't skimp on the lobster, a bit rich w/ the lobster & the dressing but gooooood.......
- butterfish blasters -- butterfish wrapped around avocado & something else (forgot) but i'd go with stinky salmon first 
-  stinky salmon -- seared salmon, w/tempura'd asparagus & tons of garlic & onions
-  hamachi nigiri -- nice large slice of tender hamachi that melts in your mouth
- scallop nigiri -- preferred the chopped over the whole hokkaido (which was toooo much for me).
author: Cindi N.

description: A friend convinced me to try again. Forget the fancy rolls and hit the sashimi/chef's specials...what a completely transformative experience! Trust the chef and you will be rewarded greatly.
author: S O.

description: I got a piece of sashimi that was so big that it must have been two fish glued together.
author: Patrick A.

description: Probably the most Americanized sushi place I have eaten at for a while. The menu is replete with rolls complete with three different fishes, four mystery ingredients, an obligatory trendy name that makes easily amused people get excited about the food they are about to eat. The issues with rolls is achieving a balance between interesting flavors while retaining their distinct flavors. The failure is when the rolls become a bloody and mushy mess. Rolls such as "monster in-laws" "sexy scallop" are examples of horrible fusion roll failure. If you blind taste tested these rolls you wouldn't be able to taste the difference as they all essentially tasted the same and had the same consistency. To add further insult the rolls were poorly made and fell apart, and I certainly doubt that the person making it had any connection with Japan. Some dishes were good however including the "red devil" and ahi tuna poke special, but these dishes were more the exception than the norm. You can go to Kabuto and have an experience which would never allow you to give this place five stars. As a complete aside the service was good.
author: Procter F.

description: The sushi was really great and fresh and they have a ton of unique rolls to fit every taste, they also have a large sake selection, that, of course fits every taste as well.  I particularly liked the C-2 roll, definitely a really good one to go with, or maybe it was the Red Dragon, whatever it was, it was awesome!
author: Craig E.

description: Overall good sushi, but not great. The butterfish blasters were probably my favorite sushi dish but even that had its flaws, I for one would've prefered it to be on the warmer end, perhaps even cooked. Also, I'm kind of a big fan of cooked sushi, so anything that sounds fried, I have to try. So, I tried the Spicy Crunchy, a whole bunch of fish rolled and deep fried, the end result was something that just tasted like your typical tempura vegetable. Too oily! Kind of gross and ruined it for me. Definitely not one of the more memorable meals for me in the bay area.
author: Dave H.

description:
This is a great little hot spot! The presentation of the sushi is just splendid and it equals the tastes. The prices are reasonable as well! I'd say great little spot for a hot little date. wink, wink. haha. C-2 is to die for! The spicy scallop is a great roll to balance off the C-2. The volcano was good, but I'd like it with rice. It's jam packed with crab!!! This place got busy for a Tuesday and they take reservations so call in advance if you don't wanna wait! 

This is my first sushi spot on my venture to try all the fabulous places in the city.
author: Je M.

description:
ok, as we all know, sushi is the best food out there and we also know why.  ok, maybe not why, but we all can agree sushi is offly darn swell.

moving on.

Sushi Bistro is one of those places which does not get any walk-in traffic due to its location and obscure front signage, however, that does not deter the truly foodie sushi lovers.

Here we have a place which has simple fair or fish, roles and quite a good selection of sake.  their fish is very fresh and they do not skimp on the cuts as i feel rather naughty since they are so think they are edging on phallic. 

their rolls are tight and not overly filled with veggies as some places are to cut down on cost.  The rolls are also not too complicated to keep up with the trends as that tends to make the rolls take longer and thus cost more.  you see, there is a reason some sushi shops cover their rolls in flaming cheese.. to mask the flavor which was gone days before.

anyway, as you may well guess Susi Bistro is a sushi place which i take close friends and 2nd dates to show a more relaxed  and down to earth me.
author: Jai D.

description: WOW.... How many times have I been here??  I can't even remember.  There was a time when I considered this place a second home, and would even go for dinner alone sometimes, cause it was just so good I didn't care if I had to enjoy it alone.  The staff is friendly, and they have great hot house sake and don't mind if you get roudy and sake bomb.  They play good music, and their specialty rolls are OFF THE HOOK.  The Spicy Crunchy roll is amazing, as is their Hamachi Kama (yellowtail with ponzu sauce), the Y.T. Jalepeno (I am obviously a fan of yellowtail--this one is yellowtail with thinly sliced jalapenos), and lastly the Aloha 101 and the Big Island specialty rolls are my favorite.  Come here with a thick wad though, cause if you want to order a lot, it will be pricey.  I'm getting hungry just thinking about all those rolls.....
author: Cel H.

description: I was introduced to this place (now called Sushi Bistro), located on a quiet block in the Richmond, for the first time by some friends the other night and really enjoyed it.  The creative "fusion" rolls are the stars of the menu, and there are a lot from which to choose.  I strongly recommend the C-2 (baby lobster and shrimp tempura) and the Napoli.  We will definitely go back.
author: Tyler N.

description:
EDIT* - 

My past two visits were complete disappointments. Inedible albacore just won't do. Seriously...when fish that is supposed to melt like butter is ribboned with sinuous fibers it really makes you want to say - screw you I'm not paying for this crap. Also I asked for them to please not put sauce on the rolls yet they made us a 5 wishes..dressed it..remembered just before handing it to us that we asked them not to..failed to take the sauce off of the pieces that were splattered with it and completely removed the salad that accompanies it. We asked if we could have the dish in it's entirety but with sauce on the side (so we could use it for the lettuce..cos salad needs dressing..not rolls..). Oh and the sauce they use on the albacore is atrocious - it's sweet and further destroys the already hideous albacore. *IF* I go back it will be for sake and crab mix..cos..I still love their stupid crab mix...blah

What the crap, Bistro? From 4 to 2..not lookin good buddy..

--------------------

This is a sushi bar I go to when I have a hankering for crab mix. The fish and rice itself is good but once you have gone to Sushi Zone it is certainly knocked down quite a few notches. Several of the rolls are over-dressed and I for one am not such a fan of cooked fish in my rolls (unless it's eel). This aside, the food arrives quickly, the cold sake selection is rather nice, and the sushi is very good for what it is (when you consider 93% of the selection is fusion stuffs). 

My absolute favorites?

49 roll (add crab mix on the inside)
5 wishes
Dragon Roll
Okunomatsu (black pine tree) Sake


Albacore dream would be great but the sauce kills it. And don't waste your time with the Omega 3 roll. Sexy scallop isn't anything to write home about either...


Oh and parking? The suck.

4 stars for the things I enjoy
author: Natalie G.

description:
Alright so hands down THE BEST sushi restaurant in the San Francisco area....

This is definitely a case where you get what you pay for.  The prices may be more then many sushi restaurants in the area, but let me tell you, its DEFINITELY worth it. Oh and let me just say, the reggae music that plays in the sushi restaurant just adds to the charm and uniqueness of the place.

Service:
Great!  The place is small which means consequently the servers are always around.  This is one of the places ive been where for several visits i have not had to ask for a refill for my water.  The older woman who does the serving in this place is incredibly friendly, if your lucky enough to get her, then good for you! 

Food:
Oh the food....oh the food...words can't even describe the sushi at this place.  Since i've lived in the city ive tried several sushi places and this place definitely has by far the best fish.  I know that sushi places get their freshest fish on Thursday's in order to be prepared for the weekend rush, and we went Sunday and Monday 2 nights :-)  and wow the fish was still so incredibly fresh and tasty.  Plus, we ordered several kinds of nigiri and man the fish was bigger then the rice they give you! How rare is that?? Plus none of the fish had that yucky white farmed color, their fish was so beautifully colored and fresh tasting.  The real bonus of this place in my opinion is their selection of sushi.  They offer unique combinations of fish in their sushi with adequately unique names such as crouching tiger, c-2, and african spider.  Oh and there is this roll with lobster in it, and wow, i was surprised to find...it wasn't imitation lobster! It was real lobster! Definitely a treat.  Everything here is priced higher then im used to for sushi, but for the quality and serving size, it is definitely worth it.

I would say the only drawback of this place is the limited seating.  Make sure you get here early or make reservations! You know a place is very good when its a hole in the wall in a random location and people are waiting outside in the cold! :-)  But the wait is definitely worth the food, so it is hardly a drawback.  

So if your looking for some delicious sushi with a nice atmosphere, this is the place to go!
author: Mark R.

description: This place has so many great things on the menu it makes your head spin..or maybe it was the quantities of sake and beer we had at the table!  Definitely delish...I went with a group of friends so I didn't sit where I prefer--the sushi bar.  I'm definitely heading back to see what kind o' magic the sushi chefs can work.  Noisy, crowded, yes, but we had a great time!
author: Adonica W.

description: Don't go here! Seriously... The more people that go, the harder it is for me to get a table, and I know that sounds selfish but honestly, being able to get a table and start getting down on the Ahi Poke Bowl and the Equinox Wrap as soon as possible, with out having to wait for you first timers to choose between ALL the amazing options on this menu is worth a little bad karma in my opinion.
author: Joseph M.

description: I really liked the sushi here.  But the service was bad, the bathroom was gross, and I was shouting over the music.
author: Joanna S.

description:
This is my first yelp review. I honestly prefer to just read others reviews but I am beginning to feel like I need to add my two cents to the deal. 

I have eaten my way through a number of sushi restaurants in the city and I am sorry to see that the average rating for sushi bistro is 4 stars. I just don't see what people are so excited about. 

The only good thing I can really say is that the service was fast and that was nice because I was hungry. 

The food was just mediocre. In fact I found the portion sizes of the nigiri and sashimi to be kind of a turn off because they were so large. Good nigiri is all about good balance between the rice and the fish. The pieces of fish were like 3 pieces of fish at other better sushi places I've been to. I guess it was fresh? It wasn't fishy but if thats all the good I can say about it then I don't think thats a very good sign. 

The server was nice enough to offer to take the unfinished sushi off my bill. I guess it was obvious I wasn't that pleased with it because I only ordered a couple things and still wasn't able to finish.

I don't think I will be going back any time soon. In fact I feel al little ill right now just thinking about it.
author: Lisa L.

description: I'm always looking for new sushi places that are good... even decent. Sometimes they are hard to come by. A friend took me here though and it was superb! The rolls are crazy and creative and delicious! It seems a little high priced at first but you really get what you pay for. I highly suggest making a reservation, or going earlyish, though because when all those SFSU kids get home from school this place gets crowded fast.
author: Eileen N.

description: The lack of parking alone is enough to discourage me from going to this place, but if you just have to get your sushi on in Inner Richmond, then this place isn't so bad. We ordered five specialty rolls: Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon, Nemo Found, Rainbow, Caterpillar and one which isn't on MenuPages that I can't remember the name of with seared tuna and apples, which tasted good, but was more of an appetizer than something I'd consider "sushi". It's a nice place, but unless you're confined to the area, there's better out there.
author: Michael A.

description: Watery, tasteless sashimi, "creative" rolls that would have been better left forgotten from the drug bender that must have designed them. gross. Yes, I can say for sure that some things should not be in a sushi roll. You can do much better some place else for cheaper. Way too much hype.
author: Claudia M.

description: Delicious and Quick! The rolls were delicious and exotic. The service is a little too quick, but perfect if you're hungry and/or on the go. oh, and how could I forget, clean! Parking is tricky on weekends, but definitely worth it.
author: Karolina Z.

description: This place is amazing!  I made reservations a few days in advance and there was no wait when my friend and I arrived.  I had a rainbow roll (my standard) and it was great.  The assorted sashimi plate came with HUGE pieces of delicious, fresh fish.  I also had the deep-fried soft-shell crab appetizer, which was also a delight.  But the highlight of the night was the Toro Nigiri.  The fish just melted in my mouth... it was practically orgasmic, seriously.  Service was quick, and the staff was friendly.  I would recommend this place to any sushi-lover, and I will definitely go again :)
author: Ashley D.

description: One of my fav sushi spots in the city, but di the Balboa St. one close????
author: Scott L.

description: well the menu is quite large so there is a large variety of sushi rolls to select from.  crouching tiger was my favorite as it actually had some real flavor to it.  maybe i didn't order the right thing.  hey, i'm a white guy.  i managed to eat with chop sticks....that's about all you can expect from me at a place like this.  i wouldn't say my opinion warrants a 'go or no go' on this place.  i thought it was good.
author: Hammer Time H.

description: I love Sushi Bistro! We have been going there since the first week it opened. Live just a few blocks away. Baby Lobster handroll is a family favorite, watermelon man, Hot Love, Mr Brown and don't forget the lettuce wraps. My favorite is the Summer Wrap. I have turned all my friends onto this place. The service is great. Expect crowded weekends. Even Sunday night.  A lot of locals come here. Well worth the trek to inner Richmond. Also, close to so many bus stops 31 Balboa stops right in front. Easy walking distance from the 38 geary, 5 fulton, 21 Hayes. Great selection of Sake too. Fish is very fresh, the specials are amazing, prices are right too.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Huh - maybe it's been closer to two years since I was last at Sushi Bistro.  Seems really different from what I remember...much louder and crowded with tables.  

It was Grace M's sushi bday fest, and we were there to eat TORO! Toro toro toro....  
Off their chalk-written specials we had an order of the toro and their tuna delight (a 'sandwich' of fried sushi rice, spicy tuna, grilled tuna, avo and other random things) and more nigiri: hamachi toro, fresh sake, shrimp and uni.  
It was supposed to be two orders of the toro nigiri but we were told they ran out.  It was already ridiculously large portion slices of fish laid over a thumb-nub size of rice; they criss-crossed another two triangles of flesh ontop of the pair, I guess to make up for being just a one-off.   But it was soooo fresh and delicious, I still shoveled the entire piece in and relished every one of the 3minutes it took for me to work around such a mouthful. 
The tuna delight wasn't all that delightful - the sandwich quicky devolved into more of a sushi sloppy joe and the grilled tuna parts were overdone.  We also tried their Five Wishes special roll, pretty good; I could've wished for a lighter mayo-ish cream sauce, but Grace liked it the way it was.
The hamachi toro was also exceptionally good. 
Prices aren't bad, especially considering their portion size - you're almost getting 2 orders for 1.
Coming here before 7:00pm is apparently key if you're not doing reservations.  And once it gets crowded, you're gonna have to 'work it' for your tea refills and complimentary ice cream.  Overall, money well spent. Happy Bday, Chiggins.  Toro toro toro....
author: CINDY K.

description:
hands down, best sushi in the sf richmond. 


favs: 
-butterfish blaster!

make reservations before coming to avoid the crowd
author: Thomas L.

description: Great sushi place with fresh fishies! They have some really creative roles that were delicious. The African Spider role is definitely recommended. If you're going for sashimi or nigiri, they also have fresh catch specials which are sure to please. Not the best sushi place in the city, but definitely up there on my list of great places for sushi within walking distance of my apartment.
author: Emily B.

description: Good food and well priced when you order bunch of things to share. get there early as it fills up quick.
author: Amlan S.

description: I'm hesitant to write anything about sushi bistro.  It's a tiny spot in the middle of no where.  I'd like it to be all mine.  ALL MINE!  Freshest, most innovative rolls in the city.  It has helped me cope with the loss of midori mushi.
author: Joe S.

description: 3.5 stars rounded up.  Parking is fairly difficult around here, but if you luck out or live within walking or bus distance, give Sushi Bistro a try.  Bf and I must have been starving because we polished off 4 rolls, a nigiri and edamame just as fast as they came out of the kitchen (which was near lightning speed for a sushi restaurant -- amazing).  They have a lot of cooked rolls, which aren't my fave, and not a ton of raw rolls, but the fish is fresh and the rolls tasty.  I especially liked the spicy tuna roll, which, although not nearly spicy enough, you could tell had really good quality tuna -- the flavor of the fish came through and wasn't masked by the spice.  The restaurant is pretty small and the tables are close together so inevitably, you get knocked around by the wait staff or the patrons (annoying).  All in all, a good sushi option and very reasonably priced.
author: Mitzi C.

description: After finally trying this place, I'll say it is just OK.  I usually can take a little spice in my food here and there, but man the rolls I ordered were SPICY.  Particularly the African Spider roll.  There were gracious portions of soft shell crap but the hot sauce burned going down.  But the main reason why the rating was a little low was because we were seated in the middle walkway of two other tables.  The waitress then took the tables order next to us when they came in after us.  It was kinda busy that night but it irritated me.
author: Danny P.

description:
ok, here's the rationale behind my 4 stars. i love sushi, but i rarely find a place that can impress me to the point of even bothering to review it because i eat it so much at so many different places. there are times when i am in the mood for mouth watering, basic, authentic, fresh fish and rice bare bones sushi and times when i'm in the mood for delicious over the top fushiony american sushi. this place is for sure in the second category of sushi joints. that said, it is great for what it is and here's why...

it is loud and colorful and entertaining and busy. if you're heading out for a night on the town or have already started day drinking and are looking to parlay that into dancing, then this place is great without being one of the annoying marina douchetard hangouts.

for the insane fushiony style of sushi, the fish is really fresh in my experience.

the portions are super big and you will leave full....especially if you're group is downing lots of nigori and beer.

dear god...order anything with the butterfish. the butterfish blasters are heavenly. but again...this isn't bare bones mom and pop sushi...this is creamy and saucey and heavy.

the service? yeah...it's not great. my party of four ordered a shit ton of food and the runner couldn't tell us what anything was and it was damned near impossible to track down our server for the most part. but i don't feel like we ever went hungry or thirsty. and by the end of the night, our bill only ended up being $140 for 4 people and that includes two 6'6" meatheads who can put away A LOT of food and alcohol. we all left feeling like it was a bargain.

i will be back!
author: marisa g.

description: Let me start off by saying that I am not a sushi fan.... however this place has turned me into a sushi lover!  A friend of mine recommended this place after looking at the reviews and we decided to give it a try.  We ordered a few different rolls and they were all to die for and they tasted to so fresh.  I live in San Jose and will take the trip to the city just for this place.  The only issue is parking... yes as usual parking in SF is so hard to find and if you get suck in a parking garage you pay almost as much as what you paid for your meal.  But it's worth it!
author: diana r.

description: We came in here wanting to just have some drinks.  When we ordered the waiter told us that we had to order something else...not in a polite tone at all, like he owned the place.  After making an order for a crunchy roll we asked someone what was in it.  The reply "shrimp"... great (you think they could give a better description then that).  The sushi itself was mediocre nothing to write home about (though there might be better stuff ont he menu), but due to the horrible service im going to have to write this bad review.
author: Diego C.

description: I really enjoy this sushi restaurant and would go more if it were closer to where I lived. Anyways, their food quality is always great and I have never had anything bad here. I LOVE their lettuce wraps (summer wrap, autumn wrap, etc), which are only $4 or so each. Their signature rolls are a little expensive but still amazing. Their Rock n Roll is soooo good. The service has also been great and the ambiance (when not crazy busy) is nice, great for a date or night out with the girls.
author: Holly F.

description: Thanks to Yelp - helping me find this place. We wanted something close by w/ a good review and were pleasantly surprised. The sushi is awesome, the sake selection is great and the sushi chef is passionate about his job. One Saturday night and some serious sashimi and rolls later we were chatting w/ him about fish and what it takes to get the fish that sits on our plates - it's incredible. he was truly passionate about what he does, so knowledgeable and not pretentious at all which is awesome-  he was so nice and he also gave us a sample of the blue fin tuna that he bid on that day at 4 in the morning! so happy to have found this place.
author: melissa h.

description:
I've been here once now and I was so impressed. The waiter took plenty of time with us to explain all the specials and answer all our questions. The menu had so many interesting rolls were were pretty overhwhelmed (in a good way) on what to order.

When the rolls came I was very impressed. You get a lot of food for your money and they don't skimp on the ingredients. Lots of fish, sauce, veggies, etc. and not too much rice. I could tell a lot of design went into each roll and all the rolls had unique and wonderful flavors
author: Ty V.

description: I love this hidden gem! Great quality, reasonable prices, cozy, low-key atmosphere, and fun music (usually reggae). There can sometimes be a bit of a wait at rush times, but it is well worth it.
author: Amanda D.

description: The new sushi bistro has less of the neighborhood joint feel and more of a loud, happening bar/restaurant feel but it's still awesome.  The fish is always incredibly fresh, and they have creative rolls that you won't find anywhere else.  Also tons of appetizers.  The sashimi dinner is cheap and great - so is the ahi tuna poke salad.
author: Allison C.

description: Good reasonably priced sushi. Ever since I dined at Sansei in Maui, which I still think has the best sushi I've ever tried, and had combo rolls which included mango and macadamia nut sprinkles among other things, I've always sought out something comparable. With Sushi Bistro I think I found it. Went on a busy weeknight and were still seated right away at the sushi bar. Loved the Aloha roll, a Big Eye Tuna shared plate with Jalapeno, and another roll with baby lobster. Where else has lobster in the sushi? Also complementary with the meal was cucumber salad and mocha almond fudge ice cream. I will definitely be back. Parking is a little difficult in the area though. Take the 31 Balboa.
author: Rob H.

description: Saturday night - I'm jonsing for some sushi. After reading the GLOWING reviews of this place i convince my boyfriend to deviate from our regular place. Flash forward to us at the restaurant - the sushi is OK, decent but not awesome. I'm thinking i won't come back. A couple hours later, not only am i thinking that I won't come back, but I should warn my friends as me and my boyfriend are sicks as dogs and spend most of the night throwing up. Maybe it was a fluke (or the lobster roll) but considering the nasty bout of food poisoning, I am never going back.
author: Avery L.

description:
really good sushi restaurant. they have a wide variety of creative rolls that aren't standard japanese fare. tried the monster-in-law, which was spicy and yummy. also had the butterfish nigiri -- fish was fresh and melted in my mouth, but not enough rice with the huuuge piece of fish. also tried the poke special, LOTS of poke so be prepared. and finally finished off with the equinox lettuce wrap which was totally worth it.. less than 5 bucks for a lettuce wrap with shrimp tempura, unagi, and sushi rice.

like the music, although it was a bit loud and hard to hear what my friend was saying to me. lots of "what did you say? what? what?" going on. service was overall good. definitely will come back again.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Sushi Bistro is my favorite Sushi in the city, and I've tried quite a few places. The fish is fresh and the peicies are huge.  The prices are very reasonable and the service is awesome.  

I'd higly suggest the sea bass.  Their nigri is great, and I suggest the ocean trout. 

They almost always have fresh Uni.  The rolls are very creative and of you're up for something different just ask Sheen- the owner to suprise you (you won't regret it).
author: Sterling O.

description:
Had dinner with the cousins at SB tonight.  We had reservations for our party of 4 for 6pm and thank god we did because the place started to get really packed around 6:30ish.

We ordered:
~ Butterfish Blasters: delish!  The butterfish was super buttery.  My cousin described it as a California roll without the rice and seaweed and instead, wrapped in fish...which is exactly what it is.
~ Hot Love: sort of like the first dish except it had baby lobsters and it was baked.  I liked that it was a little spicy and peppery but that the heat did not overwhelm the dish.
~ C-2: it was yummy but not as spectacular as everyone else made it out to be.
~ African Spider: like your regular spider roll with Cajun spices although I didn't taste much of it.  The soft shell crab was still good nonetheless.
~ Waikiki: most unique roll with mango and macadamia nuts.  The mangoes they used were not ripe so it was hard and sour (tasted more like apples) but I loved the macadamia nuts.
~ New Wave Mahi-Mahi: you can't really taste the mahi-mahi but I loved the mango salsa in it
~ Monster-in-Laws: the albacore and yellowtail were really fresh but not that special
~ Stinky Salmon: the onions actually over-powered everything else but I thought the asparagus added a nice crunch to it

We also had two large and one small Asahi's, a house sake, another cold sake and a glass of plum wine and our bill came out to $150 including tip.  Yes...four small Asian girls managed to finish all that food and drinks.  It was crazy but we couldn't help ourselves.

I enjoyed everything especially the Butterfish Blasters and Hot Love.  Everything was really unique and I loved that they only use a thin layer of rice for their rolls.  One complaint is that although their menu is huge, a lot of the ingredients repeated in their rolls, i.e. Hawaiian Breeze and Waikiki sounded really similar so it's hard to differentiate between rolls.

Anyway, we kept ordering more food as we devoured the dishes that came but the servers were really nice each time and didn't seem to mind at all even though the place was packed.  The restaurant got really noisy, so it's not really a good date place if you want to chat but the cousins and I seemed to enjoy ourselves.  And yes...parking is a bitch as it is anywhere else in the Richmond so come early and make reservations!
author: Katelynn L.

description: Sushi Bistro is some of the best sushi in SF!  The service is great and their rolls and unique small places are refine and delsih!  Their butterfish blasters are a must try.  Reservations help but they are pretty good about walk ins as well.
author: Julia B.

description: After several visits they have yet to disappoint. Large fish portions, good quality and selection, some unique and creative combinations for rolls. It can get pretty loud and sometimes the service seems haphazard, but that won't stop me from going back again and again. Caucasian Afro is one of the best things ever, and save room for the green tea tempura ice cream, yum.
author: Gucci M.

description: 600+ reviews? Crap! Had no idea this place has been around so long. Thought I'd discovered a hidden gem in the inner Richmond. Anyway, this is by far my favorite sushi resto in SF ever. Have done Sushi Zone, Blowfish, No Name, Godzilla, and Yoshi's. Nothing compares to the freshness, flavors, and creativity here. I love their Monster-in-Law rolls and the 12-piece of sashimi. Incredible. Finish off a pitcher of beer too. The service is pretty good despite how busy the place is. No fret, the wait on a Friday night for two wasn't bad at all.  Alas, their mochi is worth a pass.
author: c t.

description: Note to self.  Never go here again.  We paid $84 for sushi doused in MAYO.  The 4-star rating on this place comes from crackheads - ignore it - this place is the furthest thing from authentic and the furthest thing from good.  Their menu says nothing about aioli being slobbered on their rock 'n roll (by the way, isn't aioli italian? wtf?), but that is what you get at this "bistro."  Mayo, Mayo, Mayo.
author: Ellen R.

description: Not sure I was quite as wowed as Deb, but I definitely liked the place.  The culinary angle reminded me a little of Roys--sort of nouveau Pacific Island fusion, a mixture of Japanese, Hawaiian, and other influences all filtered through the California cuisine thing.  Everything was really tasty and the servers were definitely very attentive and friendly.  As mentioned, the jazz in the background was pleasant--more conducive to digestion, perhaps, than the KOIT usually playing at Ichiraku, but it's hard to deny the campy joy of eating sushi to the strains of Phil Collins and Peter Cetera.  I'm getting off-subject, though, and Sushi Bistro is a delightful little spot--maybe more of a 4 and 1/2 rating.
author: Michael T.

description: I love the Bistro!  Sushi Bistro is like the "Cheers" of Sushi.  I go there quite a bit and everyone knows my name.   I would eat here every night if I could.  I know it can get busy sometimes, but I live close and try to go soon after they open and I never have a problem finding a table.  My favorites are the M&L roll, the Equinox lettuce wrap, the Big Island, the Waikiki, and just about everything else on the menu.  Xin and Debby make the Bistro the place to be to eat and enjoy sushi!
author: Lori T.

description:
Despite the slight disorganization with waiting for seats (there is no real place to wait so you are awkwardly standing around other people eating, and you don't really know if anybody is going to come get you any time soon), this is some of the best sushi I have found in the city.

The fish is very fresh and you get a lot of it!  They are not skimpy on their fish here!  Also, if you sit at the bar, the sushi chef is very friendly and he will make special things for you!  

They have an assortment of special rolls--usually places with an abnormally large number of special rolls make me very wary, like they are trying to hide something (usually bad fish)--but Sushi Bistro's rolls highlight the fish, using the rice and veggies to accent the fish, not mask it.  

Highly recommend sushi bistro!
author: Whitney T.

description:
Great sushi and udon. The sashimi are very tender. Although the portions are not that big, they are not cheapos who give you itsy bitsy dice sizes of raw fish (at least not in the tekka maki). The fried yellowtail with eel sauce was delicious. The poke appetizer was great! Their udon is not the regular udon you normally eat where it's all floury. This one has a springy feeling when you chew on it (kind of like some of the wonton noodles). 

4 stars b/c one of the appetizers (hot lovin') was only alright. Also, my friends who had the bento boxes said it was only okay (regular bento boxes where you can get anywhere).

I highly recommend ordering sushi with raw fish and udon!

Small and cozy place, and fills up fast so make sure you make reservations!
author: M L.

description: (This was Deep Blue Sushi and is now called Sushi Bistro.) Over three years in this neighborhood, and I never went here till tonight!  What's wrong with me?  At first was a little on guard against the hipster feel and higher prices than I'm used to.  But the service was extremely friendly, the jazz they were piping in made for an animated though not overbearingly-so backdrop, the cozy little place was buzzing, and the food was just delightful.  Five rolls was enough to satisfy two, and the total bill of $45 + tip was definitely worth it as these were gourmet rolls.  We got the Napoli, Spicy Crunchy, Five Wishes, Ragin' Cajun, and Waikiki, all beautifully presented and a panoply of flavors, like mango in an eel roll or macadamia nuts atop lightly fried tuna.  Eat here now!
author: Deb T.

description: This is my new favorite sushi place.  They've got a crazy menu filled with good old favorites and inventive newbies.  The service could be better, I think the sushi chef got his mom and little sister to wait tables.
author: Christine E.

description: Absolutely amazing, every time.  Expect a wait, but it is definitely worth it.  The butter fish sashimi is perfect, and the Hot love is something very special.
author: Dane H.

description: There are tons of different rolls you can eat here.  The even have cool lettuce wraps stuffed with random crap.  Its like a Japanese burrito.  Most of their rolls are served warm.  The fish is pretty fatty fresh.  I might come back if I can ever find a parking spot in the area.
author: Fatty A.

description: Our favorite sushi place (Live Sushi in P'Hill) has just become serious competition! Sushi Bistro is fantastic. Food, drinks, atmosphere, service - all excellent. Reading other reviews, I'm wondering why we had so much of a better experience?! Maybe because we got there for late dinner (around 8.30pm)? Or maybe they have changed their attitude. ;-) The bartender is a bit grumpy but the cheery waitress/waiters make up for it. The food is delicious! Heaps of extravagant choices - quite creative roll creations - at decent prices for that kind of sushi. About $60 for 2 person for dinner including alcoholic beverages. You'll have to try 'Hot Love'. Baby lobster, crab meat and avocado wrapped in snapper. Hm, yeah, exactly. Can't wait to come back and continue to work our way through the rest of the menu.
author: Kristina T.

description: I am long overdue in writing a review for Sushi Bistro. I have had sushi all over the place but nothing compares to Sushi Bistro on Balboa St. in the Inner Richmond in San Francisco. We have been going here for several years and I still think they make the best sushi. The prices are reasonable, the fish is always fresh, the portions are very generous (they give you a lot of fish without adding too much rice on the rolls), and the menu is very creative. My favorites include the Ahi Tuna Poke Special (cubes of fresh ahi tuna marinated in spicy sauce, served with organic baby greens), Billie Jean roll (baby lobster, avocado, cucumber wrapped with soy paper and aioli and topped with salmon, Mont Blanc roll (shrimp tempura, avocado and cucumber, topped with butterfish and ginger soy sauce), Baby Lobster roll, Volcano (baked salmon with spicy aioli, crabmeat and avocado) and the Butterfish sashimi. The service is always exceptional and the staff is very friendly. I also like the reggae music! My only complaint...I wish they had a full bar.
author: Serghio P.

description: Maybe would be better if I didnt read all the hype on yelp. I expected it to be the best sushi ive eaten in my life, but it became such a disappointment. IT was packed service was ok. and sushi wasnt the best Ive ever tasted..
author: d n.

description: Yes, there may be a wait and not a lot of parking. Yes, it's a trek out to the chilly Richmond. I have enjoyed my several visits to Sushi Bistro. Why? Fresh fish, creative combinations, friendly staff and more actual fish than rice (love it). It is always a treat to have some sush at Sushi Bistro!
author: Abby W.

description: Walked into this place unexpectedly and wow were we pleasantly surprised.  A HUGE menu of fabulous sushi rolls and speciality rolls and great dinners.   They also serve brown rice...much healthier than white.  GREAT dinner !  Very nice people too !
author: Lorin S.

description: This restaurant was recommended to me by an old co-worker and man he was right. It's not your usual Japanese sushi. They have very unique rolls and you can't find it anywhere else. My favorite is the Rock N' Roll and the Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon. It does get crowded so make a reservation and parking is extremely hard to find in that area so arrive EARLY! So to sum it up, if you want to try something new and different this is definitely the place to go!
author: Sunny K.

description:
Sushi Bistro is clutch for fresh and appealing delicatessens.  They have not compromised quality since they started 5 years ago.  

-The atmosphere is great but it get a little noisy and crowded because of their popularity. Its worth it though for top notch sushi, I always pay more and get less at other places.

-Try the C2 or African Spider and don't forget the complimentary Green Tea Ice Cream
author: Randy H.

description: Truly one of the best sushi places I've ever eaten at. I had my birthday dinner here and i have to admit everything we've ordered was very good.  We ordered two specialty rolls (The New Legend and Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon), a dinner combo (Chicken Teriyaki and Tempura), and 3 other rolls (spicy tuna, salmon skin, and California roll). My favorite dish for the night was The New Legend, the fish was really fresh and each bite was just dynamite. Luckily we went there on a Monday, but i've past by this place a lot on Fridays and Saturdays and its always extremely packed, but i say its worth the wait.
author: Harrison C.

description: I am not gonna lie, Sushi Bistro is my favorite sushi place in the city, and even looking for parking, which ain't easy, is totally worth it. Very warm service, and top notch quality sushi is what I like about this place. It's not cheap, but I have been treating myself to the food here ever since the place moved from further down the block.
author: Kevin K.

description: One of my fav sushi places in SF. Great food, great service. Sexy scallop and C2 rolls are my favorite. Love the other location on 24th st as well.
author: Alina B.

description:
great decor, creative and yummy interpretation of sushi, and the service was awesome.

multiple waitresses and waiters came by to refill our tea.

you have to try the Waikiki roll (mango, avocado, unagi, and macadamia nuts)
author: William C.

description:
yup. one year later, and still as good as it gets!


new location is much nicer, more spacious, larger bar too. ;)
author: Sharon G.

description: I love this place!!! I visit the Norcal every so often and find this place to be pretty good compared to other places. They offer many unique rolls, the sashimi is fresh but Ive tasted better. My friend ordered the Udon soup, and the broth is very tasty and flavorful. The service was really good as well.
author: Jenn T.

description: This place is absolutly amazing! There might be a wait but its absolutly worth it. Its slightly hidden between other sushi restaurants but don't let those distract you! Make sure you order the "dave" roll from the young man thats serving you! (ya...thats Dave!). The best part? MORE BEER THEN SAPPORO!
author: Stacy L.

description: Nice, delicious and fun sushi restaurant! Their rolls are different from the ones you see at Japanese restaurants..they have many hawaiian based rolls which is good! This place gets really packed so make reservations or be prepared to wait a while. Service is great and your food comes out really fast and they keep on coming! If you order lots of rolls, your bill will get a little high since this place is a lil pricey but in the end, I think you'll forget about it because you'll remember how good it tasted and forget about the price.
author: Rhonda H.

description: I do not know how this place gets such good reviews.  The people that eat here must not know anything about sushi.  Service was good food no bueno.
author: Larry C.

description: I've been going here since they opened and it's always been amazing.  I brought my SF friends here who are sushi snobs and they're all hooked.  I take anyone who comes from out of town here and they love it.  It really is the best.  If I go anywhere else, I always feel cheated by the small pieces or end up spending $50+ for standard fish.  The Bistro's one of the least expensive sushi joints in SF.  Their standouts for me are: Ahi Tuna Poke (heaven), Yellowtail Basil, C-2, New Legend, Albacore Dream, Napoli, and Monster-In-Law, along with salmon, hamachi, uni, and albacore.  MMMM.. so good..
author: Jason D.

description:
tasty!
the kimchi to start was a nice touch. feels like a date sushi spot instead of just another sushi bar. all the sashimi tasted extremely fresh and ymmy. I was met with lots of smiles any direction I looked.. chefs, servers, fellow customers. and I like smiles. smiles make me happy.
author: Jeremi M.

description:
pro: Sushi was pretty dang tasty
con: Sushi was pretty dang expensive (12 dollars a roll?!?)

went here with a group- mixed feelings. I made a reservation ahead of time, so we were seated right away...but the staff really rushed us (as in yelled at us because some of our party couldn't find parking in the un-parkable warzone of balboa & 5th). And the place is not made for groups (i guess a sushi bar....excuse me, "bistro" really wouldn't cater to large groups....although they have enough of them that they so gratefully and automatically added 18% gratuity to the bill)...they busted out these dinky, HEZZA uncomfortable folding chairs...downgrade.

their sushi was inventive and creative, but SO FRAKKIN EXPENSIVE. My first thought was, "this sushi is too pretty to eat in one bite"
My second thought was, "this sushi is too expensive to eat in one bite"

there were 9 of us, we ended up double-ordering 7 types of rolls...the bill was about $174... ended up being a little more than $20 per person but everyone only ate like 7 pieces of sushi...
ended up having to buy a Digiorno pizza from Safeway quickstyle and  bake it at home for a quick, cheap meal.

sushi bistro is in a weird category- its portions, by nature of sushi, aren't enough to fill you up like a dinner should- but its prices are high enough to be satisfying dinner-status...
author: Sammy G.

description: Excellent food, a very unique array of rolls and appetizers that are different than anything I've seen at another sushi restaurant, but really come together well.  Above all though they have a number of people who have been there for many years, truly know their sushi and sake, are happy to recommend other places in various parts of the city, and are laid back enough to make you feel relaxed and comfortable the whole time while providing great service.
author: true r.

description: I think this is the best Sushi I've ever had in SF. The Mont Blanc roll and baby lobster tempura roll gave me multiple mouthgasms. I pigged out AND got Sake AND got beer for only $40! GREAT deal, BUT... make a reservation ahead of time as the wait can by 'trying' to say the least!
author: Aaron S.

description: It always seems a little silly to me that I'm a vegetarian and ever suggest sushi for dinner.  A friend took me to Sushi Bistro last night and it was delicious. Service was incredibly friendly, attentive, and fast!  Deeelicious. The only draw back was that it was really loud inside and hard to have a conversation without raising our voices over the noise of others doing the same.
author: K M.

description: Our favorite sushi bar in sf.  Huge pieces of nigiri, great hawaiian role combinations.  Try dave's legacy role, the best.
author: Pat M.

description:
One word: this place is for "GAIJINS"!! 

For those who don't know what Gaijins are, well then you probably are one!

I am pretty much a sushi snob and have had opportunties to eat at very good, true japanese restaurants and this is not one of them.

Went here tonight and I really don't know what all the fuss is about. I guess I am more of a traditional sushi nigiri with no wierd messy cream sauce sushi type of gal. Yeah occasionally I like to try the special rolls here and there but this place was a miss for me.
This is probably the first time that I've been to ANY japanese restaurant where the miso soup tasted like it was watered down. It had no miso flavor at all but it was hot, like someone poured a whole jug of hot water into their soup pot then it was dished out. 

Had the agedashi tofu-this was pretty good, but nothing special or worth coming back for. The 4 chunks of fried tofu were huge.

I had the black weed roll, and it sounded good: seared ahi tuna with cucumber, sesame seed and oil, topped with seaweed salad and chunky spicy albacore. This roll was $10.50 and it came cut into 6 thin pieces (about 1 and 1/2 inch thick). The seared ahi inside the roll was not seared at all nor fresh, it was the equivalent of getting chopped tuna out of a can. It was dry and small, and looked like had been cooked at the beginning of the day and stored a plastic tubbie until I ordered my roll. I had imagined a succulent piece of seared ahi tuna (like the ones you see at the store, slightly charred on top). this was literally cooked all the way and resembled cat food. YUCK. The albacore on top was nothing to die for, and couldn't even really taste anything in the roll except the seaweed salad. A sad disappointment for a expensive roll. I looked around me and the other rolls at all the other tables were exactly the same. Funky rolls with sauce drenched all over the top.

My BF had the s-2 special, 10 piece nigiri with tuna, hamachi, ebi, tobiko, butterfish, unagi, the cuts of fish were pretty good, but not the best we've had. I love butterfish and this came through not even close to what I had at Kiji. It was not as buttery and melt in your mouth like it should be. It came with the same bland and watered down miso soup and a ok usual salad at any old japanese place. My BF said the rest of his nigiri was OK.

The place was packed-full house and the noise level is so loud here I couldnt hear myself think. The decor is cool inside, and this is definetely a place to go to have drinks and OK sushi. Like I said, this is a place for crazy rolls with crazy names and over the top sauces that masks the true flavor of the fish. I would equate this place to the same level as places in the richmond like kitaro, or sakana bune, where you could get the same rolls for 1/2 the price less the cool atmosphere, bar, and misc other trendy dishes like hamachi carpaccio. Yes they have some special items on their menu that makes it perhaps more facinating for most but not for me. It was like everyone around me eating their gaijin sushi were in sushi heaven and I was like WTF it ain't that good!? 

 Also, one last thing I CANNOT stand is how the sushi chefs were not Japanese. Ok not all of them can be, but hey if you look at the kitchen and see one mexican, and the rest some form of asian other than japanese making your sushi, what can you really expect?
well it explains why each of the rolls that came out, to our table and to the next were all DIFFERENT IN SIZE! 
$45 out the door, no alcohol. Price isnt a factor when eating good food, but this wasnt worth it at all. Service was decent, and everything was prompt.

Once is enough, never again.
author: Petri Y.

description: Sushi Bistro has alot of special and unique rolls, but what makes sushi bistro stand out the most from other sushi restaurants are their sashimis.  They are really fresh and their slices of sashimi are bigger than any other sushi restaurants I been to.  Normally, I would stuff the whole piece of sashimi in my mouth, but the sashimi at sushi bistro takes 2 bites.  Their prices are not outrageous either.  The only complain I have is looking for parking.  If your unlucky, your gonna have to circle the vicinity for 30 minutes looking for parking.
author: Damon J.

description: SO good! Pretty cheap too...great atmosphere! Cool staff!
author: Lynn B.

description:
The rolls are yummy and decent size for the price, the sake menu is good and the fish is fresh! What more can you ask for?

Visited sushi bistro with a couple of friends and ordered:

-Monsters In Law- Yuuummm! spicy yellowtail inside and yellowtail out with fresh jalapeno and sriracha sauce to the side! This roll was delicious with just enough spice to it! what I like to call the "good burn"

-Albacore dream (i thinks)- It was good, not as good as the monsters in law though! All i remember was that it had a special sauce on it which tastes like creamy ponzu.

-crouching tiger hidden dragon- good if you like shrimp tempura and eel. Of course anything with eel will be on the sweeter side.
author: JustPeach E.

description:
Sushi Bistro is a little contemporary Japanese restaurant. This is my first time trying this restaurant and it was great. It opens at 5:00 but there was already a line in front of the restaurant. 

The menu is creative, starting with brown rice sushi to the tasty salads. You don't get the basic miso soup with a salad of water down salad from Sushi Bistro.  I especially liked the Ahi Tune Poke Special. You have raw tuna topped on a bed of arugula with a very delicious salad dressing. Another favorite is the Big Island sushi. You should definitely check out the menu before getting there because there is so much to choose from.
author: Liana C.

description: The hostess was very nice and we were quickly seated. The place was clean and the sushi was really fresh!! Will definitly be back!!
author: ANdrew M.

description:
I haven't been here in a while since I moved out of the city, but I surely do miss it!  I've been going there since it was an unknown hidden gem.  And after all the advertisement and after people started noticing and writing reviews, it started getting busier and busier.  It was now the HOT SPOT!  It was especially busy at nights and on the weekends.  

Parking is difficult which is pretty typical in the city.  You may have to walk some amount of blocks, but once you see the spot (might I add that I love the SB emblem of the butterfly), then you'll know the walk was well worth it!  It is a small and intimate setting that makes a nice date spot/ lounge spot w/ friends.  I'm thinking that the maximum occupancy is about 35-40 people.  The lighting is fairly dim but it has a nice ambience feel to it.  The owners of the restaurant are very welcoming and personable.  They were a Japanese couple (I have to add this b/c you'll find a lot of Japanese restaurants in the city are filled with Spanish sushi makers, servers etc).  But you really feel the warmth of the Japanese culture with a twist of moderness.  The wife always remembered mine and my ex's names and what our favorite dishes were.  We would go here at least 2 times a week - it's out of our way too, but that's how much we loved this place!  She also always gave us free edamame, soup, and green tea ice cream.

The food was fantastic - It reminded me of a Japanese/ Hawaiian fusion -similiar to Roy's Fusion, but better and affordable.  It had a great selection of creative and unique dishes and rolls.   They always came out so beautiful and pleasing to the eyes.  I loved the colors of every dish.   They also serve generous portions.  The food itself were all very tasteful, flavorful, fresh, and filling.  You'll find that you'll come out there very satisfied yet it's all so healthy.  

My usual order was Seaweed Salad and the "Big Island Roll"... this is my ultimate favorite roll!  I don't really eat white rice (I prefer brown rice)... but this roll had everything in it without the rice.  It was wrapped in cucumber and it was soooooooooooo goood.  mmMMMm I'm craving it right now... but I just noticed their site and they're now serving Brown Rice Rolls (they didn't have this a few years ago)!!! I have to move back for these!!!  Also, they also have an option to use Soy Paper instead of Seaweed... it's very good too - it melts in your mouth.  My ex would always get a Combination Dinner - usually Teriyaki Chicken or Beef Teriyaki and that was good too.... They give a lot of meat, salad, rice... they definitely fill you up.  It was also prepared very beautifully.

All the items on their menu looked good and I was hoping to try every one of their items!  

But yes - I LOVE SB... everytime someone asks for recommendations of Japanese restaurants in the city, this is the place that I highly recommend... it is to die for ... I mean to live for! 

(Oh - one con that I have of this place is that they had this tiny aquarium on the wall - it was a half of a bubble and it had a Beta in it .... we would notice that it wasn't getting cleaned regularly - everytime we went there, we were feeling sorry for that fish haha ...that's all!)
author: L A.

description:
i LOVE their variety and creative rolls
I LOVE their fish
But somehow, I didnt love their sushi...

Went there on a Sun, and we got lucky and got seated right away (AND got parking just outside - good karma day!). We ordered the YT Jalapeno, Spicy girl and the Drunken Halibut from their unique section, the Monsters in law from the Signature, and the Red Devil from Brown Rice rolls.

The YT Jalapeno was delicious. Halibut was cooked a little too much, and kinda blandish. Spicy girl was okay. Monsters in law and Red devil were kinda okay too. The problem was that almost everything (except the YT) was served on a bed of sweetish sauce. so everything tasted sweet. The fish quality was excellent no doubt, and the portions were decent, but the sweet sauce caused it to be not-as-great as it woulda been on its own, without any sauce.

ooh - almost forgot! i ordered the tempura ice cream at the end. I thought it would be a single piece (like the Mochi that the table next to us had ordered) , but it turned out to be 6 pieces. it was good - unique - but I woulda liked to see a menu so that I could guess from the price whether it was a small or a large dessert...

Plus of course, it isnt the cheapest even though it is not terribly expensive. Not sure if I would go there again.
author: Priya K.

description: i have now been to sushi bistro twice and i cannot wait to go back for more. they have such a variety of creative sushi rolls to fit all dietary considerations - fish, vegetarian, and even a few options with brown rice! the rolls are beautiful, the fish fresh, and the prices fairly reasonable. dinner with a friend = two rolls and a veggie gyoza appetizer = 16/each including tip. SO CHEAP for such high quality sushi. YUM. the decor is sleek and modern, it feels like a hip sushi lounge, and they have an extensive selection of sake. i couldn't really ask for more in a neighborhood sushi joint.
author: Rachael S.

description: Still have not been able to find a sushi place that comes close anywhere in the Bay Area. Every one of their rolls are unique and distinct in flavor and texture which I really appreciate. It's too often that at many other sushi places 99% of the rolls taste exactly alike because they only differ by 1- 2 ingredients and the base is usually a california roll or spicy tuna. Not at Sushi Bistro. If only the trek to the Inner Richmond wasn't such a pain...
author: Thu S.

description: New favorite sushi in SF.  Since we happened upon it 2 months ago, we've been back 1-2 times per week and have never been disappointed.  Great combination of traditional and original creations.  The lettuce wraps are amazing & unique; generous portions of fresh sashimi; specials are always great.  Only roll we haven't liked is the ragin' cajun.
author: Ken H.

description:
Sorry, waaaay behind on my yelping.  I've gone a few times over the past two months and ihaven't had a bad meal yet.
The menu is primarily adventureous rolls and in season sashimi.  they have a hefty appetizer section as well.  i like this resturaunt becuase its a very neighborhood place-a place where real people go to eat.  It's not big, or fancy and it's often packed to the rafters.  The style of food is so conducive to family style eating that it's a good spot for groups, but i would definetly make a reservation at peak times or if you have a party of 4 or more.
Of course the name escapes me at the moment-but my favorite dishes are the calamari tempura (cooked to perfection and lots of sauces!) the roll with the tuna and mango in a chili/garilc sauce that is tempura'd, and the drunken halibut.
they also get a +10 in awesome for their eclectic/reggae music and the sushi chefs who drink MASSIVE quantities of alcohol, yet manage to make everything de-lish!
author: Natalie R.

description: Did you see that movie "Super Size Me" where the guy says how addicting McDonald's is? Well my husband and I feel that way about Sushi Bistro. Between NY and SF, this is by far THE best sushi in SF! The rolls are really innovative and delicious. The fish is fresh and the rolls are a really good size. No skimping here. My husband and I go here a couple times a month. Its our little date night, we sit at the bar and have sake and we start with the M&L Forever. It is DELICIOUS! Everything here is great. Even the decor in their new place. I highly recommend!
author: Sue S.

description: Very friendly staff. However, the sushi was below average. The fish was NOT fresh - very watery and lacked flavor, like overly frozen fish. It did not have that subtle sweetness and buttery texture associated with great fish.  The nigiri did not have balance; not enough rice to complement the size of fish slice. Tempura had good flavor, but had a dense batter coating; not airy light tempura.  Would not recommend this restaurant if food quality is important to you. Okay if you can accept average food, but are looking for a good atmosphere to spend with friends.
author: G L.

description:
This is my fav. local fishing hole, a block away from my door. We have our own bottle of cock sauce; you can borrow it, but don't lick the cap.  Debbie treats me right, knows me by name and always finds me a table.  I feel like Norm here.  I hate to share, but they deserve the business.  Unfortunately the secret is already out and thursday-sunday you might find yourself waiting on the sidewalk for a bit.  This place is SMALL and hard for big parties, but if you call ahead, Debbie will reserve a table for ya.  Try the lettuce wraps, summer is my favorite.  Their rolls are innovative to say the least.  I eat here almost once a week and still struggle with ordering because everything is SO good and unique!!   
Favorite apps: Agadashi Tofu & Ahi tuna poke special
Favorite rolls: watermelon man, nemo found & the in-laws
You really can't go wrong!
You also get a happy ending with every meal! Free Ice Cream with flavors like green tea, coconut, mango..yum yum give me some.  
Sake anyone?  See you there!
author: Michele M.

description: Last minute choice based on Yelp reviews. Sushi was good but not outstanding. Rolls are creative and the sushi chef was very friendly. I ordered everything on the specials blackboard: White tiger roll (delicious); aji (good); tai (good); butterfish (very good); toro tataki (excellent); toro (ran out). I got an order of uni at the end and it was just okay. I'd describe this as a friendly neighborhood place; since the girlfriend lives one hood over, we'll probably be back.
author: Stewart A.

description: This place has a pretty wide variety of their own "creations" of sushi. I would recommend the C-2 sushi as it has some saucy goodness to it. The atmosphere is nice and even though I sat by the door, it was rather warm during a cold night. This place gets very crowded by 6PM, and with good reason too. I will definitely come back here for my sushi fixes whenever the feeling occurs.
author: Michael S.

description: The sushi here is amazing. You can't find the combinations anywhere else. The sushi chef makes very modern rolls with fresh flavors (mango salsa - yumm). My favorite is the Big Island - no seaweed at all..just rolled up in thinly sliced cucumber. So fresh, so good. I wish I had the stomach to try every roll on the menu - but I'll definitely come back for sure!
author: Nancie T.

description: I just moved here from Washington DC not too long ago and the choices of sushi restaurants are limited.  Of course you have all your usual sushi choices to choose from in J-town and all throughout SF however I have to say Sushi Bistro is by far my favorite.  Their custom rolls that they have are very untraditional with many rolls to choose from their menu being served hot which was new to me and it was great.  Their summer lettuce roll which consists of eel is a must have as an appetizer.  Along with the many rolls we ordered I also ordered some tong katsu and shrimp tumpura  which was very good.  Also nice to have Kirin on tap as well as the very friendly service.  It's a small cozy place, good place to bring a date.
author: David C.

description: The food is good but pricey. My wife and I sat at the bar area. You might need a reservation if you want to sit at a table. Parking wasn't easy to find but then again it's SF. It's to be expected. We tried a variety of rolls to include: Hot Love, Rock n' Roll, and Spider. The Hot Love is good (takes 20 min to make) but won't fill you up as you only receive 2 pieces. The other rolls we got are the standard set of 6. They have some unique sushi here and I would recommend getting the Rock n' Roll. I felt sick after dining here but I don't think it was from food poisoning. My wife was fine and it was probably the combination of spicy rolls and fried crab that upset my stomach. Don't let my experience deter you. This is still a place I would return to but I wouldn't make it a regular visit unless you want your credit card to look like a miniature sumo wrestler.
author: Armstrong B.

description: Sushi Bistro is amazing (best sushi I have had in the city so far).  It has a great atmosphere and the rolls are outstanding.  The albacore dream and the C2 might be some of my favorites.  Great lettuce wraps are really good too.
author: Ryan K.

description:
MMM I had some absolutely fantastic sushi here. 

Butterfish Blasters:
I've never had butterfish sashimi before, and was very tempted to get it, but decided on this dish instead. Its crab and avocado rolled up in butterfish, and lightly torched on the outside. Damn I just salivated while writing that. Anyways, the fish stays mostly raw, and this is an EXCELLENT dish. The butterfly is very flavorful, and the crab meat inside is well seasoned. I'd say a must get.

African Spider Roll:
Got this on yelp recommendations. It was definitely good, but can't say it was that much above a spider roll elsewhere. I do have to say, that I normally find spider rolls overstuffed with sprouts, and the end pieces aren't as pleasant to eat; however, this roll did not have that problem, and they also left the large pieces of crab out of the roll, to eat on the side. 

Yellowtail and Tuna sashimi:
WOW. Very. Large. Pieces. I'd say 2.5 times the size of any piece of sashimi you normally get for the same price. Fish was fresh, but had some stringy tendons in it. 

Overall excellent sushi. I'd want to try some of their more special rolls next time.
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
great food, great sushi. my fiance' and i come here when we want good sushi. and yes, i'm gonna go there, my fiance is Japanese and so we tend to be sushi snobs. we like fresh fish, presentation, and good service. this is what you will find at sushi bistro! 

only set back is the total lack of parking! it can be hit or miss. get there early in the evening to beat some of the crowds on thursday nights. other nights of the week, generally not as busy. bus or walk, either way, enjoy!
author: June Bug M.

description: U want some quality sushi... Sushi Bistro is the spot! They got some really fresh fresh rolls. Lots of variety and not just the typical dragon rolls and tempura rolls. They got some more creative rolls I haven't seen at other restaurants. The prices are fairly reasonable. Also they have this really really great salad that is a combination of ahi tuna, onion crisps and some yummy dressing.... highly RECOMMENDED! It gets really crowded and unless you go early most of the time you have to wait for a table... but who can blame the situation when they make rolls like that!
author: Crystal S.

description: One of the best in SF.  Very good by Tokyo standards, though you dont get fusion in Tokyo.  It is a gem that my nihon-expat friends love.  They also love me so I dont know if they have good taste.  Stay away, this place is too small for both of us to eat at....we might have to do a ninja style showdown.  Dont make me whip out a bento box of whoop-ass.
author: H C.

description: Parking can be a bitch, but its well worth it.... MMMMM SOOOO GOOOOOD! And a bonus, they serve saki in akward square cups... which makes it entertaining to watch your friends try to drink it.  :)
author: Erin M.

description: I don't understand why this place is rated so high on yelp. My brother and I went here earlier this week and we were not impressed with the service or the fish. They give you these large water cups sans ice so as to avoid having to come around with fresh, cold water and our waiter forgot to bring one of the appetizers that we ordered but still charged us for it until we sent the bill back. The unagi had a weird aftertaste and the rest of the fish we had (salmon, tuna, etc) didn't taste very fresh.
author: matt m.

description: this place rocks....but i suggest making a reservation.  if it happens to be packed, you'll find yourself giving the stink eye to anyone sitting down and stuffing themselves.    Go during the week to avoid the influx of annoying marina folks.  Stick with the chef sashimi selection....Oh...and you can get Kirin by the pitcher.  Can't beat that!
author: chrissy k.

description: This is a truly great sushi spot. Their sake selection is amazing and their special rolls are some of the best I've had. Of course they are typical of all good sushi spots in that they are so big that you have to gag and choke them down if you want to get them in one bite (what is up with that, does this not bug the hell out of anyone but me?). This would be a five star rating but we had a reservation and still had to wait 45 minutes and they forgot one of our orders but remembered to put it on the bill. I think that the word is out on this place, go at an unconventional time for best results.
author: M L.

description:
i arrived to find people waiting in line and a mouth-watering smell wafting out the front door... a very promising start. 

don't come here if you're looking for an authentic sushi experience, but if you're like me and enjoy experimentation in your sushi then this place is for you. their inventive sushi rolls are fun and unlike any other. 

here's a run down of our order: 
- african spider: cajun spices, avocado and soft shell crab had a perfect balance of textures and flavors, with just enough kick.
- c2: like a california roll but with lobster instead of crab and topped with shrimp tempura. a classic roll, only better.
- iron punch: tuna, butterfish and fuji apple in a warm, satisfying soup-like sauce. adds comfort to traditionally cold sushi.
- nemo found: soybean paper instead of seaweed totally changes it up, but in a good, subtle way.
- hamachi sashimi: HUGE. the serving was generous and fresh. melted in my mouth.
- new wave mahi mahi: it was a four star until this dish. the mahi-mahi was totally overcooked that the dish was almost inedible. i did enjoy the mango salsa though.
- mochi dessert: seemingly simple since it comes out of a box. mine was stale. bummer.

huge praise for the unique menu. there were so many things i wanted to try that i'm coming back just to try more! a few helpful pieces of advice: 1) make reservations if you can and 2) come in a party of 2. its tiny and you'll get seated faster.
author: eileen b.

description: Very nice ... dim lighting, small, great music (at least when we went), and friendly servers.  I've only been here once but it was yummy.  I went especially craving interesting rolls and different dishes.  And for the most part, I thought it was great!  Some of the rolls looked so delicious but, when you ate them they were just ok.  But others like ... the African Spider or Butterfish Blasters Roll were excellent.  And, their nigiri sushi was just how I like it - long, thick pieces of fish made beautifully.  Loved the ocean trout, hamachi belly, and albacore belly in this category!  Another major plus is the prices... great prices for sushi!  Beware tho, parking is difficult so go early cuz you'll be circling around for a while!
author: Alisu C.

description: Yummmmm I love this place! Ahi tuna poke Yummmm, very fresh, very tastey rolls, not overpriced. One of the best suhi places I have eaten at in the city. You must go! Yummmmmmmmm
author: christina C.

description: Interesting selections........poorly presented, no atmosphere whatsoever, definitely on the lower end of the spectrum. Tried it 2 x would never go back.
author: Bill K.

description: I have only eaten here once and would probably go back.   They have really good tempura, light and fluffy the way it should be.  Some interesting rolls on the menu although I was highly disappointed that they did not serve Kanpyo.  That is why I eat at Ebisu when I want Japanese food.
author: Nick L.

description:
i really wanted to like this place because it's pretty cute from the outside, is in a good food neighborhood, and the menu IS kind of interesting. 
but the food is not. 
the fish tasted old.
and they put the same sauce on three of the four rolls we ordered, making everything taste like a mix of mayonnaise and rooster sauce.
author: lindsay f.

description: Amazing Sushi! Its just as good as my favorite Sushi place in san luis obispo except that its here and i dont have to drive 4 hours to get it. My favorite so far is the Rockin' Roll and Crunchy Roll - very simliar to the rolls i usually get. I know people have been raving about the portions and how huge they are but imo they're avg size but you definitely get more than you pay for since its sooo good. I'm really impressed w/ how fast our  dishes came out especially since i only see 2 chefs at work. I've been to places where there's 3 or 4 chefs and they are no where near as fast as these guys (even tho they serve about the same amount of people).
author: Mike B.

description: I always drove by it and saw the crowds inside and wanted to give it a try. When I finally did, it was great! A lot of different, creatives rolls to choose from. I was so hungry that I ordered more than I could eat, but all of it was great. Some nights it can get crowded since its a pretty small place, so you may want to call ahead and come ahead of time to find parking. Also, the rolls can be a bit pricey so be careful how much you order if you're not looking to spend too much.
author: Kim C.

description: This is a solidy 4-star sushi establishment. The fish is fresh and beautifully presented at great prices. The variety, however, is limited and their special dishes (rolls and other) are all drizzled with some sort of sweet sauce -- very heavy-handed. Don't go here if you're seeking authentic Japenese. Otherwise, a cheery vibe, and they let us sit forever.
author: Surely I Am C.
