description: Amazing Sushi restaurant, the Best in San Fran! Great food, saki, and music. Good place to eat sushi and drink saki with friends. Fun rolls, great sashimi, good variety of appetizers and other dishes.  5 Stars.
author: Natalie B.

description: I walk in, quickly sit at the sushi bar and look up at the sake menu like it's the beginning of one of those star wars movies. This overflowing cedar box is magic start of a wonderful evening. Debbie and Sheen(chef), yes I like to get to know those who will be handling my food and play nice, are gracious hosts. With confidence I allow sheen to show me his game face and he does. His skills are clean and generous, just the way I like 'em. Uni, super dynomite and anything he has written on the boards are your best bets.
author: Wine F.

description: Easy way to get a good sushi meal and not break the bank. Consistently good service - not outstanding, but I'm not picky about that unless they really suck. The wrap type rolls are fun to order and they have tons of specialty rolls that I always order. I like anything they have with Jalapenos on it, I forget the names of the rolls. Also, they give you ice cream at the end of the meal which is SUCH a bonus. Parking sucks around there, so be prepared for that.
author: Eric D.

description: seriously the best sushi place in the city! a group of 12 of us were there last weekend and had a blast! they were so great to fit us in and kept the good coming! everything they do is so delicious and has a fun sushi bistro twist. the blasters on the starter menu are AMAZING!
author: Emarie C.

description: good sushi, generally a happy experience, but crowded for no real good reason (just cuz it's hip maybe?).  The staff is nice enough, and they give free ice cream after dinner, which is a plus.  Except they don't tell you it's free, so you can rest assured...(I think).  The sushi is interesting, actually...diff variety, but just doesn't hit the spot for me personally.  Wouldn't think about going back, unless I really really want sushi and don't want to drive too far.
author: judy j.

description: with a little help from my yelp, i decided to get the new legend and the crunchy roll...wow! delish! great flavor and texture and the fish was so fresh. we even tried a vegan roll called the tuscan (avocado and sundried tomato) which was yummy, too! my roommate is a vegan so we love coming here for their array of vegan choices. ambiance is cute but it's good they're moving a few blocks down because this place is teensy! i can't WAIT to come back and try more rolls!
author: N. M.

description: Favorite sushi restaurant in the city.  Fresh fish and innovative rolls.  You can seriously try anything on the menu, even if it seems different, and it will be delicious!  I eat here at least once a week and it is what I look forward to.  Seriously, it is that good, but it gets busy so I suggest getting there before 6:30.
author: Les L.

description: Yes, I agreed that Sushi Bistro is a gem.  The food is very fresh esp. the fish.  I love the lettuce wrap.  It is very refreshing.  They have very unique roll.  I tried the watermelon-man roll, it was awesome!  It has mango and tuna and mac nuts, all adds up to a great taste.  The sushi chef is very zen-like (when it is not busy according to him).  Weekends are packed.  Go early!
author: V G.

description: This is hands down the BEST sushi I have ever had. It is a little pricey, but WELL worth it. It is a tiny place, so if you are going on the weekend, it is crucial that you make reservations. One of my favorites is the hot love roll. Cute atmosphere, and friendly/helpful service.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
Briefly,
Pros:
  Awesome service
  Casual
  Ambiance
  Fresh fish (probably because of the high volume of customers)
  Thick, properly cooked fried calamari
Cons:
   Busy and probably requires reservations
   No warm water in restroom sink
   Some seats very close to counter, kitchen, route to restroom, and            
   front door
   Can get pricey
This place was great all around. I was happy  to see a server wearing his baseball cap while waiting tables, as I was wearing a hat too and had no intention of taking it off. We changed our reservations with out issue at the last minute on a busy Saturday night. The sake selection is amazing, and they even serve it in little wooden cubes that look like tiny wine boxes, which my partner was thrilled about because that is how they serve it in swanky NYC joints. The fish was very very fresh, and somehow the salmon was fresh enough to be completely lacking in fishy flavor, which is something that I have never experienced : ). The fried calamari was amazing. It was not those little circles, but big finger sized fried pieces that were no where near rubbery. We sampled the 12 piece sashimi to decide what was fresh and what we were feelin' that day, and decided that the butterfish and hamachi were working the best for us. We searched over the menu for something with both, found nothing, and asked if they could make a roll with the two fish wrapped in cucumber. They did and it was no problem, so we added 5% to her tip. We left talking about the fresh fish and great service, so full that we couldn't imagine eating anything else and paid about $120 between the two of us for a full sushi experiance, sake included.
author: David P.

description: As a sushi lover this place is the best!!!  I haven't ordered anything here that I haven't liked, nay loved.  Definitely recommend the New Legend, Rock n' Roll, Spring Lettuce wrap, and Tekka Maki! The service is great and the reggae is a nice touch.  The only bad thing is that it is too small.
author: pat j.

description: This new fusion style of sushi is great. They have a mix of Italian, Japanese, Hawaiian, Chinese, and Californian flavors in the sushi. The flavors in the sushi is so good that I didn't even need to use soy sauce. The fish there is also very fresh, (firm and flavorful) compared to other places where the fish is soggy and flavorless. I highly suggest sitting at the bar because the sushi chef there is very friendly and knowledgeble. You can also see him making the sushi. Try the wild salmon or tuna sashimi, it is very flavorable. If you're looking for a nice intimate place for about $15 max, a person (tax included), go try it out. Go on the weekdays when you can sit on the sushi bar, if not, weekends are just as good.
author: Avery W.

description: luv this place. the sushi is fresh and the service is great.  also the prices are reasonable.  i had the rolls and nigiri and though both were equally good.
author: Young L.

description: Wow, what can I say.  Utter disappointment, perhaps?  I came here with my fiancee after seeing stellar reviews here, but we thought this place was horrible.  That's right.  It downright sucked.  The food looked ok, but the flavors were totally off.  Maybe we shouldn't have started with the pesto sushi.  It sounded interesting, but the pesto didn't taste like it should have.  Maybe it was rotten or something.  We had a couple other special rolls that were not good either.  We decided to have some traditional rolls that would be easier for the chefs to make.  Maybe those would be better.  Nope.  Horrible.  We had a spicy tuna roll and an unagi roll.  Both were bad.  The unagi was drowned in that brown sauce that is usually used as just an accent at better sushi restaurants.  My fiancee also detected something hard in her roll and she nearly vomitted.  If that's not bad enough, all the rolls we ordered were not uniformally cut, and they were rolled loosely.  We asked for our check promptly and wondered why there were so many young hipsters waiting in line out on the sidewalk.  It seems like a cooler place to be seen than a quality restaurant.  I will never go back to Sushi Bistro.
author: lars g.

description: i have to say they have really unique rolls, but I also must admit i never felt fat after eating sushi before in my life. take the volcano roll for example, it was so creamy, it just oozed weight gain. also, i could tell from the crab meat that this is just generic run of the mill imitation crab. their plating is nice, and the rolls look nice, but this is not *real* sushi, more westernized, so I can see how it would be great for some, but sadly, not for me.
author: P M.

description: besides passing conversation, the only words we spoke were, "Oh my god, holy s**t, you have to try that one," and speechless grinning. at the end of the adventure we decided on one word for the evening, "sushi-gasm."
author: mike r.

description: Let me say I was skeptical when my Caucasian co-worker recommended this place to me.  I will never doubt her food taste again!  This place is probably some of the best sushi I've ever had.  We take all of our guests visiting SF here and they all agree.  One of the comments we got from our friends was "this is better than any sushi I've had in LA" or "top 5 sushi I've ever had".  I think it's family run and they are always super friendly and  very accommodating.   They are very genuine and nice.  I love the place because it is not an over-sized dark swanky wannabe hot sushi place.  You come here for good food and it has yet to disappoint.   I highly recommend the sashimi, it is some of the thickest and softest cuts I've ever had.  Of course the rolls are delicious and very creative.   Lastly, the prices are ridiculously cheap.  For what you get, you should be paying twice as much.   Everything about this place rocks, but make sure you make a reservation.
author: shar d.

description: As far as originality and quality of fish goes, this place is doing it right.  A buddy of mine was visiting out of town and we were about to go to namu, but fortunately we stumbled on Sushi Bistro.  It was much busier than namu and not as pretentious.  The wait was not bad on a Thursday night, we got there about 8 and were seated in 3-5 mins.  I ordered the Hawaiian Breeze which ranks up there with the best rolls i've ever had.  The reason I think its so good is because of the mix of the textures and taste.  You have sweetness from mango, crispness from fuji apple, crunch from fried macadamian nuts, pesto and of course really fresh fish.  I also tried their fried oysters which were not fishy at all, and no sand.  The specials of sashimi or nigiri you see on the board are very big portions.  I tried the blue fin tuna nigiri which was very fresh, you really didn't even need wasabi.  Service was great too, the place is pretty small so there's always a wait person nearby to refill your tea.
author: J C.

description: all i can say is this is my favorite sushi. i drive from the East bay just to eat here. love it
author: a b.
